If I study hard I believe my family and I will have a better life. Mohamed  12  from Somalia. We hope he achieves his dreams! Thanks to UNICEF Somalia for sharing.

What I like most is playing on my tablet. When I grow up  I would like to be a doctor so I can treat people. Firaz  6  is originally from Homs. He fled the brutal conflict in Syria and now lives with his family in Amman  Jordan. Thanks to UNICEF Jordan for sharing.

Jhuma  14 from Bangladesh  does homework beneath a lamppost because her family has no electricity. A UNICEF cash transfer programme helped her stop working  return to school  and become one of the top students in her class. We’re inspired by her determination!   Read her story in our 2016 State of the World's Children: http://uni.cf/sowc16
From Nigeria to Bangladesh  how we're working to give every child a fair chance in life. #foreverychild
All girls should live in a safe and supportive environment and have the opportunity to thrive! Thanks to UNICEF Africa for sharing. #foreverychild

It's blue and I cannot wait to wear it for Eid! Fayan  6 from Syria  shares her excitement about the gift she received from her mother for the Islamic holiday that comes after Ramadan. "On the first day of Eid  I want to visit all my friends in the neighbourhood. We will visit our teacher together. On the second day  I will go with my parents to visit my grandparents and aunts. I also want to go with my cousins to the theme park to play on the swings and the pirate ship.” Via UNICEF Middle East and North Africa.
A moving video. Displaced Iraqi family members ask one another emotional questions about their former lives. #foreverychild

A year ago 3-year-old Kumba was so malnourished she couldn't eat or walk. But after treatment at a rehabilitation centre in her Mauritania village  she is happy and healthy. "I was so relieved when she started getting better " says her mother. "She could not even stand at the beginning but slowly she began to walk  talk and giggle. I really want her to go to school because I did not have this chance." We’re glad little Kumba's doing so well! Thanks to Unicef Mauritanie for sharing.
Powerful and true. Change starts when you choose to care: http://uni.cf/sowc16 #foreverychild

At least 125 people were reportedly killed and hundreds wounded  many of them children  in two separate bombings in Baghdad early this morning. As violence across Iraq intensifies  children continue to pay the heaviest price. We reiterate our call on all parties to the conflict to protect children.
Education transforms lives and entire communities. Read our 2016 State of the World’s Children report: http://uni.cf/sowc16 #foreverychild
What would you hold onto if you were forced to flee home? #foreverychild

UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador Orlando Bloom visited children in eastern Ukraine who've survived terrifying experiences and just want to return to the safety and routine of school. Join him to #FightUnfair and make sure all children have a fair chance at a better future: http://uni.cf/fightunfair
These Canadians are welcoming Syrian refugees with open arms. #actofhumanity
It's the weekend. Chill out and take care of the one you love. Thanks to Unicef CHAD for sharing.

On his recent trip to Lebanon  UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador Ricky Martin met Syrian refugee children who have been uprooted by war. Some have been forced to become breadwinners for their families  working up to 12 hours every day. The world must do more to keep these children safe - join Ricky and #FightUnfair: http://uni.cf/fightunfair
From cleaning car windows to cramming for the next big test  a 12-year-old's life changes in just one year. #foreverychild

Muhammad  15  was in school until Boko Haram attacked his village in Nigeria and sent his family fleeing through the bush. Now  he has no choice but to collect and sell garbage to support himself.   Without education Muhammad will continue to live in poverty. Ending child poverty is a choice. It’s our choice: http://uni.cf/sowc16 #foreverychild
Iraq is one of the most dangerous places in the world for children.

After bonding with these children in one of the poorest and most remote parts of Vietnam  UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador Katy Perry calls for a much bigger focus on left-behind children so they can achieve their dreams. How you can help #FightUnfair: http://uni.cf/fightunfair #foreverychild
One girl reminded me of myself as a teenager - she told me she wanted to be a musician as she belted out an amazing version of 'Firework'! - UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador Katy Perry.
If current trends continue  167 million children will still be living in extreme poverty by 2030. It's our choice to change this: http://uni.cf/sowc16 #foreverychild
If you saw this little girl on the street  would you pass right by? #foreverychild
Mostly through low-cost  proven interventions. Read our 2016 State of the World’s Children Report: http://uni.cf/sowc16 #foreverychild
If trends continue  167 million children could still be living in extreme poverty by 2030. Read our 2016 State of the World's Children Report: http://uni.cf/sowc16 #foreverychild

Healthy baby  happy mother! Merdiya smiles carrying one of her twin sons on her back after he was vaccinated at a hospital in Ethiopia. UNICEF Ethiopia is supporting a campaign to vaccinate 25 million children against measles in the most drought-affected areas of the country.
Start the week off with a smile! Thanks to Unicef CHAD for sharing.
ALL children have the right to play - regardless of their background. http://uni.cf/team #TeamUNICEF #CopaAmerica #Euro2016
If I study hard I believe my family and I will have a better life. Mohamed  12  from Somalia. Thanks to UNICEF Somalia for sharing.

When I grow up I want to be president. I will build roads  markets  hospitals and give everybody water. I will have to give gifts to children like computers and books and help them to go to school. I will also give them food and mattresses. Lukman  10 from Ghana  has big dreams! Via UNICEF Ghana.

“My main concern is to go to a safe country where I can bring up my child  and get her the treatment she needs  so she doesn’t waste her future. Our future is lost already  but it’s not fair that she should lose hers too.” Meet Syrian refugee Rasheed Tari from Aleppo and his one-year-old daughter Ella. Having arrived in Greece some months ago from Turkey  the family is now stuck in limbo waiting for resettlement in a new country. #actofhumanity
Happy #FriYay! We hope you have a restful weekend. Thanks to Unicef CHAD for sharing.
My dream is to work with communities to convince them child marriage is wrong. Marah  Syrian refugee in Jordan. Child marriage is a human rights violation and must end! Via UNICEF Jordan.

Willinton  15  and Solanyi  13  lost their parents to conflict in Colombia. Generations of children there have known nothing but war - we welcome the ceasefire and laying down of arms deal between the Colombian government and FARC: http://uni.cf/28PQbgG

A beautiful moment. Nyabitu  7  is reunited with her grandmother two years after conflict separated them in South Sudan. More than 12 000 separated children have been registered by UNICEF South Sudan and partners since the fighting started - we’re working to reunite all of them with their families.

“I didn’t even think about it. It was just impossible for me to let them stay in this condition so I just took them in my house.” Spyros Tsapras  a volunteer with Greek NGO SolidarityNow  is sharing his Athens home with several refugee families  among them young children and a heavily pregnant mother.  Learn more about our #actofhumanity campaign in support of refugee and migrant children: http://uni.cf/actofhumanity

Merdiya  23  smiles carrying one of her twin sons on her back after he was vaccinated at a hospital in Ethiopia. We supported the Ministry of Health's campaign to vaccinate 25 million children against measles in the most drought-affected areas of the country. The drought and food shortages have caused a rise in malnutrition rates  making children more susceptible to measles. Thanks to UNICEF Ethiopia  for sharing.

Hamida Mohammed  6  says she wants to protect her baby goat  standing under a tree in the blistering heat of Afar  Ethiopia. Her family lost much of their livestock in the worst drought in decades. Nearly 6 million children are at risk from hunger  disease and lack of water due to the El Niño related drought. Thanks to UNICEF Ethiopia for sharing.
Great news from the Democratic Republic of Congo! Child mortality there has decreased by 30% in 7 years. Read more from Unicef DR Congo: http://uni.cf/28LiOQF

“The scariest part was the water crossing. We managed to put all three kids to sleep before the boat left  and we put them in the middle of the boat  and used our bodies as shields between them and the sea  so they couldn’t see the water.“ Amira Raslan with her daughter Jannat  7  outside an emergency shelter in Berlin  Germany. The family  including Amira’s husband and their two other children are refugees from Homs  Syria. They arrived in Germany in December after making the weeklong journey from Turkey by land and sea to seek asylum here. Find out more about our #actofhumanity campaign in support of refugee and migrant children: http://uni.cf/actofhumanity

“I want to go to college to become a lawyer. But what I want above all is peace and stability in my country  Mali.” Aïsha received her high school diploma in Mauritania’s Mbera refugee camp after fleeing conflict in Timbuktu with her family in 2013. We’re inspired by her determination! #WorldRefugeeDay Unicef Mauritanie

“My main concern is to go to a safe country where I can bring up my child  and get her the treatment she needs  so she doesn’t waste her future. Our future is lost already  but it’s not fair that she should lose hers too.” Meet Syrian refugee Rasheed Tari from Aleppo and his one-year-old daughter Ella. Having arrived in Greece some months ago from Turkey  the family is now stuck in limbo waiting for resettlement in a new country. #actofhumanity #WorldRefugeeDay
On World Refugee Day  watch the inspiring story of a Norwegian man welcoming a Syrian family with open arms. #actofhumanity

Mohammad  17  from Gambia bumps fists with a local Italian man in Pozzallo  Sicily. “We risked our lives to come here ” he says. “We crossed a sea. We knew it is not safe.” More than 9 out of 10 refugee and migrant children arriving in Europe this year through Italy are unaccompanied: http://uni.cf/1UguBbq #actofhumanity
Happy #FathersDay to fathers and father figures everywhere! Pictured  Philip holds his newborn son in Ghana using a technique called ‘kangaroo care’.
This #FathersDay  these dads deserve some extra recognition.

“When I grow up I will participate in the Paralympic Games. I know I will win medals. Carrying the flame will show to many people that children like me must have the same chance to practice a sport and study.” Adriana  15  carried the Olympic Flame in the city of Belém in Brazil’s Pará state  as part of UNICEF Brasil's partnership with Rio 2016. This inspiring girl raised her voice for every boy and girl with disabilities. #TeamUNICEF
At just 17  Winny is  already speaking out against cyberbullying in her Brazil community. Read her story and others in this photo essay. #ReplyForAll
From Somalia to Italy  one teen's miraculous story of survival. #actofhumanity

I spent a year without education because of war. I want my sisters to go to school because we are the future. Idriss and sister Malka are Chadian returnees from Central African Republic. On Day of the African Child - and every day - let’s work to ensure children like them can reach their full potential! #DAC2016
Happy Day of the African Child! Let’s work to protect their rights today - and every day. #DAC16

25-year-old Tesfit from Eritrea plays with Bettie  3  the daughter of an Eritrean friend at a reception center in Mineo  Sicily. 4 760 children are among the 28 000 people who have made the perilous journey from North Africa to Italy in first 4 months of 2016. Find out more about our #actofhumanity campaign in support of refugee and migrant children: http://uni.cf/actofhumanity

A beautiful moment. Nyabitu  7  is reunited with her grandmother two years after conflict separated them in South Sudan. More than 12 000 separated children have been registered by UNICEF South Sudan  and partners since the fighting started - we’re working to reunite all of them with their families.
The amazing journey and friendship of seven Gambian boys who met while waiting to travel by boat from Libya to Italy. #actofhumanity
More than 9 out of 10 refugee and migrant children arriving in Europe this year through Italy are unaccompanied. They face danger every step of the way: http://uni.cf/21iNJo9 #actofhumanity

Fleeing al-Shabaab in Somalia  18-year old 'Omar' survived imprisonment by human traffickers in Libya and a sinking boat in the Mediterranean. He made the trip alone  like more than 9 out of 10 of the refugee and migrant children arriving in Italy this year. #actofhumanity

Some people make fun of me when I tell them I want to continue going to school  but for me  there's no right age. Yande  17  enrolled in school for the first time in Chad's Daresalam camp. Read her inspiring story: http://uni.cf/1U7M1kt
On #AlbinismAwareness Day  let’s speak out against discrimination and violence! We must protect children and people with albinism. Photo via UNICEF Mozambique
Malak fled Baghdad. Rapu fled Syria. They met at a school for displaced children in Iraq and their friendship will make you smile. #EmergencyLessons

I am first in my classroom this year. I want to be a doctor when I grow up to I can help sick children. Feleknaz has lived in Syria's Ain Al-Khadra refugee camp for the past two years after fleeing Sinjar mountain in Iraq. We hope she achieves her dreams!
On World Day Against Child Labour  let's remember the 168 million children like Mohammed who are forced to work - many out of school.
On World Day Against Child Labour  let’s remember that 168 million children worldwide are still forced to work - and denied basic rights. Say no to child labour!

Hamida Mohammed  6  says she wants to protect her baby goat  standing under a tree in the blistering heat of Afar  Ethiopia. Her family lost much of their livestock in the worst drought in decades. Nearly 6 million children are at risk from hunger  disease and lack of water due to the El Niño related drought. Thanks to UNICEF Ethiopia sharing.
Social media can be hurtful  and sometimes dangerous. Will you be there for your friends if things go wrong? #ReplyForAll
Happy Friday everyone! Have a wonderful weekend. Via Unicef Sierra Leone.
When Jessica’s phone was stolen and nude photos made public  she wasn’t sure she could bear the shame. But Winny  a friend at school  decided to stand up for what’s right. #ReplyForAll
Congratulations to Niger on ending maternal and neonatal tetanus! The killer disease has been officially eradicated in the west African nation. Thanks to UNICEF Niger for sharing.

Goodwill Ambassador David Beckham  travelled to Swaziland this week to see how his 7 Fund with UNICEF is helping to support and protect HIV-positive children. Learn more about his visit here: http://uni.cf/1PoPqPX

Nadiya and Saffiya  both 6  live in the Nowruz refugee camp in Syria. They fled Sinjar mountain in Iraq with their families more than two years ago and just received their new shoes for the summer. We've distributed 4 000 pairs of shoes to children in three camps in Syria.

I refused to marry a man from my village and now I am fighting child marriage.  Matilda is a peer educator in Ghana teaching girls in her community how to resist early and forced marriage. Child marriage is a human rights violation and must end! Thanks to UNICEF Ghana  for sharing.
Take a big leap to start off the week. Happy Monday! Thanks to Unicef Myanmar for sharing.

We honour the life of Muhammad Ali  who was not only a legendary boxer but also a world champion for equality and peace. He fought for a better world and used his platform to help lift up humanity.  Pictured  Ali visits a UNICEF-supported girls school in Kabul  Afghanistan  2002.

“I am the first in my classroom this year  I want to be a doctor when I grow up so I can help sick children ” says 4th grader Feleknaz after receiving new pair of shoes for the summer. She has lived in Ain Al-Khadra refugee camp in Syria for the past two years after fleeing Sinjar mountain in Iraq.

Smile! This is 10-month-old baby Edmore Danatus after receiving his birth certificate in his village in Ghana’s Upper West Region. Birth registration is every child’s right. Thanks to UNICEF Ghana for sharing.
Girls must be empowered with the knowledge  skills and options they need to reach their potential. Thanks يونيسف العراق - unicef Iraq  for sharing.
'Lorna'  8  from the Philippines  was forced to perform sexual acts for foreigners in front of a computer. We must #ENDviolence and abuse online.
Happy Friday from three friends in Swaziland! Hope you have a great weekend.

“I have new Syrian friends in Lebanon. I truly admire their perseverance and spirit.” After visiting refugee children with UNICEF  Goodwill Ambassador Ricky Martin calls for increased focus on safeguarding the futures of millions of children affected by the Syria conflict: http://uni.cf/1TSRmlv

All the children I met have incredible dreams. We have to help them fight for those dreams. Goodwill Ambassador Katy Perry visited rural Viet Nam with UNICEF this week and is calling for greater focus on vulnerable children there: http://uni.cf/1TPfTrG

As violence escalates across Syria  we risk losing the chance to vaccinate and save the lives of more than one million children. With the World Health Organization (WHO)  we appeal to all parties to the conflict to end the fighting and let health workers resume the vaccination campaign safely: http://uni.cf/20VhkDU
'Lorna'  8  was forced to perform sexual acts three times a day in front of a laptop for foreigners. We must #ENDviolence and abuse online.

Happy Global Day of Parents! Thanks to all the parents and guardians around the world doing the most important job out there - keeping their children safe and inspiring them to reach their potential. Via UNICEF Niger.
As violence escalates in Falluja and across Iraq  we call on all parties to protect children and provide safe passage to those wishing to leave the city.

I like to play the drum. All my friends follow me because I am the best drum maker here. One day  I will play it on the radio. Abukari  4  in his village in Ghana. Watch out for this musician on the rise! Thanks to UNICEF Ghana for sharing.

With my baby  I was hesitant to come to school  but the principal said that I could come to class with him. Yande  17  enrolled in school for the first time at Chad's Daresalem refugee camp. Her story proves it's never too late to start learning: http://uni.cf/1U7M1kt
Girls playing jump rope during a class break in Chad’s Daresalam refugee camp. 90% of the children there had never been to school before arriving at the camp. Thanks to Unicef CHAD for sharing.

Every year  around 3 million children die due to undernutrition. For millions more  chronic malnutrition will result in stunting - an irreversible condition that literally stunts the physical and mental growth of children. The good news is that we can change this. The first 1 000 days from the start of a woman’s pregnancy to a child’s second birthday offer an extraordinary window of opportunity for preventing undernutrition and its consequences. Thanks to Unicef Myanmar for sharing.
For children in crises  education cannot wait.
Naptime. A baby sleeps under a bed net in Angola. Nets help to prevent diseases such as malaria and yellow fever. Thanks to Unicef Angola for sharing.

When we - youth - work hand in hand  we can do the impossible. We can rebuild the Syrian society. Deeb  23  Syrian youth volunteer helping children continue their education: http://uni.cf/1sNTHCB Via UNICEF Middle East and North Africa.

Happy Menstrual Hygiene Day! In many places around the world  periods are seen as dirty or taboo  leading to a lack of information and damaging misconceptions. #MenstruationMatters - help break the silence around this normal part of life: http://uni.cf/1WQHeKg
An author at 16  Erij has written a story inspired by her grueling journey from Syria to Turkey. She introduces her ‘unfairy tale’.
If you’re ready for the weekend put your hands up! Thanks to Unicef CHAD for sharing.
Investing in girls' education benefits everyone! Thanks to يونيسف العراق - unicef Iraq for sharing.
Peace is so sweet to me  because I can go to school  says eight year-old Hafaf  a participant at a UNICEF South Sudan-supported poetry contest in Juba.

Patricia holds 6-month-old daughter Dominique at a temporary shelter in Pedernales  Ecuador  a city hit hard by last month's devastating earthquake. 100 babies are born every day in the country's worst-hit areas: http://uni.cf/1XeTkMc UNICEF Ecuador
Monday means it’s time for every boy and girl to resume classes. Have a great start of the week! Thanks to Unicef CHAD for sharing.
School means more than a classroom. After living through conflict in East Ukraine  Yaroslav and Nastya show us why their school is special. #EmergencyLessons

I come to school because I want to learn”  says Abdul Razac Turay  7  who wants to be a statistician. Mathematics is my best subject because I like numbers. When I am big I want to work at the census office. I will help the government to know how many people live in my country." Thanks to Unicef Sierra Leone for sharing.
Let’s ensure that all children have equal access to quality education in order to achieve their full potential. Thanks UNICEF Türkiye for sharing.
Smile  it’s the weekend! Thanks to Unicef Sierra Leone for sharing.
In Chad  only 48% of girls attend primary school. We’re committed to ensuring all children realize their right to a quality education. Thanks for Unicef CHAD for sharing.
Happy Friday! Have a good weekend! Thanks to UNICEF Canada for sharing.

“I find strength and power from my grandmother ” says Jericho  12  from the Philippines. “She is the one who sends me to school  feeds me  raises me  and the one who gives me affection.” Jericho wants to become a doctor to help people when they're sick  especially his grandmother. Thanks to UNICEF Philippines for sharing this sweet story.

“If more parents supported girls' education  we could put an end to child marriage.” Achai  17. In South Sudan  a girl is three times more likely to die in childbirth than complete primary school. Thanks to UNICEF South Sudan for sharing.
Grandparents and elders are inspiring figures to children around the world. Thanks to UNICEF Mozambique for sharing this sweet photo.

One-year-old Ami Yin Silva plays at a shelter in Ecuador’s Esmeraldas province  one of the worst-affected areas by last month's devastating earthquake. You can support UNICEF Ecuador’s efforts to help children and families there: http://support.unicef.org/

Madaya  Syria: Just a few months ago  Mohammed  8  was severely malnourished and extremely weak living in the besieged town. After being treated with therapeutic food  he’s now stronger and is back in school. But despite signs of recovery  children are continuing to suffer from the devastating consequences of the siege: http://uni.cf/24OMqn7
In case you missed it  a truly inspiring story of friendship between seven-year-old classmates  Nawwar from Syria and Alec from Germany. #actofhumanity

Were it not for the war I would be at university but I am still in secondary school because I had to drop out of school for two years after my father was killed in the 2013 conflict. I am happy to be back in school and looking forward to a bright future. I want to be a doctor when I grow up so that I can help the people of my country. Victoria  16. UNICEF South Sudan and partners are sending half a million children back to school in South Sudan.
Sleeping soundly  a newborn baby is cared for at a UNICEF Ghana-supported newborn care unit at a hospital in Ghana’s Upper East Region.

Every day  Bora Robu Etu’s family spends three hours walking in search of water  leaving at 1 am and not returning until well into the next day. He says people are not only angry at not being able to feed their children  but also their cattle. One of the worst droughts in decades has left children and their families struggling to cope in Ethiopia. http://uni.cf/1VMGbuN

We used to come every Sunday to play at the beach  now we're staying here. Ines holds her niece in Pedernales  Ecuador  one of the areas worst affected by last month's devastating earthquake. Support our efforts to help children and families there: http://support.unicef.org/  UNICEF Ecuador

“I find strength and power from my grandmother ” says Jericho  12  from the Philippines. “She is the one who sends me to school  feeds me  raises me  and the one who gives me affection.” Jericho wants to become a doctor to help people when they're sick  especially his grandmother. Thanks to UNICEF Philippines  for sharing this sweet story.
Happy Mother’s Day to all the amazing mothers and mother figures worldwide!   Tell us why you love yours in the comments. Pictured  Sara smiles with her newborn baby in Malawi.
Born without the use of his arms or legs  Amir  16  creates art by painting with his mouth in Nepal. Here's how he chose to celebrate his mother. Happy Mother's Day!
This Mother’s Day  we say a big THANK YOU to mothers everywhere for the incredible work you do! Via Unicef Malawi
The touching moment these South Sudanese children are reunited with their loved ones after being separated for two years by conflict.
Happy weekend! Thanks to UNICEF Cambodia for sharing.

I come to school because I want to learn”  says  Abdul Razac Turay  7  who wants to be a statistician. Mathematics is my best subject because I like numbers. When I am big I want to work at the census office. I will help the government to know how many people live in my country." Thanks to Unicef Sierra Leone for sharing.
No water. No life. For these boys in Sudan  the threat is real. The region is suffering from a severe drought  made worse by the effects of climate change. #ElNino
For many  all they want is to get back to the safety and routine of school: http://uni.cf/1pYw1cm
Inspiring. How filmmaker and Syrian refugee Nizar changed the lives of children around him with one #actofhumanity in a Serbia camp.

Meet Amita and Arpita. Arpita was born the day of Nepal's devastating earthquake last year. "I love my daughter the most in the whole world " her mother Amita says. "But when I think of the day she was born  I feel like crying." How they’re getting on now: http://uni.cf/1rzHf97 Via UNICEF Thailand.

In 1988  Audrey Hepburn accepted what she considered the greatest role of her career  as a UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador. Today we pay tribute to her on what would have been her 87th birthday!  This picture was taken in Bangladesh in 1989 as she takes a group of children for a ride in a rickshaw. Find out more about her work for UNICEF: http://uni.cf/1kLkarz

“We need the global momentum to give every child in humanitarian emergencies a fair chance at a bright future.” Goodwill Ambassador Orlando Bloom just returned from eastern Ukraine  where he met children who’ve survived terrifying experiences and just want to return to the safety and routine of school. Education rebuilds lives! Find out more: http://uni.cf/1pYw1cm
Start the week with a smile. Happy Monday! Thanks to Unicef Sierra Leone for sharing.
Children on the move need a hand - an #actofhumanity to show them it's okay. Here’s how you can help: http://uni.cf/actofhumanity

Happy birthday to our Goodwill Ambassador David Beckham! Thanks for your work to protect children's rights worldwide. He is pictured here meeting vulnerable children on a visit with UNICEF to Cambodia.

A little girl sits at a shelter the city of Portoviejo in Ecuador. The recent devastating earthquake has damaged more than 280 schools leaving 120 000 children temporarily without education. UNICEF Ecuador is setting up learning spaces and providing education supplies to get children back to learning. You can support them at: http://support.unicef.org/
For these boys in Sudan  water is life. The region is suffering from a severe drought  made worse by the effects of climate change. #ElNino
Smile  it’s the weekend! Thanks to UNICEF Greece for sharing.
Seven-year-old best friends  one German  one Syrian shows us that friendship knows no borders. #actofhumanity

Dr. Mohammed Wassem Maaz  one of the last paediatricians in Aleppo  was killed in yesterday's attack on Al Quds Hospital. He was so devoted to his patients that he stayed in Aleppo even after his family left for Turkey. We join the many voices expressing outrage for this attack that took the lives of doctors  paramedics and many patients  including children: http://uni.cf/1O0a8zA Thanks to UNICEF Italia for sharing his story.
It’s #InternationalDanceDay! What’s your favourite move? Pictured  children dance at school in Malawi.
We’re outraged at the alarming number of attacks on health personnel and facilities in Syria. Our statement with World Health Organization (WHO): http://uni.cf/1O0a8zA
Born without the use of his arms or legs  Amir  16  creates beautiful art against all odds in Nepal.

I love my daughter the most in the whole world  Amita says of baby Arpita  born the day of Nepal's devastating earthquake last year. "But when I think of the day she was born  I feel like crying." How they’re getting on  one year later: http://uni.cf/1rzHf97 Via UNICEF Thailand.
Will you do your part to battle stigma and make all refugee and migrant families welcome? Via Voices of Youth #actofhumanity
10 outrageous things you may have heard about vaccines and the best ways to debunk each of them. #vaccineswork
Fiyori Teame  9  is a third grade student at the UNICEF Ethiopia-supported Baáti Akhor Primary School in Ethiopia’s Tigray region. She wants to become a maths teacher.

These mothers react to a 'vaccine' they really didn't expect. Thanks to Unicef CHAD for sharing.

When I grow up I'd like to become a judge because I believe in justice for all. Meet 10-year-old Fatima from Aleppo  Syria  who is attending school for the first time “in a long time. Thanks to UNICEF Jordan for sharing.
We expect action. Action on a big scale. - UNICEF climate advocate Getrude Clement  16.

6 million likes and counting! Thanks to every one of you for your support -  we simply cannot do our work without you.  And thanks especially to those who’ve done an #actofhumanity to help child refugees and migrants. Whether it’s volunteering  donating clothes or fighting stigma  a small act can make a big difference. Get inspired here: http://uni.cf/actofhumanity

“It has been one year since children of Nepal had their lives shaken by the devastating earthquake. My heart goes out to these children and their families. Thanks to millions of UNICEF’s supporters around the world  children in Nepal are going back to school and families are building back better. Thank you. Namaste.” UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador Orlando Bloom.
The world must remember that nobody chooses to be a refugee. Thanks to our Eminent Advocate Queen Rania for speaking up for refugee and migrant children in Lesvos  Greece. #actofhumanity
It's Immunization Week! We'll be talking about life-saving vaccines all week and the importance of reaching the most vulnerable children  such as those living in conflict.
One year after the Nepal earthquake  12-year-old Sharmila is living in a tent with 11 other girls.

I was drawing the moon because I like it when it shines at night. I’m using all these pencils to give the moon colour. My name is Rashida Bangura and I am six-years-old. When I’m big I want to be president. Thanks to Unicef Sierra Leone for sharing.
It's Immunization Week! Without vaccines  children living in conflict are at real risk of dying of preventable diseases: http://uni.cf/1NR3ZdF #vaccineswork

I'm a mom... If I'm fleeing a war with a child  I hope that there's another mom saying 'okay  let me help you'. Dutch volunteer Darcia on why she's helping refugee families landing on shores of Greece. #actofhumanity

The world is now watching - you'll either be lauded by future generations  or vilified. Leonardo DiCaprio's momentous speech to world leaders at the Paris Climate Agreement signing at the United Nations today.

Do you stand with us on climate change? UNICEF climate advocate Getrude Clement  16  from Tanzania joined world leaders and Leonardo DiCaprio at the Paris Climate Agreement signing at the UN today. Read her inspiring words: http://uni.cf/1Tn7rwa
What's the first word that you think of when you hear 'climate'? Check out the word game we played with Katy Perry. #EarthDay #ParisAgreement
Why is the Paris Climate Change Agreement signing in NY tomorrow such a big deal? We break it down - with gifs!
Ecuador is reeling from a massive earthquake that's shattered the lives of thousands - including 150 000 children.

Education is what gives children and young people the skills they need to build a better future for themselves  their families and their communities.  Thanks to UNICEF Africa and Unicef DR Congo for sharing this important message!

When I grow up I'd like to become a judge because I believe in justice for all. Meet 10-year-old Fatima from Aleppo  Syria  who is attending school for the first time “in a long time. Thanks to UNICEF Jordan for sharing.

Just two days left! Join the global #ClimateChain on Instagram or Twitter for the chance to be featured at the United Nations on Friday when world leaders sign a historic agreement on climate change: http://uni.cf/climatechain

We’re in a race against time to protect at least 150 000 children affected by the weekend’s devastating earthquake in Ecuador from diseases and other risks. But we need your help to continue delivering lifesaving aid: http://support.unicef.org/ UNICEF Ecuador

When I grow up I want to be the manager of the bank.  When I have my own money  I will be comfortable and able support my mom Theresa. Anything she needs I will give her. Anything I want she gives me. I have been living with her for 10 years and she is the only family I know. - Patrick  15.   Theresa is a member of the UNICEF-supported Mokamba Mothers' Club in Mokamba Village  Sierra Leone  helping to foster vulnerable children in her community like Patrick. Via Unicef Sierra Leone.

A devastating earthquake hit Ecuador over the weekend. Hundreds of lives were lost  homes and schools destroyed. Every moment counts for the thousands of children and families living out in the open right now - we’re appealing for $1 million to continue delivering lifesaving aid: http://support.unicef.org/ UNICEF Ecuador
Swinging into the new week! A girl child smiles at a child care centre in Malawi.

Four-month-old Jibril sits comfortably on his mother's arm in a rural health post in Ethiopia's Oromia region. His mother  Shitto  visits the health post regularly  following up on his vaccinations. Thanks to UNICEF Ethiopia  for sharing. #vaccineswork
Just a few days left to join the global #ClimateChain! Add your photo on Twitter or Instagram and you could be featured at the United Nations  on 22 April: http://uni.cf/climatechain
She lost her home during WW2. Today  Panagiota  82  or just 'Mama'  is hosting refugees in her Greek village. We love this #actofhumanity.
Education prepares children like Aisha for the future! #BringBackOurChildhood

Nyaruot  14  Nyaliep  3  and Nyachan  11  just heard they'll be reunited with their family in less than a week after being separated for two years! The girls have been staying in the Bor Protection of Civilians site in South Sudan with their aunt and cousins since fleeing violence.
Have a happy weekend - and don't forget to smile! Thanks to Unicef Angola for sharing this wonderful pic.
The United States is the only country in the world that has not ratified this landmark treaty on child rights. #SendTheCRC
Abducted by Boko Haram and forced to bear a child. 'Khadija'  only 17  shares her story of survival. #BringBackOurChildhood

My dream is that one day they will come home  finish their education and choose their futures for themselves. - Malala. Today marks two years since over 200 schoolgirls were abducted by Boko Haram in Chibok  Nigeria. Read Malala's letter to their parents  via Malala Fund: http://uni.cf/1SE6JYp #BringBackOurChildhood

Today marks two years since over 200 schoolgirls were abducted by Boko Haram in Chibok  Nigeria. Children across Nigeria  Niger  Chad and Cameroon are continuing to witness unspeakable violence: http://uni.cf/22rtqUY #BringBackOurChildhood
Every refugee and migrant child deserves dignity. They deserve an #actofhumanity.

Brothers and best friends. Together Bokoï and Babouï escaped a horrific Boko Haram attack on their village near Lake Chad which killed their father. Their tragic but inspiring story: http://uni.cf/1TOGWSl #BringBackOurChildhood
Imagine having everything you know ripped away from you in just one moment. #BringBackOurChildhood
A woman and her baby share a sweet moment while waiting for the nurse at a mother and child health clinic in Freetown  Sierra Leone. Health workers play a crucial role in early childhood development!
All of these people fled Boko Haram violence. All still have hope for the future.
Thanks to Maroon 5 for sharing our Unfairy Tale!

The number of children involved in ‘suicide’ attacks in Nigeria  Cameroon  Chad and Niger has risen from 4 in 2014 to 44 in 2015. More than 75% of the children involved are girls. Pictured  Salta  11  lost her arm after a suicide attack on a market.  Two years on from the abduction of over 200 schoolgirls in Chibok  Nigeria  read our report on the situation of children affected by Boko Haram: http://uni.cf/22rtqUY #BringBackOurChildhood

4-month-old Jibril sits comfortably on his mothers arm in a rural health post in Ethiopia’s Oromia region. His mother  Shitto  visits the health post regularly  following up on his vaccinations. Thanks to UNICEF Ethiopia for sharing. #vaccineswork

My favourite story? Cinderella  I think there is no better story than Cinderella. Malak  7  just started classes in Jerash  Jordan. She is fast learning how to read and write and loves practicing her skills on her favourite story. Via UNICEF Jordan.
Sleeping peacefully. These twins were born underweight but are now feeding well at a temporary clinic in South Sudan’s Malakal Protection of Civilians site. Thanks to UNICEF South Sudan for sharing.

Children on the move need help. You could donate clothes  join a volunteer organization or speak out against stigma facing refugees and migrants. Inspire us with your #actofhumanity! http://uni.cf/actofhumanity

A proud young woman  and rightly so! Emmanuela John  19  was recently named the top scorer in her state in South Sudan’s national primary school leaving exam. Emmanuela  who lives in the village of Wau Shilluk in Upper Nile  says she studies for about three hours every day  often by candlelight as there’s no electricity in her community. More than 1 700 children attend morning and afternoon classes at Wau Shilluk’s only primary school  which is supported by UNICEF and partner  INTERSOS. Thanks to UNICEF South Sudan for sharing.
Welcome cards for Syrian refugees. We love this #actofhumanity by students in Canada! Via UNICEF Canada.

“I have been to school for one year before. I liked it a lot. I learnt to read a bit and write my name. I played football with my friends. But then the war came and it stopped. We had to run to the bush to hide and then I didn’t go again. Now I have registered at the table so I can go to school again.” Sidiq  7  from South Sudan. UNICEF South Sudan is reaching the most vulnerable communities to provide life saving support  including access to education.
Happy #WorldHealthDay! We’re working to ensure children around the world get the best start in life and grow up safe  happy and healthy.
“If I didn’t care about him so much  I wouldn’t have brought him with me.”   Ali  17  fled war in Syria with his 15-year-old brother Ahmad hoping for a new life in Germany. #actofhumanity

“I have been to school for one year before. I liked it a lot. I learnt to read a bit and write my name. I played football with my friends. But then the war came and it stopped. We had to run to the bush to hide and then I didn’t go again. Now I have registered at the table so I can go to school again.” Sidiq  7  from South Sudan. “My name is Mohamed and I am 13 years old. I want to become a civil engineer when I grow up. I will go back to Syria and build roads and buildings.” Mohammed now lives in Domiz refugee camp in Iraq. We’re doing everything we can to make sure children like him get an education and can pursue their dreams. Via يونيسف العراق - unicef Iraq.

Children on the move need a hand - an #actofhumanity to show them it's okay.   Most refugees arrive in their new cities with very few possessions - but you can help them by donating unwanted clothes and items to organizations or collection points in your city. Find out more: http://uni.cf/actofhumanity

I dream of becoming a teacher when i grow up. I really want to help children and guide them. I'm doing my best in school in the hopes of achieving my dreams. Elisa  14  from Madagascar. Thanks to UNICEF-Madagascar  for sharing.
Smile  it's the weekend! Thanks to UNICEF Mozambique for the photo.

This is a children's crisis and children need your help.  Research which organizations in your town are helping refugees adapt to their new lives. You might have just the skill they’re looking for! A small #actofhumanity can go a long way: http://uni.cf/actofhumanity
Ever wonder how a child feels when forced to flee home? This is Mustafa’s story. #actofhumanity

A Syrian baby sleeps soundly at a يونيسف العراق - unicef Iraq 'baby hut' in the Domiz camp for Syrian refugees. Baby huts have comfortable spaces where women can breastfeed and receive health advice for their children: http://uni.cf/1pIxzrM

The world is facing the biggest refugee and migrant crisis since WW2 due to conflicts  poverty and climate change. Children are not responsible.  All children deserve an #actofhumanity. Battle stigma facing refugees and migrants: http://uni.cf/actofhumanity
Some stories were never meant for children. We tell the story of a 14-year old Syrian girl - through her eyes. #actofhumanity
A must watch with a surprising ending.

An inspiring story of giving back. Kinan  26  is a Syrian refugee who left the country five years ago and lives in Belgium. He flew to Greece to welcome newly arrived refugees off the boats  like this young boy. “I am myself a refugee and I know this feeling very well.”   Share an #actofhumanity for children that’s inspired you: http://uni.cf/actofhumanity
Nothing like you've seen on the news. A 7-year old Syrian refugee's journey - through her eyes. #actofhumanity

A year since the brutal conflict in Yemen began  the lives of millions of children are being devastated. At least six children have been killed or injured every day. The country is close to collapse. The fighting must end for the sake of Yemen’s future - and future generations! http://uni.cf/1qcaRby

Today we join Unicef Pakistan in condemning the horrific terror attack on hundreds of people  many women and children  in Lahore. Our thoughts are with the victims  their families and the people of Pakistan - who all have the right to peaceful lives.

Asma  7 from Ethiopia   joins the global #ClimateChain from the blistering heat of Afar Region. Ethiopia is experiencing its worst drought in decades but Asma is still going to school  even though it no longer offers meals. Stand with children like Asma who are affected by climate change: http://uni.cf/climatechain

I would really like to be famous one day. If I will not be famous  at least I should be a pilot. For now  I am in the School Road Safety Committee. I tell my friends how to cross the road and how to prevent fires. In a way I am already famous because everyone knows me.” Abdullah 10  in Grade 4 at the Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan. Thanks to UNICEF Jordan for sharing.

Cedric  4  smiles at an Early Childhood Development centre in Rwanda. Have a great weekend everyone! Via Unicef Rwanda.

“They were buried but I don’t know where – they never told us. When I think of my Mum and Dad and what they used to do for me  it makes me cry. I miss them  but life is okay. My favourite subject is maths. When I am big I want to be able to get work so that I can take care of my family. My dream is that life is good for my family.” A year ago  Fatima  10  lost both her parents to Ebola. Now living with her aunt  she dreams of becoming a doctor. We wish her the best. Thanks to Unicef Sierra Leone for sharing.

A Syrian infant sleeps soundly at a يونيسف العراق - unicef Iraq 'baby hut' in the Domiz camp for Syrian refugees. Baby huts have comfortable spaces where women can breastfeed and receive health advice for their children: http://uni.cf/1pIxzrM

Have you heard of ‘Kangaroo care’? It’s a method developed in Colombia to help premature babies survive when incubators are not available or in short supply. The skin to skin contact with the mother or father helps normalize the baby’s temperature  heart rate and breathing. Thanks to UNICEF Hrvatska (Croatia) for sharing.

With peace negotiations under way in Colombia  we obtained a rare interview with a young woman just released from an armed group after spending 6 years in the jungle. 'Angelina' is now trying to start over with the daughter she left behind.
It’s bath time for Tamadani in Malawi! Every child has the right to clean water and sanitation. #WorldWaterDay

Happy #WorldWaterDay! Add your photo to the global #ClimateChain on Instagram and Twitter to support children affected by climate change. We’ll pick our favourites to show to world leaders at the United Nations next month: http://uni.cf/climatechain
We must protect them from droughts  floods and other disasters caused by climate change: http://uni.cf/5facts  #WorldWaterDay
Climate change isn’t a future issue - it’s threatening children’s lives NOW. Here are 5 facts about water and climate change: http://uni.cf/5facts #WorldWaterDay

Five years ago  Solanyi  13  lost both her parents to armed groups in Colombia. Now living with her aunt she dreams of becoming a teacher or a ballerina - or both. More than 250 000 children have been affected by the conflict in Colombia since 2013  despite peace talks: uni.cf/21AXoFF
Hope you spend #HappinessDay with people who make you happy! Pictured  Ilaria  4  and Juvalina  3  smile as they stand arm-in-arm in Timor-Leste.

A staggering 55% of all schools in Fiji  including this one on Vanuabalavu  were either damaged or destroyed by Cyclone Winston in February. UNICEF Pacific is working to help affected children get back into learning as quickly as possible.
Smile - it's #InternationalDayOfHappiness!  What's your happiest childhood memory?

Eyes full of hope. In the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia  children make their way to a reception centre for refugees and migrants near the border with Greece. Children and women now make up nearly 60% of refugees and migrants on the move in Europe.
These Syrian children are surrounded by war-torn buildings but only want to do one thing: learn!
Happy weekend from a bunch of friends! Thanks to Unicef Nederland for the photo.

The lives of more than 20 000 children in Greece and in the Balkans are on hold. We’re urging EU leaders and Turkey to find common ground that puts children’s best interests first: http://uni.cf/1S8mv08

It feels good to be back to school in Fiji! UNICEF Pacific provided a school tent and education supplies for these students in Lautoka who lost their classroom roof during Cyclone Winston  the strongest cyclone ever to hit the country. When disasters hit  it’s vital children can continue their education.
Without peace  women suffer and children  especially girls  cannot go to school. Awutu 16. Thanks to UNICEF South Sudan for sharing.
The practical actions warring parties in Syria need to take to save children’s lives now.

When I play football  I don't feel like I've lost anything at all.” The inspirational Saja  12  who lost her leg and four of her best friends to the war in Syria.

This newborn baby girl is already protected against polio. Her mother was first in line to receive the vaccine in Bouar  Central African Republic  at the launch of an immunization campaign. Thanks to UNICEF Central African Republic for sharing.

Seeing double! Twins Abeer and Ramia (left) and Ibrahim and Malek (right) all fled Aleppo  Syria  with their families due to increasing violence in a conflict that’s now raged for five years. They ended up as neighbours in Lattakia  Syria  and walk to school together every day. The four children study in a curriculum designed by UNICEF Middle East and North Africa to help those who’ve missed out on education catch up.
3.7m Syrian children under five have known nothing but a lifetime shaped by war.

Street children watch their friends perform skits at an organization in Uganda committed to re-integrating them with family and rebuilding their lives. Street children are often exposed to exploitation and abuse and  have the right to be protected!

Living in the coldest and one of the most polluted capitals in the world is not easy - especially for children. #Mongolia

Three women in Brazil band together to take care of Duda  a baby girl born with microcephaly  after her parents were unable to take care of her. #Zika

Meet Tina and Gina from Fiji  twin girls born during Tropical Cyclone Winston. “I love Messi because he plays very well. When I am big  I will play like him.” Our Unicef Burundi colleagues came across Leo Messi fan 7-year-old Jean-Petit (second from right) playing football with his friends in the small village of Rushubi. Arturo  "the world's saddest polar bear " has died. He was almost 31 years old & had spent over 20 years of his life suffering in a bleak  concrete enclosure (often in the sweltering heat) at the Mendoza Zoo in Argentina.  People called Arturo "the world's saddest polar bear" because of the years he spent suffering alone in the Argentinian heat. But from elephants swaying alone on concrete floors to bears pacing & biting the bars of barren cages  sadness remains on display in unnatural enclosures at zoos around the world.  PETA urges families to honor this polar bear's heartbreaking legacy by refusing to give a dime to any business that puts animals on display for human entertainment.  R.I.P. Arturo. You didn't deserve this.

R.I.P. Harambe. You shouldn't have died this way  & you shouldn't have been there in the first place.    Yet again  captivity has taken an animal's life. The gorilla enclosure should have been surrounded by a secondary barrier between the humans & the animals to prevent exactly this type of incident. Gorillas have shown that they can be protective of smaller living beings & react the same way any human would to a child in danger.  Even under the "best" circumstances  captivity is never acceptable for gorillas or other primates  & in cases like this  it's even deadly. This tragedy is exactly why #PETA urges families to stay away from any facility that displays animals as sideshows for humans to gawk at. http://peta.vg/1qyq

R.I.P Prince <3   Prince was royalty to #PETA. He donated his pro-vegan song "Animal Kingdom" to us:   "No member of the animal kingdom nurses past maturity No member of the animal kingdom ever did a thing 2 me It's why I don't eat red meat or white fish Don't give me no blue cheese We're all members of the animal kingdom Leave your brothers and sisters in the sea"   He partied with us in 2005 at our Millennium Gala  & was named our Sexiest Vegetarian in 2006.   He spoke out and sang against abusing and killing animals for food and clothing  including by serving a gourmet vegan meal to reporters and blasting the wool industry in his liner notes for Rave Un2 the Joy Fantastic  in which he appeared in a faux-wool jacket: "If this jacket were real wool  it would have taken 7 lambs whose lives would have begun like this … Within weeks of their birth  their ears would have been hole-punched  their tails chopped off and the males would have been castrated while fully conscious."   Prince's legacy of compassion & creativity will live on  & he will be sorely missed. http://peta.vg/1qcw

HUGE NEWS — Here's how it happened & what it means for the orcas already at #SeaWorld.

BREAKING: #SeaWorld has just announced they are ending their orca breeding program for good.  This means that the orcas currently held captive at its marine parks will be the "last generation" who will be imprisoned in this way.  #PETA has campaigned hard & today there is a payoff for future generations of orcas. For decades orcas  dolphins  beluga whales  seals  & many other animals have suffered in SeaWorld confinement. To do right by them now  SeaWorld must open its tanks to ocean sanctuaries so that these long-suffering animals can finally have some semblance of a life outside prison tanks.   Our SeaWorld Campaign wins Round 1. They have taken a step forward  but more must follow. PETA urges kind people everywhere to keep campaigning strong!

We're honored to partner with the National Military Family Association to support the children and families of our nation's service members.

A new VA study has revised the number of veteran suicides to 20 a day in 2014  the latest year with data available. While this is lower than the often-referenced 22 a day  it is 20 too many.   We offer several mental health care programs for those we serve  including our Combat Stress Recovery Program and Warrior Care Network. Learn more about our programs at http://bit.ly/1Zka3gy.

Warriors in New York hiked through the Catskill Mountains alongside staff from WWP and the Adaptive Sports Foundation. These types of events not only provide a means for veterans to engage in physical activity  they also provide opportunities for them to socialize with other veterans.  “Other than my house  I’m most comfortable at WWP events ” said retired Navy veteran Butch Marquis. “Vets trust each other implicitly  and life is just easier when you can trust those around you. WWP gets me wanting to be active  because I know I will enjoy my time with fellow warriors.”

A new report by a congressional commission tasked with fixing the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs health care system has found that though the VA provides high-quality care  there can be inconsistencies among health care centers in providing that same care.   How would you rate the care you've received at your VA?
Here's 9 mobile apps for veterans. We'd like to hear feedback if you've used any of them before.

24 warriors and family members in Hawaii  volunteered at a community service event last weekend with Access Surf @ White Plains! where they assisted people with disabilities as they surfed. A new bill would protect veterans' credit scores from being negatively affected due to delayed payments from the VA to doctors participating in the Veterans Choice Program.

90 Warriors and family members in Hawaii took part in a Family Challenge Course day at Kualoa Ranch Secret Island. After taking a catamaran to the island  the families spent the day completing different challenges  including relay races  tug-of-war  canoe rides  kayak races  volleyball  paddle board races and more.  By the way  the kids beat the adults in tug-of-war  and the girls beat the boys.

Warriors in Kansas recently spent a relaxing day on the range doing some target shooting and adding to the eternal debate about marksmanship between the U.S. Army and U.S. Marine Corps.  “The Army and Marine veterans will bicker about who has the better shooters  so we settle it with some target practice ” Army veteran Allen Hill explained. Wounded Warrior Project announces the appointment of Michael S. Linnington to the position of Chief Executive Officer  effective July 18  2016.  Mr. Linnington is joining WWP from the Defense POW/MIA Accounting Agency (DPAA)  where Secretary of Defense Ash Carter appointed him Director.   Mr. Linnington retired from the U.S. Army after a 35-year military career including three tours in combat operations and key command positions in numerous assignments around the world.   “I have long held the utmost respect and appreciation for Wounded Warrior Project’s vital mission  and I am excited to join them as CEO ” said Mr. Linnington. “When our wounded veterans return home from combat  they rely on WWP and the organization’s dedicated team to provide necessary physical and mental health services  as well as economic empowerment and engagement programs that make a meaningful impact on their lives  and the lives of their families and caregivers.  Being part of an organization committed to this important mission is a sacred duty and solemn responsibility. I look forward to working with the entire WWP team  including interim Chief Operating Officer Major General Charlie Fletcher and the Board of Directors to continue to serve our nation’s bravest.”              We are proud to welcome Mr. Linnington as the Wounded Warrior Project Chief Executive Officer.  https://www.woundedwarriorproject.org/featured-campaign/wounded-warrior-project-names-michael-s-linnington-chief-executive-officer

There's nothing like a good old-fashioned camping trip to bring families together  and recently  warriors and their families in Maryland were hosted by the expert campers at the Baltimore Area Council Boy Scouts of America for a weekend of fun  sun  s'mores  hot dogs and more.   “It was an amazing outdoor adventure ” said U.S. Army veteran Bryan Asaf  who attended with his wife and three children.

When wounded veteran Paul Delacerda saw a truck flip over on the freeway  he jumped into action. He was joined by his passengers  actors Tommy Flanagan and Alan Ritchson  as they pulled the victim from the wrecked and burning truck. Give 'em one!
