We were proud to partner today with Memorial Day Foundation  the wounded veterans and families we serve  and local veterans of Vietnam  Korean  and World War II to visit war memorials throughout New York City honoring those that have made the ultimate sacrifice for our freedom.  New York first began holding public ceremonies to mark Memorial Day 150 years ago  a tradition we are humbled to participate in today.
On this Memorial Day  and on all days  we honor those who have given their lives for our country.
Has the VA declared you dead  but you aren't?  Our benefits team can help. Learn more at http://bit.ly/1TIvR0q.
The next time you meet a veteran  start a conversation. You might be surprised at what they have to say.
This Army scientist has found sleep issues in troops that don't fall under traditional  previously diagnosed categories of trauma disorders.
Wounded veterans in Indiana and Illinois gathered recently for the kickoff of a 3-month UFC gym training program. The veterans will train at seven different gyms in their areas.
Wondering how you can honor those who've made the ultimate sacrifice for our country?  The Memorial Day Foundation can help. Click below for ways to get involved.
We're so proud of WWP staff member Andrew Coughlan  who recently donated a kidney to a fellow veteran. He is truly "living the logo."
This eagle amputee inspired many injured veterans during her 15 years of visits to hospitals and treatment centers.

Painting pottery was the mission for these wounded veterans and their families in Virginia. The event started with a BBQ meal  then they chose their pottery and decorated as they wished. “I've never painted a personal piece before and have been wanting to do it ” said Army veteran Gail Schnell. “The painting event sounded like a lot of fun  and it didn’t disappoint. I found it relaxing to focus on something artistic  and it helped relieve stress.”

Alumni and family members took to the paintball field in Las Vegas recently for an afternoon of friendly competition and bonding.  Our Alumni program provides opportunities for camaraderie and social interactions across the country  which are always free for Alumni and their families. Learn more at http://bit.ly/1TjJcPK.

Is this the future of prosthetic technology? Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency - DARPA thinks so  and they hope to provide wounded service members replacement limbs that are able to do almost everything the real thing can do.
Team USA showed its mettle by bringing home the gold medal in basketball at Invictus Games Orlando 2016. A packed house celebrated as these wounded veterans wowed the crowd. #InvictusGames
Ten UFC fighters who served for the Pentagon before they went in the octagon.
Lost that lovin' feeling? Creative therapies are helping veterans become intimate with their partners again.

It was a smashing good time as Team USA outscored Team Denmark to take gold in wheelchair rugby at Invictus Games Orlando 2016. On hand for the final were Vice President Biden and Prince Harry  while John Cena - WWE Universe and Wilmer Valderrama coached a celebrity exhibition game between the bronze and gold medal games. #InvictusGames

Check out the new issue of Homeland Magazine for the story of Charles "Chuck" Clark  a wounded veteran and WWP Alumnus who turned to WWP's Benefits Service to help him navigate the VA disability system after he and his family encountered financial difficulties following his injuries.   Clark is one of the many veterans who WWP has assisted in procuring more than $200 million in disability benefits since the program began in 2007  more than 2 400 in March 2016 alone.  Learn more about our Benefits Service at http://bit.ly/1TIvR0q.
Wounded veterans hit the pool yesterday for the swimming segment of Invictus Games Orlando 2016. Spectators were treated to an amazing display of the feats injured veterans are capable of performing.

Army veteran and WWP Alumnus Matthew Keil  along with his wife and caregiver Tracy  were on Capitol Hill this week to speak with senators about providing injured veterans unable to conceive children due to their service-connected injuries access to fertility treatments.   These procedures  which the U.S. Department of Defense (DOD) will pay for when the troops are active duty  are currently unavailable through the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs due to an outdated law. If you'd like that to change  let your senator know by visiting our Action Center to send them a letter at http://bit.ly/1NWakVQ.

Team USA took the gold in sitting volleyball before a packed house for Invictus Games Orlando 2016 at the  ESPN Wide World of Sports campus. 500 injured veterans and active duty service members from 14 nations are in Orlando competing in the games.

WWP Alumni got their diving certifications recently at the Nassau County Aquatics Center. The Alumni who participated enjoyed spending time with each other as well as the diving itself.  “I served in the Navy for many years  and I like to Jet Ski and snorkel  so going farther underwater seemed like the next logical step ” Kim Humphrey  Navy veteran and WWP Alumnae joked. “Everyone was super encouraging  and it was probably one of the best activities I’ve tried!”

On day two of Invictus Games Orlando 2016  the morning was all about the track & field competition  where 40 different events featuring the world’s best veteran and active-duty runners  discus throwers and shot put hurlers wowed the crowd.

Join the call to provide wounded veterans whose illnesses or injuries don't allow them to start a family the means to do so.   Let your senator know it's time to change outdated laws that prevent the VA from providing access to fertility treatments at http://bit.ly/1NWakVQ.
Athletes from 14 nations are continuing to compete in this year's Invictus Games Orlando 2016. Day one saw these wounded veterans going for gold in archery and powerlifting.
Veterans  have you always wanted emojis of your own? Your wish has been granted  courtesy of Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans of America's new Vetmoji app.
On day one of Invictus Games Orlando 2016  athletes competed in indoor rowing by using rowing machines to row the maximum distance possible during the time limit in each particular category.

Competitors cycled in a number of categories on day one of Invictus Games Orlando 2016  including single  tandem  recumbent and standard. Five-hundred competitors from 14 nations are taking part in the games  which were first held in London in 2014.
Great video from the opening ceremony of Invictus Games 2016!

The Invictus Games Orlando 2016 kicked off yesterday with an opening ceremony that introduced 500 athletes from 14 nations  and included appearances by First Lady Michelle Obama  former President George W. Bush  Prince Harry and Morgan Freeman. Performing were singer James Blunt  the United States Marine Corps Silent Drill Platoon   The United States Army Old Guard Fife and Drum Corps and more. Stay tuned throughout the week for updates from the competition!

WWP Alumni joined the Running of the Reindeer race during the 10th Annual Fur Rondy festival in Anchorage  Alaska. More than 1 300 people gathered from around the world to run  skip  jump and dance with reindeer to help raise funds for the Marine Toys for Tots Foundation.  “I found the day encouraging and supportive ” said Aaron Velvick  Army veteran and WWP Alumnus. “A lot of wounded warriors chose to live out here—off the grid and in complete isolation—because they don’t think people understand them. At the run  I saw a lot of battle buddies in the same boat as me. We don’t need to worry what other people think  because we understand each other. That kind of support is nice.”

We're proud to partner with Team Rubicon USA  helping to support the amazing things veterans are doing to continue their service to our nation. More on our $9 million partnership at http://bit.ly/2708yJF.
Happy Mother's Day to all moms  and especially the military moms and spouses in our community. You are appreciated!

We're proud to partner with Invictus Games 2016!  Stay tuned for coverage next week as more than 500 athletes from 14 nations show their stuff to the world.  Learn more about our partnership at http://bit.ly/24BVok4.

Many veterans enjoy video games. These three veterans turned that passion into careers at World of Warcraft maker Blizzard.  Looking for career assistance? WWP offers our Warriors to Work program for Alumni and their families. Learn more at http://bit.ly/1TjaG4Q.

Wounded veterans whose injuries don't allow them to have children are currently unable to access fertility treatments such as in vitro fertilization (IVF) through the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs.  If you think that's as wrong as we do  join our campaign calling on the Senate to re-examine this policy at http://bit.ly/1NWakVQ. Lets give those who have sacrificed so much for us the opportunity to start a family.
Medal of Honor recipient and Marine Dakota Meyer makes a case here for increasing career support for military spouses  who  by some estimates  face underemployment of nearly 90%.

Today is Military Spouse Appreciation Day. The day was created in 1984  when President Ronald Reagan officially recognized the contributions of military spouses towards the readiness and well-being of service members.

On this day six years ago  President Obama signed into law the Veterans and Family Caregivers Act of 2010  a bill which WWP worked hard to promote to politicians  and which created the VA caregiver program. Learn more at http://1.usa.gov/1SRWfFR.
Pets for Vets is an organization that pairs shelter dogs with veterans to help them cope with PTSD.

WWP Alumni spent a day learning to fly fish recently in New Jersey through L.L.Bean Outdoor Discovery Schools Adventures. At YMCA Camp Ockanickon  Inc.  volunteers from the local chapter of Trout Unlimited taught the Alumni how to tie flies  cast lines and catch fish.  “I used to really enjoy fishing before joining the military. And now I’ve been out several times since the WWP fishing activity and am improving my sunfish catching skills ” John McCool  Army veteran and WWP Alumnus  said. “I even plan to fish in Idaho for cutthroat trout with a former battle buddy now.”

Veterans whose injuries make them unable to have children are currently unable to access fertility treatment procedures through the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs.  We think that's wrong. Join our campaign calling on the Senate to provide wounded veterans the opportunity to start families at http://bit.ly/1NWakVQ.
The U.S. Department of Labor recently launched a new website for veterans looking for careers  employers looking to hire veterans  and prospective veteran entrepreneurs.

WWP Alumnus Bill Geiger recently spoke with The Boston Globe about his experience participating in our mental health care initiative  Warrior Care Network  in which we've partnered with four academic medical centers to increase the availability and scope of mental health care offerings for veterans. Learn more at http://bit.ly/W_C_N.
A group of veterans and service members is  at this moment  climbing Mt. Everest to bring attention to Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.

Did you know?  Veterans who have sustained injuries that prevent them from having children are not able to access fertility assistance procedures such as in vitro fertilization from the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs.  We find this to be unacceptable  and  together with a coalition of fellow Veterans Service Organizations  have called upon the Senate to re-examine this policy in a joint letter  which you can view at http://bit.ly/1NiBkPf.  You can also let your own Senator know you'd like action to be taken so our veterans can start a family at: https://www.woundedwarriorproject.org/action-center.

Veterans are increasingly turning to social media as a mutual support system  as well as to keep tabs on their buddies who may be going through difficult times.  WWP offers our Peer Support Program for Alumni interested in becoming mentors to their fellow veterans. Learn more at http://bit.ly/Peer_Support.

Looking to hire veterans? The Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM) has some tips for you. Employers can also learn more about hiring wounded veterans from our Warriors to Work Program at http://bit.ly/W_2_W.

WWP Alumni joined Habitat for Humanity to construct a new home for a deserving family in North Carolina  recently  allowing them to continue their service after their return to civilian life.  “I really liked meeting the families that were being served through the Habitat for Humanity program  and thought it was pretty cool working side by side with them on their houses ” Army Veteran and WWP Alumnus Phil Hanback said.

A study by the USC Center for Innovation and Research on Veterans & Military Families-CIR found characteristics of Chicago veterans that hold true for the national veterans population and also show a continued need to support our men and women who have served.   Among them: -More than six in 10 veterans left the military without a job  expecting to quickly find meaningful employment. -More than 45 percent of post-9/11 veterans reported their military skills and experiences were often dismissed by employers. -Nearly one in five post-9/11 veterans reported being homeless in the last three months.

Alumni conquered the Hudson River Gorge in New York alongside their family members and guests during a four mile-whitewater excursion  recently. No word on whether they've gotten the smiles off their faces following the event.
The first federally-regulated study on the effects of marijuana as a treatment for PTSD has been approved by the Drug Enforcement Agency.
WWP Alumni launched Soldier Ride Houston today by taking off from Space Center Houston. Check out the video as they rocket around the corner.
The Senate has proposed some massive changes to the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs  including increasing accountability  changes to the caregiver program and more.

...the 2015 Federal Veterans Laws  Rules  and Regulations manual is now 2 143 pages (and)...it takes 273 days for the VA to process a claim. A full 244 939 injured veterans wait more than one year and more than 58 000 wait a full two years for their claims to be fully resolved.
Whoops! Soldiers in Germany practicing airdrops learned there is no such thing as routine in the military. Caution: Strong language in video.
This company hires veterans for its apparel business  and business is booming.

Veterans in Virginia are learning how to farm on land that goes back to our nation's Founding Fathers. Interested in farming? Visit https://www.outreach.usda.gov/veterans.htm for more information from the U.S. Department of Agriculture.
The VA program for providing service dogs to veterans coping with PTSD is coming under scrutiny.
In case you missed it: Wounded Marine Corps K9 receives Dickin Medal for her heroic actions that led to zero human casualties on her more than 400 patrols.
Veterans who are immigrants would be shielded from deportation in some cases under a new bill introduced in the House.
When this wounded veteran ordered a pizza  the staff at his local Domino's Pizza delivered  and then some.

WWP continues its mission of honoring and empowering Wounded Warriors through our $9 million investment into our partnership with The Mission Continues  an organization devoted to providing veterans with opportunities to serve their communities. By the end of 2016  more than 70 service platoons across the nation will be operating thanks to WWP's funding. Read more at http://bit.ly/1UcTu6r.

When an IED exploded six feet from WWP Alumnus Brett Miller's Humvee  the impact shook Brett with such force he suffered traumatic brain injury  brain bleed  a detached right retina  blown out right ear  and nine fractured teeth. It rendered Brett hemiplegic – paralyzed on his left side  and left him with PTSD.    Brett got involved with WWP and soon was literally riding a bike across the country. “Wounded Warrior Project enabled me to do things that I would have never been able to do on my own ” he said. Read more of his story at http://bit.ly/1T3IZxa.

Army veteran and WWP Alumnus Mark Lalli suffered a severe Traumatic Brain Injury and broken bones in a helicopter crash. After attending a WWP barbecue for Alumni at a horse ranch  he found a sense of peace while riding horses  something he continues to do today.
Growing up as a military child is a very interesting experience. Do you have anything you'd add to this list?
Researchers have found that male and female veterans who experienced Military Sexual Trauma during their service were much more likely to experience homelessness after their discharge.
Happy 108th birthday  U.S. Army Reserve!
We will support them for a lifetime in a manner that inspires trust and confidence. - Major General Charlie Fletcher  US Army (Retired). Interim Chief Operating Officer  Wounded Warrior Project.

30 wounded veterans and their family members in Florida spent an evening painting pottery and enjoying each other's company.  Registered Alumni  Family Support Members and Caregivers receive a weekly email from WWP called "The Post" that contains information and links to register for events in your area. Learn more at http://bit.ly/WWP_Alumni.

U.S. Marine Corps veteran and WWP Alumnus Mike Delancey was paralyzed by a sniper's bullet in Iraq in 2006. Since then  he has become a WWP peer mentor  an athlete  and spearheaded the construction of a wheelchair accessible park in his hometown.
The Senate has confirmed the new inspector general for the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs.
Thinking about going back to school? Here's some info for picking a veteran-friendly college to earn that degree.

WWP Alumni and guests hit the slopes of Oregon's Mt. Hood alongside the Outdoors for All Foundation for a skiing and snowboarding Physical Health and Wellness event.  Learn more about our PH&W Program at http://bit.ly/P_HandW.

WWP is proud to announce a $3.4 million investment into the emergency and long-term financial well-being of our Alumni through our commitment to fund the American Red Cross  the Association for Financial Counseling and Planning Education  Operation Homefront  SALUTE  INC.  and USA Cares. Learn more at http://bit.ly/1SqIXlq.
A great writeup about the kickoff of WWP's Warrior Care Network at UCLA Operation Mend. Learn more about the program at http://bit.ly/23I3wyR.
32 female WWP Alumni attended a three-day health and wellness expo at the Mayo Clinic recently. The expo was designed to meet and support the unique needs of wounded female veterans.
When WWP Alumnus Scott Scieszinski  who is legally blind  requested technology that would allow him to see  the VA refused him. So he asked WWP  and now he can see again.

Dancing Well: The Soldier Project was created when staff at the VA Healthcare Center at Fort Knox  Kentucky  enlisted a seasoned dance instructor to offer dancing classes for veterans coping with the affects of PTSD and brain injuries. The results were pretty amazing.

32 wounded veterans and their guests in Hawaii took to the seas for a night snorkeling experience with Manta Rays. They swam alongside lighted surfboards  which attracted food that Manta Rays eat  causing some close encounters of the amazing kind.

In 1971  "...veterans made up 72% of members in the House of Representatives  and 78% of the Senate." Today  "Congress...features a Senate with 20%  and a House with 18%  of its members as veterans."  Why do you think so few veterans are represented in today's Congress? Should there be more?

Researchers have found a strong connection between Traumatic Brain Injury incurred during service and the incidence of headaches in veterans during their first year of VA care. By learning more about what causes the headaches  the researchers hope to create strategies to mitigate them.

Congratulations to all our Alumni who participated in the 2016 Austin Rattler 100 MTB mountain bike race at Rocky Hill Ranch in Smithville  Texas. The race is 100 kilometers in length and those that finished in less than 7 hours will be competing in the Leadville 100  which is a 104 mile mountain bike race in Leadville  Colorado  in August.

Check out this spotlight on seven military children  as chosen by the U.S. Department of Defense (DOD). Have an amazing military child you'd like to spotlight? Share a photo or comment on our page with #WWPKids.

Veterans with injuries to their "creative organs" would be entitled to lump-sum payments equaling $20 000 under a new bill. The money would be for the veteran to spend as wished  with the intention that it could assist with costs associated with adoption or medical treatments if so desired.

Have an appeal on your benefits claim with the VA? You're not alone. "More than 440 000 veterans have appeals cases pending in the benefits system " according to Military Times.  “We’re failing veterans ” said Veterans Affairs Deputy Secretary Sloan Gibson. “This process is failing veterans. Nobody can defend the status quo here.”  WWP offers free benefits assistance to our Alumni for VA claims and appeals. Visit http://bit.ly/Benefits_Service for more.
Some disabled Americans will be getting letters from the government starting next week informing them that their federal student loans will be forgiven.

We're honored to have President Obama  Vice President Biden  and Secretary of the VA McDonald kick-off this year's #SoldierRideDC at The White House.  Learn more about Soldier Ride and how to get involved: http://bit.ly/soldierride

We're proud to announce the launch of our Warrior Care Network at UCLA Operation Mend  one of four academic medical centers partnering in our $100 million initiative to connect veterans with world-class mental health care. Learn more at http://bit.ly/23I3wyR. #WarriorCareNetwork #honoredtoserveU

Twenty WWP Alumni and family members began a 90-day fitness challenge in conjunction with Title Boxing Club-South Tampa. Our Physical Health and Wellness Program is designed to reduce stress  combat depression  and promote an overall healthy and active lifestyle by encouraging participation in fun  educational activities. Learn more at http://bit.ly/P_HandW.

WWP Alumni and family members explored the Howe Caverns in New York recently. “My daughter had a great time interacting with everything around her - she thought it was so cool to be down beneath the surface  and touched all the slimy rocks ” Family Support Member Kristina Sledge-Moorhead said.

April is the Month of the Military Child. Millions of military children are affected by the deployments  repeated relocations and other unique facets of military life  and it is our distinct pleasure to have the opportunity to serve them  as well as their families.  Learn more about how the U.S. Department of Defense (DOD) is honoring these very special boys and girls at http://1.usa.gov/1S4p1Tg.
This author believes that business people could learn some leadership lessons from veterans.

An associate lecturer at the UW-Stevens Point was teaching classes full of veterans when he realized that their stories were so good they were worth turning into a book. "See Me For Who I Am" contains 20 stories written by student veterans. WXPR Public Radio tells the story.

23 WWP Alumni  family members and caregivers went on a Jungle Expedition Tour at Kualoa Ranch  where movies such as Hunger Games  Jurassic World  50 First Dates and Godzilla were filmed. The participants especially liked seeing the enclosure that the hybrid dinosaur in Jurassic World scratched and damaged.
We're honored we were able to give this Alumnus and Navy veteran the ability to see again.

WWP Alumni and their families in North Carolina attended a BBQ cooking class taught by Champion BBQ Pitmaster  Chef Christopher Prieto. Along with the opportunity to socialize with other veterans and their families  participants also learned how to cook BBQ the North Carolina way. “I learned how I was ruining my meat on the grill until now ” Army veteran and WWP Alumnus Anthony Adetoye said. “With this class  I learned how to fix it along with flavor profiles  seasonings  and cooking temperatures.”
Veterans coping with PTSD  anxiety or depression may find some relief by playing video games  according to a new study.

42 Alumni  Family Support members and caregivers gathered for a Ladies Painting and Sushi Night in Hawaii recently  where they learned more about the programs available to them while enjoying each other's company  painted and had sushi prepared by a sushi chef.

Veterans with concussion injuries (Mild Traumatic Brain Injuries) may be suffering from hormone deficiencies that mimic the symptoms of PTSD  and which are treatable with hormone replacement therapy  according to a new VA-sponsored study.

A new study has found that 14 percent of veterans reported having suicidal thoughts over a two-year period  and that veterans with higher levels of "social connectedness" reported lower levels of suicidal thoughts.  WWP offers our Alumni Engagement Program to provide our Alumni and their families opportunities for socialization and camaraderie  as well as our Warrior Care Network for mental health care. Learn more about our programs: http://bit.ly/WWPPrograms.

Project 22 is a crowd-funded documentary  directed by two combat veterans  that explores how veterans are transitioning home following their military lives  and discusses a variety of personal trials  treatments and therapies they've experienced. Watch the complete movie on PBS at the link below.

Veterans representing WWP and The Mission Continues joined other service organizations recently to refurbish a Houston-area church. They painted the entire church  replaced rotted wood  added handrails  removed garbage  planted flowers and leveled gravel to smooth the driveway. The volunteers also enjoyed a team lunch of crawfish and brisket near the end of the workday.

Veterans in Caldwell  Idaho  are benefiting from the Idaho Veterans Garden  where veterans and the community can work alongside each other  socialize  or even just gather around the fire-pit to relax. Three of the 27 raised beds are for Gold Star Families.   Should more communities offer this type of opportunity?

Wounded veterans and guests took in an NBA game recently as the Orlando Magic played the Memphis Grizzlies. They got the chance to meet Coach Scott Skiles  and were greeted by members of the Orlando Magic Dancers.

Did you know?  More than 100 000 wounded veterans  family members and caregivers are registered to take advantage of WWP's free  direct programs and services. Learn more about all that we offer at http://bit.ly/WWPPrograms. #WWPFacts

WWP Alumni in Philadelphia took part in a four-day  three-night outdoor excursion  where they fished and hunted for trophy rams at the Wilderness Hunting Ranch.  During downtime  they also were given information about the programs and services available to them.  Following the event  they took home the meat from the animals they harvested  or made arrangements for taxidermy.

Researchers from the Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies (MAPS) conducting a trial using MDMA to treat PTSD found an 83 percent cure-rate for participants when the medication was administered alongside psychotherapy.   The results were promising enough that they have already undertaken Phase 2 clinical trials with plans for the third phase  in order to meet the U.S. Food and Drug Administration requirements for approval of a new drug.

WWP Alumnus Nick Bennett  a Marine Corps veteran  was honored by the NCAA during a Women's Final Four game. Anucha Browne  NCAA VP of Women's Basketball Championships  presented Nick with a tournament ball  signed by all the Women's Final Four coaches.  The NCAA also hosted wounded veterans and their families at their Super Saturday Celebration Event  prior to the Women's Final Four  and honored the veterans in attendance.
Wounded veterans can do anything. Including climbing Mount Everest. Cheers to these hard-chargers.

WWP Alumni in New Orleans got to see the city from a new perspective as they paddled kayaks through the Bayou St. John neighborhood  one of the oldest in the city.  While the scenery was great  one Alumnus said being around other veterans was the most important part of the event.   "There wasn't anything in particular about kayaking that interested me; the main thing was being able to hang out with other WWP Alumni " Army veteran and WWP Alumna Tenesha Whorton said.

5.3 million Americans currently live with the effects of traumatic brain injury (TBI)  and service members are at an increased risk of incurring these injuries compared to civilians. The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs estimates that 22% of combat casualties in Iraq and Afghanistan are brain injuries. Get more facts about TBI from the CDC at http://1.usa.gov/1RXQqvr.
Are you a registered VA Caregiver? The VA has resources and support for you to help you care for your veteran. Click below for more info.
For many veterans looking for a purpose in their lives following their military service  student veteran organizations offer camaraderie and community.

Our Independence Program is designed for Alumni who rely on their families and/or caregivers because of moderate-to-severe brain injury  spinal-cord injury  or other neurological conditions.    Each veteran is able to focus on goals that provide a future with purpose  all at no cost to the veterans or their caregivers.  Currently  493 Alumni are enrolled in the program  with 280 new sign-ups in 2015 alone. We plan to have 1 150 enrolled by 2017.  Learn more at http://bit.ly/Independence_Program.

A group in North Carolina is providing veterans with free tattoos as a means of therapy.  We'd like to hear from veterans with tattoos. Did you get your ink as a therapeutic measure? In remembrance? Out of boredom? Feel free to share your ink as well. (Please keep pictures appropriate for our community)

43 percent of veterans leave their first civilian job within 12 months  according to a study cited in this NPR piece.  WWP offers our Warriors to Work Program for registered Alumni and family members interested in career assistance. We also work with employers to educate them on the benefits of hiring veterans and to facilitate employment. Learn more at http://bit.ly/Warriors_to_Work.
Female veterans gathered recently to share their stories and learn about available resources at an event sponsored by WWP's partner The Mission Continues.

Nine WWP Alumni kicked off a multi-day fitness summit in Florida at Title Boxing Club- Brandon  where they learned proper exercise techniques  followed by Crossfit action at CrossFit BNI and nutrition classes  complete with a tour of Whole Foods Market for a practical application of the lessons learned.
Looking to start a business? The U.S. Small Business Administration has eliminated fees for veterans borrowing up to $350 000  while fees for larger loans have been cut in half.

WWP Alumni in Pittsburgh gathered at Veterans Place of Washington Boulevard for a community service project recently. The volunteers landscaped the areas flanking the Purple Heart Memorial in the front of the building  which houses 48 homeless veterans  and also offers support for other homeless veterans  including laundry facilities  counseling  job training and more. After their hard work  they ate lunch with some staff and residents at the home.  At WWP  when our Alumni reach a place in their own lives where they can begin to help others  we call that "living the logo " and we are very proud of them all.

We are proud to support not only our nation's wounded veterans  but also the caregivers and family members who continue to care for these men and women once they've returned home.   A WWP-sponsored study by the RAND Corporation for the Elizabeth Dole Foundation found that "...more than a million caregivers care for service members who have served since September 11  2001."

Alumni in Hawaii took an ATV tour of Kualoa Ranch  with 23 Alumni and guests taking to the trails to view its scenic locales  which have been featured in movies such as Jurassic Park  Jurassic World  Godzilla  50 First Dates and more.

Wounded Warrior Project is proud to announce a $9 million  five-year investment into a partnership with Team Rubicon USA.  This partnership will provide WWP Alumni greater opportunities for service-oriented projects and missions  and also help Team Rubicon to build the ability of cities to respond to natural disasters by activating trained  local veterans to rise and serve as first-responders as natural disasters occur.  More details at http://bit.ly/1WYq6iI.

About 60 percent of those returning from deployments in the Middle East  and 50 percent of older veterans suffer from chronic pain  according to Veterans Affairs officials. Previously  many of those patients were treated with opiod painkillers.   This has led to almost 68 000 veterans with opiod use-disorders. "...about 13 percent of the total population of veterans currently taking opioids  according to VA data."
Since WWP's Transition Training Academy was started  7 610 wounded veterans and caregivers have enrolled in the Information Technology courses.  Learn more about TTA at http://bit.ly/TransitionTA.

A new study has found that using a type of MRI called Diffusion Tensor Imaging (DTI) can help physicians predict the long-term affects of Mild Traumatic Brain Injuries (MTBI). "More than 300 000 U.S. service members were diagnosed with MTBI between 2000 and 2015  according to the Armed Forces Health Surveillance Center."

WWP Alumni dove in the six-million-gallon tank at the Georgia Aquarium to swim alongside whale sharks  fish and manta rays  as well as to get to know each other.  “It was really awesome ” said Daniel English  Marine veteran and WWP Alumnus. “Words cannot really describe it. A whale shark actually swam over to me  and bumped me.”

One veteran has found an activity that helps her cope with PTSD  LEGOs. Such activities  when included as part of a treatment plan  are called recreational therapy  and can "relieve tension  ease anxiety and reduce stress."   What are some of the things you do to help relieve stress?

WWP Alumni and staff joined The Mission Continues Orlando Service Platoon  The Home Depot's Team Depot Volunteer Team  and A Veterans Community to renovate a house for a formerly homeless veteran and her family. Volunteers painted inside and outside  landscaped  put up new gutters and put new flooring down.

Spring training wasn't just for the players of MLB's Tampa Bay Rays recently  as WWP Alumni joined them for two days of all things baseball.  The Alumni worked out with the team  showed off their slugging skills in the batting cages  shagged balls during practice and took in games at the ballpark. #FloridaFieldofDreams

WWP Alumni braved the desert to march in the annual Bataan Memorial Death March at White Sands Missile Base  New Mexico. The Memorial March honors the original Bataan Death March in World War II  when Allied prisoners of war in the Philippines were forced to march 65 miles to prison camps  a journey that claimed the lives of many.  The Alumni also honor a contemporary service member each year  and this year marched in honor of Staff Sergeant Juan De Dios Garcia-Arana  who was killed April 30  2005  when the Bradley fighting vehicle he captained was attacked with small-arms fire in Iraq.
Did you know?  39 789 wounded veterans and family members have participated in WWP Physical Health and Wellness events since the program began  with 18 052 in 2015 alone. #WWPFacts

WWP Alumnae gathered in Phoenix for an introduction to the TRX training method at Ability360 Sports & Fitness Center  followed by instruction on the MELT method  which offers self-treatment for chronic pain and erases the effects left behind by aging and injuries that some people get from leading an active lifestyle.   "I love that Wounded Warrior Project hosts female only events like this  because it gives us a chance to discuss how our recoveries are progressing  and share different therapies that are unique to us as women. A lot of the women at the event were in the Army just like me and it was good to bond over that shared experience " said Alumna Antoinette Grimes.

Having fun while leading a healthy lifestyle is important  and Alumni in Alaska learned some great ideas and tips at the recent Fitness and Nutrition Summit in Fairbanks. The Physical Health and Wellness Team helped the attendees apply their knowledge to a snowshoe excursion in the beautiful Alaskan terrain.

PTSD affects more than veterans' mental health  it can have very real physical consequences as well  according to new research.   Learn more about WWP's mental health offerings for veterans at http://bit.ly/WWPPrograms.

Our thanks to Duke University and the Duke Men's Basketball team for hosting 32 WWP Alumni for a tour of the campus and athletic facilities. They also got to shoot hoops at Cameron Arena  something many of the veterans considered a bucket-list opportunity.
Did you know?   WWP's advocacy initiatives in Washington  D.C.  have resulted in awards of more than $2.5 billion to wounded veterans and their families. #WWPFacts
Veterans  Florida wants you to live there  and they're listing the reasons why you should consider relocating.
A new program in St. Louis is helping veterans who are coping with the effects of PTSD or other service-related issues through art therapy. St. Louis Public Radio has the story.

Wounded Warrior Project is proud to support America's Warrior Partnership  which has impacted the lives of 19 537 veterans since February 2014  in areas such as homelessness  education  healthcare  benefits and employment.  Just one of the many veteran service organizations we help fund. The need is great...and growing. View more organizations we proudly support at http://bit.ly/WWPGrantRecipients.
Some combat-wounded veterans may soon be getting a check from the government due to the Pentagon mistakenly deducting taxes from lump-sum disability severance packages.

Sixty WWP Alumni  family members and caregivers spent a day at the Tallahassee Museum  where they bonded with their fellow veterans and families while experiencing a private tour  a zip-line excursion  and activities to learn more about the snakes  alligators and turtles at the museum.

Download some quick workout nutrition tips from WWP's Physical Health & Wellness team.  Having a healthy body is a great start to improve the overall quality of life for the more than 100 000 wounded veterans  caregivers and family members who can access WWP's direct programs and services  all of which are free of charge.
Military Times has just released the results of their 7th annual survey on the the most veteran-friendly employers.

Having a healthy body is a great start to improve the overall quality of life for the more than 100 000 wounded veterans  caregivers and family members who can access WWP's direct programs and services  all of which are free of charge. Here's some quick wellness tips from WWP's Physical Health and Wellness Program.

Alumni in Florida gathered for a night of video games at the Microsoft Store  where they met fellow veterans in their area that share similar interests and learned more about how to access the 20 free  direct programs and services available to them.
Veterans are healing through camaraderie and the great outdoors while working at the Central Oregon Veterans Ranch  a functional ranch operated mostly by volunteers who are veterans.

March is National Brain Injury Awareness Month.  WWP is serving veterans with Traumatic Brain Injuries (TBI) and meeting their mental health needs through programs such as our Warrior Care Network  a $100 million investment that will connect thousands of veterans with top-of-the-line care.   Visit http://bit.ly/WC_Network and learn more about how veterans can access the program. The treatment and travel are provided at zero cost to the patient and family members.

WWP Family Support members in Maryland gathered for their first ever "Plant Nite" event recently  during which they learned from a local artist how to assemble their very own terrarium  which they then took home after first enjoying a delicious seafood dinner.
Senators in DC are working towards improving the Veterans Choice program through additional legislation that would address the issues some veterans have experienced while attempting to access it.
House lawmakers are attempting to make the process of getting service dogs much simpler for wounded veterans through a proposed VA program.

WWP Alumnus Sebastian Ploszaj was injured in Iraq and medically discharged  but the end of his military service was just the beginning of the rest of his life.   He joined and then became the president of his local chapter of the Student Veterans of America  and earned an IT certification through WWP's Transition Training Academy  a hands-on program that helps veterans explore the IT field as a possible career choice. Read more of his story below  and learn more about WWP's TTA Program at http://bit.ly/WWP_TTA.
WWP Alumni in Florida were certified in scuba diving as they tested their limits and pushed each other to succeed during the training.
If you were exposed to a burn pit while deployed  the VA would like to hear from you to document your exposure and fill out a questionnaire about your health and any effects from your exposure.
More veterans are enrolling at "elite" colleges  and the colleges say the experience is beneficial for all.

Soldier Ride season has officially kicked off in San Diego  where more than 50 WWP Alumni rode more than 50 miles while enjoying the company of fellow veterans and learning tips for leading a healthy lifestyle.  Learn more about Soldier Rides at http://bit.ly/Soldier_Ride.

In the 13 years since WWP’s founding  while we have grown tremendously  we have made some mistakes along the way.  The Board of Directors has no evidence of fraud  embezzlement or misappropriation of funds  and the decision to part ways with Steve Nardizzi and Al Giordano  who led the charge on groundbreaking and life-saving initiatives  was not based on any belief that criminal activity occurred. The decision to replace WWP’s leadership was based on an assessment of the totality of the circumstances which reflected poor judgment.  We have already begun strengthening our policies and procedures to keep pace with our organization’s rapid growth  and we now look forward to focusing on our recently launched Warrior Care Network and continuing to provide critical support through 20 free programs and services to this nation’s wounded veterans and their families.  As an organization  we certainly understand the concern expressed by Alumni  donors and staff over the issues that were raised. We hope this clarifies the decisions that were made  and you have our word that we are moving quickly and decisively as we can to address those concerns and make the necessary changes to reestablish your trust to continue your support of our mission to honor and empower Wounded Warriors.

We're proud to support Deron and the more than 100 000 wounded veterans  family members and caregivers we currently serve  through our 20 free  direct programs and services.  Learn more about all we offer: http://bit.ly/WWPprograms

The VA will be enhancing their programs to combat veteran suicide and will "guarantee same-day evaluations and establish national tele-mental health centers for veterans with urgent mental health needs."  Additionally  veterans eligible for enrollment into the VA health care system will be automatically enrolled if they do not opt out.

Virginia Tech Hokies men's basketball coach Buzz Williams noticed over the years that some college basketball players were fidgeting or disregarding the National Anthem before games  so he decided to teach his team a lesson about respect.

We're proud that the leaders of our partner organizations Team Rubicon USA and Team Red  White & Blue have been recognized by HillVets for their contributions to the veterans community  as well as our own CEO  Steve Nardizzi. This acknowledgment means so much because it comes directly from those who know and understand the importance of veterans service organizations.  HillVets forms the list based on nominations from the public  from which final candidates are chosen by a panel of veterans who work on Capitol Hill.
This Army veteran was severely injured in Iraq  and now  years later  is attempting to open a restaurant that employs only veterans. #StillServing

Veterans who have applied for VA health care  but whose applications were marked as incomplete  can expect a letter or phone call from the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs to inform them what information is needed to start their five years of free post-service health care.

Last week  BBC News published this article about the challenges elephants and the rangers who protect them in places like Garamba National Park face  including LRA poaching.   Take some time to get to know how the ivory trade feeds into armed conflict in central Africa.
You know it's a #FunFriday when there's a team jumping photo involved.
Understanding the LRA is the first step in ending Joseph Kony's violence.   Learn about how the group formed and why it still exists by reading more on our website.
There are no national boundaries  no laws  no man-made rules that trump the law of common humanity.

In the first 3 months of 2016 the LRA abducted 57 central African children  36 of whom remain unaccounted for. LRA leaders also reportedly expressed plans to train the new recruits as fighters to bolster the LRA’s fighting strength.  JOIN US in stopping LRA violence and bringing these children home. DONATE TODAY to support programs like our 'Come Home' messages to the LRA.

Our Invisible Children leadership team was able to visit Garamba National Park just a couple of weeks ago  where we met some of the brave rangers there working to turn the tide in Garamba and slow down the onslaught of poaching in the area.  Our hearts go out to the families of these fallen rangers  and to our colleagues at African Parks who continue to courageously protect some of our world’s most endangered and beautiful wildlife.

Today  our thoughts are with the brave staff and rangers at Garamba National Park who risk their lives daily to protect endangered wildlife from poachers  including the LRA.  Over the weekend  three park rangers were killed and two more were injured in a clash with armed poachers. We mourn alongside the Garamba team for this loss and hope for a full recovery of our wounded friends.

Every day  communities in our Early Warning Network report on LRA activity.  We upload these reports to the LRA Crisis Tracker  an online mapping platform that makes understanding and stopping LRA violence possible through the power of information.

We recently met up with the team at Radio Rhino in DRC  one of our 11 partner radio stations who broadcast 'Come Home' messages to the LRA.   These men and women are some of the most dedicated to seeing peace in their community and we're so honored to support their incredible work.
And we're off!  The IC//DC team is headed back to central Africa to meet with our teams on the ground.   Stay tuned for more adventures!

A critical piece of what we do is install the Early Warning Network. These radios help protect remote communities from violence by alerting them to LRA attacks.   There are still thousands of people who don't have access to this important tool and face LRA violence alone. YOU CAN HELP expand the Early Warning Network to include more communities by DONATING TODAY.   Comment #donate + any dollar amount (ex. #donate $25) and we'll respond with a one-time form to confirm your donation.

Today the International Criminal Court confirmed charges against former deputy to Joseph Kony  Dominic Ongwen  for 70 counts of war crimes  including enslavement.   Read our CEO  Lisa Dougan's thoughts on what Ongwen's trial could mean for communities still affected by LRA violence.
It's not a day in the office without a fire drill.  The Culprit: Burned Popcorn

Just finished your taxes and trying to figure out what to do with that refund?   Consider putting some of it toward bringing more LRA abductees home to their families.

Have you met our BFF Paul? He's the Director of the Resolve LRA Crisis Initiative and taking you behind the scenes of life in LRA-affected areas.

LRA violence takes a huge toll on the people of central Africa. In addition  Kony funds his violence by ordering his fighters to kill endagered elephants for their ivory tusks.  Join us and our friends at The Enough Project in urging our Senators to support Anti-Wildlife Trafficking Legislation. Together  we can help put an end to wildlife poaching and ivory trafficking by Kony's LRA and other violent groups  which will also help stop their violence against communities.

Thank you so incredibly much to all who signed and shared on behalf of the manatees. The alert is now closed so we can submit your comments to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.  The federal government has proposed downlisting manatees from "endangered" to "threatened"  under the Endangered Species Act. Manatees face threats from boat collisions  die-offs and loss of warm water habitat. Please take action below to tell the USFWS that manatees need more protection  not less: https://secure.humanesociety.org/site/Advocacy?cmd=display&page=UserAction&id=7094&s_src=fb_post040616

This is Richard and his beloved dog Roxie. Richard wants the best care possible for her  but the nearest veterinarian is 15 miles from his house and he is blind. They needed our help. The Pets for Life program provided Roxie her vaccinations  exam  and even a nail trim. You can help support this lifesaving program by joining us on our Day of Giving: www.humanesociety.org/hsusdog

The Pets for Life program helps pets in under-served communities get the care they need. Their owners live in "vet deserts" where they have no access to basic care for their pets including spay/neuter  vaccinations  medication  and pet supplies.  Our Day of Giving on March 31 will benefit this lifesaving program for pets in need. Will you join us? www.humanesociety.org/hsusdog

This weekend we’ve been cleaning Arctic beaches. We found vast amounts of trash from massive bottom trawlers. It’s been heartbreaking witnessing such an amazing place covered in plastic and fishing nets. Together we must stop this by calling for care rather than greed.  We’re right now live from a Greenpeace ship in the Arctic  writing messages to Norway’s Minister of Environment. Join in by leaving your message in the comments and ask for the Arctic to be protected from harm.  Ps. Be sure to sign the petition to protect the Arctic → http://grnpc.org/protect__what_you__love

ICYMI  Alicia Keys took her No Makeup pledge to The BET Awards and looked gorgeous!  It’s the first major red carpet event the singer has attended since announcing via a powerful Lenny essay that she’s going "no makeup" because she no longer wants to cover up any aspect of herself.  “Not my face  not my mind  not my soul  not my thoughts  not my dreams  not my struggles  not my emotional growth. Nothing ” she wrote.  By age 13  about 53% of American girls are unhappy with their bodies. By 17  it's 78%. Posting encouraging notes in bathrooms (a place that can trigger low self-esteem) can improve someone's self-esteem.

To my white friends: This is not a time to be silent. Your actions  and specifically your voice  are critical. Your black friends need to know you hear them. Your black friends need to know you support them. Moments like these are when your silence is deafening. If you love your black friends  stand with us in solidarity. Check in on us — send us a text  call us  hug us. Remind us that our lives have value extending beyond the people who look like us. Take that confederate flag off your profile. If we are being attacked on Facebook or Twitter  step in  carry some of that weight and defend us. It is heavy. Use your own platforms to elevate the importance of black lives. Educate yourselves. March with us. Stop muting my #BlackLivesMatter statements with “all lives matter.” Enjoy our culture — but advocate for our safety.

Channing Tatum talked about the importance of consent and sex education  saying "rape culture is a very real thing."  "I think we need to use education and we have to be comfortable talking about [sex]. Look I’m uncomfortable talking about it and I’m saying we should be comfortable talking about it. But it is  it’s an awkward thing to talk about  it’s an awkward thing to talk about especially probably with your kids. So how do we do that better? How do we actually come up with a plan to be able to communicate about sex and what do we need from each other and what are the lines and how do you even know where the lines are if you’re not strong enough to say OK I’m not comfortable with this anymore… People want from both directions and the only way to get to what you want is communication."  Defining what consent is and isn’t lowers the acceptance of rape myths like “She was in my bed so that means it’s okay."

Some of Hollywood's biggest names joined the "Lean In" campaign  a "Together We Can" initiative launched on Thursday  promoting the act of women supporting other women.  The initiative strives to break the stereotype that women are rivals and not allies.  Women are more likely to be successful when they see that other women who look like them are successful. Promote the concept of diverse women in film by creating and sharing a new protagonist you'd like to see represented in Hollywood.

We are a global community with members from nearly every country  including Iraq.  As the death toll from the deadly attack in Baghdad continues to rise it's important that we remember our brothers and sisters in the country and all those affected by this senseless tragedy.  It's also important to remember that Muslims are the primary victims of these attacks  making up anywhere between 82 to 97 percent of terrorism-related fatalities over the past five years.

A baby orangutan is lucky to be alive after being abandoned in a West Borneo Island store last week. Didik was discovered with a bullet lodged in his shoulder. He was suffering from eye and fungal skin infections and was so hungry that he couldn't properly open his mouth to receive food.   It's believed Didik was wounded when hunters shot his mother dead so they could capture and sell him as a pet. Wildlife rangers risk their lives everyday to protect endangered species like orangutan  tigers  elephants and rhinos.  Show appreciation by sending thank you cards to rangers. This will motivate them to be productive in their jobs  which means they can help more animals!
Police violence is a complicated  and there's no magical fix  but there are things you CAN do to help end it.  Join Campaign Zero to help make a difference.

The Great Barrier Reef has been hit by the worst bleaching event with 22% of corals dead. With so much carbon in the atmosphere  ocean temperatures are warming up rapidly. And as the oceans warm up  mass bleaching events become more common.  This year has seen the worst mass bleaching in history  threatening many coral reefs around the world including the whole of the northern Great Barrier Reef.  About half of Americans aren't worried about global warming  despite climate scientists' warnings. It's time to take big steps to save our environment. Help raise awareness by creating a Climate Change Scavenger Hunt.
The Justice Department has announced they will be investigating the death of Alton Sterling.
Alton Sterling and his family. These are the images the media should be using.

Alton Sterling is the 558th person killed by the police in America in 2016.  Cellphone footage captured the incident after the police claimed their body cameras fell off during the encounter.  His son delivered this heartbreaking message to press earlier today.

We're SO excited to be teaming up with Colton Haynes and Johnson & Johnson!  Beyond everything they do to keep us safe  military service members make the additional sacrifice of spending long periods of time away from family and friends.  Taking the time to reach out and say “thank you” by making a card can have a huge impact in making them feel connected to home! It's time to make and mail your best cards.  Submit a photo of the cards you make  because we’re searching for 11 outstanding participants with Johnson & Johnson to be our Youth Champions of Care who will be honored at a U.S. Soccer match with Landon Donovan this fall!   Sign up for Smiles for Soldiers here: https://www.dosomething.org/us/campaigns/smiles-soldiers
Scary but true: deodorant use may be linked to diseases like cancer and Alzheimer's.

Campus rape is a national problem.  For many people  reading the Stanford University sexual assault victim's powerful letter to her assailant was an entry point into the complicated  unjust realities of reporting and punishing sexual assault. While the attention the case received is unusual  the attacks are not.  Around 1 in 5 women may experience sexual assault at college and at some of the schools  the rate of sexual assault is as high as 1 in 2.
Tanning in a bed just once a year increase your risk of melanoma by 20%. Six times increases the risk to 73%.

Stacey Kozel of Medina  Ohio is too determined to give up on her favor sport although she is paralyzed from the chest down. Her goal is to hike all 2 190 miles of the Appalachian Trail which covers an area from Maine to Georgia. And she is hiking all alone! She hopes to make it to the halfway mark by July 4.

Nine-year-old Tyler Fugett told his mom he wanted to give those behind bars at the Montgomery County Jail something to take their minds off their surroundings.  He decided to use his allowance to purchase more than 100 books to donate to the jail.  The child reasoned that “If they read  they don’t have time to think about doing bad things when they come out. Maybe they’ll find one thing in there that would make them click to be better people."

My parents and relatives came to this country in search of a better life for themselves and for their children. I stand here today as a UCSB student  Mexican  voter  Queer to show that my family exists  I exist  and my heritage exists even though there are forces suppressing it all.  In 2015 alone  anti-refugee and anti-immigration hate speech contributed to a 14% increase in the number of hate groups across the US.

Modern Family actress Ariel Winter recently posted a photo of her at her high school graduation party but received some body-shaming comments online. She responded with:  "Dear sorry body-shamers  I looked HOT in that dress. And if you hate it  don't buy it. But please get a hobby. XOXO Ariel #EmbraceYourBody."  Removing or defacing fat-shaming messages highlights social stigma around bodies that are not “ideal” and misconceptions that thin = healthy. "Fixing" these offensive headlines in visible places (like a waiting room) can redefine the "ideal" body type.

It's often presumed that millennials care more about gender equality than their parents' generation. But that presumption is questionable when it comes to millennial men  at least according to a recent PLoS One study. Millennial men specifically have been less accepting of female leaders than their older male counterparts.  A majority of millennial men failed to see women as equals  according to the study  which looked at how college biology students viewed their classmates’ intelligence and achievements.  Most guys think sexist comments aren't cool but don't speak up because they think they won't be supported by friends. Guys are more likely to shut down sexist comments when (a) they’re supported by people like you; and (b) they have a clear and easy tactic to use.

By ninth grade  more than half of the achievement gap between lower- and higher-income youth can be explained by unequal access to summer learning opportunities.  Keep your reading skills sharp this summer with us and the Dollar General Literacy Foundation! Play our Context Clues game right on your phone and solve a mystery by using your vocab and reading skills. You’ll unlock some pretty cool prizes.

Prince William invited Attitude to Kensington Palace  along with several members of the LGBT+ community  to discuss their experiences in dealing with bullying and the mental health consequences  such as low self-esteem  depression and drug addiction  that bullying can lead to.  “No one should be bullied for their sexuality or any other reason ” Prince William told Attitude  “and no one should have to put up with the kind of hate that these young people have endured in their lives.”  6 in 10 LGBT students report feeling unsafe at school because of their sexual orientation. Public support from social influencers can amplify your voice to promote even more positive interaction between your straight and LGBTQ peers.

ICYMI  when Jesse Williams  who stars on ABC's Grey's Anatomy  accepted the 2016 BET Humanitarian Award  he dedicated his award to organizers all over the country; activists  civil rights attorneys  struggling parents  teachers and students that are fighting systems that divide  impoverish and destroy some.  In his powerful excerpt  Williams remembered several victims of police brutality  called out celebrities and their responsibility to step up  and then talked about the delayed freedom for black Americans.  In 47 out of 50 states  American police officers have killed at least one person so far this year. Tell the Department of Justice to mandate police reporting nationally by sharing the story of a victim of police brutality from your state.

Campus rape is a national problem.  For many people  reading the Stanford University sexual assault victim's powerful letter to her assailant was an entry point into the complicated  unjust realities of reporting and punishing sexual assault. While the attention the case received is unusual  the attacks are not.  Around 1 in 5 women may experience sexual assault at college and at some of the schools  the rate of sexual assault is as high as 1 in 2.

An alarming number of California State students go hungry  and the University is trying to find ways to help.  An estimated 1-in-5 students at California State University  the largest four-year university system in the country  go hungry  and close to 1-in-10 border on homelessness  according to research by the school.  More and more people are relying on food banks and pantries. These programs need individual donations of food to supply meals. Everyone needs to take action about hunger.

Pat Summitt  the legendary former women's basketball coach who won eight national titles at the University of Tennessee  died Tuesday morning at age 64. She guided the team to 1 098 victories  the most in Division 1 college basketball history for men or women.  In sports today  female athletes are still totally underrepresented in the media compared to men  making up only 5% of sports TV coverage. Celebrate heroes like Pat Summitt  by sharing stories of incredible female athletes and to protest biased media coverage.

Recently women on Twitter had a message for men: #NoWomanEver has fallen in love with her catcaller  harasser or stalker.  Though women laid the sarcasm on thick in their accounts of harassment  the tweets expose how pervasive and invasive misogyny is to women's everyday lives.  70-90% of women experience street harassment at some point in their lives. Take back the places where you were harassed.
Use this guide to make and share thumb socks to prevent texting-and-driving! http://dsorg.us/1oNwFH0
Happy Social Media Day! Let's use social media for good by spreading positivity and promoting the nice things you and your friends do for each other.

Jazmin's answer to very white  male comic books: Making her own.  Jazmin Truesdale is a fan of superheroes. As a child  she pored over comic books -- even though  she noted  their heroes rarely reflected who she was. The racism and sexism in what she read threatened to turn her away from comics.  Truesdale took matters into her own hands and founded Aza Comics  a brand devoted to producing comics featuring female superheroes -- many of them women of color. When designing the heroines of Aza Comics  she didn't just create what she wanted to see -- she asked other women  too.  Women are more likely to be successful when they see that other women who look like them are successful. Join #ReelWomen to draw a new protagonist to expand the representation of women on screen and promote the concept of diverse women.

On Thursday  the governor of Hawaii signed into law a trio of bills aimed at better protecting island residents from gun violence. The new Act 108 authorizes county police departments to enroll gun owners into a federal criminal monitoring database  known as "Rap Back."  This makes Hawaii the first U.S. state to enroll gun owners in the FBI system. This will alert authorities when a Hawaii gun owner is arrested for a criminal offense anywhere in the country. This measure will allow Hawaii police to evaluate whether the firearm owner can continue to possess and own weapons.  Join the movement to end gun violence by promoting gun safety through tagging cars around with information on gun safety.

Demi Lovato has been vocal about her past struggles with addiction  bipolar disorder  and an eating disorder. In a new interview  she explained why she once thought they’d cut her life tragically short.  As her acting career took off and her star power grew  she started cutting herself  drinking heavily  and self-medicating with cocaine and OxyContin. “I lived fast and I was going to die young ” she said. “I didn’t think I would make it to 21.”  Lovato is happier and healthier now — she celebrated her fourth year of sobriety this past March  and she credits her dedicated fans for keeping her accountable.  Posting encouraging notes in public can improve someone's self-esteem. Help strangers who may be going through a hard time  by spreading positivity.
A Good Samaritan and a police officer sprung into action when someone tossed a kitten from the window of a moving car on the Walt Whitman Bridge last week.  Here's a photo of the saved kitten. <3
Our hearts go out to everyone affected by this terrible tragedy.

Animal rights groups are celebrating President Obama's signing a new chemical safety law that includes a groundbreaking condemnation of animal testing.  The updated law will accelerate the movement away from animal tests for chemicals  pesticides  biocides  cosmetics  and other dangerous substances. Over 100 million animals are burned  crippled  poisoned  and abused in US labs each year.  Join Kidnaped Cosmetics to help save some furry and non-furry friends by learning which brands practice animal testing and telling friends the products they should avoid.

Arresting  shooting and ticketing homeless people hasn't accomplished much in the way of ending homelessness  the Los Angeles Police Department has concluded. So  now they're trying an alternative and more gentle approach. Police will now treat homeless people with "compassion and empathy." New rules instruct officers to offer homeless people information about housing  medical or psychological services.  This is a better approach because surveyed runaway youth feel that one of the biggest barriers to getting help is a lack of knowledge about what services exist. 40% of the current homeless population are under the age of 18.  Help the officers by signing up for Flyer Away to post flyers with a helpful hotline number for homeless youth. The flyers have information on vital resource like counseling  shelter  and first aid.

This newlywed nurse saved a life right after her marriage by performing CPR.  She rushed over to the bench where there was a woman in her early 20s lying unconscious  dropped her flowers and purse  and began mouth-to-mouth resuscitation on the unconscious woman.  As she explained later  she forgot all about her wedding and social obligations for a moment and focused on saving the woman.

Channing Tatum talked about the importance of consent and sex education  saying "rape culture is a very real thing."  "I think we need to use education and we have to be comfortable talking about [sex]. Look I’m uncomfortable talking about it and I’m saying we should be comfortable talking about it. But it is  it’s an awkward thing to talk about  it’s an awkward thing to talk about especially probably with your kids. So how do we do that better? How do we actually come up with a plan to be able to communicate about sex and what do we need from each other and what are the lines and how do you even know where the lines are if you’re not strong enough to say OK I’m not comfortable with this anymore… People want from both directions and the only way to get to what you want is communication."  Defining what consent is and isn’t lowers the acceptance of rape myths like “She was in my bed so that means it’s okay."

My parents and relatives came to this country in search of a better life for themselves and for their children. I stand here today as a UCSB student  Mexican  voter  Queer to show that my family exists  I exist  and my heritage exists even though there are forces suppressing it all.  In 2015 alone  anti-refugee and anti-immigration hate speech contributed to a 14% increase in the number of hate groups across the US.

Alicia Keys took her No Makeup pledge to The BET Awards and looked gorgeous!  It’s the first major red carpet event the singer has attended since announcing via a powerful Lenny essay that she’s going "no makeup" because she no longer wants to cover up any aspect of herself.   “Not my face  not my mind  not my soul  not my thoughts  not my dreams  not my struggles  not my emotional growth. Nothing ” she wrote.  By age 13  about 53% of American girls are unhappy with their bodies. By 17  it's 78%. 100 underserved kids had a sleepover at Dallas Cowboys' Stadium over the weekend as part of an Ashley Furniture charity event in what's been deemed the "ultimate sleepover experience." Love this! Zara Nadeem and Zehra Hassan are trying to reduce food waste in Pakistan with their Food for Thought campaign.  The women distribute to-go packaging labeled with the words “Food for Thought” at restaurants throughout the city. The idea is that when a patron says they don’t want to pack up their leftovers  staff will pack it up for them in the Food for Thought containers. Staff will then suggest that the customer give the food to someone in need.

It's often presumed that millennials care more about gender equality than their parents' generation. But that presumption is questionable when it comes to millennial men  at least according to a recent PLoS One study. Millennial men specifically have been less accepting of female leaders than their older male counterparts.  A majority of millennial men failed to see women as equals  according to the study  which looked at how college biology students viewed their classmates’ intelligence and achievements.  Most guys think sexist comments aren't cool but don't speak up because they think they won't be supported by friends. Guys are more likely to shut down sexist comments when (a) they’re supported by people like you; and (b) they have a clear and easy tactic to use.

Modern Family actress Ariel Winter recently posted a photo of her at her high school graduation party but received some body-shaming comments online. She responded with:  "Dear sorry body-shamers  I looked HOT in that dress. And if you hate it  don't buy it. But please get a hobby. XOXO Ariel #EmbraceYourBody."  Removing or defacing fat-shaming messages highlights social stigma around bodies that are not “ideal” and misconceptions that thin = healthy. "Fixing" these offensive headlines in visible places (like a waiting room) can redefine the "ideal" body type.
For all of the parents.

Actress Chloë Grace Moretz Wanted a 'Boob Job and Butt Reduction' at Only 16.  It was her mother who prevented her from going under the knife.  "My mom said  'Absolutely not  you're not allowed to have plastic surgery ' " recalls Moretz.   In the end  she believes the experience made her more comfortable with who she is. "Because of that  I found a lot of power within my insecurities " said Moretz. "They're what make me who I am now."   50 to 70% of girls are dissatisfied with their body. Be a (role) model! Reduce body dissatisfaction by redefining ideals of beauty showcased in magazines.

WOW. LeBron James has pledged to give four-year scholarships to any child who completes his “I Promise” campaign. ICYMI  four skateboarders received special recognition after they stepped in when a man was sexually assaulting a woman  scared him off  chased him down  and held him until police arrested him. When they realized what was happening  they immediately moved to stop the attack.  "He was trying to walk out and walk away from us " said one of the skateboarders. "He pushed me aggressively out of the way  kinda like just gives me the smile  like  'I can do this. You can't do anything about it.'"  Bystanders to sexual assault often do nothing because they're unsure how to step in or think someone else will. Use our guide to learn about easy ways to step in.

80-Year-Old couple Joe and Kay finish their last marathon together hand in hand. Not only did they finish together  but they won with the fastest times – 5:25:29 – for their age groups. This week  Muslim refugees starting new lives in Calgary  Canada  got a taste of the community spirit when they attended an interfaith iftar -- an evening meal to break fast -- hosted by the Rockyview Alliance Church.  Muslim and Christian volunteers came together in the kitchen to prepare Arab-inspired cuisine. Sixty people  including the Rockyview Alliance Church congregation  Muslim refugees  and volunteers from the community attended the iftar. 1 500 of the 25 000 refugees Canada welcomed between November 2015 and February 2016 resettled in Calgary. They are now seeking meaningful integration into the local community.  So much hate speech lives online in posts and comments about refugees and immigrants but most of us have immigrants in our family  friend  and community networks. Sign up for Pride over Prejudice to post a selfie online with where your family is "from." It's a positive way of showing solidarity with those facing increasing levels of discrimination.

As she gets older  Salma Hayek admits she has more hang-ups about her body  but gives some great advice.  "I think it depends on the day  for everybody " she says. "There's some days you say  'This is it ' and you love it. Then there are days when you go  'This cannot be it! Is this really it?'"  "You have to get up and become your own work of art; from the moment you put yourself together " she says. "Not that I do it! I am quite lazy in the queen department. But celebrate who you are and celebrate life  and know that this is your experience."  50 to 70% of girls are dissatisfied with their body. Be a (role) model! Reduce body dissatisfaction by redefining ideals of beauty showcased in magazines.

When Scott Dunn recently awoke from the medically-induced coma he'd been in after getting into a car accident  he was heartbroken after realizing he'd missed his high school graduation. Milla Bizzotto  a 9-year-old Miami girl is so fit that she completed the 24-hour U.S Navy obstacle race meant for very fit adults and includes running 36 miles  swimming an 8-kilometer course  and 25 obstacles  for six laps. Not only that  she's using her platform to inspire her generation to love their bodies and to be as active as they can be.  Milla  who was bullied in school  says she decided to run the race with her dad to encourage her peers to be kinder to each other and to get active.  Almost 1 in 4 students reports being bullied at school. Sharing real-life tips on combating instances of bullying can enable people who are currently being bullied to get out of a difficult situation.

ICYMI  Maisie Williams doesn’t just play a badass on Game of Thrones; she's just as badass in real life and stands up for what she believes in.  Recently  there was a news headline about Williams that read  "Unveiled: Game of Thrones' Maisie Williams goes braless in sheer lace dress and quirky headpiece at charity masquerade ball."  Maisie responded with a tweet saying  "Alternative: Game of Thrones actor  Maisie Williams  helps raise thousands at a Summer Masquerade Ball for NSPCC"  We love that she called out this sexist  objectifying headline. People who see sexually objectifying images of women are significantly more accepting of sexual harassment.  Reworking an ad to point out its sexist nature can help counteract the messages advertisers are trying to convey.

Beautiful piece. We must not erase who the targets of these attacks were.  "But here's the thing: terrorism toward LGBT people is a redundancy.   The FBI defines terrorism as "violent acts or acts dangerous to human life…that appear to be intended to intimidate or coerce a civilian population." LGBT people around the world have been intimidated and coerced all our lives. Each one of us has moved to kiss our boyfriend on the cheek in public  or reached for our wife's hand as we walked down the street  and each one of us has pulled back."

ICYMI  four skateboarders received special recognition after they stepped in when a man was sexually assaulting a woman  scared him off  chased him down  and held him until police arrested him.  When they realized what was happening  they immediately moved to stop the attack.  "He was trying to walk out and walk away from us " said one of the skateboarders. "He pushed me aggressively out of the way  kinda like just gives me the smile  like  'I can do this. You can't do anything about it.'"  Bystanders to sexual assault often do nothing because they're unsure how to step in or think someone else will. Use our guide to learn about easy ways to step in.

ICYMI  Maisie Williams doesn’t just play a badass on Game of Thrones; she's just as badass in real life and stands up for what she believes in.  Recently  there was a news headline about Williams that read  "Unveiled: Game of Thrones' Maisie Williams goes braless in sheer lace dress and quirky headpiece at charity masquerade ball."  Maisie responded with a tweet saying  "Alternative: Game of Thrones actor  Maisie Williams  helps raise thousands at a Summer Masquerade Ball for @NSPCC"  We love that she called out this sexist  objectifying headline. People who see sexually objectifying images of women are significantly more accepting of sexual harassment.  Reworking an ad to point out its sexist nature can help counteract the messages advertisers are trying to convey.
