Giving homeless people homes in San Fransisco saved the city 56% in costs over four years.  A new study  like a number before it  concluded that when homeless people are given housing  taxpayers save money.  Initially  costs spent on homeless services  such as medical care and public benefits  significantly increased  but that was mostly due to their deteriorating health and the fact that they hadn't sought out care in recent years. Once they settled into their housing and programming  those expenses declined by $31.5 million  or 56%  from 2011 to 2015.  2.5 million U.S. youth experience homelessness every year. Many kids' birthdays fall while they are in a shelter  making it hard to celebrate. You can do something small to make a big impact. Sign up for Birthday Mail to find out how to make birthday cards for your local shelter.
Say hello to our brand new Summer Interns! We're super excited to see all that you will do in the next 10 weeks.

Dan White  decided to channel his thoughts about his daughter's condition into something meaningful: a work of art. That work  a comic called "The Department of Ability " which tells the story of a wheelchair-bound superhero whose powers came from her disability.  White said the the idea was inspired by a "lack of good fun and positive visibility" about disabled children in mainstream television.  We love what White created! ICYMI  Kristen Bell opened up more about her depression to Motto  saying  "there's nothing weak about struggling with mental illness."  "Here’s the thing: For me  depression is not sadness. It’s not having a bad day and needing a hug. It gave me a complete and utter sense of isolation and loneliness. Its debilitation was all-consuming  and it shut down my mental circuit board. I felt worthless  like I had nothing to offer  like I was a failure. Now  after seeking help  I can see that those thoughts  of course  couldn’t have been more wrong. It’s important for me to be candid about this so people in a similar situation can realize that they are not worthless and that they do have something to offer. We all do."

Love this photo of triplets with their garbage men BFFs.  They spend about 10-15 minutes together twice a week  high-fiving  fist-bumping  and catching up on the latest going on in the workers’ lives.

From 2011 to 2014  the National Law Center on Homelessness & Poverty found that bans on sleeping in cars shot up 119%  citywide camping prohibitions jumped 60%  anti-loitering laws increased 35% and anti-begging laws increased 25% in a survey of 187 cities.  Studies show that laws that punish the homeless for being homeless actually keep people locked into a cycle of poverty  having the opposite effect lawmakers typically intend.  Help people experiencing homelessness by hanging flyers with a hotline number in key places to help them find vital resources like counseling  shelter  and first aid.

ICYMI  Kristen Bell spoke openly about her experience with anxiety and depression and the stigma that surrounds it. "I shatter a little bit when I think people don't like me...it really hurts my feelings when I know I'm not liked. And I know that's not very healthy  and I fight it all the time."  She talked about how her mom told her  “the world wants to shame you” for taking medication to help herself  but that it was important for her to remember that in the medical community  no one would “deny a diabetic his insulin.”  Due to stigma  college underclassmen are often reluctant to seek help at their school’s counseling center. Let's take action and decrease the stigma.

Dear Young Man   Maybe if this goes far and wide enough you’ll see it  I hope that’s the case.  Awhile back as I was walking out of Target I saw you taking a picture of my van parked in a disabled parking spot. You took off when you saw me coming  I wish you hadn’t  I wish you would have stayed so I could explain.  Yes  my van has running stickers on it  and yes  it’s an ironic picture  seeing my 13.1 and 25k stickers on a vehicle in a disabled spot  I get why you took the picture.  The playful side of me actually hopes you and your friends got a few laughs out of the picture.  But I hope you noticed my child when we exited the store. He was sitting in the cart even though he’s far too big. That’s because my child is the person the placard is for.  My guess is that the possibility hadn’t even occurred to you.  And that’s why I’m writing this.  My son is permanently disabled. He can walk  but not for any distance  and he has many health problems that sometimes prevent walking much at all.  And we aren’t alone or unusual. Maybe my perspective is slanted too because I have dozens of friends whose children have disabilities  and because of how I often struggle to find an open handicapped spot at the children’s hospitals we frequent. I  simply want you to understand that children can be disabled and get a parking placard too.  And just for the record  I don’t use it unless my son is with me.  I wish we could have chatted for a minute  because I think we would have had a good conversation  and I probably would have broadened my perspective by listening to you as well.  Although to be honest my son was in meltdown mode and we probably wouldn’t have been able to make much of the opportunity anyway. So if you happen to see this on the interweb  drop me a note. I’d like to hear from you. -Alethea  writer of: https://benswritingrunningmom.wordpress.com/

Officer Tim Purdy was dispatched to a situation involving a young autistic high school student who left the campus and may have been suicidal.  Due to the young man’s neuro-developmental disorder  he also had a history of displaying violent behavior.  In order to build a connection with the young man  Officer Purdy sat next to him on the ground  talked things through and even got him laughing.  Officer Purdy established trust and a relationship that allowed officers to get this young man the help that he so desperately needed.  There’s more to policing than making arrests and enforcing the law. Sometimes taking those extra little steps makes the biggest difference in someone’s life.  LIKE and SHARE so this story is heard.  Photo and Story Credit: Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Department

Seven-week-old Daisy was found abandoned and crying in a parking lot in Savannah  Ga. She had no tags  collar or microchip  so the president of The Savannah Bananas baseball team adopted her. After she was deemed healthy by a local vet  Daisy became the team's new bat-dog. :)

Meet Haus  a German Shepherd who saved a 7-year-old girl from a venomous rattlesnake and was bitten three times in the process.  Hundreds of donors came to the rescue for Haus  quickly topping the goal of $15 000 Friday on a GoFundMe account to help pay for the antivenin needed to keep the dog alive. By Friday afternoon  $35 000 had been raised for the Haus' care. Way to go  Haus. :)

The Roti Bank in Aurangabad  India is doing something very inspiring. "The idea behind the bank is to ask people from well-to-do families to spare food cooked at their home " Yusuf Mukati  the project's founder  told the news outlet. "The poor  unemployed and old can withdraw it respectfully  without begging."  Unfun fact: 35 MILLION tons of food are thrown away each year.  You can help  instead of being thrown out  leftover food can be donated through food recovery programs to shelters serving those in need.

A new global report from the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew  in the United Kingdom has found that there are now 391 000 known plant species.  Unfortunately as many as one in five plants may be at risk of extinction  the scientists say  due to invasive species  disease and changing landscapes.  Plants are important! People who live in urban areas with more green space tend to report greater well-being than city dwellers who don't.
Spread kindness: http://dsorg.us/1TL8gwk

Senior Jared Springer was not allowed to attend his prom in Arroyo Grande  California because of medical absences after being diagnosed with a brain tumor in 2014.  The district issued an apology to Springer and his family on Thursday  but it came after he was barred from entering.  Springer didn't get to attend his dream prom  but you can still help make prom more accessible for others. Prom is expensive  typically Americans spend $919 on each. ICYMI  Kristen Bell spoke openly about her experience with anxiety and depression and the stigma that surrounds it. "I shatter a little bit when I think people don't like me...it really hurts my feelings when I know I'm not liked. And I know that's not very healthy  and I fight it all the time."  She talked about how her mom told her  “the world wants to shame you” for taking medication to help herself  but that it was important for her to remember that in the medical community  no one would “deny a diabetic his insulin.”  Due to stigma  college underclassmen are often reluctant to seek help at their school’s counseling center. Let's take action and decrease the stigma.

After Target announced their support of transgender people using the restroom of their choice the American Family Association  a notoriously anti-LGBT organization  has begun boycotting Target claiming that children will be traumatized by trans individuals in the restrooms. In reality it's the opposite  70% of transgender and gender nonconforming people experience some form of harassment in restrooms.  Take action. Post new signs over gendered restrooms at your local school  library or community center to demand inclusive options for trans people.

Our friends at Mic sat down with Vice President Joe Biden to talk about sexual assault on campus.  Here are the facts  they're not pretty: "Sexual assault is nothing short of a national epidemic. According to a 2015 survey commissioned by the Association of American Universities  at least 1 in 4 female college seniors experience nonconsensual sexual touching  assault  or violence during college. Two-thirds of college students say they have been sexually harassed. These numbers are even more staggering when one considers that according to the Department of Justice  80% of campus sexual assaults go unreported (the American Civil Liberties Union has it at 95%)."

Did you know that students with disabilities are 2 to 3 times more likely to be bullied than their nondisabled peers?  We teamed up with Nyle DiMarco to help fight the stigma that surrounds people with disabilities. You can help  an easy way to start is to give those with and without a disability a chance to talk about their abilities!  Join Nyle and start a #WeAreAble challenge chain! Use our template to post a pic highlighting your own ability on Instagram and challenge 3 friends to post their own.

Simply put  we're sick of being treated like second-class citizens. It wears on you after a while. And we are done with it  Carli Lloyd  member of the 2015 World Cup winning team  wrote in an essay published in the New York Times.  Lloyd and four other members of the U.S. Women's Soccer team filed a wage-discrimination complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission seeking equal pay in late March.  Today is #EqualPayDay  but female players are paid as little as 40 percent of what a male player could make. Take action and protest these biases.

Targeted harassment of women online is all too common. One woman has decided to create a Wikipedia page for a woman scientist every time it happens to her.  Emily Temple-Wood was not even a teenager when she started editing and writing on Wikipedia. A few months later  she received her first harassing messages.  "I think before they realised I was 12  they just realised I was a woman " says Temple-Wood  now a 21-year-old science student. Temple-Wood has stuck around on Wikipedia and became an administrator and developing two collaborative projects aimed at closing the online encyclopedia's "content gap" - including one that adds and improves articles about women scientists.  91% of Wikipedia's editors are male. The more women who contribute to Wikipedia pages  the smaller the gender gap will become. Let's go  girls!  If you identify as female  host a "Girls-Only Edit-a-Thon." themed party. Fight the gender gap by editing and creating female-focused Wikipedia pages together.

70%-99% of women experience street harassment at some point in their lives.  Storytelling allows women to reclaim some power that’s lost when they’re harassed. Reading these stories is also a powerful unifying tool for others who have been harassed.  Sign up for facts on street harassment and tips on how to reclaim locations where it happens.

Kat McNamara and her dog Sophie want you to know about the harmful effects secondhand smoke has on pets. That’s why we’ve teamed up with her and truth  and we need your help! We’re in search of #4LeggedFinishers to help us be the generation to finish smoking for good. These women are part of Congo's growing team of wildlife rangers  who regularly put their safety at risk to protect the endangered mountain gorillas and their habitat from poachers and violence between militias and the Congolese army. In the past 20 years  more than 150 park rangers have lost their lives on the job.  The first group of women to successfully complete the mandatory training became rangers in 2014  and now proudly serve to protect the 3 000 square-mile park and its furry inhabitants.  Wildlife rangers risk their lives to protect endangered species like tigers  elephants and rhinos.  Sending thank you cards to rangers can make them more productive in their jobs  which means they can help more animals.

The revenue the US Women's Soccer team is estimated to bring in this year? $17.6 million. Over the same period  the men’s team is expected to bring only in $9 million. Recess can sometimes be isolating for a kid who doesn't fit into a clique  so this group of students took it into their hands to foster more playground positivity.  A buddy bench is a place where kids can sit if they're feeling lonely or too shy to ask their classmates if they can join in. If another student sees someone on the bench  they're supposed to approach them and ask them to join their group.  Almost 1 in 4 students reports being bullied at school. Create your own safe space like a buddy bench and spread the positivity.

Georgia governor Nathan Deal vetoed a bill yesterday that would shield gay marriage opponents. Dorothy Louise Liggett was expelled from high school just weeks before graduation after it was discovered she was married. About 7.6 MILLION pets enter animal shelters every year  needing specific supplies to stay happy and healthy.

Each year  about 2.7 million animals are killed in shelters because they do not get adopted.  Have you adopted a shelter dog? Bust myths about shelter pets by telling the world your healthy and adorable pet came from a shelter.

Every year  MILLIONS of people find themselves without a home and access to basic items.  Make Blessing Bags by collecting important day-to-day items. Then deliver them to your local homeless shelter.

At least 20.9 MILLION people are bought and sold worldwide due to human trafficking.  About 80% of these victims are sex trafficked. Providing them local hotline numbers can be the first step to break the cycle of sex trafficking.

Globally  depression is the top cause of illness and disability during adolescence.  Social connection decreases feelings of isolation  reduces stress  and prevents suicide in people with depression.  Print out an IOU activity book (or make your own!) filled with fun things to do and give it to a friend who has been feeling down. Friendship for the win!
There are a ton of simple  proven ways to cope with anxiety and stress  and we've compiled the best ones for you and your friends.

Most of the produce in the grocery store wouldn't be available if honey bees and other pollinators became extinct.  Create and plant bumble bands  which are strips of paper with seeds for bee-friendly plants glued to them.  Bee-friendly plants can provide pollen and nectar to help counteract habitat loss due to farming practices  sprawling lawns without flowers and destruction of landscapes.

Over 40% of young people say they don't verbally express enthusiastic consent before or during sex.  Educate your peers about sexual assault prevention by showing them that asking for consent doesn't have to be hella awkward. Bow chicka wow wow.

Almost 1 in 4 students reports being bullied at school.  Safe Spaces are specific areas where bullying isn't tolerated. Once someone is in a Safe Space  they have the right to feel supported and protected from any bullying they're experiencing.  Sign up for tips on how to make spaces safe in your school. You'll also get to see flags that other members have made  to help spark your creativity!

Children living in homeless shelters experience higher levels of stress than children with homes.  Believe it or not  make-believe play can reduce stress among young children. Donate homemade Superhero Kits to children experiencing homelessness. Sign up for a free template for a kit and info on how to contact your local homeless shelter.

70%-99% of women experience street harassment at some point in their lives.  Storytelling allows women to reclaim some power that’s lost when they’re harassed. Reading these stories is also a powerful unifying tool for others who have been harassed.  Sign up for facts on street harassment and tips on how to reclaim locations where it happens.

Many college-aged people are prone to contracting HIV — especially because many don't even get tested. A 2012 study showed that only two in five college students had ever been tested for HIV  and that men were less likely than women to be tested.  Teens are strongly influenced by their peers. For many  everything they know about sex and HIV is based on info from friends. Sign up for facts on sexual health and tips on next steps if you  or someone you know  tests positive.

Tobacco companies target young people in rural areas to get them to spend their money on dipping tobacco.  An effective way to stop people from buying dip is showing them what other things they could have bought.

Last year  the total number of sheltered and unsheltered homeless people in New York City was 75 323  which included 1 706 people between ages 18 and 24. The actual number of young people is significantly higher  according to the service providers  who said the census mostly captured young people who received social services.  In the US  about 300 000 to 400 000 young people are homeless on any given day. Hang flyers with a hotline number in key places to help them find vital resources like counseling  shelter  and first aid.

In 1957  nine teenagers known as the Little Rock Nine were the first black students to integrate a US school. Their sacrifices sparked enormous progress  but American schools still struggle with segregation today.  Learn about these nine brave students and what they overcame in order to make America's schools safer and more diverse for future generations.
Low self-esteem is related to self-injury  negative body image  and depression.  Boost someone’s self-esteem just by posting a positive or inspirational message.

1 in 5 young women are sexually assaulted in college. 1 in 6 young men are sexually assaulted by age 18.  Sexual assault support services help survivors start the healing process.  Get your campus involved in providing resources and messages of support for survivors in your college community.

These women are part of Congo's growing team of wildlife rangers  who regularly put their safety at risk to protect the endangered mountain gorillas and their habitat from poachers and violence between militias and the Congolese army. In the past 20 years  more than 150 park rangers have lost their lives on the job.  The first group of women to successfully complete the mandatory training became rangers in 2014  and now proudly serve to protect the 3 000 square-mile park and its furry inhabitants.  Wildlife rangers risk their lives to protect endangered species like tigers  elephants and rhinos.  Sending thank you cards to rangers can make them more productive in their jobs  which means they can help more animals.

We are always receptive to the feedback we get from your comments  we've built a community we really appreciate.  Something rightfully pointed out this morning by a fan of the page is that there were a lot of other attacks this month alone (Ankara  Peshawar  Maiduguri and Istanbul) and they hadn't seen the same kind of reaction from the media  let alone from us  to respond to them.  Our friends at Mic wrote this article about some of the other attacks that have happened this month. It's worth a read and some self-reflection on what we choose to mourn and what we choose to ignore. This isn't a competition  but we want to make sure that all stories are told  not just some.  We are a global organization with members in many countries  our heart goes out to all of them and we want to make sure they know that.  <3

Americans now use 127% more water than in 1950  and about 95% of the water entering our homes goes down the drain. Changing our habits to use water more efficiently reduces water consumption in the home.

Scary but true: deodorant use may be linked to diseases like cancer and Alzheimer's.  By making your own deodorant with all-natural ingredients  you can protect friends from chemicals in mass-produced deodorant. Sign up for facts on deodorant health and tips on making DIY deodorant.
Often  the only time victims are alone is in the bathroom. Turn that into a potentially life-saving opportunity by posting hotline info.

Thanks to the generous help of a group of firefighters  this dog and her puppy were given another chance at life.  The firefighters brought both animals back to the fire station. Then they called DFW Rescue Me  a local animal shelter  and made sure the dogs got the proper care they needed. They are expected to make a full recovery.  It can be easy to forget the great work that firefighters do in order to keep us safe (Over 1.1 million US firefighters keep our communities safe by putting themselves in dangerous situations). We have an easy and simple gesture you can do to say thanks to the firefighters in your community: dosomething.org/campaigns/fight-fire-cookies

Most guys think sexist comments aren't cool but don't speak up because they think they won't be supported by friends.  Guys are more likely to shut down sexist comments when (a) they’re supported by people like you; and (b) they have a clear and easy tactic to use.

Americans throw away 35 billion plastic water bottles a year. Right  that's "billion" with a B.  Don't hit it and quit it. Switching to a reusable bottle reduces the amount of plastic that ends up in landfills or as litter.

75% of teenagers would not receive a passing grade if tested on facts about climate change.  Research shows that most Americans do not feel a personal connection to climate change.  Pointing out how climate change can negatively affect the natural places your friends care about will give them a personal connection to the problem.
Horrific news out of Brussels today. Our thoughts are with everyone there and anyone affected by today's tragedy. 🇧🇪
Bystanders to sexual assault often do nothing because they're unsure how to step in or think someone else will.

Study-abroad students who don’t speak the native language are 3-5x more likely to be sexually assaulted overseas.  Your friends are more likely to remember tips when they're personalized by you. Keep friends safe while they're studying abroad by decorating jars filled with local numbers and addresses  vital translated phrases  and fun ideas for their bucket list!

Almost 3/4 of LGBT students with few or no supportive staff feel unsafe attending school.  The more supportive and LGBT-aware staff present in school  the more safe LGBT students feel.  This leads to lower dropout rates  higher chance of applying to college  and even lower suicide rates. Use our tips to make cards for teachers that encourage them to make their classrooms LGBT-inclusive!

Every year  MILLIONS of people find themselves without a home and access to basic items.  Make Blessing Bags by collecting important day-to-day items. Then deliver them to your local homeless shelter.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture’s tests have found widespread pesticide contamination on popular produce.  You can encourage shoppers to lower their pesticide intake by buying the 12 most contaminated produce (also known as "the dirty dozen") organic.  Sign up for facts about organic fruits and vegetables and learn when to buy organic. You'll also get tips for talking to others about why pesticides are harmful.

Every day  96 African elephants are killed by ivory poachers. If this continues  they could be extinct by 2025.  Craigslist has a policy prohibiting ivory  but it doesn't actively enforce it. Find and flag ivory products on the site to show them what a problem this is.  Get facts about ivory poaching and tips on protecting elephants.
There are a surprising number of ways to improperly use a condom. Seems easy  but people mess it up all the time.
The average American produces 4.6 pounds of trash every day. Turning a green choice into a status symbol had been proven to motivate people to make more eco-friendly choices.
There are a ton of simple  proven ways to cope with anxiety and stress  and we've compiled the best ones for you and your friends.

An annual event at Emerson College in Hollywood awarded prom dresses to more than 80 LAUSD girls who are maintaining their grades despite experiencing difficult circumstances including homelessness  according to the school district.  "Prom Day makes selecting a dress and accessories for prom possible  and is a special day for these young women  who are encouraged by the gift of improved self-esteem to graduate with confidence " a news release from the Los Angeles Unified School District stated.  In 2014  the average cost of going to prom for an American teen was $978.  Prom is a special night everyone should get to enjoy. Collect prom dresses and reduce the cost of prom so everyone has a chance to go.

85% of DoSomething.org members don’t feel like the voice of young people is represented well in national conversations about gun violence. Multiple studies have shown that over 70% of college students don’t want concealed carry on campus and that it wouldn’t make them feel more safe. There’s no research that proves that guns make campuses safer.  Make your voice be heard. Sign up for Guns Out and we’ll give you customized information based on where you live  and step-by-step tips to most effectively take a stand against gun violence.

70% of people with blood cancer rely on a complete stranger for a lifesaving bone marrow donation. Donations from people ages 18 to 44 lead to more successful transplants.  Swab your cheek to join the bone marrow registry. If you’re a match for someone in need  you could save a cancer patient's life.

At least 20.9 MILLION people are bought and sold worldwide due to human trafficking.  About 80% of these victims are sex trafficked. Providing them local hotline numbers can be the first step to break the cycle of sex trafficking.

A lot of our best teachers quit because they feel overworked and underappreciated.  You have the power to keep awesome teachers in the classroom. When students like you show gratitude  teachers are happier and even better at their job.

In India last May  temperatures rose to 120°F (50°C)  killing more than 2 300 people and melting this street in New Delhi.  About half of Americans aren’t worried about global warming  despite climate scientists' warnings about it. Research shows that most people do not feel a personal connection to climate change.  We'll give you a long list we put together on how climate change can affect your favorite things such as foods and your hobbies.

Each year  about 2.7 million animals are killed in shelters because they do not get adopted.  Have you adopted a shelter dog? Bust myths about shelter pets by telling the world your healthy and adorable pet came from a shelter.

It is estimated that more than 115 MILLION animals worldwide are used in laboratory experiments every year.  Learning which brands practice animal testing enables you to tell friends the products they should avoid. Most people just don't know which brands test on animals.

Petting and playing with dogs decreases stress levels in your brain.  Kathryn Oda wrote on Huffington Post about her experience of how her dog has helped her. "A dog motivates you to get out the door for fresh air and exercise  even when it's the last thing you feel like doing. A dog brings you so much laughter and joy  unlike anything I've experienced before  with their unique personalities and hilarious quirks. And lastly  a dog brings you unconditional love  the kind of love that never stops. With these three things in your life  anxiety and depression can be part of your past as it has become a part of mine."  Exam time is super stressful  and stress actually hurts your academic performance. Ask local people to bring their furry friends to campus during exams. Finals time is rough...so make it ruff!

Earlier this week  Prince William got 40 transport companies to sign a declaration that sets the wheels in motion for a plan to stop wildlife trafficking. “This crisis can be stopped. We know where the animals are that we need to protect.”

Paint  motor oil  litter  and anything poured down storm drains washes into and pollutes lakes and oceans.  Turn storm drains into badass street art that promote clean water! That'll teach neighbors how things we dispose of affect our waterways.

In 2012  32% of alcohol-impaired drivers were between 21 and 24. That’s the highest percentage of any age group.  Good news is  when someone tells a friend not to drink and drive  they’re successful 81% of the time. That’s HUGE.

Over 6 MILLION children are hospitalized each year  which can lead to depression because they find the hospital scary.  Games and other activities can be a great distraction for kids in hospitals. Use our free templates to create your own activity book to brighten their stay!

People who see sexually objectifying images of women are significantly more accepting of sexual harassment.  Reworking an ad to point out its sexist nature can help counteract the messages advertisers are trying to convey.  "Fixing" these objectifying ads in visible places (like a waiting room) can disrupt the cycle of consumption.

Targeted harassment of women online is all too common. One woman has decided to create a Wikipedia page for a woman scientist every time it happens to her.  Emily Temple-Wood was not even a teenager when she started editing and writing on Wikipedia. A few months later  she received her first harassing messages.  "I think before they realised I was 12  they just realised I was a woman " says Temple-Wood  now a 21-year-old science student. Temple-Wood has stuck around on Wikipedia and became an administrator and developing two collaborative projects aimed at closing the online encyclopedia's "content gap" - including one that adds and improves articles about women scientists.  91% of Wikipedia's editors are male. The more women who contribute to Wikipedia pages  the smaller the gender gap will become. Let's go  girls!  If you identify as female  host a "Girls-Only Edit-a-Thon." themed party. Fight the gender gap by editing and creating female-focused Wikipedia pages together.

Then they called DFW Rescue Me  a local animal shelter  and made sure the dogs got the proper care they needed. They are expected to make a full recovery.  It can be easy to forget the great work that firefighters do in order to keep us safe (Over 1.1 million US firefighters keep our communities safe by putting themselves in dangerous situations). We have an easy and simple gesture you can do to say thanks to the firefighters in your community: dosomething.org/campaigns/fight-fire-cookies

People who don't identify with being male or female are harassed at a much higher rate than those who do. Acknowledging the harassment that transgender and gender nonconforming people experience is the first step in reducing this discrimination.  Sign up for facts on gender and binary pronouns. You'll also get stickers to hand out to friends to challenge them to not use binary pronouns for a day.

Almost ¾ of LGBT students with few or no supportive staff feel unsafe attending school.The more supportive and LGBT-aware staff present in school  the more safe LGBT students feel.  This leads to lower dropout rates  higher chance of applying to college  and even lower suicide rates. Use our tips below to make cards for teachers that encourage them to make their classrooms LGBT-inclusive!

The U.S. Department of Agriculture’s tests have found widespread pesticide contamination on popular produce.  You can encourage shoppers to lower their pesticide intake by buying the 12 most contaminated produce (also known as "the dirty dozen") organic.  Sign up for facts about organic fruits and vegetables and learn when to buy organic. You'll also get tips for talking to others about why pesticides are harmful.

A lot of our best teachers quit because they feel overworked and underappreciated.  You have the power to keep awesome teachers in the classroom. When students like you show gratitude  teachers are happier and even better at their job.
Low self-esteem is related to self-injury  negative body image  and depression.  Boost someone’s self-esteem just by posting a positive or inspirational message.

At least 20.9 MILLION people are bought and sold worldwide due to human trafficking.  About 80% of these victims are sex trafficked. Providing them local hotline numbers can be the first step to break the cycle of sex trafficking.

75% of teenagers would not receive a passing grade if tested on facts about climate change.  Research shows that most Americans do not feel a personal connection to climate change.  Pointing out how climate change can negatively affect the natural places your friends care about will give them a personal connection to the problem.

In 2012  32% of alcohol-impaired drivers were between 21 and 24. That’s the highest percentage of any age group.  Good news is  when someone tells a friend not to drink and drive  they’re successful 81% of the time. That’s HUGE.

Every day  96 African elephants are killed by ivory poachers. If this continues  they could be extinct by 2025.  Craigslist has a policy prohibiting ivory  but it doesn't actively enforce it. Find and flag ivory products on the site to show them what a problem this is.

Paint  motor oil  litter  and anything poured down storm drains washes into and pollutes lakes and oceans.  Turn storm drains into badass street art that promote clean water! That'll teach neighbors how things we dispose of affect our waterways.
Often  the only time victims are alone is in the bathroom. Turn that into a potentially life-saving opportunity by posting hotline info.

Americans use more than a TRILLION gallons of water for showering each year. That's enough to supply all the water needs of New Jersey and the Empire State.  By reducing shower time to five minutes  the average person can save more than 1 500 gallons of water a year.

Tobacco companies target young people in rural areas to get them to spend their money on dipping tobacco.  An effective way to stop people from buying dip is showing them what other things they could have bought.

Every year  MILLIONS of people find themselves without a home and access to basic items.  Make Blessing Bags by collecting important day-to-day items. Then deliver them to your local homeless shelter.

Bystanders to sexual assault often do nothing because they're unsure how to step in or think someone else will.  There are a ton of super easy ways to step in before drunken partying crosses the line into sexual assault.

In India last May  temperatures rose to 120°F (50°C)  killing more than 2 300 people and melting this street in New Delhi.  About half of Americans aren’t worried about global warming  despite climate scientists' warnings about it. Research shows that most people do not feel a personal connection to climate change.  We'll give you a long list we put together on how climate change can affect your favorite things such as foods and your hobbies.
There are a ton of simple  proven ways to cope with anxiety and stress  and we've compiled the best ones for you and your friends.

Over 6 MILLION children are hospitalized each year  which can lead to depression because they find the hospital scary.  Games and other activities can be a great distraction for kids in hospitals. Use our free templates to create your own activity book to brighten their stay!

Chew toys make dogs more playful  which increases their chances of being adopted. Dogs just wanna have fun!  Make DIY doggie toys for shelters! That'll save the shelters money and encourage potential adopters to give those pups a new home.
There are a surprising number of ways to improperly use a condom. Seems easy  but people mess it up all the time.

Each year  about 2.7 million animals are killed in shelters because they do not get adopted.  Have you adopted a shelter dog? Bust myths about shelter pets by telling the world your healthy and adorable pet came from a shelter.

Spending time with and learning from seniors benefits their mental health and reduces ageism.  Celebrate the older adults in your life with the ultimate #TBT. Find an old photo of them doing something badass and help them recreate the moment.
First aid items are regularly needed by homeless shelters but rarely donated.  Providing shelters with in-kind donations means their operating dollars can go directly to running the shelter.

Many college students don't know what consent is and therefore don't ask for it. In fact  over 40% of young people say they don't verbally express enthusiastic consent before or during sex.  Defining what consent is and isn’t lowers the acceptance of rape myths like “She was in my bed so that means it’s okay."

Many people don't seek mental health treatment because they're afraid of how it will make them look to friends.  Increased understanding and support from others can lead people to better self care.  Create a Support Board so your classmates can leave anonymous messages of encouragement for friends and peers experiencing mental illness.

It is estimated that more than 115 MILLION animals worldwide are used in laboratory experiments every year.  Learning which brands practice animal testing enables you to tell friends the products they should avoid. Most people just don't know which brands test on animals.
Anxiety is a global issue for young people. And it's on the rise.  Having a staring contest is a form of meditation and can reduce stress and anxiety among you and your friends. (Seriously!)

Most of the produce in the grocery store wouldn't be available if honey bees and other pollinators became extinct.  Create and plant bumble bands  which are strips of paper with seeds for bee-friendly plants glued to them.  Bee-friendly plants can provide pollen and nectar to help counteract habitat loss due to farming practices  sprawling lawns without flowers and destruction of landscapes.

Safe Spaces are specific areas where bullying isn't tolerated. Once someone is in a Safe Space  they have the right to feel supported and protected from any bullying they're experiencing.  By clearly designating your Safe Space  you'll attract people who need the space and will show your classmates that bullying isn't tolerated there.

Almost 1 in 4 students reports being bullied at school.  Sharing real-life tips on combating instances of bullying can enable people who are currently being bullied to get out of a difficult situation.

These women are part of Congo's growing team of wildlife rangers  who regularly put their safety at risk to protect the endangered mountain gorillas and their habitat from poachers and violence between militias and the Congolese army. In the past 20 years  more than 150 park rangers have lost their lives on the job.  The first group of women to successfully complete the mandatory training became rangers in 2014  and now proudly serve to protect the 3 000 square-mile park and its furry inhabitants.  Wildlife rangers risk their lives to protect endangered species like tigers  elephants and rhinos.  Sending thank you cards to rangers can make them more productive in their jobs  which means they can help more animals.

Over 40% of young people say they don't verbally express enthusiastic consent before or during sex.  Educate your peers about sexual assault prevention by showing them that asking for consent doesn't have to be hella awkward. Bow chicka wow wow.  https://www.dosomething.org/us/campaigns/get-some-consent
One person can make a difference.

Petting and playing with dogs decreases stress levels in your brain.  Kathryn Oda wrote on Huffington Post about her experience of how her dog has helped her. "A dog motivates you to get out the door for fresh air and exercise  even when it's the last thing you feel like doing. A dog brings you so much laughter and joy  unlike anything I've experienced before  with their unique personalities and hilarious quirks. And lastly  a dog brings you unconditional love  the kind of love that never stops. With these three things in your life  anxiety and depression can be part of your past as it has become a part of mine." An annual event at Emerson College in Hollywood awarded prom dresses to more than 80 LAUSD girls who are maintaining their grades despite experiencing difficult circumstances including homelessness  according to the school district.  "Prom Day makes selecting a dress and accessories for prom possible  and is a special day for these young women  who are encouraged by the gift of improved self-esteem to graduate with confidence " a news release from the Los Angeles Unified School District stated. Kansas City Community Kitchen in Kansas City  Missouri  serves food restaurant-style to homeless people  a process which includes greeters  waiters and a side of respect. Almost 90% of soup kitchens rely on volunteers. Recruit friends to volunteer at a soup kitchen to feed your community.

Did you miss this news? The United States has finalized new regulations that will help shut down commercial elephant ivory trade within its borders and stop wildlife crime overseas.

Rampant ivory poaching has reduced the elephant population in Tanzania’s oldest and largest protected area by 90 percent in fewer than 40 years. Nearly 110 000 elephants used to roam the savannas  wetlands  and forests of Selous Game Reserve—a World Heritage Site—in the mid-1970s. Now only 15 000 remain as criminals continue to kill the animals for their ivory tusks.
There is undeniable global momentum in the fight to save elephants and your action is helping!
One million Americans are urging the Obama administration to end high-risk offshore Arctic oil drilling.

Incredible video of an entangled Olive ridley turtle cut free from debris and released.   A WWF-Pakistan trained observer  Amir Rahim  successfully released an entangled Olive ridley turtle about 180 nautical miles from Karachi in the Arabian Sea. According to Rahim he has seen many turtles entangled in fishing nets  but this was the first time he saw a turtle trapped in a polypropylene bag. #WorldSeaTurtleDay

THANK YOU to all who participated in #AppsforEarth. The $8 million raised in partnership with the App Store will boost our efforts to protect the world’s forests  oceans  fresh water and wildlife  and combat the dual threats of climate change and unsustainable food production.
We need your help to save the Belize barrier reef!

It’s no easy task counting the number of polar bears or seals on the sea ice in the Arctic Ocean’s remote Chukchi Sea. American and Russian scientists  with some support from WWF  are taking to the skies to record populations of these iconic Arctic species.

The king of India’s Himalayan rivers is the mighty mahseer. The name roughly translates as “mahi ” meaning “fish ” and “sher ” meaning “tiger ” further cementing its reputation as the tiger among fish. Out of the 47 species of mahseer that exist in the world  India is home to 15. The golden mahseer  one of the world’s 20 mega fishes  can grow up to nine feet long and 120 pounds.

Happy #WorldOceansDay! This is the kind of footage that reminds you just how amazing the world truly is. Whales  like this humpback  roam through all the world’s oceans  yet so little information is known about them. But what we do know is that we need to protect our oceans so whales—and an estimated 2 million other species—can thrive. You can read more about our oceans work here: http://wwf.to/1Pi2OA6  Thanks to Whale Trust for sharing this footage.
This #WorldOceansDay we need your help to save the Belize barrier reef.

‘Arctic’ comes from the Greek word for bear: Arktos. The name doesn’t come from the iconic polar bear  but from constellations in the northern sky of the Arctic  ‘Ursa Minor’ (Little Bear) and ‘Ursa Major’ (Great Bear).
Looking for something to do for World Environment Day? Join the Monarch Squad and help save the monarch butterfly: http://wwf.to/25HJZTR

Did you miss this news? Setting an example for the world in the fight to save elephants  the United States passed new regulations that will help shut down the commercial ivory trade within its borders and help stop wildlife crime overseas. These new regulations are  without a doubt  a landmark moment in the fight to save elephants  but we need governments like China  Thailand and Hong Kong to follow suit and strengthen their commitments to ending the illegal ivory trade.
If you love elephants  then you will love this news. The US has passed new regulations that will help shut down the commercial ivory trade within its borders and help stop wildlife crime overseas.

We’ve teamed up with Discovery on a new series called HELLO WORLD! The six-part series airing this summer uses the power of music to tell vibrant stories about the animal kingdom for the entire family. Legendary artists featured are Christina Aguilera  Ellie Goulding  Joan Jett  Dave Matthews  Usher Raymond  and Steven Tyler. Learn more: http://wwf.to/1XQfFjG

There’s good news for Africa’s largest forest park. As the second largest tropical forest park in the world  Salonga is a global treasure. It is home for bonobos and one of the last remaining habitats for the forest elephant. Now  a newly signed agreement brings together the Congolese Institute for Nature Conservation (ICCN) and WWF to co-manage the protected area.

With immense pleasure  we’re welcoming the birth of one very special rhino in Nepal! Moved from one national park to another earlier this year to establish a new population  a rhino gave birth to the male calf on May 22. This is an encouraging sign that the mother is thriving in her new environment. Four other rhinos were also translocated with her in March.

This isn’t acceptable! Vaquitas are heading towards extinction. Only around 60 of the world’s smallest porpoise remain. We must do everything we can to save them  including immediately and indefinitely banning all fishing in vaquita habitat.

UPDATE: The first twins born to a habituated gorilla family in the Central African Republic have been named – Inguka and Inganda.  Inganda is a forest shrub which have leaves that gorillas eat. The twins' mother  Malui  used the leaves as a cushion to give birth to them. Inguka is also a forest shrub  whose leaves gorillas eat. Malui fed on these leaves a lot when she was pregnant.

This stunning jaguar calls the Peruvian Amazon home. Its habitat is deeply threatened by illegal timber practices. But there’s good news this week about this jaguar’s home—new commitments to help ensure all timber in Peru is harvested legally by 2021  a move that will protect one of the world’s most amazing forests and its wildlife!  Photo credit: Day's Edge Productions

Mountain gorilla population numbers in the Virunga Massif increased from an estimated 380 to 480 between 2003 and 2010. To find out if this positive trend has continued  teams are now making their way through the Virunga Massif  recording gorilla nest sites and collecting fecal matter for genetic analysis.
It’s World Migratory Bird Day! Did you know the glossy ibis migrates between Europe and Africa  crossing the Sahara Desert?
It’s official! President Obama just signed the National Bison Legacy Act into law  making the American bison the official national mammal.

Weighing up to a whopping 2 000 pounds  the bison is an American epic. Did we mention they can hit speeds of 40 miles per hour while running? In the latest issue of the World Wildlife Magazine  we explore how two tribes and a host of partners are rallying to restore bison to tribal lands: http://wwf.to/26Xtn8x
Good news! Nepal is celebrating an amazing two consecutive years of zero rhino poaching!

Mexican firefighters  WWF and the National Park Service are working together to help save the Rio Grande. Learn more about Los Diablos and the dangerous work they do in this short-documentary by The Atlantic.

Make sure to turn your audio up so you can hear the underwater chorus of wildlife!   “The species we could be hearing out here could be bowhead whales  ringed seals and beluga whales...each of these species make these fantastic sounds. There’s so much going on under that water that we just aren’t aware of.” - WWF’s Elisabeth Kruger. Pictured: Elisabeth holds a GoPro underwater to record the sounds of the Bering Sea while Alaskan native  Clyde Oxereok  holds onto her for safety.  Learn more from USA TODAY: wwf.to/1pKHgFs

The U.S. House of Representatives passed the National Bison Legacy Act designating a species once on the brink of extinction as America’s national mammal. The plains bison’s remarkable recovery from near extinction in the 20th century is an important reminder that we can change the course of history when we work together to save an imperiled species.

What if your daily reality included the possibility of encounters with polar bears. What would you do? In Wales  Alaska  as melting sea ice forces bears dangerously close to land  local villagers team up with WWF for polar bear patrol training. The goal? To protect their community without harming the bears. Read more from USA TODAY:

The coral reefs of Belize teem with life: sea turtles glide through clear waters; vibrant corals stud the ocean floor; and a vast array of aquatic animals protect their young in the tangled roots of mangroves. They’re necessary for both the wildlife that live there and the people who rely on the coral reefs for income and protection. Currently 114 of 229 natural World Heritage sites are at risk to harmful industrial activity. Now more than ever  we need to protect World Heritage sites like Belize’s barrier reefs and safeguard these natural treasures and the benefits they provide.

Big news! Apple and WWF have teamed up to help protect life on our planet through an initiative called #AppsforEarth.  From now through April 24  WWF will receive 100% of the proceeds from 27 participating apps in the App Store via both the purchases of paid apps and the In-App Purchases created exclusively for the campaign. To help prevent poaching  WWF used a grant from Google.org to install FLIR thermal cameras and a remarkable new software system that can identify poachers from afar and alert park rangers of their presence. This is the first time that infrared cameras and human recognition software have been used at this scale for conservation and anti-poaching efforts to monitor a park’s boundary.

Leonardo DiCaprio on the news that wild tiger numbers are on the rise for the first time in 100 years: “I am so proud that our collective efforts have begun to make progress toward our goal  but there is still so much to be done. I am optimistic about what can be achieved when governments  communities  conservationists and private foundations like ours come together to tackle global challenges."

After a century of constant decline  global wild tiger numbers are on the rise! According to the most recent data  around 3 890 tigers now exist in the wild—up from an estimated 3 200 in 2010. Learn more: http://wwf.to/1NiOK8k

Currently 114 of 229 natural World Heritage sites are at risk to harmful industrial activity. Now more than ever  we need to protect World Heritage sites like Belize’s barrier reefs and safeguard these natural treasures and the benefits they provide.

Tiger populations fighting for a comeback in the wild will receive a much needed lifeline from the United States government. Improved and tightened regulations around captive tigers will make it more difficult for captive-bred tiger parts to filter into and stimulate the illegal wildlife trade that threatens wild tigers in Asia. More than 451 000 WWF supporters called on the US government to help make this happen!

Most endangered cat in the world is making a comeback: A new census released by the government of Andalusia shows an increase in the population of the Iberian lynx reaching the highest number since the species was found to be the most endangered cat in the world in 2002. The latest population figure of 404 individuals is up from the 327 recorded in 2014.

ICYMI: During the 2015-2016 dry season  no Mekong dolphins died and three new calves were also spotted  thanks to the efforts of 68 dedicated river guards. The dry season  which lasts from December to March every year  tends to be the most dangerous time for Mekong river dolphins as it ushers in a period of greater illegal fishing and decreasing water levels.

Happy #NationalPuppyDay! These pups are putting their sniffers to work to stop wildlife crime.

Freshwater is the world’s most precious resource  fueling everything from the food you eat  to the cotton you wear  to the energy you depend upon every day. Freshwater habitats are home to more than 10% of all known animals and about 50% of all known fish. Yet less than 1% of the world's water is fresh and accessible.  #WorldWaterDay

Tamara loves to dance and sing. So when she started having hip pain that caused her to limp  her parents grew concerned. Tamara's father  who is a pediatrician in their native country of Bolivia  suspected cancer. An MRI confirmed his worst fears — Tamara had bone cancer. Her family was referred to St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital for Tamara’s care and treatment.

While in treatment  Katherin misses playing soccer and cuddling with her chihuahua  Bibi. But she knows she’s in the right place. "My family and my St. Jude family are fighting alongside me " she said.
Watch how one young St. Jude supporter is using her soccer skills to raise $100 000 for the kids of St. Jude. Way to go  Hollis!

Meet Kristina. During her junior year of high school  she was referred to St. Jude for treatment  where she formed a special bond with a fellow patient. Today  she plans to share her friend’s message of strength in order to inspire others. http://bit.ly/295q7mt

St. Jude patient Adam was excited to be honored at this year’s Volunteer Awards Dinner for all of his hard work for the kids of St. Jude. At St. Jude we are dedicated not only to treating the toughest cases  but also to research. Pediatric oncologist and researcher Tanja Gruber  M.D.  Ph.D.  treats kids who have high-risk leukemia. She researches specific types of leukemia  including infantile acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and acute megakaryoblastic leukemia. Dr. Gruber coordinates a clinical trial designed to treat infant patients with ALL who have a mutation in the MLL gene. Kids with this type of leukemia tend to have a high risk of relapse  and most do not respond well to current therapies. The study tests a new approach of adding two known adult anti-cancer drugs to standard ALL chemotherapy. Learn more about Dr. Gruber: www.stjude.org/gruber

As a physician  I have had to inform patients that they have a diagnosis of cancer. It is never easy. What has been even more difficult has been watching a family member and friend face cancer. After watching my closest friend deal with and  eventually  run out of time as a result of cancer  I felt it was my duty to try and do what I could to help those living with and surviving cancer. LIVESTRONG became my way of giving back to those who need it. - Joe Volpe  LIVESTRONG Leader  Texas
Cancer doesn't happen to a person in a vacuum - it can affect your body  mind and day-to-day life. Know that LIVESTRONG is here to help you and your family navigate the system.

I am a brain cancer survivor. Although my prognosis was very poor  I believe that it is of paramount importance to maintain a positive outlook on life... Having day to day uncertainty has taught me to enjoy my life today instead of focusing on an ever elusive tomorrow. - John Mahoney  LIVESTRONG Leader  Chicago

We know so much about the benefits of girls’ education  including reducing the likelihood of teen pregnancies and early marriages. But out of the world’s 30 million out-of-school youth  70% are girls  according to the United Nations Foundation.  Traditionally  girls have been kept at home instead of enrolling in school  but we’re working to break these traditions. In Kenya  our programs focus on the factors that may push children out of school and showing the wider community how transformative education can be for marginalized children. Now more young girls like Jemima are enrolled in school  which opens up their opportunities for the future. Click the donate button now to help us reach #EveryLastChild and get more girls like Jemima back in school.

Crystal  pictured here with kids in our U.S. Sponsorship programs  has served as a Literacy Tutor and Sponsorship Liaison with Save the Children in Tennessee for the last 7 years.  “We have a diverse group—a lot of kids who come from good homes  but also a lot of kids growing up without parents at home ” she says. “You’ve heard that saying  ‘it takes a village.’ Well it does here  and our school community is that village. We all help those kids that don’t have somebody to help them and get them through the day.” Please join us in thanking Crystal for all that she does for #ChildSponsorship!

Girls in Ethiopia take a break from their school lessons at our Child Friendly Space. Beyond providing access to education in the midst of long-term conflict  our CFS serves as an outlet for children to express their emotions  improve their self-esteem and share their unique perspectives.

Child-Friendly Spaces are one of Save the Children's most well-known activities to protect children during the first phase of an emergency and in long-term crises. At our CFS  children have the opportunity to play  sing  and socialize with their peers — and to regain a sense of normalcy in difficult times. They also help keep children safe during the day which allows parents to focus on finding support and services they need in the immediate aftermath of an emergency.    Here  refugee children from Bosnia participate in recreational activities that we set up during the Kosovo conflict of 1999. #TBT

4-year-old Karma from Bhutan plays on her school’s playground before class. We’re helping preschool teachers throughout the country implement play-based learning activities to help set kids up for a better chance of success later in elementary school.    In a country where many children are falling behind even before completing the first grade  the new school activities give students the motivation to be present and learn the essential skills they’ll need in the years ahead.

“We can no longer feed our family ” Agness  a mother of 6  told us in Malawi. “The rain came too late  the maize is broken  and we have almost nothing to harvest. This year we’ll get maybe one fifth of the normal harvest.”  The humanitarian situation in East Africa is deteriorating at an alarming rate due to El Nino-induced weather patterns caused by climate change. Agness' children are among the nearly 5 million who risk going hungry due to drought. Learn how climate change affects children and what we're doing to help: http://ow.ly/OM7X301fsDa

6-year-old Javier washes up at a hand-washing station at his school. We’ve been running health and nutrition programs at his elementary school in Bolivia since 2013.   The school has no running water so empty soda bottles are repurposed to purify water by hanging them in the sun. We also provide Vitamin A and Iron to fight anemia and other health problems that arise from inadequate nutrition. Many parents are involved and supportive of the school  coming almost every day to volunteer as well as providing healthy food for the students. The parents see hope and are actively investing in their children’s futures by being a part of the solution.

#TBT: This photo was captured in 1996 at our programs in Mozambique where we provided this mud & thatch hut school with books and school supplies.     We began working in Mozambique in 1987 to help rebuild the healthcare system and provide emergency aid to children and families displaced by civil war. Today  the country ranks among the 10 poorest countries in the world. Our programs there focus largely on health  nutrition and education. Child protection and child rights governance—including safe migration and anti-trafficking programming—are central elements to our work. Our goal is to provide children in Mozambique with better quality nutrition and education  as well as protection from harm while increasing the population’s understanding of children’s rights.

Children and families are on the move at unprecedented numbers  creating the highest level of refugee children since World War II. This year  more than 200 000 people have arrived in Greece and Italy by sea—the vast majority of which are fleeing war  violence and persecution in their country of origin  according to UNHCR  the UN Refugee Agency.    We’re on the ground in Europe helping children and families of the refugee crisis—distributing aid items like cooked meals  emergency shelters  and hygiene kits as well as providing child-friendly spaces where children can play  release stress and talk about their experience with trained emergency staff. You can help us provide these lifesaving materials to those in need: http://ow.ly/V60R300MoPl

“When we were on the sea in the small boat  we looked death in the eyes.” –Mahdi  14  from Syria  This is a view of the refugee crisis that you haven't seen. In this interactive photo essay  photojournalist Talitha Brauer takes us on one family's long journey as they desperately seek safe passage out of war-torn Syria. See the day-to-day reality of displacement and fear through their eyes: http://ow.ly/9FF5300XYBg

Newborn baby Shephard was born premature  but our community health workers in Malawi are working to ensure his survival with interventions like Kangaroo Mother Care. The prolonged skin-to-skin contact helps the youngest and most vulnerable children by promoting breastfeeding and reducing infection—all the while providing a great bonding opportunity for mom and baby. “I’m optimistic ” mother Ester tell us. “I notice that he likes the warmth and tranquility when I put him on my chest. I think this will go well  and that he has a future.”
Our agents of change meet with Chernor Bah

This past week was one of the deadliest for refugees crossing the Mediterranean. More than 1 000 people are feared dead at sea in their desperate bid to reach safety.  Our response to the refugee crisis spans several countries across Europe where we’re distributing aid items like cooked meals  emergency shelters  and hygiene kits to families. We’ve also established child-friendly spaces that give children a safe place to play  socialize  release stress and talk about their experience with trained emergency staff. Learn more about our response: http://ow.ly/sWCB300TKup

Children make up more than half of the Syrian refugee population in Jordan’s Za'atari refugee camp  according to UNHCR. Within Za’atari  children can attend Save the Children-supported early education classes and play in our child-friendly spaces. We also provide child protection and psycho-social support for refugee children at many of our programs within the camp for displaced peoples.

In Cambodia most children start school  but fewer than 50% stay to complete their basic education. With the support of the IKEA Foundation  we’re working with schools in the country's remote provinces to help the most vulnerable children – especially children with disabilities and those from the poorest families – to access and succeed in school.

20-year-old Gledis from Nicaragua is 8 months pregnant with her first child. In the Save the Children-supported health center where we met her  pregnant women are informed about the symptoms of mosquito-borne diseases as well as how to reduce their chances of contracting them. Zika  Malaria  Dengue and Chikungunya can be prevented by using bed nets  insect repellent  covering or removing standing water  and removing trash from homes.   Learn more about the Zika virus: http://ow.ly/YrHg300QF7P

IN 1925  the World Conference for the Well-Being of Children in Geneva  Switzerland  proclaimed June 1 to be International Children's Day. Today  governments around the world recognize International Children's day to draw attention to children's issues.   Our goal is to get people talking about children around the world who need our help.  We're asking child sponsors to join in by doing the following: 1. Create a sign with one or two words to complete this sentence – “I wish all children could feel...” 2. Take a selfie holding your sign 3. Post your selfie tagging Save the Children with the hashtag #WhyISponsor so we can share your stories  photos and videos.  Together  we can continue making the world a better place for children. Learn more: http://ow.ly/zWax300NwVI

More than 1 000 people are feared dead at sea in just the past week in their desperate bid to reach Europe.    Our response to the refugee crisis spans several countries across Europe where we’re distributing aid items like cooked meals  emergency shelters  and hygiene kits to families. Iman’s* family left Syria more than a month ago after their home and schools were destroyed by bombs. They hoped to settle in Germany or any northern European country  but are among the more than 10 000 refugees currently stranded in Idomeni  a small Greek village near the Republic of Macedonia border.  Refugees live in tents placed by the railway tracks waiting in hope for the border to open. We're offering protection to children travelling alone and providing food and support to families. #TBT: Typhoon Haiyan was one of the most powerful storms ever recorded  and it left a massive trail of devastation when it hit the Philippines in 2013. Buildings and roads crumbled  fishing boats were wrecked  and groves of coconut trees were flattened— leaving many families unable to earn the incomes they depended on.   Our response was broad and included establishing a shelter program  sanitation and hygiene activities  child-friendly spaces and much  much more. We also conducted over 40 000 consultations through our mobile health units where we treated 10-month-old Mark and hundreds of children like him in the most remote areas of the island nation.

We will do whatever it takes to reach every last child. Follow the conversation here and on all our social channels with #EveryLastChild.

#TBT: 18-month-old Arati was sleeping inside when last year’s #NepalEarthquake caused her family’s home to collapse around her. The 7.9 magnitude earthquake was the worst natural disaster to strike the country in over 80 years  leaving 9 000 people dead  more than 22 000 injured  and 2 million people in urgent need of water  sanitation and hygiene support. Investing in early childhood education is one of the most effective ways to break the cycle of poverty. The Social Impact Partnership Act (S. 1089/H.R. 1336) could help fund an expansion of high-quality early learning programs in the U.S. Tell Congress to #InvestInKids by cosponsoring this critical bill to ensure all kids have the chance to succeed in school and life: http://ow.ly/10Bb5S

Play helps build the foundation for a lifetime of learning  but children living in poverty often don’t get the opportunity for structured play in their daily lives. Toys''R''Us is helping us change that by supporting our early childhood development programs where children benefit from educational play. How do you #PlayWithPurpose? Tell us in the comments.

Three-year-old Victor has already discovered the magic of a good book. Today for #ChildrensBookDay  share the wonder of reading with a child. #books #reading #goodreads  #ICBD2016 #InternationalChildrensBookDay

7-year-old Sao Vin  right  went through home-based preschool run by Save the Children in Cambodia  and she is a voracious reader. Now in 1st grade  she is at the top of her class  loves teaching younger kids to read  and is always encouraging her friends to open a good book. Learn more about our education programs: http://ow.ly/10aNEt
Do you follow us on Instagram? Head on over to instagram.com/savethechildren and click 'Follow' for more pictures of adorable kids!

This month  American sports fans are focused on #MarchMadness. But March also marks 5 years of the conflict in #Syria  which has caused millions of children to suffer. That's the real madness.   Text SYRIA to 20222 to donate $10 to help Syria's children.  *Message and data rates may apply

In Nepal  8-year-old Kailalia reads aloud with friends. The children attend our Literacy Boost program  which promotes reading habits and learning both in and out of the classroom. Our approach to the program includes assessments  teacher training and community action to significantly improve a child’s core reading skills. We believe that more children will learn to read if they are well supported to do so in their classroom and beyond the school walls.

Claire-Rose is a friendly and outgoing 10-year-old from rural #Haiti. Our Sponsorship programs are giving her a brighter future through education and school health & nutrition programs. Do you sponsor a child like Claire-Rose? Tell us why in the comments below with #WhyISponsor.

At our Child-Friendly Spaces  children in emergencies have the opportunity to play  sing  and socialize with their peers — and to regain a sense of normalcy in difficult times. “I come to the CFS very often ” 10-year-old Emma*  a refugee from Burundi tells us at a refugee camp in Rwanda. “Normally we go to school in the morning and then I go home and help my mother cook. As soon as I am finished  I come to the CFS. I try to cook very fast so that I can have lots of time here.”  We are so happy to be able to bring smiles to the faces of children like Emma. *Name changed for protection

#DYK games and activities help with brain and muscle development in young children? Join us today at 2 p.m. EST for a Twitter Chat with Toys''R''Us to learn the value of play and ways you can engage little ones during this critical time in their development. Follow the conversation with #PlayWithPurpose.

A healthworker measures a baby's arm circumference in a health post in #Ethiopia.  With current #drought conditions persisting in Ethiopia  400 000 children could fall prey to severe malnutrition this year. We’re implementing projects and responding to the urgent humanitarian needs in affected areas. Learn how you can help: http://ow.ly/ZOTdm

In #Ethiopia  a woman fills her container with precious water delivered on truck by Save the Children as conditions continue to deteriorate due to severe drought. We’re working in over 70% of the worst-affected areas providing essential aid items like food  medicine  and water to children and families who so desperately need it. Learn more about our response: http://ow.ly/100tqF

Spring is here! Celebrate the season of new beginnings by giving new hope to children in need. Give a meaningful gift to make a lasting difference for children in the U.S. and all around the world: http://ow.ly/ZTtxY

Thirteen-year-old Dang enjoys an afternoon break from inside her classroom. In #Cambodia  we work with the provincial education and environment departments to improve coastal communities’ resilience to the impacts of disasters and climate change. We help children like Dang thrive after disasters through programs that improve household livelihoods  increase life skills of children and adults  and improve land-use planning.
Take a trip to Build-A-Bear Workshop in NYC with kids from one of our programs. They had so much fun picking out new furry friends!

In Mozambique  more than 1.4 million children are orphans. By working with local partners and the government  we’re able to provide food  healthcare and education for vulnerable children. We do whatever it takes to protect children from harm and exploitation because kids everywhere should have the chance to let loose and just have fun. Like if you agree!

Jazmine  7  explores the magic of the rainforest outside her home in Washington state. Spring brings out the green lush of the forest and encourages children to go outside to play. Jazmine  an active and creative girl   is enrolled in Save the Children literacy programs at her school.

Many children around the world suffer from oral health issues. Sponsorship programs teach kids like Nada how to take care of their pearly whites through school health & hygiene programs. Our sponsors keep children like Nada smiling - and we love to see it! #WhyISponsor

Save the Children is among the main aid agencies screening for and treating severe malnutrition  writes our staff in a blog from the field  "I have never experienced anything like this drought before." Read more from #Ethiopia:
Climate change affects children like Ayan*. With severe drought continuing to wreak havoc on East Africa  millions of children and families are at risk of extreme hunger and malnutrition.

In Ethiopia  people gather to fill their containers with precious water delivered on truck by Save the Children. Unsure of when their next supply will arrive  some bring their donkeys and camels to help carry their containers of water.  Conditions in Ethiopia continue to deteriorate due to severe drought. We’re working in over 70% of the worst-affected areas in Ethiopia providing essential aid items like food  medicine  and water to children and families who so desperately need it. In honor of #WorldWaterDay  help children affected by the #EthiopiaDrought: http://ow.ly/ZOTdm

Clean and safe drinking water is crucial for all children. Our dedicated staff does whatever it takes to make sure children have access to this essential human need. For #WorldWaterDay  learn what we're doing to bring clean water to kids all over the world:

We didn't leave #Syria because we were poor. We left Syria because we needed an education ” Rula* told us at our Child Friendly Space in #Lesvos. She was only 4 years old when an airstrike hit her school in Syria  killing most of her friends and classmates. She hasn’t been to school since. Read her story:   *Name changed for protection.
savethechildren,2016-03-21T16:10:29+0000,1532252,8047221596_10153909073986597,1806,121,36,photo,Pushpa  a nurse and midwife in Nepal  places a newborn baby in the arms of its grandmother.  After a prolonged and difficult labor  the baby was born at home with a blocked airway. Pushpa  who had just finished our newborn care training  was able to resuscitate the baby with newly acquired skills. It wasn't until her own complicated birthing experience motivated her to become a healthcare worker  but overcoming obstacles to pursue her dream has resulted in unexpected rewards. “I became a health worker thinking I would help women ” she told us  ”but now I am also saving newborns.” #MondayMotivation
savethechildren,2016-03-21T12:50:13+0000,1532252,8047221596_10153908531126597,2321,224,36,photo,When temperatures drop  children need extra attention to stay warm  safe and healthy. Young children are less likely to recognize when they are cold and more likely to lose body heat quickly due to their smaller size. Read our tips for keeping children safe in cold weather: http://ow.ly/XpF3v
savethechildren,2016-03-20T16:47:15+0000,1531216,8047221596_10153905461491597,798,1,25,link,Thank you Mashable for sharing the stories of these Syrian children.

Here  she attends a meeting at the children’s club where we advocate for child rights and against child marriages. With support from the government and local partners  we educate and raise awareness to end child marriages so girls like Saraswati can stay in school and follow their dreams.
