savethechildren,2016-03-17T19:04:33+0000,1528068,8047221596_10153896096516597,1255,122,25,link,The first time we tried to get a boat to Greece  a person drowned so we had to turn back " Rabia* told us of her family's escape from Syria with two young children. "When we got back to Turkey  we were arrested and put in jail."   *Name changed for protection

#TBT: In 2012  thousands of refugees began pouring into Jordan and other neighboring countries to escape the violence in Syria that had erupted in the previous year. Children like Abir* and Nur* were living with their families in tents at Za’atari Refguee Camp where authorities struggled to meet the basic needs of the overwhelming numbers of refugees arriving each day. Today  not much has changed  and the problem continues to grow—in 2015  an average of 100 Syrians fled the violence every hour. Learn what we’re doing to help #SaveSyriasChildren: http://ow.ly/ZmKfu  *Name changed for protection

Put yourself in the shoes of a mother who watched her malnourished infant die in her arms because she wasn’t allowed to cross a security checkpoint  writes our CEO Carolyn Miles in the GlobalPost. "Imagine the fear a young child feels as his school is bombed and he sees his friends killed." Read more:  #SaveSyriasChildren
Listen to Katrine*  a 15 year old Syrian refugee  and hear her story of how her life has changed since she left Syria. #ZaatariLive
Today our teams in Jordan are streaming live from Zaatari Refugee Camp in Jordan. Watch now to hear from some of the young voices living in the camp: #ZaatariLive #SaveSyriasChildren

“The planes were shelling everyone and killing everyone ” 10-year-old Rami* told us of life in Syria. His family was living under siege for several months before they were able to flee to Lebanon. They had no food and his parents  like many others  resorted to feeding their children grass just to stay alive.   With today marking 5 years since the Syrian war began  children like Rami need your help now more than ever. Please donate now to help #SaveSyriasChildren: http://ow.ly/Zr13v  *Name changed for protection

Today marks 5 years since the war in Syria began  and children there continue to witness horrifying scenes on a daily basis. Even those who've fled  like Hassan * are unable to forget what they saw. Please donate now to help #SaveSyriasChildren: http://ow.ly/Zr13v  *Name changed for protection

Today our teams in Jordan are streaming live from Zaatari Refugee Camp. Watch now to get an inside look at our kindergarten programs for refugee children and see our staff in action:   #ZaatariLive #SaveSyriasChildren
Like Save the Children UK's Facebook page and tune in at 8 a.m. EST tomorrow to see what real life is like for kids inside Zaatari Refugee Camp in Jordan. #ZaatariLive

All his life  5-year-old Ayman* has known nothing but war. He was born at a military  hospital in 2011 when the conflict in Syria began  but life in a war zone took a devastating toll on the boy. Read his story and learn about his connection to Cristiano Ronaldo:   #SaveSyriasChildren *Name changed for protection

Little Mahmoud* should be starting kindergarten this year—instead  he’s growing up in a world of conflict. Please donate to help #SaveSyriasChildren so memories of war can become a thing of the past: http://ow.ly/Zr13v   *Name changed for protection

Gearing up for March Madness? This championship season you can compete with your friends and help kids in need  too! Fill out a free college basketball bracket and win up to $100 000 for Save the Children: http://ow.ly/ZoYCt
As a Dad  Cristiano Ronaldo knows what's at stake for the children of Syria. We must all do what it takes to #SaveSyriasChildren. http://bit.ly/1Rg47z9
Shocking stats about the conflict in Syria that you can't ignore. Learn what we're doing to #SaveSyriasChildren: http://ow.ly/ZmKfu

The number of people under siege in Syria has more than doubled in the past year—reaching nearly 500 000 people in 18 besieged areas. Children are among the most vulnerable  experiencing bombing  facing starvation  and dying from preventable diseases. One mother said that some children are so depressed that they are just waiting for their turn to die. Read more in our latest report: http://ow.ly/ZmG6X   #SaveSyriasChildren

When Omar* first escaped Syria  he suffered from severe malnutrition. Now he’s living in an informal settlement with his family in Lebanon. At only 5 years old  he’s among the nearly 50% of Syrians who’ve been forced to flee their homes since the conflict began in 2011. Learn what we’re doing to help #SaveSyriasChildren:  http://ow.ly/ZgQmA  *Name changed for protection

Syrian children like Rami* want so badly to get an education  but constant attacks on school buildings are keeping them out of class. These children shouldn’t be left without hope  but without an education their futures are uncertain. Read Rami*’s story: http://ow.ly/ZlvkV #SaveSyriasChildren  *Name changed for protection

The continuous shelling and sniper shooting  the lack of food and water  and the lack of medical supplies—that’s why we decided to leave ” Ali* told us of his decision to flee Syria. “I couldn’t bear to see my children dying of hunger.   Before fleeing to Lebanon  Ali and his family were under siege in Syria for 6 months. Adults were forced to go without food for days in order to have enough food for the children  w ho were not allowed to leave the house. “If a child ran or played in front of their house  they could get shot ” he said. Read more in our report: http://ow.ly/ZiDq8 #SaveSyriasChildren  *Name changed for protection

Five years on  the war in Syria has forced at least half of the country’s population to flee their homes—but 6.5 million of those people are still living in besieged or hard-to-reach places within Syria. Children in these areas live in constant fear of bombing  with many parents reporting their children have become more aggressive  withdrawn or depressed. Learn what we’re doing to #SaveSyriasChildren: http://ow.ly/ZiDq8

Five years into the Syria conflict  thousands of 5-year-olds like Lara* have grown up knowing nothing outside of war. These children should be happily getting ready to start kindergarten  but instead they’re growing up in a world of terror. Learn more: http://ow.ly/ZgQmA #SaveSyriasChildren  *Name changed for protection

Research Participants Requested:  The Congressionally Directed Medical Research Program (CDMRP) is seeking men and women of all ages who sustained service-connected injuries or illnesses to participate as reviewers of research applications dealing with treatment of injuries and illnesses attributed to military service. Approved reviewers assess and comment on proposals on treatments such as acupuncture  resilience and readiness interventions  and particular conditions such as acute lung injury  bronchiolitis (from burn pit exposure) and other respiratory conditions  chronic migraine  epilepsy  traumatic brain injury   hearing loss  tinnitus  vision and balance deficits  orthopedic injury  post-traumatic osteoarthritis  sleep disorders  spinal cord injury  infectious disease (dengue  hepatitis B  malaria  tuberculosis)  and cancers (such as blood  kidney  lung  and skin).   Stipends and travel reimbursement for approved reviewers may be provided in accordance with government regulations. These meetings are slated to begin in July 2016 and will occur as either online or  in-person (in the DC metro area). If you (or your personal caregiver in some cases) are interested in participating as a reviewer  please contact Ann Dodelin at Ann.Dodelin@csra.com or 240-236-9055  or e-mail Consumers@csra.com.

It is with great sadness  we share the passing of Mr. Harry Ferrier  last Midway Survivor of VT-8. He was 91.  Harry Ferrier enlisted in the Navy on January 28  1941  three days after his sixteenth birthday. After boot camp and aviation radio school  he joined Torpedo Squadron 8 (VT-8) stationed on the aircraft carrier USS Hornet.  In 1941  VT-8 was flying the outdated TBD Devastator  but in early 1942  the squadron was selected to receive the first of the new TBF Avengers. Since the USS Hornet was immediately needed in the Pacific  a small detachment of VT-8 was chosen to stay behind and train on the new planes. Harry Ferrier  his pilot Albert “Bert” Earnest and gunner Jay Manning were selected to be part of this detachment.  After about three months of training on the Avenger  Ferrier and the detachment of six Avengers were sent to Pearl Harbor to join the rest of VT-8. Arriving on May 28  1942  the detachment had missed the USS Hornet which had sailed for Midway a day earlier. The group then volunteered to fly directly to Midway Island to re-enforce the Marine Garrison there.  On June 4  1942  Harry Ferrier and his crew received word of Japanese aircraft heading towards Midway and sightings of an enemy fleet 150 miles out to sea. All six Avengers took off immediately. Five minutes later  Jay manning reported seeing Japanese planes starting their attack on Midway Island.   About an hour later  Bert Earnest saw Japanese ships on the horizon. As the Avengers prepared to attack  they were jumped by Japanese Zeros. Harry Ferrier heard Jay Manning fire a few rounds from his turret  but then go silent. He looked up after feelings Manning’s blood drip on him and saw Manning’s lifeless body and the turret full of holes.  Flying at 200 feet  the Avengers pressed home their attacks on the Japanese fleet  but under a swarm of Zeros they were being shot down one by one. Canon shells from the Zeros shot away the elevator  compass and hydraulics on Ferrier’s plane. Pilot Bert Earnest struggled with the controls  but managed to release his torpedo at a Japanese cruiser. Soon after  Harry Ferrier was hit by shrapnel and knocked unconscious.  After fending off Zeros and flying on dead reckoning  Bert Earnest managed to locate Midway Island. Harry Ferrier regained consciousness and Earnest asked him to confirm that the torpedo was successfully launched. Ferrier couldn’t tell because the window to the bomb bay was covered in blood.  Ferrier’s Avenger approached Midway and prepared for landing. With only one wheel down  it was waived off twice. On the third approach Earnest touched down. The plane ground looped and came to a gentle stop.  Harry Ferrier and Bert Earnest were alive. They were the only plane of VT-8 to return to base. Five out of six of VT-8’s Midway based Avengers were lost and all 15 of their carrier based Devastators were shot down during the battle. Their Avenger had nearly 70 holes in it.  For his actions that day  Harry Ferrier was awarded the Purple Heart and the Distinguished Flying Cross. His pilot  Bert Earnest was awarded the Navy Cross and the Purple Heart.  Harry Ferrier continued to fly with VT-8 after the Battle of Midway  participating in the Battle of Guadalcanal. After WWII  he stayed in the Navy and served in Korea and Vietnam.  RIP  brother.

Attention Gulf War veterans: The UC San Diego School of Medicine's Dr. Beatrice Golomb is studying Gulf War Illness and may be interested in speaking with you.  The study is examining the treatments Gulf War veterans (or other veterans with similar problems) with Gulf War illness symptoms. This study will seek to understand which treatments are helpful  harmful  or have no impact in controlling the symptoms of Gulf War Illness. They also wish to hear from others with similar problems to learn how treatment effects differ and identify other promising treatments.  A total of 400 study participants who live within the United States are needed to participate in this study who meet the following criteria:  1. Gulf War veterans: Veterans who were deployed to the Persian Gulf Region July 1990 - August 1991 and have experienced health changes.  2. Veterans: Active members of the United States Military that have experienced unexplained chronic multisymptom health changes. Study participants will complete up to 6 online surveys. Each addresses a different aspect of your treatment experience or symptoms  or asks about factors  like exposures  that may lead to differences in the effect of a treatment. Each survey will take approximately 0.5 – 2 hours. The surveys will consist of questions that ask about your overall heath  well-being  symptoms  exposures  treatments you have tried  as well as your healthcare experience.  You can proceed to the next survey either immediately after  or a week after  a prior survey has been completed (or specify another time to be reminded). After each survey has been completed  you will receive a $5 gift card to either Amazon.com or Starbucks (depending on your preference). The more you complete the more you will help.  If there is a chance you might be interested in participating  please contact call (858)558-4950 x203 or x210 or email jbritchie@ucsd.edu or hkoslik@ucsd.edu to learn more.

Deterrence policies sold to the public as humanitarian solutions have only exacerbated the suffering of people in need.  Jerome Oberreit  MSF's International Secretary General just announced that MSF will no longer take funds from the European Union or its Member States  effective immediately. This is to oppose Europe's damaging deterrence policies and intensifying attempts to push people and their suffering away.

The global migration crisis will remain a defining issue of our time; and it is one which I believe we must collectively meet together. To do so  a paradigm shift is urgently needed. An extremely vulnerable migratory population of children  women and men deserve dignified assistance and care  and the opportunity to rebuild their lives and prosper. MSF Executive Director Stephen Cornish in The Huffington Post. Monday  June 20 is World Refugee Day.

Mariam is an internally displaced person from Makhmour  Iraq. In this photo from May 2016 she helps an MSF doctor to treat Fatma  her one-month-old daughter in Dibaga camp in Iraqi Kurdistan.   Fatma was born in Debes hospital  a medical structure a 45 minute drive away from Dibaga camp. Her parents and six siblings have been living in Dibaga camp since the camp was established a year ago. “It was a difficult delivery. It took two days and a midwife helped me give birth. I came to the clinic today because the baby’s belly button has a problem. I am not well myself  I feel sick and I keep bleeding.”   3.3 million Iraqis are now displaced in the country. While the humanitarian response in camps within the Kurdistan Region of Iraq has been strong and people have overall good access to services  they represent only 10% of the displaced population.  The majority live outside camps  with relatives  in rented houses  in unfinished buildings  surviving on their savings and struggling to find work and with little access to aid.  MSF has been running mobile clinics in the area for over a year. When the camp opened in September 2015  the medical team started working in the healthcare centre of Dibaga providing primary healthcare with special focus on mother and child  chronic disease and mental health services. In the last four months over 4 500 consultations were carried out.   © Manu Brabo / MEMO for MSF

A joint statement by MSF and the International Committee of the Red Cross on attacks on medical facilities and personnel:   Who has been carrying out these attacks? Well  just about everyone. Armed forces  armed groups  yes  even governments that sit round the table at the United Nations. And let us be clear. It is not always “collateral damage”. It can be systematic  planned  and deliberate and illegal. An attack on healthcare  whether intended or “accidental”  is an attack on humanitarian law. What we are witnessing is a sustained assault on  and massive disregard for  the provision of healthcare during times of conflict.

“Two bombs fell last night less than one kilometre from our house. It was a very strange and scary feeling. We later learned that another MSF hospital had been targeted in the north of the country and that two MSF staff had been seriously injured. It’s upsetting; the targeting of hospitals evokes strong feelings. People are questioning “Does international humanitarian law even exist anymore? Are there absolutely no rules?”  #StopBombingHospitals #Yemen #Ibb #EvenWarHasRules
It’s been a horrific night for our colleagues.

On average  an MSF-supported health structure was bombed or shelled every week in 2015 in Syria and in the first six weeks of 2016. Our health workers and health structures have also been targeted in Yemen  South Sudan and Afghanistan  among other countries  causing intolerable suffering  death and destruction.  Please stand with us in asking the United Nations Security Council to reaffirm the protection of impartial medical care  health workers and of all patients  regardless of their background  and to establish effective  independent investigations to report attacks on medical facilities and hold accountable those who attack them. Hospitals are #NotATarget!  Learn more and take action: msf.ca/NotATarget

Premature twins Zohal and Ojate Hosine rest in their home in Dasht-e-Barchi  Kabul.   Since November 2014 MSF has been running a specialised maternity department dedicated to emergency obstetric  neonatal care services and complicated deliveries in the Dasht-e-Barchi public district hospital. The hospital serves a population of more than 1.3 million in western Kabul.   Functioning at maximum capacity  1 303 babies were admitted in the newborn unit in 2015  staying for an average of eight days with complications such as low blood sugar and breathing problems. With 32 mothers admitted on average each week for observation in the IPD  the hospital’s bed occupancy rate reached 146% in December 2015.

With more than 2.7 million people uprooted from their homes  the Lake Chad basin is currently home to one of the African continent’s biggest humanitarian crises. The region is reaching breaking point due to attacks by the Islamic State’s West Africa Province group (ISWAP)  also known as Boko Haram  and a strong military response which has been launched to curb the violence. “India is such a vital source of affordable  generic life-saving medicines on which millions of people around the world rely  that any blow to the pharmacy of the developing world would have disastrous consequences ” Dr Joanne Liu  International President of MSF.  Ahead of Today’s EU-India Summit in Brussels  MSF urges Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to keep his country’s ‘pharmacy of the developing world’ open and to resist pressure from the European Union to accept harmful provisions in a trade deal that would restrict access to affordable medicines for millions of people.  Prime Minister Modi and EU officials are expected to announce at the Summit the resumption of negotiations in the nine-years-and-counting free trade agreement talks between the two trading partners. Negotiations have mostly stalled for nearly three years  but appear set to soon resume with many contentious issues remaining on the negotiating table. They include those surrounding intellectual property issues  which could have a seriously negative impact on access to medicines  including on the production and export of affordable generic medicines from India.  94% of the medicines MSF uses to treat HIV  TB  malaria and other infectious diseases are generic medicines.

More than 200 families had to flee their homes and take refuge in the forest in the Ziralo area  South Kivu  Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) following heavy fighting between armed groups earlier this month.    On the day of the fighting in Bohole  Lea Nandundo  a 25-year-old mother of four children  had gone to work in the fields. When she came back  all the houses were on fire and the village was empty. “Fortunately  a neighbour had taken my children and I managed to find them later ” she says.  Now she is concerned about the future  “I lost everything: my house  the seeds for cultivation and my work tools ” she explains.  https://www.msf.org.uk/article/drc-msf-assists-victims-of-violence-in-south-kivu

To mark the day MSF staff and patients print their hands on a large white cloth that hangs in the waiting area of the clinic for the rest of the year.

“We lost everything we had in Afghanistan; I sold my house to find a way to escape my country. I lost my parents in Panjshir  I don’t have anything there.   "My kids were so scared when we had to cross the Aegean Sea  we were about to sink when the engine of the boat broke down and our boat crashed on the rocks  we were in the water. My little boy was so scared.  "In the night he is crying and here the conditions are so bad. We don’t have enough space and we are obliged to sleep on the ground.”   A portrait of 28-year-old Kamuluddin with his children Mirimo (2) and Omar (5 months) from Afghanistan at a registration centre in Tabanovce on the Serbia - Macedonia (FYROM) border.   © Alex Yallop/MSF

A young patient sits up in bed in the recovery ward of the MSF-run Khmer Hospital in Amran  Yemen  on 20 February 2016. She visited MSF hospital facilities in Amran and Haydan whilst also gathering stories from refugees seeking sanctuary in the relative safety of Amran.  ©Rawan Shaif

Five years after the start of the conflict in Syria  more than half of all Syrians have been forced to flee from their homes. Many have faced extreme difficulties leaving  and for those making the perilous journey across the Mediterranean  they are often greeted with razor wire fences and squalid refugee camps. We look back at the past five years of conflict  and the toll it has taken on the people of Syria: http://msf.me/1Roh6yU #withSyria

In the future  the doctors in areas like Ghouta will be considered the most famous in the world because of the extraordinary things they had to do. We spoke to a doctor working in Damascus as the Syrian conflict enters its sixth year. We stand #withSyria.

Jeanine at her home  in a camp for internally displaced people  near Goma  Democratic Republic of Congo.   "I’ve had a difficult life and I’ve known poverty. My mother raised me and my siblings on her own. My husband abandoned me because I had too many children; I have felt the bitterness of life..."  "One day I was at home in my village and heard mortar fire and bombs. Looking outside  I saw our neighbours fleeing. The whole village fled. Then we walked 24 hours to get here. That was four years ago."  "I go to bed thinking of my children. I think about what they will eat the next day. Every day I wake up early in the morning and look for work in the community. If you wake up too late  the work may already be taken."  "Every time I find a job  I invest lots of energy into doing well  so the boss will rehire me in the future. Sometimes I go to the nearby Virunga Park in search of firewood  which I can sell to others to make a living. Unfortunately  the area is very insecure and park rangers and rebels can be very violent against us women."  But I fight. I'm still standing!"  Picture © Sarah Vuilleumier

“We  against all the odds  used to manage in the Jungle. We were trying to adjust to our conditions 'til we could find a way to join our families in the UK. But even that - they took it from us.” Mohammad Ghannam was in the Calais Jungle the day it was razed to the ground. Read more: msf.me/1M2dRB1

“In general  young women are at greater risk of rape than older women.”  The issue of sexual violence involves every country and social class; it may occur within the family or broader community. But sexual violence increases with factors of poverty  during times of conflict  displacement and natural catastrophe  and it preys on the young.  Please share this story to help us speak out about the impact of sexual violence worldwide  as part of our International Women's Day special feature 'Breaking Down The Barriers to Sexual Violence Care'.  #SexualViolence #IWD2016 #Rape #RiskFactors #Poverty #Conflict #Displacement #Childhood  http://www.msf.org.au/international-womens-day-2016/sexual-violence/risk-factors/childhood

To provide the best quality of care to victims of sexual violence from the first moment of contact  Médecins Sans Frontières has defined an essential package comprising medical and psychological care  and medical certification. Our centres offer these essential services to all family and sexual violence victims in their first visit  in the one place. This means that integrated medical and psychosocial assistance is provided at the earliest opportunity in ‘one-stop’  so that victims of violence do not have to move back and forth between different service providers.   Please share this story to help us speak out about the impact of sexual violence worldwide  as part of our International Women's Day special feature 'Breaking Down The Barriers to Sexual Violence Care'.  #SexualViolence #IWD2016 #OneStopCare #MedicalHealth #MentalHealth   http://www.msf.org.au/international-womens-day-2016/sexual-violence/one-stop-care

Esteban knows hardship. As a child  he was sent to work long hours selling produce in Santo Domingo. Today  he's on our staff in the Dominican Republic  working to rebuild the struggling community where he grew up near the Haitian border through youth clubs.   These clubs  supported through child sponsorship  teach youth how to stop domestic violence  treat women right  avoid early marriage  and plan for their futures by staying in school. And Esteban infuses all of these programs with the values of God's Kingdom.   Working together  these clubs are helping their community be greater than the hardships they've faced for generations. Sponsorship has fostered transformation here since 1997  and today empowers a new generation of youth leaders.   Share God's love and invest in a child's future today. Sponsor a child in the Dominican Republic here: http://bit.ly/24qieLp #WVBloggers #GreaterTogether

As summer approaches  are you prepared for mosquito season? Highlighting #Zika this #WorldMalariaDay and what you need to know:
Commit to the Lord whatever you do  and he will establish your plans. –Proverbs 16:3

Blogger Funtastic Life will be joining us as our #WVBloggers depart for the #DomRep on Sunday to see firsthand how communities are working together to be greater than poverty! Read about why we're excited for this trip … and what we have planned:

Domestic violence  teen pregnancy  and early marriage can derail a girl’s future in the Dominican Republic. As our #WVBloggers prepare to visit the #DomRep next week  see how we're working to empower girls and their communities! #GreaterTogether

Our sponsorship communities help keep children happy  healthy  and safe  and resilient when disasters—like the #EcuadorEarthquake—strike. Join us today in supporting the children of Ecuador … Sponsor a child:
Whoever is happy will make others happy too. –Anne Frank. Share this photo to bring a smile to someone's day!

Children traumatized by the #EcuadorEarthquake will find their lives shaken long after the aftershocks end. To help them cope  we opened two children's activity centers yesterday  and a third today. As we provide shelter  water  food  and more  learn how you can help:

A native mother in Peru  Mariana deals with poverty and hunger as she works to provide for her daughter. "I will carry my daughter  always." See how our partnership with Gifts With A Cause helps mothers like Mariana and what is giving her a chance to prosper!
It takes a child to raise a village. It sounds backward but it's true! See how  along with four other ways that our child sponsorship program makes a positive  lasting impact:

Help now! Ecuador has declared a national state of emergency as aftershocks from yesterday's 7.8 magnitude earthquake continue. With more than 230 people killed  our staff are setting up shelters and preparing aid—support our relief response now:
Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful  committed citizens can change the world. Indeed  it is the only thing that ever has. –Margaret Mead. #GreaterTogether
After three straight days of deadly #JapanQuakes  and a 7.8 earthquake yesterday in #Ecuador  join us in prayer for all affected and be among the first responders here:

When you look around our world and see children cold and suffering in poverty  do you wonder  "What can I do?" Author Debbie Macomber does. See how she's bringing knitters together to make a tangible difference to help children! #GreaterTogether

All mothers want the same things for their children. Megan wonders: had her family not adopted Max from Guatemala  would another mom have chosen to sponsor him? Being a child sponsor to seven kids around the world  she is humbled to be an answer to prayer. This is her #GreaterTogether story of saying yes:

Happy birthday to a boy with an infectious smile  Akash from Bangladesh  who is turning 9 today! We are praying for a sponsor for Akash on his birthday. If you'd like to learn more  please send us a direct message (clicking the "Message" button in the banner above)  and we'll reply with a link to his video profile. Happy birthday  Akash!

Our staff writer in Malawi  Charles  knows hunger: he grew up during a drought and food crisis just like the one today. See why meeting 13-year-old Leonard and his siblings was unforgettable for Charles  and how both of their stories made a transformation toward hope. #GreaterTogether

These children in Cambodia were so excited to see their photo on Stephanie May Wilson's phone … imagine how much they would love receiving a letter from their sponsor! Help give hope to a child in need in Cambodia and be #GreaterTogether: http://m.worldvision.org/sponsor/search?country=Cambodia&campaign=3041210

Saoly's family used to live in debt and hunger: she and her seven siblings would fight over who got rice to eat that day. But families are greater when they work together and when they're empowered with God's love. Watch this family transform! #GreaterTogether

BREAKING: Tomorrow  the House of Representatives will vote on the Global Food Security Act  which will help fight hunger and malnutrition around the world. But the bill is not across the finish line yet! Join us today and urge your member of Congress to pass this critical bill to help save the lives of over 800 million people still suffering from chronic hunger. #no1hungry
“It's not complicated. Just love the one in front of you.” –Heidi Baker

In Cambodia  children present a "gratitude tree" to honor those who have made a difference in their lives. Bring your kids to your local Family Christian store between 11-2 today to make their own gratitude tree! And when you sponsor a child and help build a greater tomorrow  Family Christian will thank you with a $20 gift card. #GreaterTogether

Shhhh...it's a surprise! Efrasina is celebrating her 10th birthday today in Tanzania. We are hoping to find her a sponsor for her birthday. Might that sponsor be you? Please direct message us (use the "Message" button in the banner above) and we'll reply with instructions.
Can children escape poverty? We think so—with the support of child sponsorship  which helps families and communities grow #GreaterTogether. Read the Spring edition of our Magazine to learn more.

22 years ago today began Rwanda's 100-day genocide that left 800 000 dead. But afterward  women like Jacqueline were able to rise from the ashes. See how communities in Rwanda are #GreaterTogether: guest blog by our writer Kari Costanza at ClaireDiazOrtiz!

Fatuma poses in her grocery store with Athumani  her son who is sponsored in Tanzania. Micro loans have empowered Fatuma to improve her business. Her hope? To build a house for her family! Empowerment is the foundation of communities growing #GreaterTogether.

An idea that began in a rice field in Tanzania is today building resilient livelihoods for farmers across five African countries and empowering their families to grow #GreaterTogether … through forgiveness. See how this innovative program provides hope:
Yet I will rejoice in the Lord  I will be joyful in God my Savior. –Habakkuk 3:18 (NIV)

Working together  we can be greater than hunger. Farmers in Tanzania used to face "a recipe for ruin": unpredictable rain  destructive values  and soul-crushing poverty. But today  their future is secure. See how an innovative program reversed this course … to plenty and dignity. #GreaterTogether

Soccer fans: Mamadou is celebrating his 11th birthday today in Mali  where soccer is really big! You can help him fulfill his dreams by becoming his sponsor on his birthday. Simply message us privately (by clicking the "Message" button in the banner image above) and we'll send a customized link to his video profile.

Mohamed (left) is an aspiring money manager and investor … and he's only five! See how his ambitious children's savings group is helping the economy in Sierra Leone recover after #Ebola  and helping the group's members prepare for their future. #GreaterTogether

During the Ebola outbreak  not one of our 58 000 sponsored children in Sierra Leone contracted the disease. See how we're bringing hope to children in their long-term recovery  and through their eyes experience what 11-year-old Millicent calls "the best day of my life." #GreaterTogether

Step 3 of the Year of Getting to Know Your Sponsored Child is writing your first letter! "One of the best parts about child sponsorship is the ability to communicate with your sponsored child." See why your letters are the most heartwarming part of sponsorship…

We're heartbroken over the events of the past week in #Brussels  #Pakistan  and more. As we continue to reflect on the promise of Jesus during this #Easter season  join us in prayer that the Prince of Peace would enter into these horrific situations and bring the healing and reconciliation that only He can provide.

Alima and 3-year-old Samuel know what #Ebola feels like. They both survived it. Now  Alima cares for orphans of the disease  like Samuel  and worries about their future. See how Alima and the people of Sierra Leone were greater than this sickness  and today are moving forward. #GreaterTogether

But Christ has indeed been raised from the dead  the firstfruits of those who have fallen asleep. (1 Corinthians 15:20) Photo: A new morning dawns over Huanta  Peru. Happy #Easter! He is risen indeed!

Jesus knew firsthand what it was like to be persecuted. He could have put a stop to it  at any point  but He chose Good Friday .. for our sake! "After he has suffered " says the prophet Isaiah  "he will see the light of life and be satisfied ... and he will bear their iniquities."  Thanks be to God for his indescribable gift! Have a blessed #Easter!

When we join in with others  hope rises from ashes and the beauty of God’s Kingdom intensifies. A #GoodFriday reflection from Benjamin L. Corey: how Jesus was greater than the suffering in our world … and how we're invited to follow in his footsteps. #GreaterTogether

The light shines in the darkness  and the darkness has not overcome it. –John 1:5. Even at the darkest of times  there can be hope. Through the eyes of our videographer  experience the darkness of the 1994 #Rwanda genocide … and his return to hope. #HolyWeek #GoodFriday

Our goal is for everyone to have access to clean water in every community where we work by 2030. But is this really possible? This #WorldWaterDay  see why we believe that we can achieve this goal … together. #GreaterTogether #WaterNow

Every Share of this video is a promise: that you will #PrayforRefugees of the Syria crisis. Let's not only raise awareness … let us make change. "Be the Content" — a spoken-word performance by Christian Paige - Keynote Speaker. #WorldPoetryDay

They took palm branches and went out to meet him  shouting  'Hosanna! Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord!' 'Blessed is the king of Israel!'” (John 12:13). Happy #PalmSunday!

Peace in Rwanda is something of a miracle after the 1994 genocide. Now  the people are #GreaterTogether with each other  World Vision  and God's love. See how this story of peace and reconciliation gives us hope for the people of Syria in crisis today.

World Vision relief worker Antoine Rutayishiri speaks with a 5-year-old boy who fled 100 miles through jungle and rough road after his family was massacred in the 1994 Rwanda genocide. We helped in his recovery  and during the past 22 years have worked to promote peacebuilding and reconciliation in Rwanda.

Today marks the fifth anniversary of the Syrian Refugee Crisis. It's big  bigger than any one of us. And that's why we pray: because together  with God  we can accomplish anything. Join us in action on behalf of refugees … Join us in prayer. #PrayforRefugees #Syria5Years

In the midst of the Vietnam conflict in the 1970's  Kim—an orphan of the war—received care from World Vision staff that helped her find a better future. Now a mother with three children of her own  Kim sponsors six children because she knows that sponsorship  together with God’s help  is greater than the challenges that keep every child from a full life.
A friend loves at all times  and a brother is born for a time of adversity. –Proverbs 17:17

Syria is crying for her children. Her children were her candles  and they have faded out.” From the song 10-year-old Haya sang to our president  Richard Stearns. Read her story and more about the refugee crisis in Rich's free ebook:
worldvision,2016-03-12T22:04:00+0000,1084562,108970206976_10153771155491977,1757,244,29,photo,Our desire is that children everywhere would experience fullness of life!
