Prayer Point: Army Specialist Justin Lloyd worked as an X-ray technician in Baghdad during the Iraq war and became accustomed to the random rockets lobbed by insurgents into the Green Zone. Typically they caused no major damage  but on April 10  2007  a mortar hit the trailer where he was working  right outside the hospital’s main gate. The attack sent him flying off his chair and through a plywood door. “It was the wrong place  wrong time ” he said. The blast injured Justin’s brain  and his left leg sustained severe nerve damage  which continues to cause him constant pain. Today he uses a wheelchair  sometimes a cane. Because of his mobility issues  as well as social anxiety caused by post-traumatic stress disorder  he rarely goes out. On top of that  Justin suffered a stroke on Mother’s Day 2014. When he and his wife Christina were accepted for a week of Bible-based marriage enrichment training in Alaska with our Operation Heal Our Patriots ministry  the couple felt it would stretch Justin out of his post-injury comfort zone. Their thinking proved correct  and the experience—bonding with his wife  nine other couples  and our staff—did push Justin in a good way. “This was a big personal step to come up here ” he said. Physically  he engaged by participating in outdoor activities. Emotionally  he connected with Christina  and they recommitted themselves to their marriage vows. Spiritually  the Lord touched his heart through the teaching from our chaplains. Most important  he rejoiced to see Christina receive Jesus Christ as her Lord and Savior and get baptized under the waters of Lake Clark. “It was something that I wanted for her  but I didn’t know how to go about it ” he said. “I gave myself to the Lord on this trip ” Christina said. “It’s been great for our marriage.”   Please pray for Justin  Christina  and their three children to grow together in the Christian faith. Prayer Point: Six-year-old Miracle walks by faith  not by sight. Though born blind  she was nonetheless a miracle to her mother  who previously suffered three miscarriages. Miracle lives in a crowded house with her aunt and 13 cousins in an impoverished neighborhood of Belize City  the largest town in the tiny Central American nation of Belize. She clutched the arm of her 12-year-old cousin Primalee as they walked into an unfinished concrete-block building that serves as a youth outreach ministry center for Calvary Baptist Church. The church stands on a street corner that divides rival gangs and used to be a Muslim prayer center for Asian merchants in Belize. Miracle and Primalee were among the 200 neighborhood children who flocked to the church to hear the Gospel message presented by local musicians  a red-nosed clown named Ozzie  and an evangelist who explained to them why we all need a Savior. Then each boy and girl received a gift filled Operation Christmas Child shoebox. Miracle sees through her fingertips. She learned to read Braille at age four and is one of the top students in her class. When she recognized the voice of Ozzie the Clown  a local TV personality  she insisted on touching his nose. When she opened her shoebox  she enjoyed her gifts her own special way—the cuddly softness of a baby doll  the fascinating shape of a spiral straw  the sweet taste of hard candy  and the fresh waxy smell of new crayons. And when the evangelist presented the invitation  Miracle and Primalee were among the children who stood with their heads bowed  eyes closed  and hands folded in prayer to accept Jesus Christ as their Lord and Savior. “But to all who did receive him  who believed in his name  he gave the right to become children of God” (John 1:12  ESV).  Please pray for precious children like Miracle to know God’s sustaining love in their lives. For Belize to be transformed through a generation of children who have heard the Gospel as they received shoebox gifts. For the worldwide ministry of Operation Christmas Child  which has reached millions of children in more than 100 countries with the true meaning of Christmas.

Prayer Point: Juanita was orphaned at a young age  leaving her feeling alone. As an adult  she found companionship in the man who became her husband. After 17 years of marriage and three children  she gave birth to another child  Thiago. To Juanita’s dismay  he was born with a congenital heart defect. The challenge of his medical condition caused her to feel alone again in her struggles. Eventually  Juanita brought Thiago to the Children's Heart Project office in La Paz  where he was accepted for surgery in Canada. Juanita had to leave her family to undertake a long journey to try to save Thiago’s life. What she didn’t know was that amidst this season of suffering  pain  and fear  she was experiencing the love of a parent she had never known  her Heavenly Father. Through the interpreter who traveled with them from Bolivia  Juanita heard the Good News of Jesus Christ. The Spirit of God touched her heart  and she recognized her need for a Savior. She began to feel a surprising embrace. Through her Canadian host family and host church  she felt God’s love and He became more real in her life. “It was incredible receiving so much love and care from people who did not know me ” Juanita said. “I believe God Himself was demonstrating His love  using all of these people.” Thiago’s heart surgery was a success. Today  he is a healthy 3-yearold child who can talk  run  and jump. As for Juanita  she has a new eternal heart as well. Even though she continues to experience life’s difficulties  she is actively aware of God’s blessings in her life. Juanita regularly attends a local church and is active in a women’s Bible study. “I believe I am another person ” she said. “God has changed me. Now  I can laugh  and now I can love my children like God  my Father  loves me.”  Please pray That Thiago will continue to grow in health and will experience God’s love from his mother. That Juanita will “grow in the grace and knowledge of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ” (2 Peter 3:18). That other children who receive surgery through Children’s Heart Project—and  their families—will experience physical and spiritual healing.

PRAYER POINT: Two vital project completions in 2015 have the Alaska Bible Seminary poised not only for greater growth but  more importantly  for greater impact for the cause of Jesus Christ. Samaritan’s Purse contributed directly to one of those projects—and witnessed the other. More than 225 Samaritan’s Purse volunteers from around the United States teamed with local residents and worked throughout the summer to construct a new dormitory and administrative building  for the seminary. Equipped now with additional classrooms and dormitory space  even more men and women can receive training in God’s Word and be sent out to reach more Alaskans for the Savior. A dedication ceremony was held in Bethel on Oct. 16. Bethel is located on the tundra of southwestern Alaska  400 miles west of Anchorage. The new dormitory was dedicated in memory of Ruth Bell Graham  the late wife of Evangelist Billy Graham. Even though Mrs. Graham died in June 2007  her dedication to studying and obeying God’s Word is still making an impact for Christ nearly 5 000 miles away from where she lived in western North Carolina. The dedication plaque included one of her often attributed quotes: “Down through the years  I’ve turned to the Bible and found in it all I need.” “Ruth Bell Graham had such a strong history with Bible education  and it seemed only appropriate that we dedicate this new dormitory in her memory ” said Ed Dehnert  seminary president. Earlier in the year  Samaritan’s Purse leaders witnessed the dedication of the completely translated Bible in the Yupik language  indigenous to this region. “The Yupik people are very devout in their walk with Christ ” said Luther Harrison  Vice President for North American Ministries for Samaritan’s Purse. “Now they have the full Word of God. What an honor to witness what God is doing.”  Please pray that God will send the right students to the seminary for training in God’s Word. That more men  women and children throughout Alaska will be reached for Jesus—especially among those Native Alaskans who speak the Yupik language. That God will continue to lead Samaritan’s Purse with respect to Alaska building projects.

PRAYER NEED: The plight of refugees in Europe has become more desperate as Macedonia closed its border today with Greece. There are now around 35 000 men  women  and children stranded with no opportunity to continue their journey north  and thousands more continue to arrive daily. We have teams on the ground responding to meet the immediate needs.   Please pray for the refugees as the hope of a new life in Europe dwindles. Pray also for our staff members  as they continue to meet the physical and spiritual needs of the refugees trapped in what has been called  “warehouse of souls.” You can help meet immediate needs here: http://bit.ly/1LdiSGP

She is a feisty four-year-old who has inspired the photographer Giles Duley. “My spirit is free when I dance  I am in another world.”   Dance like nobody is watching... no matter how hard your circumstances. This photo  taken by our supporter Helena Christensen  is of Maribeth  41  who lives in Altos de La Florida in Colombia. She has four children and works as a cook and a traditional dance teacher.   Maribeth was displaced from her home in Choco when she was 7 years old  when armed guards shot and killed her mother and sister. She fled  never to return to her home town  explaining "I am too afraid and it has been too long”.  Altos de La Florida is an illegal settlement  which means there is no access to running water  schools or healthcare. We are working to have the settlements legalized  so services are provided to the community living there. Maribeth dreams of opening her own traditional choco restaurant in Bogota  and teaching children to dance like she does.   © UNHCR/Helena Christensen
Saoud has prostate cancer  and fled to Iraq from Syria  seeking treatment. Now his funds have run out.

On World Refugee Day  our High Commissioner is in Kabul to highlight the plight of one million displaced Afghans.   There are now 65.3 million displaced people on Earth. Afghans make up the the second largest refugee population in the world.  Afghanistan needs peace and development.   Its people need sympathy and support  wherever they are.  Today  stand #WithRefugees across the world.

"We must find humane and dignified means to ensure refugees don’t risk their lives and those of their families by resorting to ruthless traffickers or by boarding flimsy boats in a bid to reach safety." Carmen is a refugee from Colombia wants to inspire other women through her work. This is her story:  "I left my country  Colombia  because it was too dangerous. I couldn’t have raised my daughters in such a violent place. I found safety in Ecuador. I met a famous shoe designer there. Together  we created a gladiator sandal called ‘She loved me’. The name represents the struggle of the everyday woman who wants to improve her life.   I believe that if we love ourselves and believe in ourselves  we can improve not only our lives  but the lives of our children.”  Stand with Carmen. Stand #WithRefugees.

Iran hosts almost 1 million refugees from Afghanistan. On Friday our chief Filippo Grandi met some of them  and heard how if more refugees – especially young people - could receive training and employment  fewer would feel compelled to leave for Europe.
On a visit to Iran  our High Commissioner Filippo Grandi talks to Afghan refugee Saahebeh Vafaie  at the Imam Khomeini vocational training complex in the holy city of Qom.   © UNHCR/Morteza Nikoubazl

I’m following my dream of doing cancer research.”  Mojtaba only had elementary education when he fled the Taliban in Afghanistan at the age of 13. We believe all refugees like Mojtaba deserve to live in safety and have the opportunity to go to school. UNHCR,2016-06-15T21:50:19+0000,1150833,13204463437_10155118384583438,634,72,24,photo,“Refugee youth know best what we need… We need to be educated  and not just 'education' but a quality education.  These are the words of a young refugee from South Sudan  Simon Marot Touloung  who is attending the Global Refugee Youth Consultation which convenes in Geneva this weekend. Challenges faced by young refugees across the world - from access to education to personal safety. Full story: http://trib.al/tBjbvYr

Our Chief Filippo Grandi met 5 members of Olympic #TeamRefugees during his visit to Kenya and told them "All the refugees in the world are looking at you because you are their champions.  I think you have a responsibility then to show them that you can achieve great results  and that being a refugee does not make any difference. You are human beings like everybody else."  Rio 2016 #Rio2016

Baw Meh  77  fled Myanmar’s Kayah state in 1996 - 18 years later she still lives in Ban Mai Nai Soi refugee camp with three generations of her Karenni family.   “I carried the children and ran. They grew up as we ran  and they became adults in the camp. I hope they continue studying because I want them to be educated.”   Stand with Baw Meh  stand #WithRefugees - please sign our petition now.

I was very happy to hear the President say that any solution - and repatriation is obviously the best solution - has to be conducted in a way which is humane  dignified  and respects international law and principles  - Filippo Grandi  UN High Commissioner for Refugees  on his meeting with the President of Kenya.   Somali refugees need the world's support. Stand with them. Stand #WithRefugees.
“Resettlement can be an effective way of sharing responsibility for refugee protection - we must grasp this opportunity"  - Refugees Chief Filippo Grandi
“I want to go to America. I would do my exams and get good grades there.”  Solaf  a refugee from Syria  loves sports and dreams of becoming a doctor.   Please stand with Solaf. Stand #WithRefugees.

Of the nearly 20 million refugees under UNHCR’s care  half are children below the age of 18.  Yet only 50% of refugee children are enrolled in primary education. 25% are estimated to be in secondary school and just 1% have access to higher education.   Without education  an entire generation is at risk. By supporting UNHCR  you can help refugee children access quality education.  Please support if you can: http://trib.al/xUDRuFo

On his first visit to Kenya and Somalia as UN High Commissioner for Refugees  Filippo Grandi discussed solutions for Somali refugees in Kenya and received assurances that the return of refugees to Somalia would not contravene international obligations.  Following his meeting with Kenya President Uhuru Kenyatta  Grandi said: “I was very happy to hear the President say emphatically that any solution - and repatriation is obviously the best solution - has to be conducted in a manner that is humane  dignified  safe and respects international law and principles."  The visit comes as the Kenyan government announced plans to close the Dadaab Refugee Camp  home to nearly 350 000  mostly Somali  refugees. Kenya has been hosting the world’s largest refugee camp for a quarter century  and has consistently welcomed refugees from other conflicts  most recently from South Sudan.

Every year  400 000 desperate migrants from Central America pour across its borders.  Journalist AA Gill joins them on their perilous search for sanctuary  in a special report for The Sunday Times Magazine.

Thank you Europe for protecting these refugees.   Join us and stand #WithRefugees. You can help by sharing this video  made in partnership with the Mayor of Paris for #EURO2016  far and wide. http://www.unhcr.org/refugeeday

Our High Commissioner  Filippo Grandi  made his first visit to Somalia today where he met former refugees who had recently returned home  only to find their homecoming was very difficult.   "I spoke with a woman who said she has a house  she has a place to go back to but it was destroyed. I asked her if she was fixing it  but she said she is just rehabilitating it because she doesn’t have the means to do more  and she has seven children. Returns have to be sustainable - that means a house  but also health facilities  education and employment"  High Commissioner Grandi said.    14 000 refugees from the Dadaab Camp in Kenya have returned to Somalia over the last three years  but continued insecurity and lack of opportunities in the war-torn country have made it very difficult.  The High Commissioner’s visit comes as the Kenyan government announced plans to close Dadaab  the world’s largest refugee camp  which hosts nearly 350 000 refugees  most coming from Somalia.

On a visit to meet refugees in Greece  our Goodwill Ambassador Barbara Hendricks met Aaala  an eight year old boy who is struggling with severe disabilities.  Aaala's parents left Syria with their three young children because they could no longer get medical care for their eldest son. They carried them by foot  over land and sea  to Greece.  They are now living in Diavata Camp  near Thessaloniki for the last three months  seeking medical assistance for Aaala.
Home to thousands of refugees  this is an aerial view of a section of the Dadaab refugee camps in Kenya  where our High Commissioner is this weekend.  © UNHCR/Siegfried Modola

“My favourite player is Cristiano Ronaldo  because he’s the best and the fastest."  Ahmad  7  fled the war in Syria  and found refuge in Germany. A natural with the ball  Ahmad is watching #EURO2016 closely and dreams of becoming a professional footballer  just like his hero. “I’m fast too. My dream is to meet Ronaldo one day and play football with him.”  Thumbs up for Ahmad! Share his story here: http://trib.al/2BEFstS
“They took two of my kids  a son and daughter.”   Two years after 500 000 fled Mosul  Iraq  many are still displaced  suffering daily hardships and devastating memories: http://trib.al/bQFEWT5

Nobody wants to be a refugee. But to stop being a refugee  conditions must be there.   - Filippo Grandi  UN High Commissioner for Refugees  visited refugees in Dadaab  Kenya  on Friday. Many of the refugees he spoke with said that they would like to return home to Somalia  but that repatriation should be done in a dignified and humane manner. They also called for continued investment by the international community in the Dadaab refugee camps.  © UNHCR/Siegfried Modola

“I dream of becoming a lawyer. To help innocent people who are prosecuted for crimes they have not committed.”   16 year old Tinalbarka and her family fled violence in Mali. We believe all refugees like Tinalbarka deserve an education. If you agree  please sign the #WithRefugees petition to send a clear message to governments that they must work together and do their fair share for refugees.

#ThrowbackThursday to this 1981 photo of children playing in the Khao I Dang refugee camp in Thailand.   Today the camp  which was home to tens of thousands of Cambodian refugees for more than a decade  has been turned into an education centre on the response to the Indochinese refugee crisis.  “Although more than 30 years have passed  I’m still impressed by the support and commitment of the humanitarian response. I hope we can develop this place into an ecological tourist spot that can attract young people to learn about the refugee crisis”  local Governor Phakharathon Thianchai said.   Thailand has hosted more than 1 million refugees from the region since the mid-1970s. Some 106 000 Myanmar refugees are currently living in nine camps along the Thailand-Myanmar border.  Read the full story: http://trib.al/lRAZfsx
A Syrian girl attends a Ramadan event for refugees living in Jordan.

“I want to go to America. I would do my exams and get good grades there. I want to become a doctor and treat diabetes.”   Solaf is from the town of Bosra in southern Syria. She fled to Jordan in 2013  with her family  after their home was partially destroyed by a missile strike.  We believe Solaf and all refugees deserve to live in safety. If you agree  click the link below to sign the #WithRefugees petition  to send a clear message to governments that they must work together and do their fair share for refugees.  Stand with Solaf  stand #WithRefugees

Being in Za'atari reminded me that human nature is not just some force acting upon me  human nature is something we are creating together  as we decie how to treat each other  and the world we share.  New from our supporter and vlogger  John Green.

Full of beans after last class!   These Nigerian refugee children greeted us with joy  after we met them in Sayam Forage refugee camp  in south Niger. They escaped attacks by Boko Haram in their country. We work with partners to make sure the children continue to receive primary education  despite fleeing their homes. However  our work in this region is heavily underfunded  and we wish we could do more to support their schooling and psychological recovery.   They are among 2.4 million people displaced in the Lake Chad Basin area because of Boko Haram linked-violence.   Learn more: http://trib.al/Ay7EYfu More about the funding gap: http://trib.al/QHTVp24

Birth registration is changing the lives of indigenous people  like Virgnia  in Central America:  “I gave birth to all my children at home for fear of being deported. This caused my family a lot of problems in school. Now  UNHCR registered all of us  which means my daughter who needs leukaemia treatment can now access it.”   Virgnia is part of the indigenous Ngöbe Bugle people  who live a cross-border life in their ancestral territories straddling Costa Rica and Panama. Their traditional lifestyle contributes to their risk of becoming stateless  but a UNHCR supported project has helped clear their way to Costa Rican nationality and the benefits this brings – including access to school and health care.   Learn more about the project: http://trib.al/Vbe2pAS. Part of our #IBelong Campaign to End Statelessness by 2024.

Ramadan Kareem.  "Millions of men  women and children are observing the Holy Month amid fierce conflict  uprooted from their homes  and seeking basic safety and protection. My thoughts are with them  as well as the communities that so generously host them year after year."  Watch this Ramadan video message from our High Commissioner  Filippo Grandi.

We are proud to support refugees Rebecca  who is transgender  and her partner Francisco  in safety  together in Mexico.  The loving couple both risked their lives for their relationship. At home in El Salvador  Rebecca was shot and left for dead by gangs who targeted her because of her transgender status. Francisco was beaten and shot in the knee by his brother  the head of one El Salvador's brutally violent gangs  who refused to accept his relationship with Rebecca.   Ordered to leave the country or risk being killed  Francisco fled to Mexico  where he slept rough and often went for days without eating. Rebecca fled first to Guatemala and then Mexico. Francisco and Rebecca were reunited when she found him begging for food.   We granted them refugee status and they now live in accommodation we support.  Watch more stories from those fleeing Central America: http://trib.al/aPemfzw

I will be representing my people there at Rio. Maybe if I succeed I can come back to South Sudan  and conduct a race that can promote peace  and bring people together.”  Rose Nathike Lokonyen fled war in South Sudan when she was 10 years old. Then  during a school competition in a refugee camp in northern Kenya  a teacher suggested that she run a 10-kilometre race. Now she has qualified for #TeamRefugees and will compete in the 800 metres event at the Olympics this summer.  Meet the team: http://www.unhcr.org/news/latest/2016/6/575154624/10-refugees-compete-2016-olympics-rio.html#_ga=1.265703946.40566369.1444042791

UNHCR,2016-06-04T17:50:02+0000,1144354,13204463437_10155084457913438,959,153,21,photo,Hondurans  Salvadorans and Guatemalans  including families with young children  are making the long and dangerous journey to Mexico  often on foot and in extreme temperatures. They are fleeing escalating gang violence in their home countries  and seeking safety and protection in Mexico.  Our colleague Laura met with families in Mexico: “Central America is in the clutch of an epidemic of violence and it’s heart-breaking to hear so many stories of murder  abduction  rape and extortion. Even very young children are targeted for recruitment into gangs. That’s why an increasing number of families are left with no choice but to flee to Mexico to save their children’s lives.”   Learn more: http://trib.al/8oa1EpZ
UNHCR,2016-06-04T12:40:00+0000,1144354,13204463437_10155081780108438,377,121,9,video,I want to represent all the refugees of the world. I will compete to win a medal  to change my life. "My medal will be a medal of the refugees. Because I am on this team of refugees"  Meet the rest of the team: http://www.unhcr.org/news/latest/2016/6/575154624/10-refugees-compete-2016-olympics-rio.html
“Swimming is my life ” says Rami. “The swimming pool is my home."  He fled fighting in Syria and is now going to compete at the 2016 Olympic Games as part of #TeamRefugees

These 10 refugees have overcome adversity to be selected for the first-ever Refugee Olympic Athletes team  to compete at Rio 2016.  “I want to show my fellow refugees that they have a chance and a hope in life"  Visit our website to watch videos in which #TeamRefugees share their journeys of overcoming unimaginable hardships on their road to Rio - http://trib.al/Kq5hxQX

Congratulations #TeamRefugees! The first Refugee Olympic Athletes team was announced today by the International Olympic  Committee. They will compete at Rio 2016 this summer.  UN High Commissioner for Refugees Filippo Grandi said: “Their participation in the Olympics is a tribute to the courage and perseverance of all refugees in overcoming adversity and building a better future for themselves and their families. UNHCR stands with them and with all refugees.”  Meet #TeamRefugees and hear their stories - http://trib.al/QxA5LMf

'All I want is my son to be safe.' Griselda and two year-old Ernesto have fled gang violence in El Salvador.  Now safe in Mexico they had no choice but to run for their lives. At home  children and women face forced recruitment into criminal gangs  sexual- and gender-based violence and murder.  Although the United States remains the main country receiving asylum applications from El Salvador  Honduras and Guatemala  the number of asylum claims in other parts of the region —Mexico  Costa Rica  Belize— has also risen dramatically.   Ernesto’s story is not unusual - two out of every five persons receiving refugee protection in Mexico  are children.  Learn more about our campaign to help children: http://trib.al/gEfb8QR Read our Children on the Run report www.unhcr.org/en-us/children-on-the-run.html
You're never too young for football! Archive photo of a child refugee from Liberia playing in a Côte d'Ivoire transit camp  in 2003. #TBT
“We are the link between the community and the hospital - this is our duty"   When Ebola hit Liberia  refugee health workers took a frontline role - http://trib.al/854dPtu

Exhausted  but safe.   Hundreds of vulnerable people are fleeing brutal gang violence in Central America.  Over the next few days we’ll be sharing stories from some of those forced to flee - families and Lesbian  Gay  Bisexual  Transgender and Intesex people  who are at particular risk of violence.  We have called for urgent action to help people escaping violence which has surged to levels not seen since the region was wracked by armed conflicts in the 1980s.  Please follow and share these stories from Central America  over the coming days.  Learn more:  http://trib.al/hjkVBcB
Being born without legs hasn't stopped him. Meet the remarkable Belind.    His story: http://trib.al/rs3evzz
A horrifying number of lives lost during sea crossings in 2016.  http://trib.al/m0qXNpA
