A shy smile for the camera. This young Nigerian refugee is amongst 241 000 people who are displaced in Niger.     Many children remain traumatised by the violence they endured or witnessed when Boko Haram attacked their homes. As well as providing safe shelter and schooling  together with our partners  we offer some psycho-social activities to help them deal with the trauma. But the needs are great  and more programmes and qualified staff are needed to properly address the issue.   Learn more about the situation in Niger: http://trib.al/09ZEMQ7 Learn more about the funding gap: http://trib.al/0xKQbFt

“We lived in panic for bread. We couldn’t make any for three months. We ate dates and yogurt. We were able to eat that  thank God.”  Layla  a mother of three  managed to escape the besieged Iraqi city of Falluja where Government forces are battling ISIL militants for control. She has been moved to safety  and is now living in a camp for the displaced.  We are working with partners including Muslim Aid to register people and distribute emergency relief items to families.

Two Burundian refugees smile for the camera at our refugee camp in Nduta Kigoma district  Tanzania.  We care for 15 million refugees like these boys  but face a half a billion dollar deficit in paying for their shelter.   When people are forced to flee. You can help shelter them: http://trib.al/qjF9UZT  #iShelter
Refugees are often lumped together with migrants.  But they are different.  http://trib.al/QkjZP4B

We made these ourselves. We used socks  ribbons and buttons!”   Making hand-puppets was the activity of the day at our community development center in Koura  North Lebanon  last week.   At the center  Lebanese children and Syrian refugees play  learn and are entertained  this week by making puppets. We aim to build bonds between refugee and host communities  and raise awareness about key messages like education and hygiene.   Over half of Lebanon’s 1 million Syrian refugees are below the age of 18.
UNHCR,2016-05-27T17:54:12+0000,1140137,13204463437_10155061867488438,842,628,29,video,We are seriously concerned about sub-standard conditions at several sites in northern Greece where refugees and migrants were evacuated this week from the makeshift site at Idomeni.    Poor conditions at these sites are compounding the already high level of distress of refugee families  fuelling tensions within refugee populations and complicating efforts to provide assistance and protection”  our Melissa Fleming - UNHCR  said on Friday.   UNHCR will continue to support Greece to improve conditions.

Harrowing escapes.  Iraqi families are risking their lives fleeing besieged Falluja  where Government forces are battling ISIL militants for control. Running for their lives at night and on foot  survivors tell of hiding in irrigation pipes and fields.   We're supporting new arrivals with emergency aid and shelter: http://www.unhcr.org/news/stories/2016/5/574833264/unhcr-delivers-aid-iraqis-fleeing-falluja.html#_ga=1.268407307.40566369.1444042791

“It went completely against the sentiment of giving your old clothes to the poor  helpless new arrivals. It was more about just being young people here in Berlin  having that in common and making the best out of it.”  “We didn’t want to go down the classic route of giving ad-hoc aid  where refugees tend to end up getting stuck in this position of being helped. We wanted it to be an exchange between equals from the very start. We wanted to do more than waving at them in a train station and instead start helping shape their new lives here.”  Nina  from Start with a Friend Berlin  explains the approach of this German volunteer initiative  that matches asylum-seekers with local contacts to help them find their feet and start anew..   In just 18 months  Start with a Friend has matched 400 pairs. The simple premise of teaming up asylum seekers and refugees one-to-one with local partners has struck a chord in Germany  where efforts are being stepped up to integrate more than 1 million newcomers who sought asylum last year. In January  the project secured government funding and now employs seven full-time staff in four cities.  Learn more: http://trib.al/faw6ycY

Conflict in Libya is pushing refugees and migrants to seek other routes to safety. Lately  more boats are heading from Egypt to Italy.   Ali boarded one of them  after he and his wife fled the fighting in Yemen. Fearing for his children's safety  he left them behind with his sister in a safe place.   After 10 dangerous days at sea  Ali regrets crossing the Mediterranean and is glad he didn't risk his children's lives.

The first time I walked  I took a step and it was difficult  so was the second and third. I started wondering – is it always going to be to be difficult  or is it going to become easy? At the same time  I felt very happy  it was a beautiful thing. I felt like I was a child again  building myself and my body all over again.  Five months after Syrian nursing student Wisam  22  got married  a rocket landed on her house  shattering her spine and paralysing her from the waist down. Her family  and new husband had no choice but to rush her to the border for a life-saving operation in Jordan. She is now rehabilitating  undertaking intense and exhausting physiotherapy on a long but determined road to recovery.  "It's difficult to say the word disabled in our society. What does it mean to be disabled? It shouldn't be physically or mentally limiting. On the contrary  no matter how difficult it is  let the experience give you courage and strength."  Eventually  Wisam hopes to return home to her husband  and perhaps resume the nursing course she was forced to abandon when she left. “I want to live my life normally  without feeling sorry for myself or having other people pity me. I hope there is a future for me back in Syria – a different future than before  but a beautiful one.”  "I want to say to all young Syrians  to all the girls and boys  not matter how difficult the situation may seem  no matter how difficult their experiences may be. Never give up."  http://trib.al/tfGB1sk

Beautiful work by Malian refugee artists and craftspeople  as they acquire new skills to rebuild lives and livelihoods  in Burkina Faso.   "When I left Mali  the only personal belongings I brought with me were my practical knowledge and my hands. I want to make the most of this luggage: I want to ensure I can pay for my children to continue to go to school until they can get decent jobs. I want them to enjoy a safer life than mine."  We are pleased to be working with French social enterprise Afrika Tiss to help refugee artisans develop new products  using traditional materials including palm  wood  leather  metal and fabric. During the course  the artisans will develop new products  as well as productive  business and entrepreneurial techniques that will take into account their traditional way of life.  Learn more: http://trib.al/Easii9D

“Our lives matter. Otherwise  we won't be able to stand alongside the victims anymore."  Vincent Cochetel  Director of our Bureau for Europe  reflects on his harrowing experience as a hostage  and how the World Humanitarian Summit this month is a vital chance to find ways to better protect aid workers.

On this day in 1930  our first High Commissioner for Refugees  Fridtjof Nansen  passed away.   A famous polar explorer scientist and diplomat  Nansen was a visionary for refugee rights  directing the successful return of 450 000 prisoners of war to their homes after the First World War.    Nansen created the "Nansen Passport"  a revolutionary response to the lack of identity documents amongst hundreds of thousands of post-war refugees.   Following his crucial work to save millions of lives during the famine in Russia  Nansen was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1922.   An outspoken supporter of burden sharing amongst nations  Nansen believed states should do their fair share to find solutions for families forced to flee.   In his honour  UNHCR established the Nansen Refugee Award in 1954  to continue the legacy and recognise other heroes who are committed to improving the lives of refugees.   Learn more: http://www.unhcr.org/nansen

“I enjoy discovering what lies behind a magic trick  like Sherlock Holmes uncovering a mystery.”  Meet the Syrian refugee magic man – "Sherl Nazer" – named for his love of the famous Mr Holmes.  Magic is more than a hobby for Mohamad Al-Nazer  he practices for weeks before showing his tricks to enthralled spectators in Hungary. “I get ideas from YouTube. There was no YouTube in Syria  but here in Budapest there are magic shops and meetings for magicians.”  Mohamad works 10 hours a day  six days a week  in a mini supermarket. He spends his spare time practicing magic  and entertaining journey-weary new refugee arrivals.  His family fled Syria and were able to settle in Budapest because his father  physician Anas  first came to Hungary in Communist times as a medical student. Dr. Nazer  who speaks Hungarian and retained some ties from his student days  watched the situation deteriorating in Damascus and applied for Hungarian visas for himself  his wife Lelas and their five children.  “We were hoping that by some miracle we could stay in Syria ” Mohamad said. “But when a huge bomb exploded right by our house  we knew it was time to leave. All the windows were blown out and the building was shaking.”  “We are lucky. There were no arrests in our family and we did not lose anyone. Other Syrians have suffered much more and we are glad to help them.”  Last summer  at the height of the refugee influx  the phone kept ringing in the Nazer household  as fellow Syrians got in touch to say they were in Hungary. A number stayed temporarily with the family. Mohamad translated for the refugees  guided them and provided moments of light relief with his magical skills.   Mohamad will soon take up a place at Budapest Metropolitan University  to study animation  on a course partly sponsored by the Walt Disney Animation Studios.  Learn more about Mohamad and his magic touch: http://trib.al/Vo0naVM

We found humanity here. They provide everything we need. They are so helpful.  Free wifi  warm water  a dry bed and legal advice. We are working to help Syrian and Iraqi refugee families - like Nisrine's - move from poor conditions at Idomeni  Greece  to new  decent facilities we're supporting at Lagkadikia.

We appeal to Kenya to reconsider its decision to stop hosting refugees.  For almost a quarter of a century Kenya has played an extraordinary role in providing asylum to people forced to flee persecution and war. The safety of hundreds of thousands of Somalis  South Sudanese and others has hinged on Kenya’s generosity and its willingness to be a leading beacon in the East Africa region for international protection. Tragically  the situations in Somalia and South Sudan that cause people to flee are still unresolved today.  We recognise the many consequences that being a major refugee hosting nation has had for Kenya and its population  and we have been a prominent advocate for robust international support for the country.  The closure of Kenya's refugee camps could have potentially devastating consequences for 600 000 people. We appeal to the Government of Kenya to reconsider its decision and to avoid taking any action that might be at odds with its international obligations towards people needing sanctuary from danger and persecution.  Full story here: http://trib.al/OMgJIW6  Photo: aerial view of the world's largest refugee camp complex in Dadaab  Kenya  taken October  2011

Every day hundreds of lone children are forced to flee the violence in Honduras  El Salvador and Guatemala. They leave everything behind  risking danger as they cross borders in the hope of saving their lives and finding safety.  “I always liked going to school. I was going very well. I even got an honorable mention for having the best scores. But in Honduras  to go to school represents a risk as gangs are always behind you. " Ana  14  was forced to flee her home  despite doing well at school.  Children fleeing violence should be able to tell their stories and have continued access to asylum procedures in the United States. Urgent action is needed to make sure unaccompanied children and other vulnerable people receive the protection they need.  Watch this video by Acnur/Unhcr Américas which is part of their #NiñezRefugiada campaign  and click here to find out how we are helping unaccompanied child refugees in Central America: http://trib.al/UrFFfxR

Three weeks after the earthquake hit Ecuador on April 16th  our teams on the ground continue to work around the clock to help survivors in the worst-hit areas. Thanks to generous donations from people like you  we and our partners have delivered essential aid – including tents  kitchen sets and mosquito nets – to families who’ve lost everything  including many Colombian refugees.  Ecuador is the biggest refugee-hosting country in Latin America and currently hosts over 200 000 Colombian refugees. Many of them had settled in the earthquake-affected areas and are among the thousands who’ve lost their homes and now have to start over again.  Thank you for helping these families in their time of greatest need.

Abdullahi loves his school so much  he dreams of coming back one day to work there as a teacher.   A refugee from Somalia  he's one of 2 415 students at Central Primary School in Hagadera camp in Dadaab  Kenya.   We're working in all of Dadaab's education centers to make sure that young people like Abdullahi have access to learning. More than half of the 344 648 refugees in Dadaab are school-age children  but only 60% of them are currently enrolled in school. We want to make that 100%!  In the meantime we’re pleased to report that 245 students at Abdullahi’s school passed the Kenya Certificate for Primary Education exam in 2015 and graduated to one of Dadaab's seven secondary schools.  Follow us as over the next few days as we introduce you to schoolchildren in Dadaab and underscore the importance of their right to an education.

Join us over the next few days as we introduce you to schoolchildren at the Dadaab refugee camps in Kenya and share our work to enable their right to education.  “I am impressed with the refugee students  they are passionate about their study and performing well.”    Meet Louise  a teacher from Nairobi  and her daughter Joy.  Louise works hard to inspire her students each day at the Bullakheir primary school in Dadaab.  Dadaab is home to 344 648 refugees. We work with education partners to run the schools and ensure children get quality education. Altogether there are 35 pre-school centers  35 primary schools  7 secondary schools  4 vocational learning centers  3 adult literacy centers and 3 libraries! We also support the teachers  providing training in pupil-centered teaching methods which helps students’ participation in the learning process.    The schools in Dadaab are not like the ones in modern cities. Most of the school buildings are old  and in most cases classes are congested and the students have to share their textbooks. But despite the challenges  it's clear to see the passion and love for education shared by the refugee children.

We are pleased to announce the appointment of Cate Blanchett as a global Goodwill Ambassador.  "There has never been a more crucial time to stand with refugees and show solidarity ” said Cate. “We are living through an unprecedented crisis  and there must be shared responsibility worldwide.”    Our announcement comes as Cate returns from a mission to Jordan to meet people displaced by the conflict in Syria and witness the ongoing humanitarian operation to assist them.     In Jordan  Cate met Syrian refugees like Abu Mohammed and his family. She heard about the perilous journeys they had taken  and the challenges they face every day.    Cate described the world being at a “at a fork in the road” when it comes to responding to the needs of refugees. “As a mother  I want my children to go down the compassionate path ” she said. “There's much more opportunity  there's much more optimism and there is a solution down that path.”   Join Cate and support refugees - www.unhcr.org/cate

Time to go home! Big smiles from Sidahmed while he waited for his parents to check in for their flight to Mogadishu.   After spending six years in Kenya's Dadaab refugee camp  Sidahmed’s family have decided to return to Somalia to rebuild their lives .   Voluntary returns to Somalia  from Dadaab  have been increasing since we began supporting them in December 2014. Sidahmed's family are some of 13 800 Somali refugees returned so far. To help them establish new lives  we provide cash grants  essential household items  food and other community-based support programs.
We are lucky to have a beautiful new mural on our wall in Beirut  Lebanon!  Last weekend  Syrian artist Diala Brisly  and refugee children worked to bring a splash of colour to all our lives:

We have our own tent but it gets wet. The UNHCR tent looks like it won't get wet  because it's built more like a house.  Paola's two storey family home in Pernales  Ecuador  was destroyed in the April 17h earthquake. A tent won't replace the family home  but it provides the shelter they need now  while they begin to think about how to rebuild their lives.  We are reaching affected communities across Ecuador. Please support if you can:  http://donate.unhcr.org/int-en/ecuador-earthquake

“I dream of the day when we go back to our home  I wish it would come soon.”   When Ali was 9 years old his family were forced to flee their home in Homs  Syria. Now at 13  he still lives in Homs  but he misses his old life in the city:   “I go to school every day with my friends  I’m happy with them  we have a lot of fun together  but still I miss my old school and neighborhood. I had good times there.”   Ali's family fled fighting in Homs' Al-Khaldiea neighborhood  moving first to a collective shelter  and now to a rented house in Baba Amr neighborhood. Babr Amr was once home to 80 000 people. Now 3 000  like Ali  from across Homs and all of Syria are trying to rebuild their lives there.

In Chamanga  Ecuador over half the population lost their homes in the April 17th earthquake.  We are there and our priority is providing shelter to survivors - a temporary home  but a crucial first step on the road to recovery.

Carrying the The Olympic Games torch for refugees everywhere. Please watch and share this special moment from yesterday in Athens  when Syrian refugee Ibrahim helped the torch on its road to Rio 2016.  Yesterday  Ibrahim's dream came true  and for the first time this summer  a refugee team will compete under the Olympic flag.  Learn more: http://www.unhcr.org/571fb1c56.html

Congratulations Ibrahim! What a moment in Athens this evening  as the inspiring Syrian athlete became the first refugee to ever carry the The Olympic Games torch. He represented refugees everywhere  as he took part in the official relay to Rio 2016!  "I've arrived. Twenty-two years I've been an athlete and today I've reached my dream of being part of the Olympics. ...It is my honor to hold the torch  it is truly an honor."    The gesture showed solidarity with the world's refugees at a time when millions are fleeing war and persecution worldwide  and was a proud moment for the 27-year-old refugee and athlete  who resumed swimming and basketball last year in Greece after his promising sports career in Syria was cut short by war -- and a 2012 bombing that amputated his right leg below the knee. Ibrahim now walks with a prosthetic.  Hundreds of refugees gathered around Ibrahim as he walked with the flame held high through Eleonas  the Athens center which houses some 1 500 asylum-seekers. Ibrahim smiled even as he was mobbed by media cameras and refugees taking selfies on their smartphones.    Learn more: http://www.unhcr.org/571fb1c56.html  Photos: UNHCR/A.Zavallis
LIVE now: Refugee athlete Ibrahim is about to carry the Olympic torch in Athens  on behalf of all refugees  as part of its journey to Rio. Watch now
Q&A with president of the Hellenic Olympic Committee Mr. Spyros Kapralos  who will hand over the Olympic flame to Syrian refugee athlete Ibrahim. Join us now!
Q&A with refugee athlete Ibrahim  who will carry the Olympic flame in Athens this evening. Join us now!

Join us live for a big moment in Athens later today. Refugee athlete Ibrahim will carry the The Olympic Games torch - for refugees everywhere - as part of its relay journey to Rio 2016. Watch live at around 7pm (Athens time) today!

One year on determined Nepal quake survivors are rebuilding their homes and lives.  Unfortunately many families  like these residents of Baramchi and Jhankridanda villages  still live in temporary shelters built with salvaged materials and tarpaulins distributed in the weeks after the quake.  We have focused our help on shelter - tarpaulins  rebuilding kits  solar lamps  blankets - and education - supporting 175 temporary schools.  Learn more: http://www.unhcr.org/571dc9f86.html

One year after violence erupted in Burundi  250 000+ people like Suzana cannot go home  and more flee new atrocities daily.  Our Burundi appeal is only 27% funded  meaning we are struggling to provide even the basics such as shelter  and latrines. Counselling  disabled and elderly care  environmental protection and even primary health care may also fall by the way side.  Learn more: http://www.unhcr.org/5719f0119.html

Try to fulfil your dreams  because you came to a country where you can. Come here with an open mind and try to utilize all the opportunities you can get. It is going to be a struggle  but it's a struggle wherever you are in the world.  Somali-Swedish dentist Amal  once herself a refugee  gives this advice to new refugee arrivals in Norway.   When Amal fled to Scandinavia in 1991 with her family  they hoped it would be just a brief stay in Sweden until the civil war in Somalia was over. However  the fighting in east Africa continues  causing a new exodus to northern Europe.    Amal is happy to help patients who  like herself  have refugee backgrounds. Some seeking care at her practice in Norway have low incomes and have never visited a dentist before  she does her best to make them feel at ease.  "I have days when I feel I'm making a difference  and others when I am drained " Amal said. "But the patients give me back so much. They teach me about Africa and the Middle East  they give me a glimpse of how their lives used to be. Then you remember we have something special in common – we all came from other countries  we all had other lives before we came here."  Read more: http://www.unhcr.org/56d82b286.html

Our colleagues in Ecuador are currently distributing aid to communities affected by last Saturday's earthquake.   Ecuador is Latin America's biggest refugee hosting country  sheltering 200 000 Colombian refugees. We are working hard to reach and support locals and refugees alike  in the most-affected communities.  Learn more and support if you can: http://donate.unhcr.org/int-en/ecuador-earthquake

“I am carrying the flame for myself  but also for refugees everywhere  for Syrians  for Greece  for sports.”  Syrian refugee athlete Ibrahim  who lost part of his leg in Syria's war  has been chosen to carry the The Olympic Games' torch through an Athens refugee site on Tuesday.  Ibrahim was selected to take part in the Olympic torch relay  on behalf of refugees worldwide  as part of it's journey to the Rio 2016 Olympics.  “It is an honor. Imagine achieving one of your biggest dreams. Imagine that your dream of more than 20 years is becoming a reality.”  The 27-year-old once dreamed of competing in the Olympics himself  but the war interrupted his plans - whilst helping a friend after a bombing  Ibrahim lost part of one leg.  Since arriving in Greece  Ibrahim has worked to rebuild his life. He swims three days per week and is also part of a wheelchair basketball team that meets five times per week  and travels across the country for competitions. Ibrahim does all this despite working 10-hour overnight shifts at a cafe.  “It’s not just a game for me ” Ibrahim says of his training schedule. “It’s my life.”  His coach Eleni told us: “He has not let anything stop him—not the war  not losing his leg. He’s been an athlete his whole life. Now  he’s back on track.”  Learn more about Ibrahim: http://tracks.unhcr.org/2016/04/bearing-the-olympic-torch/

We have airlifted aid to Ecuador and are distributing it to earthquake hit communities  to support local and refugee populations. Ecuador has the largest refugee population in Latin America  generously welcoming over 200 000 Colombian refugees and others in need  many of whom were settled in the earthquake-affected areas.  Learn more: http://www.unhcr.org/5717e80b6.html  Support us if you can: http://donate.unhcr.org/int-en/ecuador-earthquake

As many as 500 people are feared dead after a ship capsized between Libya and Italy. We spoke to some of the 41 survivors. Please read  and share our continued call for regular pathways to access asylum in Europe.  http://trib.al/JDk8tMZ

Time is running out to nominate your unsung hero! www.unhcr.org/nansen   Sister Angelique was honoured with the Nansen Refugee Award in 2013  for her courageous work – spending years supporting women to recover from sexual abuse and suffering in the Democratic Republic of Congo.   Since being awarded with one of the world’s top humanitarian prizes  Sister Angelique invested the Nansen Refugee Award prize money into a cooperative bakery  which opened in June 2015. Women who have been displaced and abused are employed in the bakery  earning a small income to support themselves.   Sister Angelique reflects the characteristics of Nansen laureates: courageous  determined  inspirational and will stop at nothing to support and protect those displaced by war and conflict.     Who is your 2016 Nansen Award winner? Nominate by 25 April: www.unhcr.org/nansen

Eunice fled her home just days after giving birth. She is among 2.3 million South Sudanese  spread across 7 countries  who still can’t go home.  Our funding appeal for South Sudan is at just 11%  meaning life-saving services are threatened. We’re extremely concerned as the numbers fleeing and in need  is increasing.  Learn more: http://www.unhcr.org/571634ac9.html

On their way to class in Turkey - Syrian students Dua  Geyda and Raanya are grabbing opportunity with both hands. They are part of a German-funded scholarship programme  offering young refugees higher education in their host countries.  We met the students at the picturesque campus of Harran University in Sanliurfa  south-eastern Turkey  where they are studying public administration  economics and food engineering respectively. The scholarship programme  known as DAFI  funds 75 scholars in Turkey  of whom 70 are Syrian.   Raanya  19  fled Syria three years ago. She told us: "If there was no scholarship  my family would not have been able to afford an education for me. I want to be able to go back to Syria when I graduate and work as a professional in food and nutrition. I want to be able to contribute to the health of my country."  Learn more about the students: www.unhcr.org/5702722a6.html

“All refugee women have to take courage. We are doing well  but I encourage us to do more. We are growing  and we need to improve so we can have our dreams. As women we must always be the head  not the tail. A woman has to stand up for her herself and be able to ‘catch the fish’. You see  if you always give a woman the fish  she will never learn how to catch it."  Meet the inspirational Irene  a refugee from Côte d’Ivoire who trains other refugee women in Liberia  in tailoring  hairdressing and pedicures  so they can have their own livelihoods.   "I always look out for these women. I try to place all the graduates in shops so they can practice and start working. It is not easy for a refugee woman to start over by herself; I know that pain. This is why I train them so they can stand up for themselves."   After fleeing violence at home  at just 13 years old  Irene has established a new life. As part of our work to empower refugee women to be-come self-reliant  we funded her new training centre. There  since 2011  Irene has used it as a base to change many lives.   “I have moved my training centre plenty of times. I always have problems with landlords who kick me out even before the contract ends. It’s always a different story; they think that because I am a foreigner and a woman that I am weak. But I don’t let this put me down  I will keep training these women"

Nominate someone you know helping refugees now! www.unhcr.org/nansen  Last year we honoured Aqeela Asifi with the Nansen Refugee Award for her brave and selfless campaign to open schools for Afghan refugee girls in the Kot Chandana refugee camp in Pakistan. Aqeela is an Afghan refugee  teaching in one of the toughest environments you can imagine – a desolate refugee village in Pakistan. She’s given the gift of education to hundreds of young Afghan refugee girls who had previously been denied it. Thanks to her  their lives have been completely transformed. She is a true hero and is now planning her project with Nansen prize money  to help impact the lives of even more refugee girls.   Now we are on the search for the next unsung hero. Do you know an individual or group who are courageous  heroic and going above the call of duty and undertaking work that is having a huge impact on the lives of refugees  internally displaced or stateless people? Then nominate them!   You have until 25th April to nominate your unsung hero:  www.unhcr.org/nansen  #NansenAward

Generous shopkeeper Abu Yacoub has become a lifeline to many of the Syrians living in the Bekaa Valley. They come to him for rice  flour  bread and sugar - very few can afford to pay  yet he still gives them what he can.  http://tracks.unhcr.org/2016/04/a-shopkeeper-and-a-lifeline/

After competing for Somalia in the 2008 Beijing Olympics  athlete Samia was determined to return to the track at the 2012 London Games. Her story is one of ambition and drive  and the refusal to accept that poverty  repression  threats and violence cannot be overcome.  Sadly  there is no happy ending to this remarkable young woman’s quest for Olympic glory. Samia’s story ends with her death at sea  trying in vain to reach safety in Europe after receiving threats from al-Shabab in Somalia.  In his book  An Olympic Dream  the award-winning German graphic artist Reinhard Kleist  traces the last years of the Somali sprinter’s life. Learn more: http://tracks.unhcr.org/2016/04/an-olympic-dream-shattered/  We have pushed for an increase in safe  orderly ways for refugees to access protection in Europe under managed programmes – such as humanitarian admission programmes  private sponsorships  family reunion  student scholarships and labour mobility schemes – so that refugees do not resort to smugglers and traffickers to reach safety.

“When I got to sixth grade  I started hearing about girls as young as 12 or 13 getting married. They would come to the school to say goodbye. I remember thinking they were making a big mistake  even before I knew the facts. Girls from my home have their future lost or destroyed  this is something I can't accept. I have to fight for women's rights"  Fighting early marriage amongst Syrian refugees  meet the passionate Omaima. In Jordan's Za'atari Camp  the 15-year-old Syrian works tirelessly as an outreach volunteer  running workshops where through drawing and acting she educates young refugees and their parents  about the risks of marrying too young.  For herself  she says she looks forward to getting married one day. “But only on my terms  after I’ve finished my education and been to university. And hopefully when I do get married  I won’t be living in Za’atari anymore.”  Learn about Omaima and our work to prevent early marriage: http://trib.al/vCX7rqb  In pre-war Syria  an average of 13% of all marriages involved someone below the age of 18. Among Syrian refugees living in Jordan  this rate had risen to 32% by the first quarter of 2014.  Working in cooperation with the local Shari’a judge based in Za’atari camp  we provide early marriage counselling to all individuals intending to marry before turning 18. Such counselling is designed to raise awareness of the risks of early marriage  including the health dangers posed by early pregnancy.  If there is any evidence that the child is under 15 years old  or that the marriage is forced  we provide extensive counselling to families on the legal  health and psychological consequences in cooperation with the government’s Family Protection Unit  which will seek to prevent such marriages taking place.

They call her 'Mama'  and Panagiota  82  says refugees are her family now.   The Greek villager hosts 5 refugees in her house in Idomeni  and more visit each day. She welcomes them warmly with home-cooked food  hot showers - and limitless grandma hugs.   "I have company in the house  I talk… we laugh… even though we can't understand each other.'
We are very worried about use of teargas against refugees at Eidomeni on Greece’s northern border. Read the latest: http://trib.al/kdkbna7

Syrian sisters Maria and Jinan are celebrating one year of refuge in Wellington  New Zealand.  Maria's interests mean she is known as 'the little engineer' meanwhile Jinan wants to become a dancer. After a year of safety and welcome in New Zealand  their parents can begin to hope their children's dreams will come true.  In March 2015  we resettled Maria and Jinan  their brother and parents under New Zealand’s refugee intake program. After escaping the conflict in Syria in 2012  they are now happy to be an ‘ordinary’ family again  learning English  going to school  and playing freely outside.  Before the war  mom Mirvat and her husband Nazeh lived with their children Ahmed  10  Maria  9  and Jinan  6  in a residential suburb south of Damascus. Mirvat had taught for 16 years and Nazeh was a journalist and entrepreneur. The family owned three prosperous businesses: a barber shop  an interior decorating company  and part of a bus garage. “We had a perfect life ” Mirvat says.  But as  Syria's the conflict escalated  the family's suburb became an area of intense fighting. Reluctant to leave their home  the family tried to temporarily move to another part of Syria  returning a month later disappointed to discover it had only gotten worse. Recalling the heartbreaking decision to leave Syria due to their fear for the safety and future of their children  Nazeh says  “you cannot stop and think  there is no time to think  you have to move.”  Mirvat is especially thankful for the welcome her family has received from the community and particularly the local school. She would love to continue her career teaching Arabic and is just happy to be in a peaceful environment where her children can feel safe. “If [a country] has 40 million sheep  then it has to be safe ” she laughs.  Read more of their story: http://unhcr.org.au/news/one-year-wellington/  Photo: New Zealand Red Cross

Jack is a busy man. Elected refugee leader just five days ago in Tham Hin camp  Thailand  he has his work cut out for him as he now represents almost 8 000 refugees in this orderly camp on the Thai Myanmar border.   Things work well here with three primary schools  a secondary school and a junior technical college. But there are still challenges like making sure teenage girls stay in school. Best of luck with the new job  Jack!  Photos: UNHCR/A.Needham

The warmest of welcomes to Canada. Syrian refugees Mohammad and Sahar found a second chance for their young family – thanks to five Canadian couples who have privately sponsored their resettlement to British Columbia.  The sponsors  approved by the Canadian Government  take on the costs and obligations that go with resettling the family. They also offer friendship.  Learn more: http://tracks.unhcr.org/2016/04/the-kindness-of-strangers/

Sometimes ordinary people do extraordinary things.   For refugees escaping violence and conflict  the compassion of strangers can be a lifeline.  We want to recognize the brave people who went beyond the call of duty in 2015.  The life-savers  the teachers  the medics  the local communities  the charities – the people who made it their mission to stand up for refugees.   UNHCR is opening up nominations for the #NansenAward for an additional three week period. Nominate your refugee heroes by 25 April 2016 at unhcr.org/nansen.

Large-scale violence is forcing thousands  like Juan  Diana and Ana*  to flee their homes in Central America. We are calling for urgent action as asylum claims soar. Learn more: http://trib.al/ycmrqGX  *Names changed for protection reasons.

Three hours too late. Syrian father and son Monzir and Yusef have reached Greece  but their boat landed after the new EU-Turkey deal took effect  meaning they find themselves behind fences topped with coils of razor-wire in Moria  a detention facility where they await a possible return to Turkey.   "In Syria I was a prisoner of the war. I escaped so I can be free  but now again  I’m in jail. Even if they only give me a tent on a mountain  I just want to live with my kids in peace.”   UNHCR are not party to the EU-Turkey deal under which all new arrivals are being kept in detention until their asylum claims are assessed. Learn more about Monzir's journey and the deal: http://www.unhcr.org/5702505b6.html

I was really competitive; I always wanted to be first. No time to play. I had to be focused. As a young girl I have to be educated.  Congratulations Aiwon! This ambitious and determined young woman cannot believe the news she has just heard - she has won a scholarship to study medicine and become a doctor.   A refugee from Côte d'Ivoire  living in Liberia  Aiwon has realised a dream that proves impossible for too many young refugees - to access higher education.  Aiwon says she knew that as a refugee girl  education was the most important thing to ensure a better future.   We wish Aiwon the best of luck  and we are sure her drive and ambition will take her far.

“I love being in Brazil. I’m so happy to be here. I have my friends and my teacher is the best.” - Hanan  12.  Hanan is one of 2 100 Syrian refugees who have sought safety in Brazil. After four years of war and flight  her family are working hard to start over in São Paulo. Quick to learn Portuguese fluently  Hanan carries a great deal of responsibility  helping with daily tasks like shopping and bill-paying  for older family members who are not yet as fluent.  Brazil has recently extended their “open-door” policy of special visas for Syrians  to give more of those fleeing war a chance to rebuild their lives.   “You turn back into a human being when you arrive in Brazil  I’ve never felt so good" Hanan's Dad Khaled told us. The whole family say they love Brazil and plan on settling for good  since they do not see an end in sight for the war in Syria.  Read the family's story: http://trib.al/0QSu8sA

A  B  C  D  E  F... Samina is working hard to learn English and wants to be a teacher when she grows up.  An Afghan refugee in Kot Chandana refugee village  Pakistan  Samina has been lucky to learn from a very inspiring teacher - Aqeela Asifi.  Aqeela  a refugee herself  pioneered girls’ education in the camp  where before her arrival they did not even have a name for a female teacher. Thanks to Aqeela’s hard work  today  there are 9 primary and middle schools - 4 for boys and 5 for girls in the camp - teaching 1400 students. In 2015 Aqeela won our Nansen Refugee Award for her dedication and hard work in bringing education for refugee girls. She has taught and inspired thousands of children  and so many girls especially in the camp want to be teachers.  Learn more about Aqeela: http://trib.al/8csKSS4

Proud of her writing practice  this young refugee from the Central African Republic showed us her class work during playtime in Inke refugee camp  in the Democratic Republic of Congo.  The camp in North Oubangui province  is home to more than 20 000 Central African Republic refugees. The Democratic Republic of Congo hosts over 100 000 people who have fled ongoing conflict in their homeland.  Read more about CAR and their recent elections which we helped refugees take part in: http://trib.al/2O55Fxh

Our aim is to find a form of admission for 10% of the Syrian refugee population  or 480 000 people  over three years.  This may seem a large number  but it is not. If Europe were to welcome the same percentage of refugees as Lebanon in comparison to its population  it would have to take in 100 million refugees.    Today  the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees  Filippo Grandi  emphasized that the responsibility for caring for refugees fleeing war in Syria should not be left to Syria's immediate neighbours alone  but should be shared more equitably.  "The magnitude of this particular crisis shows us unmistakably that it cannot be business as usual  leaving the greatest burden to be carried by the countries closest to the conflict " Grandi told a high-level conference in Geneva.  "Offering alternative avenues for the admission of Syrian refugees must become part of the solution  together with investing in helping the countries in the region " he added.  Learn more: http://www.unhcr.org/56fb98dc3.html
United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon called for an exponential increase in global solidarity with refugees today in Geneva.   Read more: http://trib.al/PFXKApn

“The first thing I knew about Canada is that it gets very cold " says Kevork with a smile. But  he adds  “it’s a country that accepts people.”  Kevork is working hard to rebuild his family's life - less than four months after arriving in Montreal  he is already supporting himself and his twin sisters. The 28-year-old is one of 15 Syrian refugees working full-time at the Seatply Products Inc. wood factory. Kevork was resettled to Canada through the country’s private sponsorship programme  after fleeing violence in Syria with his family in August 2015.  Thanks to his sponsor and a whole community of support behind him  Kevork has a real chance for a new beginning. “Everybody wants a safe and happy life ” Kevork says. “That’s all I wish for my family  too.”  Today we are hosting a high-level conference highlighting the need to generate a substantial increase in resettlement and other answers for Syrian refugees like Kevork  over the next three years.  Read more: http://tracks.unhcr.org/2016/03/a-syrian-family-starts-over-in-canada/

Fantastic to receive this support today for refugees from 1.2 million people  who signed an Avaaz petition calling for “urgent and massive humanitarian action” to help those forced to flee.   Our High Commissioner Filippo Grandi was handed the petition by Avaaz's Campaign Director Alice Jay  ahead of our conference tomorrow in Geneva at which we seek greater resettlement pathways for Syrian refugees. Learn more: http://trib.al/60dYOKK

Even though they’ve seen the worst of the Syrian war and lost their parents  these resilient kids still have their smile.   These young boys are some of the 50 some orphans living in an orphanage in Homs  Syria  which we support. The orphanage is home to 25 boys and 31 girls.  Thanks for following our posts from the orphanage over the last few days. We hope to bring you more news from this incredible organisation through 2016  as we support their essential work.

“I want to be a doctor so I can treat people in need.”  Ghaidaa faces an uncertain future in war-torn Syria  but she still has big  big dreams. The seven year old has been living at the Islamic Charity Association Orphanage in Homs for the past three years with her sister. She loves math and Arabic and possesses a healthy competitive streak. When our colleagues met Ghaidaa recently  she was unphased by the camera and kept studying hard for her upcoming Arabic exam.   The orphanage makes a huge difference in the children's lives - we find them happier  more positive and learning fast whenever we visit. This is incredible work considering the situation inside Syria  and we're so pleased to support them.

“I want to be an airline stewardess  because I want to tour the world." Rayan  17.  “By the time I reach university I'll try to master English speaking and writing  and enhance my computer skills. I need to  if I want to accomplish my dream.”  Ambitious Rayan has lived at the Islamic Charity Association Orphanage in Homs  Syria since she was 4 years old. Her teenage years have been lived through Syria's war  including a November 2014 mortar attack on the orphanage. Rayan and the other residents were forced to flee their well-equipped home that included playgrounds  activity halls  a sports arena  and bedrooms for every child. Now the orphanage uses a rented facility in a nearby neighbourhood that lacks the required infrastructure and requires the children to sleep in dorms.   Despite this  Rayan is optimistic about her future. Surrounded by people who care  she has a dream to seek. The orphanage is supporting her every step of the way  and we are proud to support the orphanage.  Photo: UNHCR/Q.Al Azroni

“I have to study a lot to become a big woman. When I grow up I want to be a doctor to help my family and all of the sick people.”  A smile of joy and hope at simply being eight years old  safe in school and surrounded by friends.   We work with partners in Liberia  to help refugees like this little girl from Côte d'Ivoire  access the opportunities they deserve to build new lives when they go home.

“People here have always been supportive and kind to me  they help me with my studies  and in return  I help the younger brothers and sisters.”   Razan's home has been the Islamic Charity Association Orphanage in Homs since she was only eight years old.  “I’m the eldest here  I’m 20  and I study physics at the University of Homs.”    Despite her current situation as an orphan inside Syria  she considers herself lucky to be surrounded by people who care. Razan’s dream is to work for the UN to help other vulnerable people.

“I bring a piece of fabric and I sew it. When I finish  I turn it over and fill it inside. Then I fit the head on. The hair comes last.”  Crafty sisters Thuha and Shamsa make ragdolls from scraps of cloth  to remember good times and play in Syria with their cousins and toys. The day bombs forced them to flee their home  they rushed to protect their dolls:   “We hid the ones in Syria in a bag in the outdoor clay oven...They probably got burned now because someone needed the oven.”  The resourceful sisters are proud of the dolls they make in Lebanon  but ultimately hope to go back to Syria and rescue the dolls in the oven.  See more of their story: http://tracks.unhcr.org/2016/03/the-ragdolls-and-the-clay-oven/

Time for a snuggle. Six-year-old Baraa cuddles her teddy bear inside the orphanage in Homs  Syria  she calls home. Baraa's mother passed away and her father is stuck in the besieged neighbourhood of Al Waer.   Homs has been witness to some of the worst fighting of the Syrian conflict and much of the city now lies in ruins. Many children just like Baraa have lost parents or have been abandoned as a result of the conflict.  Over the next few days we’re sharing the stories of some of the children we have met at the Islamic Charity Association Orphanage  in Homs  where we are increasing our support in 2016.

Millions of Yemenis have suffered over a year of intense conflict. 2.4 million have been forced to flee their homes in Yemen 173 000 people have fled for neighbouring countries   Hassan and his family fled to Djibouti after their home was bombed  killing a mother and son. Watch their story  and learn more about Yemen's crisis and our efforts to get aid to people who desperately need it: http://www.unhcr.org/56f2976b6.html

We’re thrilled to announce the appointment of our newest Regional Goodwill Ambassador  Malian singer Rokia Traore.  Watch her new video 'Né So' dedicated to refugees and forcibly displaced people around the world.   "This is the title song of my new album  'Né So'  which means ‘house' in Bambara  my mother tongue.  I saw thousands of internally displaced people inside Mali  and refugees in neighbouring countries  who were forced to leave their homes  their families and everything that is familiar.  They are not alone. While the world continues to see a record number of people displaced by war and conflict  I am grateful to be able to play a role in calling attention to this unprecedented refugee crisis as a goodwill ambassador."

One person cannot do anything alone. It is vital to be in touch with legal advice  the institutions  UNHCR and  of course  to take the decision  as a family  to get ahead.  Meet Nancy  a determined Peruvian refugee and restaurant-owner  who will happily serve you up delicious Peruvian specialities like ceviche  lomo saltado or ají de gallina in one of her two family-run restaurants in Santa Cruz  Bolivia.  “We had to make our living and move forward"  said Nancy  who sought asylum in Bolivia after fleeing persecution and serious threats against her husband. In Bolivia  despite missing her homeland deeply  Nancy has raised her children  seen the birth of her grandchildren  and opened two successful Peruvian restaurants.  We wish the family every success in the future.
As old as Syria's conflict  five-year-old Farah lost her parents at two in a bombing. She now lives in a shelter in Homs  and though war is all she has known  her smile never leaves her.

When we look back on history  we know that closed borders and closed minds have never led to progress or innovation  or changed this planet for the better. New population movements  even those rooted in tragedy  can carry with them new dreams and ideas.   So within the current refugee debate  to those who say “close the borders ” I say that a politics rooted in fear and exclusion is not only wrong legally  economically and morally  but it is also the most small-minded approach  and one which will not push us forward as a people.   When we are courageous and clear-eyed enough to view the new population movements and changing landscape as an invitation and an opportunity  rather than a threat  the possibilities for human growth and innovation will be limitless.  Read more from Amin Awad  our Refugee Coordinator for the Syria and Iraq Situations:

UNHCR's Special Envoy  Angelina Jolie Pitt  spoke with refugees in Athens  Greece  on Thursday.   Read more about her visit and call for safe pathways to shelter for those fleeing their homes: www.unhcr.org/56ead8206.html  Photo: UNHCR/A.Zavallis

Selfie time! Our colleague Gloria grabbed a selfie with these Burundian refugee children in Lusenda camp in the Democratic Republic of Congo's Kivu province.  With tension remaining high in Burundi  the number of people who have sought shelter in neighbouring states has now passed the 250 000 mark. Read the latest: http://trib.al/Oh21BiH

“I want to represent all the refugees because I want to show that after the pain and the storm comes calm days.”   Syrian refugee Yusra  17  is training in Germany to compete at  The Olympic Games this summer  as a Rio 2016 Refugee Olympic Athlete.   She has already swum to save her life and others - after her overcrowded boat from Turkey failed  she swam to Lesvos  Greece. Yusra's determination and strength saved the lives of 20 other refugees.   From Greece  Yusra and her sister traveled through Europe to Germany  where she now trains daily  with a focus on qualifying for Rio.  "I want everyone to do what they feel in their heart even if it’s impossible “ she says. “The war will stop and I will go back with experiences  and I will teach everyone what I had here.”  Read more: http://tracks.unhcr.org/2016/03/syrian-refugee-eyes-rio-olympics/

“The school lacks a cafeteria  and uniforms for all the students. We foresee additional children enrolling in the close future.”  Meet Assistant Dean  Carine  a refugee and busy mom of four from Bangui  Central African Republic (CAR)  who volunteers at a refugee camp school in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Carine gives her time generously in one of Boyabu camp's two elementary schools  regularly organising discussion groups with parents  to improve the school.   Her energy is in spite of her own hardship: “I really hope our family can be reunited again soon." Carine fled violence in CAR for the DRC with her four kids in September 2013  but was separated from her husband who is now in Cameroon.  We hope for good news for the family  and thank Carine for her energy supporting parents and pupils.  Photo: UNHCR/F.Salvi
Meet Bilal  Mirfat and Ali  three Syrians who at five  are as old as their country's devastating conflict.  All now are refugees in Dohuk  Iraq. Click on each to see their families' story.

How can the world stand with Syrians? They can host more refugees in their own countries  and offer greater support to Syria's struggling neighbours.  Learn more about what we'll be asking from governments  at our conference on March 30th: http://trib.al/uhP69AA

Moona was quite shy when we met her on International Women's Day  at the Women's Refugee Centre in Nouakchott  Mauritania.   Little Moona was born in Nouakchott  after her parents fled violent clashes in Cote d’Ivoire in 2002. Making a life for their new family in Nouakchott  Moona's dad teaches French and her mom sells coconuts and shea butter at the local market.  Read about our work at the Women Refugees Centre in Nouakchott: http://trib.al/5rylgit

“We Yazidis have suffered a lot. We can’t go back home.”  Barfi  a 63-year-old Yazidi grandmother from Sinjar  Iraq has spent the past week in the fields of Idomeni  Greece sharing a small camping tent with her son  his wife and their five children  one of whom has severe developmental disabilities.  The family fled Sinjar in 2014  after militants laid siege to the area. They first went to a camp for displaced people outside Dohuk  in the Kurdistan region of northern Iraq. They then sought safety in Europe.   The family worries that new border restrictions will prevent them from crossing the border into the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.
“In five years time I will be..." Syrians needs hope.   We asked some of the 11.7 million Syrians forced to flee  what they hope for the future after five years of conflict.

Aqeela Asifi  our Nansen Refugee Award 2015 laureate  has reached the final Top 10 of the Varkey Foundation Global Teacher Prize 2016 at the Global Education and Skills Forum in Dubai.  We honoured Aqeela last year for her brave and selfless campaign to open schools for Afghan refugee girls in the Kot Chandana refugee camp in Pakistan – while herself a refugee and overcoming the struggles of life in exile. Today  from 8 000 nominations across 148 countries she has won the Teacher Prize – set up to recognize one exceptional teacher who has made an outstanding contribution to the profession.   Congratulations to the winning teacher Hanan Al Hroub!  Read Aqeela's story: tracks.unhcr.org/an-education-multiplied  #TeachersMatter

Little Chance's brave mum Eunice  fled fighting in South Sudan with her three day old newborn girl  on December 26th.  Despite still needing medical care  Eunice walked for three days to reach safety  sleeping under trees  without food or medicine  unable even to wash.  Now in the Democratic Republic of Congo  Eunice and her family are among thousands fleeing killing  raping and looting in previously peaceful provinces  which has caused 2.3 million South Sudanese to flee their homes.

Good luck Aqeela Asifi in tomorrow's Global Teacher Prize!   The remarkable Aqeela's journey continues. From brave refugee teacher transforming the lives of thousands of Afghan refugee girls in Pakistan  to our Nansen Refugee Award winner 2015 and now Top 10 Finalist for the global Teacher Prize.    Read her story: tracks.unhcr.org/an-education-multiplied

“Waiting has been the most difficult part  more difficult than the boat.”  Esmail worries about his elderly mother  Fatima  who is wheelchair-bound  always beneath a mound of blankets. The previous night’s rains have left puddles around the tent where they have been sleeping for the past 10 days and caked the wheelchair in mud  as they wait to cross the border into the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia from Greece.   Esmail  who was a mechanical engineer in Syria’s Idlib province  fled to Europe with his mother  his wife and four children after an airstrike hit their home. Esmail carried his mother on his back at several points along the way. Now the family wait their turn to cross  with little information on when they will be allowed to move forward.
“Five years ago I was at home in Syria  living in peace.”  Five years of conflict. 11.7 million forced to flee. Syria needs peace.

It's too dangerous  we can't go home.  Haseebullah and Hassan are like brothers in exile  sharing the unusual fate of having found sanctuary in Hungary.  Both young men fled mortal danger in at home  making arduous journeys through the Middle East and the Balkans before finally finding peace - and each other - in an orphanage in Hungary.  While Haseebullah fled his native Afghanistan and Hassan was forced to leave his home in Western Sahara  they’ve both have had a positive  if atypical experience near Budapest.  Although Hungary has harsh and restrictive policies for refugees  their story shows that there are some refugees that stay and build new lives. They also challenge the perception that young Muslim men without families mean trouble for European society.  Read more about their story: http://trib.al/jr3O36c

“How can we feed our children? We ran out of money 10 days ago.”  Zooda tries to calm her 10-month-old son  Mahmoud  who is crying from hunger. Travelling with her husband  Mohammed  and her three children  Zooda is tired after a rainy night in a makeshift camp near the village of Idomeni  on the border between Greece and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.   The family fled their hometown  Dara’a  Syria  in January  along with 50 members of their extended family. The entire group is staying in tents at Idomeni.  We’re urging Greek authorities and EU Member States to strongly reinforce capacity to register and process asylum-seekers like Zooda. We want to see far more resettlement and humanitarian admission  family reunification  private sponsorship  and humanitarian and refugee student and work visas. We know that all of these instruments would serve to reduce demand for people smuggling  onward movements  and dangerous boat journeys.  Learn more about the situation at Idomeni: http://trib.al/BdyapLI

Located 1 000 miles south of Hawaii  Palmyra Atoll is one of the most spectacular marine wilderness areas on Earth. Its unique location near the equator  its phenomenal biodiversity  & its history of minimal human impact make it an unparalleled natural marine laboratory.

1 000 mile south of Hawaii sits Palmyra Atoll  an island of just 680 acres. The land  lagoons  & coral reefs support a complex web of life: whales  dolphins  sharks  sea turtles  manta rays  birds  & the largest land-living crab in the world. It's a living laboratory where we study just how resilient our planet's unique life can be.   Join us TONIGHT at 7pm EST (6 Central) as Dateline NBC explores this sanctuary while #OnAssignment...

32 million acres of forests  roughly the size of New York state  are cut down & cleared worldwide every year. Smaller parcels of forest can become unsustainable habitat for important species. The natural processes that some forests need  such as fires and flooding  have been altered. And the introduction and spread of tree pests and diseases threaten forests globally. But while the situation seems dire  there is so much we can do. This #ArborDay  help us plant 1.2 billion trees in carefully-selected forests around the world.

WFP assists people in the most volatile and insecure environments.   In Syria  WFP provided food assistance to 4.9 million people & assisted 2 million refugees in neighbouring countries. In Yemen  WFP supported 8.9 million people – more than one third of the entire country's population.

“I have always lived in Mariant. I grew up here  and things have changed a lot since my youth. There is electricity  roads that are becoming better and better every year. I am a farmer  and what I grow normally feeds my wife and my 5 kids.   I lost a leg in a tribal fight when I was young  around 18 years old. Everybody here walks around with a bush knife  so when there is a fight  people get hurt badly.    When I was young the weather was different.  Here in the mountains  it was very cold.  I remember when I was 25  I always needed 2 or 3 blankets to be able to sleep. Now  only one is enough  most of the time.   In 1972  there was a big frost. It was freezing. Everybody left the district and went to seek refuge on the coast. Right after that winter  it was very warm and it has been hot ever since. So after El Nino  when the drought came and then the frost  people here were lost. We didn’t know what to do – noone was prepared for that. Noone was used to being that cold. All my crops were destroyed. The kaukau (sweet potatoes) were rotting in the ground. All the plants got burnt by the drought  then the frost  and I lost everything.  For more than one week we had nothing to eat. We were suffering in silence. Then the government came and gave us some rice  and then the World Food Programme came. So now we are ok  but we still do not know what to expect. If that happens again  I do not know what will happen to us. Maybe I will have to move away and go to the coast to be able to feed my family. We are really scared of the future.”  Papua New Guinea  Steven Akop  61

“Now that I have a job again  the first thing I will do is buy food  school supplies and clothes for my children. The skills and knowledge I acquired through WFP training will allow me to gain some income and support my family  and also to help my fellow villagers by teaching them the same skills.” - Ahmad   Ahmad  a father of 5  participated in WFP’s cash for work project in Jordan. Through the project  participants received a daily cash incentive to train for jobs in plant production  animal production and rehabilitation of forestry. With the support of the Jordan's Ministry of Agriculture and thanks to generous contributions of donors  WFP has been able to give jobs to thousands.  Today  Ahmad has graduated and now trains others enrolled in WFP's cash for work project.

“My name is Zakariya. I am 26 years old. I am from Homs in Syria. I live in Denmark now with two of my younger brothers  Issam and Mohammed.   We had everything in Syria. We had two dairy factories. In my home  we had cats  dogs  birds  horses. My mother would make bread on the terrace. It was so delicious. She was very good at that. We had everything we wanted. But it was all destroyed.   I felt like I should do something to help in Syria. I wanted to help my friends and my family - and all the Syrian people are my family. I drove ambulances  medicine and food to people across the Turkish border into Syria. I bought the food from the local market in Syria and not in Turkey  because it is good for the Syrian people that we buy from them.  I tried to give people the most important food – like rice and olive oil  sugar and tea.   The first time I was delivering food  I was so nervous. What should I say? I wanted to show them that I am exactly like them. I didn’t know how to knock on the door or how to tell them to take the food. It is hard to say how they felt when they received the food; they were happy and ashamed at the same time  and so was I.  Giving food meant a lot to me. When you give food to people  they feel alive and can do something. Food is the most important gift in life because it is life.   In 2015  I couldn’t help in Syria anymore  I couldn’t get a job  and I couldn’t study. That’s why I chose Europe to start my life again. I traveled to Izmir first and I found a smuggler to go to Mytilini on the Greek Island of Lesbos.  People had told me Denmark is a good country to go to because the people are very friendly and the life here is good. When we got to Europe  I started the travel to Denmark with my two brothers.  Now we are living in a shared house in Solrød Kommune. We are better now  of course  but how should we continue?  When you live outside of your country  you are just a number. As a refugee  people look at you like you are less than them…but I am not. I was rich. I was studying. I had a job. I had everything. I am like you. A war started. It is not my fault  and I am not less than you are.” #IamSyrian  ©WFP/ Ingrid Erno  panorama.wfp.org/iamsyrian

“The cyclone took away everything  just as I was about to revive my life ” she says.  When Cyclone Roanu hit southern Bangladesh in May  vulnerable women such as Sukhiya were extremely affected. Worrying about immediate food needs  the cyclone threatened the previous gains from the Enhancing Food Security (EFS) programme.  With emergency food assistance coupled with ongoing trainings  Sukhiya is able to keep going without worrying about putting food on her family's table.  “Since I don’t have to pay for rice  I can both repair the house and continue buying nutritious food ” says Sukhiya. “I can go to the training without worrying about that now.”  Photos: WFP/Kauser Haider  http://www.wfp.org/stories/providing-emergency-relief-sustain-fight-against-poverty

“My name is May  I am Syrian and I am Swedish. I am a daughter  a wife and a mother to triplets  my three musketeers.   We came to Sweden three years ago as refugees from Damascus  Syria. Nowadays we live in Teckomatorp  a small village outside of Malmö.  We left Syria to protect ourselves  our children and our future. Sometimes I feel very ashamed and guilty because I managed to leave with my family and children. When we left  my mum and dad were still in Syria  but they died last year  they were very sick. My mum died from cancer and my father died six months later - he was depressed after my mum’s death.  In Damascus  in 2000  I volunteered for the Syrian Red Crescent and became a first aider in 2001. I especially remember one day when we were in the ambulance and we came to a checkpoint. They pointed their weapons at us  we couldn’t go past them. We could hear shooting but we were not allowed to give help.   On my birthday in November 2012  my friends asked me if I wished to travel  and I said no  I wouldn’t want to leave Syria in a thousand years. Six months later  I had to. I didn’t want to leave  but I wanted my kids and my family to be safe.  It was only when I came to Sweden that I realised that I am a refugee and I am not able to go back home.   I am wearing colourful clothes because in our culture we say that pink breaks deep sadness. That’s why I wear a pink scarf. This is very different from what is inside me now – there is a lot of pain  and there is a lot of stress.  We are waiting for Syria to be a free and peaceful country  which our people deserve. Then we might want to come back home. Although  we really do feel home again in Sweden. I feel guilty because… Syria is my country  the place of my dreams. I really wanted to live and die there.” #IamSyrian #WithRefugees  http://panorama.wfp.org/iamsyrian ©WFP/Jonathan Eng
I am ≠ a number.  I am a refugee. I have a story. #WithRefugees

Meet Paula. #IamColombian  Paula escaped the violence in Colombia and moved to Ecuador  in the hope of a better life. But after a few years in her new home  she had to escape violence once more- this time  her boyfriend’s abuse.  Tired of suffering  Paula and her two children fled the domestic violence  without food or work.  When Paula heard about WFP assistance for vulnerable refugees in Ecuador  she signed up to receive cash-based transfers in the form of an electronic voucher  made possible by donors like USAID and ECHO.  Now  Paula and her children can enjoy nutritious home-cooked meals together.  Thanks to her own strength and WFP’s assistance  Paula does not need to worry about having to escape anymore and is a better life for herself and her children. #WithRefugees  https://www.wfp.org/stories/paula-has-stopped-fleeing

Nutrition in early childhood is crucial.     Scientists now know that malnutrition in the first two years of life (the first 1 000 days from conception) can affect mental and physical development into adulthood. Undernourished children are more likely to get sick  have trouble concentrating in school  and may earn less as adults.   This is why a large part of WFP’s nutrition work is directed at young children and mothers  providing deep-field  community-level support in both humanitarian and recovery situations.   Learn more: http://www.wfp.org/nutrition   © WFP/Ranak Martin

Food emergency? WFP will be there. But WFP is about much more  too. The other half of our work is building up resilient communities & markets *before* crisis hits.   Increasing access to markets  giving tools to farmers & educating on resilient farming methods help prevent food crisis before they happen.

FACT: the majority of the world’s hungry live in environments prone to climate hazards such as droughts & floods.   Climate change is making such hazards more frequent and intense  land and water more scarce and difficult to access  and increases in agricultural productivity even harder to achieve.  http://www.wfp.org/climate-change  ©WFP/Agron Dragaj

Thriving markets  agriculture production + community infrastructure are all tools for reaching #ZeroHunger.  In the Democratic Republic of Congo  WFP has partnered with Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) to implement programmes to revive markets and farms after years of mismanagement and conflict. http://ow.ly/9bHc30085jC   ©WFP/Olivier Le Blanc

Climate change is both cause and consequence of many problems  but none of them are insurmountable. With the Paris Agreement and the Global Goals for Sustainable Development we have a blueprint for change. Now we need the determination and will to achieve them. Together we can do it! http://www.wfp.org/stories/quick-guide-climate-change

In Cambodia  our school feeding programme has reached 840 000 children annually since 2011  thanks to the support of U.S. Department of Agriculture's McGovern-Dole International Food for Education and Child Nutrition Program. By providing school meals and scholarships  the programme supports universal access to primary education and promotes increased attendance and retention.   In 2014  WFP piloted the Home Grown School Feeding  a sustainable model of the school meals programme. It created business opportunities for the local producers  suppliers and farmers as most of the commodities are purchased and procured locally.  Building on this success  WFP is working with the government to establish a national school feeding programme by 2021. In recent days  representatives from the Royal Government of Cambodia  including the Ministry of Education  Youth and Sport  of Cambodia  Ministry of Economy and Finance  Ministry of Information and Communication Technology  and representatives from USAID - US Agency for International Development  USAID Cambodia and Plan Cambodia visited schools in Siem Reap province.   Photos: WFP/ Bushra Rahman

The people in South Sudan face incredible challenges every day. But  WFP is working to ensure that food & nutrition aren't one of them.    This summer’s lean season may leave up to 5.3 million people with severe food shortages. As the crisis worsens  WFP  UNICEF  Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)& other United Nations agencies are already in the region providing aid and preparing for the hardships ahead.  ©WFP/Giulio d'Adamo

Meet Aashana  a bright 6 year old student at Jaffna Hindu Ladies’ Primary School in Sri Lanka.   Her parents come from a poor family & cannot afford to provide breakfast to all members of the family. She is very happy to have a nutritious meal every day at school provided by WFP. Her grades have been increasing – as her health does too!  She is one of the best students in her class (evident as she proudly shows a WFP staff member her grades!).   Way to go Aashana- WFP is proud of you too!   ©WFP/Nagarajah Sathyaruban

Did You Know: In India  the right to food is enshrined in law. WFP is supporting the Government in modernising and transforming the national food distribution system  which is designed to ensure that the poorest people have access to food.  The transformation  in-line with the National Food Security Act  is aimed at minimising waste  improving transparency  empowering people  and helping those involved make informed public policy decisions. www.wfp.org/stories/modernising-indias-food-distribution-system

Women are often victims of hunger. They also have a crucial role to play in defeating hunger. As mothers  farmers  teachers and entrepreneurs  they hold the key to building a future free of malnutrition.
