With the right tools and training  communities that once struggled with food security in the past can begin to build a self-reliant agricultural system to boost local markets.  Even in this refugee camp in the Democratic Republic of Congo  WFP programs like Cash for Work has encouraged small scale trade and local agriculture. Learn more here--> http://ow.ly/uv5w3004cC9

Climate disasters are a leading cause of hunger. How the world addresses climate change will have a major impact on our ability to reach Zero Hunger.  To learn more about how climate change could affect food security around the world  check out the interactive map we developed with the Met Office: www.wfp.org/climate-food-insecurity-vulnerability-index
Did you know: 66 million primary school-age children go to class hungry in the developing world.   WFP works to change this through school meals. http://m.wfp.org/school-meals

The world is at a critical juncture. We are witnessing the highest level of human suffering since the Second World War. This is why  for the first time in the 70-year history of the United Nations  Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon has convened the World Humanitarian Summit.  On 23 - 24 May 2016  world leaders will meet in Istanbul to stand up for our common humanity and take action to prevent and reduce human suffering.  via United Nations

“We can avoid this crisis getting worse by meeting the needs of families today.” – WFP’s Executive Director Ertharin Cousin.  WFP has committed to helping Ethiopia  which is in the grip of its worst drought in recent history. Here at a food distribution point  grains  pulses & oil are given to those in need.  ©WFP/Michael Tewelde

“The most beautiful bouquet of flowers I've ever received. Hand-picked by the gorgeous Rasha in a camp for displaced families in the coastal city of Tartous.” – WFP staffer Dina El-Kassaby on a field mission in Syria.  Rasha is a 3 year old girl from Aleppo and  like many displaced children  her only memories are from the camp. Her family came to Tartous 5 years ago when fighting in Aleppo shook the roof over their heads day & night. #IamSyrian  ©WFP/Dina El-Kassaby
Smiles like these make our work worth while!  Happy Monday everyone - together we can reach Zero Hunger and achieve the Global Goals for Sustainable Development :)

FACT: In Pakistan  six out of 10 people are food insecure despite the fact that food production is sufficient to feed all Pakistanis. In 2015  WFP assisted over 3.6 million people in the country.  Learn more facts about hunger in Pakistan here: https://www.wfp.org/stories/10-facts-about-hunger-pakistan  Photo: WFP/ Rein Skullerud

There’s nothing more wonderful than knowing your child has the chance to grow happy & healthy!  Looking for the ultimate  last-minute Mother's Day gift? Consider donating to ShareTheMeal! Help support children like Hamada & Rimas so moms don't have to worry about where their next meal is coming from.

Mothers have a crucial role to play in the fight against hunger. As a child’s first and most important source of nourishment- strong  healthy mothers are the best guarantee of strong  healthy children.    Thank you for everything you do! Happy Mother’s Day!

As many people around the world celebrate Mother's Day  watch our video to see how one mother in Bangladesh coped when disaster struck.   As a single mother and day laborer  Rizia Begum and her family were particularly vulnerable when flooding hit southeastern Bangladesh last summer. “My daughter caught a cold and fever  and there was no money for medicine or food.” “We went for two or three days with little or no food  and couldn’t cook because even the clay oven was flooded ” she says. “I had no money to buy groceries.” Rizia was one of 185 000 people in southeastern Bangladesh to receive food assistance from WFP after the storm hit.  “Receiving this money allowed me to buy the foods we needed. Most of it I spent on rice  lentils and small fish  but also on medicine and school costs for my children.”

An earthquake may last moments but the impact lasts far longer. More than a year after the Nepal Earthquake  Nepali people are still picking up the pieces of their lives.  Check out our photo story to see how WFP has helped reach those in the most remote communities.

FACT: In the last decade  almost half of WFP emergency and recovery operations responded to and helped people recover from climate-related disasters. WFP responded to climate disasters in 20 countries.   Learn more about WFP's response to climate change & how our work is helping to achieve the sustainable development goals-->http://ow.ly/RqvL3000x5g

As Mothers Day approaches  we want to stop to thank mothers around the world! Your unconditional love & constant support is fundamental for your children.   THANK YOU for all you’ve done!   ©WFP/Donaig Le Du

#FACT: Each year around 218 million people are affected by disaster.  Disasters disproportionately affect the world’s poorest people and communities  significantly increasing hunger and malnutrition.  Because of this  disaster risk reduction is a central priority for WFP.  Time to boost resilience & #sharehumanity!   Photo: WFP/ Eddie Gerald

In the last week of April  strong winds  hail and heavy rains destroyed more than 1 860 houses in Myanmar and damaged almost 20 000 homes.   WFP provided one month rations of rice  salt  cooking oil and pulses to 2 048 people affected in Mandalay region  thanks to the generous support of donor governments including Australia  Canada  Czech Republic  Denmark  European Union  France  Germany  Italy  Japan  Republic of Korea  Luxembourg  New Zealand  Norway  Switzerland  U.K  and U.S.A.

Ever wonder what happens to food assistance containers AFTER they’re used?    These displaced South Sudanese boys grew up in the heart of conflict & poverty. Without any money or means to buy games  they’ve been able to create their own TOYS. Check out these boys’ cars  made with the remains of donated vegetable oil tins from USAID - US Agency for International Development  ©WFP/Giulio D'Adamo

In Latin American & the Caribbean nearly 85 million children receive a daily breakfast  snack or lunch at their schools. School meals are often the only regular and nutritious meal a child receives.  Learn more about WFP's Latin American school meals programme and the quest to end hunger --> http://ow.ly/4nunng  ©WFP/MikeBloem

Amazing the heights you can reach with the right support!  From receiving school meals as a child to becoming the youngest woman to summit Mount Everest and raising the Global Goals for Sustainable Development flag for #ZeroHunger.  See how Nimdoma Sherpa used her climbing expertise to help WFP reach remote villages in Nepal.

150 000 children in Laos receive nutritious meals every day  either as a mid-morning snack or lunch  thanks to U.S. Department of Agriculture support through the McGovern-Dole Food For Education Program. The meals help increase the children's attentiveness during class and make the most of their education.   USDA’s support also contributes to setting up vegetable gardens in schools – boosting dietary diversity for the school lunches and teaching children about agriculture.  Last week USDA visited WFP’s school meals programme in Laos.   Photos: WFP/ Rocio Rebollo

FACT: In the last decade  almost half of WFP emergency and recovery operations responded to and helped people recover from climate-related disasters. WFP responded to climate disasters in 20 countries.   Interested? Read more --> http://www.wfp.org/stories/quick-guide-climate-change

“Place human dignity before economic growth or political power ” HRH Prince El Hassan bin Talal  On Tuesday  His Royal Highness Prince El Hassan bin Talal of Jordan addressed diplomats and staff at WFP’s Headquarters in Rome. The focus of the event? How to build resilience amidst chaos in the Middle East.  ©WFP/Rein Skullerud

FACT: Asia has two thirds of the world's hungry people and is the most disaster-prone region.  How will climate change impact food security in the region?   Check out our report to learn more: www.wfp.org/content/climate-impacts-food-security-and-livelihoods-asia  with Met Office International Water Management Institute (IWMI) CGIAR Research Program on Climate Change  Agriculture and Food Security CGIAR

Did you know 795 million people do not have enough food to eat and yet as much as 1/3 of food produced in the world is wasted?   The wasted food causes giant CO2 emissions  making it the world's third top emitter and contributing to climate change.  What can you do? Don't waste food!  via United Nations

The war in Syria has raged for 5 years. Millions have fled  but for 18M who remain – what is life like for them?     BBC News reports on life the war-torn country & how food is being used as a weapon of war --> http://ow.ly/4nk9qg  ©WFP/Dina Elkassaby

Syrian refugees living in camps in Jordan use WFP’s innovative iris scan technology to purchase food from local shops. The system is eliminating the need for cash  vouchers or credit cards  while improving the delivery of food assistance.  Read more about WFP's iris scan on Mashable --> http://ow.ly/4np1nb

“If I can get basic food at subsidised rates  I will be able to save some money. The savings will take care of my other expenses like medical bills ” Sushmita says.  Sushmita benefits from India’s vast food distribution programme in the State of Odisha. Here  the programme was outdated  but efforts supported by WFP are modernising distribution methods. New  efficient bar-coded ration cards have been distributed to 8 million households. Learn more about our efforts here: www.wfp.org/stories/modernising-indias-food-distribution-system

FACT: Poor nutrition causes nearly half (45%) of deaths in children under five each year - that's 3.1 million young lives lost needlessly.   But it doesn't have to be that way. Working together  supporting governments  communities and families  together we can reach the Global Goals for Sustainable Development and create one future with Zero Hunger.  Photo: WFP/Colin Kampschoer

Women have a crucial role to play in defeating hunger. As mothers  farmers  teachers and entrepreneurs  they hold the key to building a future free of malnutrition.  Learn more how WFP is empowering women to achieve #ZeroHunger --> http://ow.ly/4njRP4

“When I think of my home in Aleppo  I remember how beautiful it was and I think of my school which was next door… All my hopes today are to go back to my country. I want my life back in Syria.” - Nassar  a 13 year old Syrian refugee. #IamSyrian  Read more about Nassar & discover other Syrians' stories --> http://ow.ly/4njhbF  ©WFP/Abeer Etefa

Shiwa has been living in a house made of mud and plastic sheeting for the past three years. The 26-year-old  along with her husband and five children  are one of the countless families living in Kabul’s informal settlements (KIS)– a collection of temporary communes dotted around Afghanistan’s capital city  housing displaced people who have left their homes due to conflict  natural disasters  or severe poverty.  WFP is providing families like Shiwa’s with vital food assistance. Instead of handing out food directly to families like Shiwa's at KIS  WFP registers them to receive e-vouchers through their mobile phones. Recipients can then go to nearby participating stores and purchase the food they need.  Learn more on #TechTuesday: https://www.wfp.org/stories/wfp-supports-afghanistans-most-vulnerable-people-through-difficult-winter
What does it take to give a 1 to 2 year-old child all the nutrients they need? Check out this great video from our nutrition team mythbusting a common myth about childhood nutrition to find out.

El Niño is fueling a major  global food security crisis affecting 60 million people.  Unless resources are mobilized swiftly  poor harvests and food scarcity will threaten decades of development progress and leave vulnerable communities even more exposed to a changing climate.
WFP is working hard to achieve Goal 2 #ZeroHunger of the Global Goals for Sustainable Development.   Find out how we plan on eradicating hunger by 2030 --> http://ow.ly/4nccFP

FACT: the majority of the world’s hungry live in environments prone to climate hazards such as floods and droughts. Ending hunger and addressing #climatechange go hand in hand.  Learn more: http://www.wfp.org/climate-change

The All-Ladies Emergency Response Team (ALERT) are breaking gender stereotypes as one of the first all-female emergency response teams in the Philippines.  With the help of WFP and Yum! Brands  the Cotabato city government aims to provide a gender- and culturally-sensitive lens to their disaster risk reduction initiatives.  Learn more: http://www.wfp.org/stories/philippines-all-women-emergency-response-team

“There is nothing we can do except wait for the rains” explains Belony  father & husband.   Belony’s family lives in a small village near Flamands  Haiti  which has been affected by drought for more than 5 years. Recent El Nino weather has exacerbated the drought  leaving 3.6 million Haitians food insecure. WFP has launched an emergency response to address immediate food needs for drought-affected Haitians.   ©WFP/Thomas Freteur

When we see that an emergency is looming  WFP can lessen its impact. WFP has one of the most comprehensive Early Warning Systems that collects and analyzes information on natural and man made hazards.  Extra supplies can be ordered in advance and moved by trucks and ships  rather than by air. This saves time  money - and lives.  Learn more --> https://www.wfp.org/our-work/being-ready  ©WFP/Rein Skullerud

#DidYouKnow: In India  the right to food is enshrined in law.  WFP is supporting the Government in modernising and transforming the national food distribution system  which is designed to ensure that the poorest people have access to food.  The transformation  in-line with the National Food Security Act  is aimed at minimising waste  improving transparency  empowering people  and helping  those involved make informed public policy decisions.   http://www.wfp.org/stories/modernising-indias-food-distribution-system

#DidYouKnow every $1 governments invest in nutrition to reduce stunting sees on average a return of 16 times as much.   The cost of poor nutrition is high  physically and mentally  and it affects every country in the world. Among the challenges is how to ensure nutrition is seen not just as a health issue  but also as an issue in agriculture  infrastructure  social protection and education policies.  If the world can address this challenge  we can ensure that every person has the opportunity to reach their potential.

The war in Syria has entered its sixth year leaving hundreds of thousands of people dead. It has caused the world’s largest humanitarian crisis since World War II.  In a new video  euronews highlights how WFP is helping Syrian refugees get their basic needs with e-Food cards ---> http://ow.ly/4neNAI

Educating girls is one of the most effective ways to improve food security: when girls are educated they are more likely to be able to meet the nutritional needs of their children & to head households that are food-secure.  When money is scarce  parents often keep girls at home to work or care for family members. Where school attendance is limited  the promise of at least one meal each day with our School Meals programme motivates parents to send their daughters to school.  ©WFP/Ranak Martin

Climate change often impacts the poorest people the most.   Last summer  nearly 2 million people in southeastern Bangladesh were affected by flooding and landslides. With the support of DFID - UK Department for International Development  WFP was able to reach more than 185 000 people with emergency food assistance and provide cash assistance to 35 000 affected people.

When Nepal was hit by two powerful earthquakes  no terrain could keep WFP from reaching those most in need.   We used all means possible to deliver food and relief items to remote earthquake-stricken mountain villages.   Local people  along with animals and trekkers transported shelter material  food  hygiene kits and medical supplies to thousands of people in rural communities inaccessible by road or helicopter.   http://panorama.wfp.org/moving-mountains

In only three months  @WFP’s @ShareTheMeal app has raised funds to support 2 000 mothers and their babies in Homs  Syria  for a full year. Good nutrition is crucial during pregnancy and while nursing – for both mother and child. Thank you for your generosity!

FACT: Yields for women farmers are 20-30 percent lower than for men. This is because women have less access to improved seeds  fertilisers and equipment.  Support WFP in eliminating the gender gap. By empowering women we can help reach #ZeroHunger.  ©WFP/Marco Fratini

#ThrowbackThursday to Afghanistan  2012: A convoy of WFP trucks braved mountain passes and precarious road conditions to deliver food to schools in remote villages in central Afghanistan that had been cut off during the harsh winter.  “The main challenge in the central highlands is the road conditions ” explains Wahidi  the Senior Logistics Assistant who helped arrange the mission. “There’s rain and mud  and even still some snow left on the ground or falling during the night.” Two mountain passes on the route  the Qonaq and the Shatoo passes located at more than 2 000 metres above sea level  posed special challenges but WFP’s seasoned drivers managed to make the crossing.  Photo: WFP/Hukomat Khan

FoodSECuRE: An innovative approach to disaster preparedness & response.  Climate disasters hit the poorest people the hardest. It’s estimated that by 2050  climate shocks could increase hunger and child malnutrition by 20 percent. This new approach will release funds for disaster preparedness and response before the crisis occurs while providing the necessary funds for resilience building activities.

Now that I have food  I can spend money on my children’s exam fees and notebooks for school”.   Sushila Kami worked as a porter near the village of Bigu  in Dolokha district  after the #NepalEarthquake .   She  along with a network of other porters across several districts  worked to clear debris  rehabilitate trekking and community trails  and deliver vital emergency supplies.   Together they contributed to the rehabilitation of 495 kilometres of trails  opening up access to more than 120 000 people living in remote mountainous terrain.

WorldFoodProgramme,2016-04-20T11:00:00+0000,755511,28312410177_10153412026320178,61,13,0,video,With grim and staggering statistics of the Syrian refugee crisis  it can be easy to forget that there are faces behind the numbers. These are their daily realities in their own words: http://panorama.wfp.org/iamsyrian
WorldFoodProgramme,2016-04-20T06:05:00+0000,755511,28312410177_10153411769095178,48,10,6,photo,“My name is Badreya. I am 26 years old and I come from the town of Ar-Raqqa in northern Syria.  The entire area is a hell on earth today and the remaining inhabitants are besieged and trapped - unable to escape to safer parts of the country.    I still miss my life and country terribly: the spring breeze  laughter  family lunches…but the Syria I know and love is history now. I’m afraid to return and see for myself the devastation my mother-in-law describes.  She’s still in Syria and I worry about her. She’s old now and immobile  so she couldn’t come to Lebanon with us four and a half years ago  but she insisted that we leave for our children’s sake.   I married when I was 17 and we moved to Darayya in Rural Damascus so we could be close to his family. My mother-in-law treated me like her own daughter  she spoiled me and took me with her everywhere she went. I was her pride and joy and I felt like a queen. I was so happy.  My fondest memories with her are in the kitchen where she taught me to cook dishes like Asheh – a special homemade Syrian sausage made with rice and spiced meat. We usually have Asheh on special occasions like Eid or on Fridays when all of our relatives would come to the house and eat together. Even though she did most of the cooking  she would tell everyone that I cooked it myself and my husband would kiss my hands in front of everyone. It was so easy to laugh those days.   Now  I live in a tent with my husband and our five children in dismal camp in the Bekaa Valley. I hate it here. Both of our sisters and their families were evicted by their landlords because they couldn’t afford to pay rent. They live with us too now.   We try to wake up before sunrise and sneak out of the tent  leaving our husbands and kids asleep. The three of us sip coffee and chat.  It’s the only downtime we get all day. When the sky starts to light up  my sister tells us to close our eyes and listen. The sound of the birds reminds us of Syria.  I thank God that we’re together and safe in Lebanon  but I do pity myself for our misfortune. How can life be so beautiful one day and turn this ugly the next? We have no heating  no running water  I don’t have enough money to feed my children and relatives every day  and people in Lebanon are sick of us being here. Life is getting too hard to bear and I feel I have forgotten what happiness feels like.” #IamSyian  ©WFP/Dina El-Kassaby
WorldFoodProgramme,2016-04-20T01:30:00+0000,755511,28312410177_10153411622540178,97,13,3,photo,Life in the Kabul Informal Settlements in Afghanistan is challenging. WFP provides vital food assistance through an innovative cash-based transfers programme. This puts the choice of what to buy in their hands and supports local businesses.   https://www.wfp.org/stories/wfp-supports-afghanistans-most-vulnerable-people-through-difficult-winter

WFP has traditionally focused on humanitarian requirements in Uganda  but the future emphasis will be on building the country’s agricultural capacity. “Usually parents give children the food they like not the food they need. Parents’ knowledge about good nutrition  even when their household income is good  is minimal. So I recommend that they buy eggs not Coca Cola  even though the kids like Coca Cola ” Noemia de Jesus Ximenes  a teacher at the Nino Konis Santana preschool  explains some of the challenges faced in combating malnutrition in Timor-Leste.   Here  children and parents learn about different food groups and the importance of eating a diverse diet at a joint event organized by WFP & the Ministry of Health. This programme hopes to help children under 5  pregnant women & breastfeeding women recover from malnutrition in areas with the highest rates of chronic malnutrition.   It is supported by funding from KOICA Timor-Leste Office (KOICA 동티모르사무소) and the EU Delegation To Timor-Leste.   ©WFP/ Cesaltino Ximenes

Our hearts go out to the people of #Ecuador during this very difficult moment for them. WFP is is monitoring the situation in the aftermath of the #Earthquake and is ready to support the Government's response and help the most vulnerable people affected by this tragedy.

Udai  a 5-month-old baby  is one of the causalities of the ongoing crisis in Yemen.  Born during the war  his family was ravaged by malnutrition. Although planes dropped bombs on his city  it wasn’t a blast that claimed his life  but a lack of food.   This tragic news demonstrates the massive hunger crisis in Yemen. WFP is on the ground & working around the clock to help Yemeni families who are in desperate  urgent need. Every donation provides more nutritious food for hungry children and families. Please donate now: http://ow.ly/4mMEWR

Good nutrition during the first 1 000 days—from a mother's pregnancy to a child's 2nd birthday—determines the course of a child's life  and in time  shapes the fate of their families  communities & the stability and prosperity of our planet. Research shows that under-nutrition during this critical phase can lead to irreversible long-term damage to physical growth and cognitive development.  To prevent malnutrition in women & children  WFP supplies specialised nutritional products and education to mothers and children.   © WFP/Marco Frattini

Children from vulnerable families are often pulled out of school when more work is needed at home. A daily school meal is a strong incentive for families to send their children to school while addressing malnutrition.   WFP has been working with the Government of India to develop a successful school meals programme across the country. Here  women in community kitchens prepare freshly cooked mid-day meals with local ingredients. Each meal guarantees a minimum calorie & protein count.  ©WFP/Aditya Arya

The large majority of the world’s hungry live in fragile situations prone to climate hazards. When disaster strikes  the situation of already vulnerable people can quickly deteriorate into a food and nutrition crisis. It has been estimated that the risk of hunger and malnutrition could increase by up to 20% by 2050 if we do not improve climate resilience.   Visit our interactive map to see how climate change could affect future food insecurity around the globe --> www.wfp.org/climate-food-insecurity-vulnerability-index

WFP delivers millions of tons of food aid each year during emergencies  but once relief is in place  our focus shifts to rebuilding community infrastructure & improving resilience.    After devastating floods hit Pakistan in 2011 and aid was delivered  WFP implemented a "Cash for Work" programme. The programme provides food vouchers in exchange for work. By working as farmers  these men have been able to purchase food for their families & support sustainable agriculture in their community.   © WFP/Photolibrary

“I like to study and I want to go to college someday. I know my mother is working very hard in the rice field. I want to work in an office and support her when I grow old”  Meet 12- year old Bean Sokhath and her pet cat Meao . Bean is a 6th grade student in Siem Reap  Cambodia.  Bean is an only child. Her mother  a hard working rice farmer  is the sole breadwinner of the family. Her father  a former soldier  is disabled after he was hurt in a battle field. Bean is one of the 7 400 children  who receives school meals supported by Tencent in Siem Reap.    She also receives a food scholarship (a take home ration of 10 KG of rice)  which supports her to continue school.

WFP’s ShareTheMeal app is nominated for a Webby Award  one of the Internet’s highest honours!   ShareTheMeal is WFP’s first fundraising and awareness-raising app. Free to download  the app makes it easy for people to donate 50¢ USD or more during their own mealtimes (or anytime) to help provide nutritious food to refugees  displaced families and others in need of vital aid.  Cast your vote now: http://bit.ly/1T1o9RL
#ThrowbackThursday to Nepal last year: following the devastating earthquake of April 25th  our Remote Access Operation (RAO) moved mountains to get vital assistance to those in need.

#DidYouKnow: Asia and the Pacific is the most disaster-prone region in the world. Myanmar  as the largest country in Southeast Asia  is prone to recurrent natural disasters which can seriously affect food security.  Last night's earthquake is the latest in a series of disasters and we hope its impact on people's lives will be as minimal as possible.  In 2015  floods and landslides affected 1.7 million people  destroyed more than 500 000 ha of rice fields and killed more than 250 000 livestock. WFP was the first agency to respond to the government’s declaration of a disaster and provided life-saving food to more than 455 000 people in the first month after the floods.

The problem isn't a lack of food. Hunger is a logistics problem. Esther Ndichu  Humanitarian.  In South Sudan WFP’s roads help farmers get their products to markets  earn an income and feed the community. A journey that once took one week  now only takes 3 hours.

“I am humbled to be part of WFP’s incredible work in fighting hunger  day in and day out.”   We’re excited to announce that Michael Kors received the World Food Program USA's McGovern-Dole Leadership Award for his fight against hunger!  Michael’s partnership with the WFP has helped to provide over 13 million school meals to hungry children.  Learn more his work to #WatchHungerStop: http://ow.ly/10BPlx

Sushmita is a daily wage worker in Odisha  India. With a child to feed and no family support  it’s not easy for her to put food on the table and cover medical and other expenses.  “If I can get basic food at subsidised rates  I will be able to save some money. The savings will take care of my other expenses like medical bills.”  In India  food is a right. Learn more about how WFP is helping the government modernise its food distribution system to ensure the right to food is fulfilled for all:  https://www.wfp.org/stories/modernising-indias-food-distribution-system

Healthy  safe and nutritious food is a basic necessity for everyone  but not everyone has it. Every night  80 million people around the world go to bed hungry. Many others only have access to food that isn’t always good for them.  How can we all contribute to a sustainable food system that can feed everyone  everywhere  every day?  Share your idea for #food4all: http://wrld.bg/10zOvM via World Bank  Photo: WFP/ Susannah Nicol

Major step forward: High above in Syria  we were able to airdrop food  to the besieged people of Deir Ezzor. For the last two years  over 200 000 people have been living under siege in Deir Ezzor and are in dire need of food and humanitarian assistance: http://www.wfp.org/news/news-release/wfp-food-assistance-arrives-air-besieged-people-deir-ezzor      Financial assistance from the governments of Canada  Italy  Germany  the Netherlands and the U.S make these airdrops possible. Thanks are also due to Jordan  the United States and Russia for their specialized support.

FACT: Poor nutrition causes nearly half (45%) of deaths in children under five each year - that's 3.1 million young lives lost needlessly. But it doesn't have to be that way. Working together  supporting governments  communities and families  together we can reach the Global Goals for Sustainable Development and create one future with Zero Hunger.

On 20 and 21 February Cyclone Winston  a Category 5 Severe Tropical Cyclone  cut a path of destruction across Fiji. The Fijian people have shown that they are #strongerthanWinston. However  many are still struggling to recover from the impact of the storm.   Yesterday WFP formalised a partnership with the Department of Women- Team Women Fiji and the Ministry of Rural & Maritime Development and National Disaster Management  to provide additional assistance to 71 700 people in areas where damage was particularly bad.  Learn more: http://reliefweb.int/report/fiji/fijian-government-and-world-food-programme-launch-top-cash-support-families-affected  Photos: © USAID/ Daniel Dieckhaus

As part of our commitment to a hunger-free world  WFP works with national governments in designing and operating nutrition programmes.   In Colombia  we had a goal to reduce anemia among 3 to 5 year olds by delivering integrated nutrition packages. The programme successfully reached more than 61 000 children  and the research showed that iron deficiency in the targeted children has been halved.   Learn more: http://panorama.wfp.org/colombia  ©WFP/Mike Bloem

Did you know: Evidence shows that cash transfers combined with nutrition education can improve income  diet  & nutrition.   A joint research project between WFP and International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) conducted in Bangladesh shows that if we provide regular cash transfers to ultra-poor women with small children  and combine this with good nutrition training  we can achieve a significant reduction in child stunting within a short period of time. The research was supported by Switzerland  Germany  USA  DFID - UK Department for International Development through its Transform Nutrition programme and the United Nations Development Programme - UNDP.  Learn more: https://www.wfp.org/news/news-release/safety-nets-cash-nutrition-education-has-greatest-impact-child-nutrition  Photos: © WFP/ Kauser Haider

FACT: the majority of the world’s hungry live in environments prone to climate hazards such as floods and droughts. Climate change is making such hazards more frequent and intense  land and water more scarce and difficult to access  and increases in agricultural productivity even harder to achieve.  http://www.wfp.org/climate-change   Photo: ©WFP/Kamrul Mithon

Did you know that more than 227 000 children in Myanmar benefit from WFP-supported school meals?  In many poorer countries  school meals are often the only regular and nutritious meal a child receives. They help families to educate their children and protect their food security in times of crisis.   http://www.wfp.org/stories/10-facts-about-hunger-myanmar

“We decided to work together so that those who do not have livelihood will have one ...The actual work was easy especially if you have companions with whom you can talk to ” Analyn is one of a group of 40 women who developed a communal garden in their village in southern Philippines.  With the cash she received  Analyn was able to buy rice  fish  sugar  and soap for her family. She has also set aside some money for emergency needs.  As the World Food Programme (WFP) increasingly uses cash-based assistance in the Philippines  women farmers like Analyn are able to grow their own produce and choose what to buy with the money they earn.  Photo © WFP/Faizza Tanggol

Children in South East Asia face a ‘double burden’ of obesity and undernutrition according to a new report by UNICEF  World Health Organization (WHO) and ASEAN   The causes of overweight and undernutrition are intertwined. A child whose growth was stunted in early childhood is at greater risk of becoming overweight later in life. The risk for being overweight goes up with increased access to junk food and drinks  physical inactivity and sedentary lifestyles. This is an increasing trend in many countries in the region  and contributes significantly to the growing prevalence of chronic diseases like diabetes and heart conditions.  Read the report here: http://www.unicef.org/eapro/media_25351.html

Women have crucial role to play in defeating hunger. As mothers  farmers  teachers and entrepreneurs  they hold the key to building a future free of malnutrition.   In Bangladesh  WFP teaches women how they can help break the cycle of malnutrition. In fact  one study showed that women's education contributed 43% of the reduction in child malnutrition over time.  ©WFP/Ranak Martin

“My ambition is to become a tailor  because I can earn money very quickly and reduce my mother’s burden.” Meet 14-year-old  Kajalaksmi from Jaffna  in the north of Sri Lanka.  Kajalaksmi survived civil war in her country but lost her father and her home. “I live with my mother  three brothers and a sister in a makeshift house ” she says. “During the conflict  my father was shot by gunmen while my family was visiting the temple. My mother tried to block the gunmen  but she lost her thumb.”   Kajalaksmi is one of 160 000 conflict affected children in 963 schools in northern Sri Lanka receiving school meal support with the help of WFP.

FACT: There is enough food in the world to feed the entire planet and yet 795 million people do not have enough to lead a healthy active life.    Hunger has many causes and WFP is working to end it  but we need YOUR help! The whole planet has to come together to reach #ZeroHunger and the Global Goals for Sustainable Development.  http://www.wfp.org/hunger/causes

Meet one of our pilots for the United Nations Humanitarian Air Service (UNHAS). When disaster strikes  she helps WFP provide passenger and light cargo service to some of the world’s most challenging and remote locations.   Thanks to the skill and dedication from UNHAS pilots  WFP’s humanitarian efforts can reach emergency zones around the globe.
Did you know that malnutrition comes in many forms? http://www.wfp.org/hunger/malnutrition

Did you know the kingdom of Bhutan measures  its quality of life through “gross national happiness”?   See how WFP is helping ensure children in Bhutan get the nutrition they need to live happy  healthy lives.

Imagine something that could help reduce poverty  hunger and malnutrition and ensure every child has access to education  health and nutrition. Would you believe it already exists?!   School meals are a sound investment in our children's future. WFP provides school meals to more than 20 million children each year and is working towards a world where school meals are universal.
Hunger is still one of the most urgent development challenges  yet the world is producing more than enough food. Recovering just half of what is lost or wasted could feed the world alone.

Sandori is from a remote village in the Philippines. She has four children  including an 11-month old daughter  Asma  and she is pregnant with her fifth child. Her husband is a farmer and earns a net income of around US$63 per year from their corn and rice harvest. Their harvest has suffered as a result of shifting weather patterns caused by El Niño.   The support they receive from WFP together with the local government provides much-needed assistance to both Sandori and Asma and helps ensure they can enjoy balanced meals every day and receive the nutrition they need to grow and flourish.  https://www.wfp.org/stories/philippines-nutrition-support

How would you feel if your home was washed away and you lost everything?   Last year in Myanmar it happened to over 1.9 million people who were displaced by flooding  with more than 9 million people affected.   Learn more about how WFP initiated a rapid emergency response and provided life-saving food assistance to many of those in need: http://www.wfp.org/stories/myanmar-five-months-after-floods

“I like to study  especially mathematics. I want to go to college some day and get a job.”   Meet 11-year old Muon Malai. Malai's mother is a rice farmer who  along with providing for her children  has to take care of other family members  including Malai’s disabled father.   Malai is one of 277 000 underprivileged children in highly food insecure parts of Cambodia currently receiving regular hot meals at school from WFP.

Most hungry people live in places that are prone to disasters. Climate change is making things worse.   Together with Oxfam America  WFP is helping vulnerable rural households boost their food and income security in the face of increasing climate risks through a comprehensive risk management approach  the R4 Rural Resilience Initiative.

Forget the millennial stereotype. These college students at Universities Fighting World Hunger - UFWH are making a world of a difference in getting to #ZeroHunger. Probably the best 16 minutes you'll hear this week! Listen to the podcast right now:  http://bit.ly/1RlROSQ

Two boys in front of the WFP distribution center in Al Dew village in Abyan governorate in Yemen.  More than 10 million or 41% of Yemen’s population is food insecure. Conflict since March of last year has exacerbated Yemen’s already poor food security. In February  reached more than 3 million people with much needed food.   ©WFP/Ammar Bamatraf

Climate disasters are a leading cause of hunger. That is why building resilience to disaster risk & #climatechange is crucial to reaching #ZeroHunger.  To reach the Global Goals for Sustainable Development we need to tackle both! See how WFP is helping people adapt to climate change.

Amazing the heights you can reach with the right support! From receiving WFP school meals as a child to becoming the youngest woman to summit Mount Everest. Now  Nimdoma is using her climbing expertise to help WFP reach remote villages. #ZeroHunger
Hapsatou is 12 years old. She fled the violence of Boko Haram. This is her voice: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4I11c-5GPGc

Boko Haram violence in northern Nigeria is forcing families to leave their homes and cross borders. Nearly 200 000 people are seeking refuge in Niger  Cameroon  and Chad. See  in photos  what life is like for those who fled the violence: http://panorama.wfp.org/classroom-12  © WFP/Marco Frattini

“I like to study  especially mathematics. I want to go to college some day and get a job." Meet 11-year-old Muon Malai. She is one of 277 000 underprivileged children in Cambodia currently receiving a hot daily breakfast from WFP’s School Meals: http://www.wfp.org/stories/cambodia-daily-breakfast-key-keeping-kids-school   ©WFP/Bushra Rahman

Climate change often impacts the poorest people the most. Last summer  nearly 2 million people in southeastern Bangladesh were affected by flooding and landslides. With the support of DFID - UK Department for International Development WFP was able to reach more than 185 000 people with emergency food assistance and provide cash assistance to 35 000 affected people.

Meet 12- year old Bean Sokhath and her pet cat Meao. “I like to study and I want to go to college someday. I know my mother is working very hard in the rice field. I want to work in an office and support her when I grow old”   Bean is an only child and 6th grade student in Tbeng  Siem Reap  Cambodia. Bean is one of 7 400 children  who receives school meals supported by Tencent in Siem Reap. She also receives a food scholarship (a take home ration of 10kg of rice)  which helps her to stay in school.   © WFP/ Bushra Rahman

FACT: 66 million primary school-age children attend classes hungry across the developing world. School meals help feed bodies and minds and help ensure every child has access to education  health and nutrition.  Learn more about how WFP supports school meals: https://www.wfp.org/school-meals
When women control additional income  their families enjoy better health  nutrition and education.

This child attends the Siamatika Basic School in Siavonga  Zambia where he eats daily school meals. In fact  Zambia's program focuses on homegrown school meals through WFP  which means their food is locally sourced and nutritious and helps boost the local economy. The national government aims to expand this program to support 2 million school kids by 2020.   © WFP/Rein Skullerud

FACT: Poor nutrition causes 45% of deaths in children under five each year. That's 3.1 million children. One child would be too many  3.1 million children is unacceptable.  Let's work together to stop this and achieve Zero Hunger and the Sustainable Development Goals.  http://give.wfp.org/ Photo: © WFP/Eoin Casey

The choice of food selection is ours. We can buy any type of food now ” said Mohammad Rasoul 37  a displaced person living in Kabul's Informal Settlement.   Read more to see how e-voucher cash-based transfers have helped WFP bring food to 120 000 people in Afghanistan. http://www.wfp.org/stories/wfp-supports-afghanistans-most-vulnerable-people-through-difficult-winter  Photos: © WFP/Eoin Casey

Have you heard of the SDGs? These Global Goals for Sustainable Development can transform our world for the better by 2030 and YOUR government has signed up to implement them!  Everybody has a role to play in making them happen - government or NGO  public or private company  organisation or individual. That includes YOU!
Lives uprooted. Meet the people fleeing Boko Haram. Read their stories of survival and learn what WFP is doing to help: http://www.wfp.org/stories/fleeing-boko-haram-diary-survival
#RecipeOfTheDay: Vegetarian Borscht from Kyrgyzstan. Try this nutritious  delicious and award winning recipe for lunch or dinner: http://www.wfp.org/stories/familychef-vegetarian-borsch

Ever wonder how humanitarian aid workers reach the most remote and challenging locations when disaster strikes?  The United Nations Humanitarian Air Service provides access where no safe surface transport or viable commercial aviation options are available.

FACT or FICTION? Because children are small  it is easy for them to consume the recommended intake of essential nutrients. What do you think?  Check out this great video from our nutrition team explaining what it takes to give a 1 to 2 year-old child all the nutrients they need.
Water gives hope  health & opportunity. Share this post to show support for access to safe water for all! #WorldWaterDay

Water is life! It quenches thirst  cleanses food  helps farms flourish  provides fish and keeps us healthy. For all these reasons and more  it is essential for reaching #ZeroHunger and the #SDGs. Happy #WorldWaterDay 😃

WFP’s ShareTheMeal app just reached 5 000 000 meals shared! We want to thank each and every one of you who has shared the meal with a schoolchild in Lesotho  a Syrian refugee child in Jordan or a mother and her baby in Syria. Together we can build a world with #ZeroHunger! If you haven’t already  download ShareTheMeal here: http://ow.ly/ZBpX9

School meals help ensure every child has access to education  health and nutrition.   In the fight against hunger  school meals are a sound investment in the future of the next generation. WFP is working towards a world where school meals are universal.

Many women suffered during the armed conflict here in 2002. So we established the Women of War in 2013 with the vision of building a new and peaceful Matanog”  See how one women's group in the Philippines has transformed a their lakeside community from a 'place to avoid' into a tourism haven.

WFP is currently facing four hunger emergencies at the same time. We are on the ground providing assistance to families in urgent need of food in South Sudan  Yemen  Iraq and Syria: http://www.wfp.org/emergencies

Climate disasters are a leading cause of hunger. To reach the Global Goals for Sustainable Development we need to tackle both! See how WFP is helping people adapt to climate change and supporting #AngryBirdsHappyPlanet !

Ever wonder why the Angry Birds are so angry?!  Perhaps it's because our beautiful planet and the life it supports are facing problems like never before. Luckily we have a solution with the Global Goals for Sustainable Development! Join us and raise your voice for #AngryBirdsHappyPlanet .  With the United Nations  United Nations Foundation and United Nations Development Programme - UNDP.

Last month  WFP implemented the use of iris-scan payment technology  which allows refugees to pay for food using an eye scan as opposed to cash  vouchers  or credit cards. By using this system  we aim to improve efficiency of the distribution process  since cash  vouchers  and PIN numbers can be lost  stolen  or left behind: http://www.wfp.org/news/news-release/world-food-programme-uses-innovative-iris-scan-technology-provide-food-assistance-

Happy St. Patrick's Day everybody!   What do zero hunger and #StPatricksDay have in common? Quite a lot actually! A history of famine and emigration led to Irish communities cropping up all over the world  and now the whole world goes green for an Irish holiday! With the support of Irish Aid and the Irish people  WFP is working to put an end to hunger for once and for all!

Women and girls make up more than half the world’s population and are often those most affected by food insecurity  poverty  climate change  lack of healthcare  and global economic crises.  Last week the world celebrated International Women's Day. At WFP  we recognise that to solve these problems  women must be included. That is why we like to celebrate women every day!
Here's to a world where every child has enough nutritious food to live an active  healthy and long life.  © WFP/Boris Heger

Life is tough enough already for those forced to leave their homes due to conflict  natural disasters  or severe poverty. In Afghanistan  we are using technology to provide families in temporary accommodation with vital food assistance. Learn more about our innovative cash-based transfers programme.

Yesterday marked five years of war in Syria. For many children  five years is a lifetime. 6 million children are among the 13.5 million Syrians who are in need of assistance. Yesterday  today and always we must stand #WithSyria.  Join us and show your support by posting a picture of yourself making the dove symbol on Facebook or Twitter using the Hashtag #IamSyrian.
Five years of war. 11.7 million forced to flee. Stand #withSyria because Syria needs our collective voice to call for peace. #IamSyrian

5 years of brutality and bloodshed have turned Syria into the epicenter of a massive humanitarian crisis. We will not stand by while Syria continues to burn. Celebrities and Syrian refugees have joined their hands to tell world leaders that this must end. Join the campaign by posting a picture of yourself making the dove symbol on Facebook or Twitter using the Hashtag #IamSyrian.   Today & always we must stand #WithSyria: http://panorama.wfp.org/iamsyrian

Money means power. But it can also mean empowerment!  In the Philippines  cash-based assistance helps women farmers like Analyn grow their own produce and choose what to buy with the money they earn. Photo © WFP/Faizza Tanggol

FACT: A child's first 1000 days is critical for full development.  In the life of a child  nutrition during the first 1 000 days - from a mother’s pregnancy to the child’s second birthday - can mean the difference between a promising future or one plagued by poor health and stunted physical and mental growth.

My uncle brought me back to Turkey. I live with him and his family. I can never forget my parents but now my uncle is like a father to me. I work at a candy factory  10 hours a day  6 days a week. In Syria I was working as a carpenter. I miss my old life. I had friends and family  I was happier. Now I’ve lost everyone. My only dream is to go back to Syria. This is the only thing. Please help my dream come true. (2/2)  Join #IamSyrian: http://panorama.wfp.org/iamsyrian

My name is Firas  I am 18 years old and from Syria. My whole family was killed in an attack. My dad had sent me to Turkey to work. Three months later my uncle called me and told me to come home. When I returned I saw my house had been torn down and learned that my family had all been killed. I felt so lonely  I had 6 brothers and sisters and parents and now they were all gone. (1/2)

“It’s changed me as a woman  mother and wife as well as a leader of this group. My husband always helps me and we are happy to have joined the Enhancing Food Security project ” says Hasina. Learn more about how a food security project in Bangladesh is helping women like Hasina take control of their lives.
Let us not forget the human face of the Syrian war. Innocents have suffered and have had their homes destroyed. #IamSyrian
On Tuesday the world celebrated International Women's Day. At WFP we celebrate women every day :) #IWD2016

“I miss everything about Syria: its people  our life there  the smell”. Aliye would go back to Syria today if she could. The war forced her entire family to flee from Raqqa four years ago.  Her tears won’t end until she's able to go back home. #IamSyrian
Fact: For every $1 invested in nutrition a country can get $16 in return.   © WFP/ Ranak Martin

How do international agencies support gender equality? This great infographic explains some of the work of WFP and organisations like United Nations Development Programme - UNDP  UN-Water  UNESCO  Gavi  the Vaccine Alliance  United Nations Research Institute for Social Development (UNRISD) and others.

What do you eat for breakfast?! Some say it's the most important meal of the day. For 11 year old Muon Malai  and many like her  it is  as it means she can stay in school and one day fulfill her dream of going to college and getting a job!
After having fled their home in the Lake Chad region following Boko Haram attacks  this mother is now just one of the 138 321 displaced persons from Northern Nigeria.   © WFP/Tim Dirven
As the crisis in Syria enters its sixth year  WFP wanted to take a moment to salute the women of Syria for their strength and resilience. Share this video to show your support.

R4 Rural Resilience Initiative is a comprehensive risk management approach that helps vulnerable rural households increase their food and income security in the face of increasing climate risks.   We were honoured to receive  a Climate Change Business Journal Business Achievement Award for our work with Oxfam America bringing insurance to more than 30 000 African farmers through R4.

“Women of War” may sound like fighters but this women's group in the Philippines advocates for peace and supports community development. They have transformed their lakeside community from a 'place to avoid' to a peaceful tourist haven.

“Growing up I got assistance from WFP and thought one day I want to do this work. I want to save lives and help people the way that I have been helped.”  --Dimanche  a WFP Field Monitoring Assistant in South Sudan   More from Dimanche: https://www.wfp.org/stories/building-future-for-women-south-sudan

Fact: In many developing countries in Asia and the Pacific and Africa  women typically work 12 to 13 hours per week more than men. Learn more facts about women in the world below and tell us why you think gender equality matters! Photo: © WFP/ Tina Stacey

Winter is drawing to a close. In Afghanistan  where winter can be particularly harsh  WFP uses technology and cash based transfers to ensure that those who need it most have food during the winter months.  Photos © WFP/ Eoin Casey
Do you know the warning signs of heat exhaustion? (+ more tips for staying safe in the summer sun!) http://rdcrss.org/29BTQEq
Red Cross volunteers from across the country are working tirelessly to help West Virginia communities get back on their feet following the worst flooding many areas have seen in 100 years.

In June  West Virginia was struck by its worst flooding in 100 years. Hundreds of Red Cross volunteers answered the call to help  and many remain as the community recovery work continues. When disasters create such tremendous need  we are thankful for all those who jump in to provide families  friends  neighbors and total strangers a helping hand.

There is a significant blood shortage but you can help! Your blood or platelet donation can help save hospital patients' lives. Every two seconds someone in the U.S. needs a blood transfusion  and the Red Cross must collect 14 000 donations every day for patients at about 2 600 hospitals nationwide. Please make an appointment to #GiveNow: rcblood.org/29d5fu8  Red Cross Blood Donor App (3cu.be/blood) or 1-800-RED CROSS. Thank you for supporting patients in need!

We really needed help  the Red Cross was there and we thank you.  The #ErskineFire in California has burned thousands of acres and destroyed hundreds of homes  like John Couracos' in Lake Isabella. This is his story.

Liz Hungerford started her day in Texas as a Red Cross volunteer prepared to help hand out lunches in communities devastated by historic floods. What she didn’t know was that she would save a life that day. Her story: http://rdcrss.org/29dnDmH

James Sams lost his home to the recent floods in White Sulphur Springs  West Virginia. “My wife and I lived in the house for 40 years  and I thought there wasn't any chance of flooding ” James explained to Red Cross worker Marko Kokic. “So I never paid attention to flood warnings  but boy was I wrong this time.” This is James’s second shelter and his wife’s third since the floods. He’s looking forward to a hot shower that this shelter will be able to provide.   Read more stories and learn how to help: http://rdcrss.org/29a5N3R

Did you know holiday weekends (like Fourth of July) always make it more difficult for us to collect enough blood and platelet donations to keep up with hospital patient needs? This year is no exception. Please make time to donate blood or platelets between July 1 and 5. You will receive this limited-edition Red Cross lunch cooler (while supplies last). Make an appointment now at redcrossblood.org. #ChooseYourDay

Over the last several days historic flooding in West Virginia and destructive wildfires in California have threatened and destroyed multiple communities. Red Cross volunteers from across the country have responded to help those impacted by these disasters and bring comfort in the midst of tragedy. See how we are responding and how you can help: http://rdcrss.org/292Rjn9

The Red Cross has hundreds of workers on the ground in West Virginia responding to the disastrous flooding that has forced people from their homes. In addition to teams opening shelters  providing meals and relief supplies  our Red Cross disaster mental health workers are reaching out to help families cope during this traumatic time.  We’re continuing to monitor the situation and are working with state and local officials and partners to help ensure people get the assistance they need.

Devastating floods have swept across West Virginia  covering a large portion of the state. Red Cross workers have opened numerous shelters and are providing meals  relief supplies and other assistance to those affected as well as meals for first responders. We are monitoring the situation and working with state and local officials and partners to help ensure people get the help they need. For information on how to stay safe in an area where flooding may occur  or how you can lend a hand  please visit: http://rdcrss.org/28TIUi3

Our friends at ARC West Virginia Region are responding to severe flooding across the state. Forty-four counties have been declared a state of emergency  and the Red Cross is providing safe shelter  food  emergency relief supplies  emotional support  health services and recovery assistance to families who have been affected. For continuing coverage around flooding in West Virginia  check The Weather Channel.

This historic image deserves more than just a passing glance  as it speaks volumes about the the changing roles and importance of  women and the American Red Cross during World War II. Find out the story behind these courageous Red Crossers: http://rdcrss.org/28QleuZ

It's shaping up to be another dangerous wildfire season in many western states as ongoing drought conditions  high temperatures  and winds have already driven flames across several thousand acres in California  Arizona  and New Mexico. Understand the risks in your area and what you can do to protect you  your family  and your property from the dangers of wildfires http://bddy.me/28M1xYk

Did you know the American Red Cross  along with our global Red Cross partners  provides vital humanitarian assistance to refugees and migrants? In countries such as Jordan  Greece and Rwanda  the global Red Cross distributes food  water  hygiene kits  baby supplies  clothing and first aid kits. We also provide medical care and first aid  shelter  and psychosocial support.   Today  on World Refugee Day  we honor the strength and resilience of these refugee communities. We also recognize the current struggles faced by refugee populations and work to educate people around the world about refugee issues and how they can help displaced populations. Find out more about our services: http://rdcrss.org/1SMxjF2
Celebrating dads everywhere  Red Crossers share stories of the superheroes in their lives: http://rdcrss.org/FathersDay

For 60 years Lina Czubas has been giving back to our military service members as a Red Cross volunteer. At 92 years young  Lina continues that dedicated service today  spending four days each week providing comfort and care to soldiers at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in the nation's capital: http://rdcrss.org/1typIPw (American Red Cross - Walter Reed National Military Medical Center)
As you head out this summer  don't forget to "pack" the Red Cross First Aid app on your mobile device. It can help prepare you to handle this season's bumps and bruises. http://rdcrss.org/1tqUxVM

On this World Blood Donor Day  we want to thank each and every one of you who has rolled up a sleeve after the tragedy in Orlando. Across the country  we've witnessed your willingness to provide help for patients in need and stand in solidarity  and we are truly grateful. Please remember that volunteer blood donors are needed every day to help save lives. http://rdcrss.org/1totJ8z

The deepest sympathies of the entire American Red Cross family are with the people of Orlando and those affected by Sunday morning’s tragic shooting. As our nation grieves over this loss  many of us may be experiencing a variety of emotions such as shock  disbelief and sadness. To help cope in the aftermath of this devastating tragedy  we wanted to pass along these recommendations and resources. http://rdcrss.org/1tsGdMX

Our thoughts and deepest sympathies are with the people of Orlando and those affected by last night's tragic shooting. Right now  Local Red Cross volunteers are supporting emergency responders with water and food.
What's it like to deploy to Djibouti with Red Cross Service to the Armed Forces? Amber gives us an inside look: http://rdcrss.org/1tmGgdo
You may have seen our emergency vehicles deployed to a disaster. Now meet two of our drivers - friends Jess and Marcus - and read what compelled them to take the wheel. http://rdcrss.org/1tkaMoc

Supermodel and Red Cross ambassador Niki Taylor was on GMA this morning to discuss the importance of donating blood or platelets this summer. Donors are encouraged to roll up a sleeve in honor of World Blood Donor Day  June 14! Make an appointment to donate blood or platelets at redcrossblood.org. #ChooseYourDay

We're six days into the Atlantic hurricane season and Tropical Storm Colin is moving toward Florida with strong winds and heavy rain. We have NOAA's prediction for this hurricane season and tips to get prepared for anyone in Colin's path: http://rdcrss.org/1t281al

As you plan for summer vacation  don't forget to make an appointment to give blood or platelets. Be a hero to patients in need! Make your appointment by downloading the free Blood Donor App at 3cu.be/blood  visiting redcrossblood.org or calling 1-800-RED CROSS. #ChooseYourDay

Floods  tornadoes and severe storms have devastated lives and livelihoods for months across Texas. Please join us in helping the thousands of residents who have been impacted. http://rdcrss.org/1P8vA5T

Red Cross volunteer Santana Garcia distributes bottled water in the greater Houston area to those coping with massive flooding in their neighborhoods. He and his wife  Idalia Trevino  drove from southern Texas to help families in need  and they feel humbled to serve fellow Texans as the rain continues to fall. In addition to bottled water  their volunteer team distributed tarps  mops  bug spray  cleaning supplies  gloves  face masks and other items. This is the couple’s sixth year volunteering with the Red Cross  and we are grateful for their service.

Red Cross volunteers are responding to record rainfall and historic flooding in parts of Texas. Fifteen emergency shelters have been opened thus far to provide support to affected communities  and more severe weather is expected throughout the week. See the latest update on the response efforts and how you can help those impacted. http://rdcrss.org/1P1nTyr

Today we honor the members of the U.S. Armed Forces who have made the ultimate sacrifice in service to our country. We are humbled by those who have given so much on our behalf and thankful to all the brave men and women who have served and continue to serve. May we never take for granted the freedoms we enjoy and never forget those who protect and preserve that freedom each day.

Our hearts are with the people of Texas as they once again face unrelenting floods  forcing thousands from their homes. Please consider helping as we work to provide relief to those affected by this disaster. http://rdcrss.org/1sW9z6c

Do you have #MemorialDay plans? Be a hero and roll up a sleeve this weekend! Vacation plans  summer activities and school breaks can make some donors less available to give  but patients don’t get a summer vacation from needing blood. #ChooseYourDay to help save lives. As a special thanks  those who come to give blood or platelets from May 27-31 will receive a #RedCross t-shirt  while supplies last! Make your appointment to give blood or platelets by downloading the free Blood Donor App at 3cu.be/blood  visiting redcrossblood.org or calling 1-800-RED CROSS.

Vacation plans  summer activities and school breaks can make some donors less available to give  but patients don’t get a summer vacation from needing blood. #ChooseYourDay to help save lives. Make your appointment to give blood or platelets by downloading the free Blood Donor App at 3cu.be/blood  visiting redcrossblood.org or calling 1-800-RED CROSS.
What's our favorite beach activity? Reviewing hurricane tips  of course! This week's Weather Red Report covers three steps you can take now to prepare for hurricane season.

When a fire forced the evacuation of more than 130 seniors from a Littleton  Colorado apartment building  social media served as a critical link in keeping family overseas informed about the safety of their loved ones http://rdcrss.org/1Wvu6u2 #smem
#TBT to 1917: Red Cross nurses work at a recruiting station to enroll new members during World War I.
“I love coming to help in the United States ” says Eric Travesi. “Here I can help many more people doing disaster relief  bringing them hope.” http://rdcrss.org/21XJejN

When disasters such as home fires strike  Sean is among the many dedicated #RedCross disaster volunteers who answer the call 24/7/365. Learn how you can volunteer in your community: http://rdcrss.org/1WmmmKF

We tip our hats to nurses everywhere for National Nurses Week  but couldn’t help calling out some fantastic nurses serving with our Service to the Armed Forces (SAF). Read about our amazing nurses near and far: http://rdcrss.org/nursewk16
Just in time for Mother's Day! Share this fun note with the special women in your life to let them know just how much you care – and that you're taking care of yourself and others  too.

“If it weren't for the American Red Cross supplying that hospital with donor blood  I don't know where I would be ” said Johnetta Goolsby. As we celebrate the strong and loving women who shape our lives this Mother’s Day  consider making a lifesaving gift to patients in need – patients like this inspirational young mother and breast cancer survivor. Read her story: http://rdcrss.org/21A9K2p

This Service to Armed Forces volunteer never dreamed he'd need help from the Red Cross when a crisis hit home. Read his story and find out how the Red Cross emergency communications helped him: http://rdcrss.org/1W7ZP4b…

When you're helping somebody  it puts a glow in your heart. Dennis  a Red Cross volunteer  participated in a smoke alarm installation event in his community. Smoke alarms installed that day would help save this family from a home fire later that year. #firesafety

Hold onto your lightsabers  friends! American Red Cross of Alaska has important tips to help you prepare for the rise of the First Order. Plus learn how you can be a #ForceforChange and support our mission – you could win some great prizes too! https://www.crowdrise.com/FFCRedCross

When an individual  family or community is faced with a string of crises  disaster fatigue can set in. As Lindsay from Houston shares  the emotional strain around having to rebuild lives is difficult enough the first time. Doing it all over again adds even more stress. If you're facing disaster fatigue  try these tips for coping: http://rdcrss.org/1rlBv2g

“Our family is very grateful to those donors who donated their platelets and blood ” said John Betzen. “This is not something you can go to the store and purchase. We are certain it helped save Sarah’s life.” Read this donor's inspiring story: http://rdcrss.org/1rl7orL

Not sure how to prepare for severe weather and other disasters? Our Emergency App can help! Download the free app to your mobile device for easy access to important emergency tips  resources and information. ALL of your family members will be glad that you did: http://rdcrss.org/1YTXdVK #PrepareAthon

Forecasts indicate a high threat for severe weather and possible tornadoes across much of the Central U.S. beginning this afternoon and evening. Know the risks  monitor your local weather conditions and take steps to be prepared if your area is affected. http://rdcrss.org/1YRL8QX
There is potential for severe weather throughout the Midwest this week. Watch as our colleague Brigette shares tips on how to be Red Cross ready!

One year after a devastating 7.8 magnitude earthquake took nearly 9 000 lives and damaged or destroyed more than 800 000 homes  the American Red Cross continues to help the people of Nepal rebuild their lives. While the road to recovery is still a long one  the earthquake ravaged villages of Nepal aren’t defined by destruction  but by hope. For more information  visit www.redcross.org/Nepal.

The flood can happen at any moment and you don't know it's coming until it's there.   See how we're helping people like Noble during the devastating flooding in Houston and surrounding areas of Texas. You can help people affected by the Texas floods and tornadoes. Your donation enables the Red Cross to prepare for  respond to and help people recover from these disasters: http://rdcrss.org/TXFB
Friends  we are truly grateful for the generosity and support you shared this Giving Day. We couldn't do it without you. On behalf of the families we help  thank you! #help1family
You can help ensure children and families stay warm after disasters and can get a good night’s sleep with six comforting blankets. #Help1family by donating $30: http://rdcrss.org/1RPHI2b

Families need help when they lose everything to a disaster  and Linda's story moves us every time we hear it. "If it wasn't for the Red Cross  we wouldn't have a place to go." Your gift of $88.50 could provide a family with a day’s worth of food  plus blankets and other essentials: http://rdcrss.org/1RPHI2b #help1family

In times of tragedy  the comfort of a warm meal cannot be overstated. Your support helps put food on the table and smiles on the faces of those touched by disaster. #help1family http://rdcrss.org/1RPHI2b

Nearly every eight minutes  the #RedCross responds to a disaster and helps families who have lost everything. But you can help during those first devastating hours. Thanks to our generous Giving Day Corporate Supporters  your gift will be MATCHED dollar-for-dollar up to $210 000 – but only if you give before midnight! Donate now: http://rdcrss.org/1RPHI2b #help1family
We've teamed up with iHeartRadio and What's Trending  for #TUBEATHON! You don't want to miss these performances starting tonight at 7 p.m. PT. Tune in here: http://rdcrss.org/1XJ41VQ #help1family

Devastating flooding has struck the greater Houston area  with nearly two feet of rain washing through communities and forcing many from their homes. The Red Cross has opened 13 emergency shelters to assist residents in the affected areas. This is the latest disaster to strike a region that has been hit hard by severe weather over the last year. http://rdcrss.org/1XH7zrL

Did you know that Red Crossers have responded to three times more disasters so far in 2016 than the last three years combined? It's been a busy time for us  which makes this year's Giving Day  coming up in just three days  all the more meaningful. Watch our latest #WeatherRed Report  and learn how you can help! http://rdcrss.org/1VawYKW #help1family

Heavy rains in Texas have created flash flooding risks for millions of people. The Red Cross is working to mobilize volunteers and provide assistance to all those affected by the storms. Here's what you can do to keep you and your loved ones safe in a flood emergency: http://rdcrss.org/1YDlVta

Ecuadorean Red Cross (Cruz Roja Ecuatoriana) teams are continuing search and rescue efforts  after a 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck the South American country last night. 800 volunteers were activated to provide first aid and search for survivors.   Our hearts are with families suffering in the affected areas. American Red Cross teams have been working in Ecuador for years  helping prepare kids and communities for earthquakes  as seen in this photo.

As families reel from the second earthquake in two days  the Japanese Red Cross has dispatched 12 medical teams to help the injured. Volunteers have distributed blankets  sleeping mats  tarps  pillows  and hygiene kits to people in shelters. Our hearts go out to those affected in Japan.

We're proud of the hard work our volunteers and partners do to spread our #firesafety message far and wide. Whether they are sharing their personal stories  installing smoke alarms or practicing fire escape plans  they are helping to make their communities safer every day. Watch a handful of our favorite clips: http://rdcrss.org/april-hfc #help1family

Would you know what to do if your pet had an allergic reaction? Was choking? Got frostbite? Quickly find answers to these scary situations and so much more in our (free!) Pet First Aid App: http://3cu.be/sharepfa
We're just one week away from #RedCross Giving Day on April 21. What type of giver are you? Take our quiz to find out! http://rdcrss.org/GDquiz #help1family

San Diego-based Red Cross logistics volunteer Eddie Gilbert literally “hiked” onto a Disaster Relief Operation deployment last summer during the wildfires in Washington state. Read the rest of Eddie's volunteer story  plus other inspiring volunteer profiles in honor of National Volunteer Week: http://rdcrss.org/nvw2016

During National Volunteer Week  and every week  we celebrate the thousands of everyday heroes who volunteer for the Red Cross. The Brown family is one example of the countless volunteers who help respond to disasters in their home state and beyond.   We offer a heartfelt THANK YOU to all of our amazing volunteers! #help1family

Have you ever wanted to help a family after a disaster but didn't know how? You can help us provide a family with a day’s worth of food  plus blankets and other essentials. Make an impact. Be one of the first to make a Giving Day gift: http://rdcrss.org/1VawYKW #help1family

#ThrowbackThursday to July of 1944 in Washington  D.C. A total of 106 000 pints of blood a week was required to keep the Armed Forces fully supplied during World War II. Responding to a recent Army-Navy request  Red Cross workers prepared voluntary blood donations for shipment. (Photo by E. Johnson/American Red Cross) #TBT

Meet Aubri Johnson  an American Red Cross youth volunteer and daughter of military parents stationed in Daegu  South Korea. She is one of a number of military children who volunteer at the Camp Walker Veterinary Clinic. Watch her story and learn more about our services with the military and military families: http://rdcrss.org/1Xh2FBx

It's been a difficult start to 2016 as the devastation wrought by severe weather has left thousands in need of help. Red Cross workers from across the country have been working non-stop alongside affected communities to provide much needed relief in the face of disaster. Here Red Cross president and CEO  Gail McGovern  shares her thoughts on what we've seen so far in this already historic year. http://rdcrss.org/1UTvQwX

If we each #help1family  think of what we could do. Nearly every eight minutes  the #RedCross responds to a disaster and helps families who have lost everything. The good news is you can help during those first devastating hours. Join us for Red Cross Giving Day on April 21: http://rdcrss.org/1VawYKW

Musicians Cam  Dakota Bradley  Marty Roe of Diamond Rio and Lauren Alanina share their personal stories of how home fires have touched their lives. Watch here: http://rdcrss.org/chideo #2steps2minutes #firesafety

Did you know that O negative blood is the universal blood type that can help save the lives of patients with any other blood type? Because of that  there is often a significant need for O negative blood donors. Check out how blood donations make a difference - http://rdcrss.org/1MTvcqY
A big thanks to the Empire State Building for shining a light on Red Cross Month! #BeAHero

This week  devastating flooding in the south has forced thousands of people from their homes. Preliminary reports indicate more than 1 000 homes have been destroyed or severely damaged across Louisiana  Mississippi  Arkansas and Texas. Hundreds of American Red Cross disaster workers are on the job  responding to help the many communities impacted by this disaster - http://rdcrss.org/22j21GG

Nearly every eight minutes  the #RedCross responds to a disaster such as a home fire  and assists a family in need. You can help make an impact with us! Join us on April 21: http://rdcrss.org/gd16 #help1family

Red Cross volunteers come in all shapes and sizes. Say hello to Timmy  Lucy  Aslan Leonberger and the rest of this pack of pups that lends a comforting paw to patients  families and staff at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center.

The Belgian Red Cross (Rode Kruis-Vlaanderen) has mobilized nearly 400 people in response to the March 22 bombings in Brussels. On the day of the attacks  the Red Cross dispatched 30 ambulances to the Zaventem Airport and Maelbeek metro station—and transported more than 100 wounded people to 16 different hospitals. The entire ground floor of the Thon EU Residence Hotel in Brussels was turned into a Red Cross medical post.  Red Cross volunteers  doctors  nurses  paramedics and psychological emergency response teams have been working around the clock to support people present at the scene of the attacks and their loved ones. For more information on their ongoing response  please visit their website: http://www.rodekruis.be/en/

Ever wonder what happens on an overseas Red Cross Service to the Armed Forces installation? We have a Q&A (with pics!) from Jonathan Glenn  SAF Regional Program Manager at the Naval Station in Rota  Spain. #BeAHero http://rdcrss.org/safspain

How would you celebrate your 100th birthday? Blanche  a longtime Red Cross volunteer  decided to host a blood drive! She more than met her goal of 100 blood donors  with 114 participants. She’s already thinking about next year. Read her story: http://rdcrss.org/blanche       You can make your next appointment at redcrossblood.org.

With coffee brewing as early as 2:45 a.m.  Red Cross volunteers prepared for a soldiers' welcome home ceremony at Fort Bragg in North Carolina. Meet some of the family members at the event who eagerly awaited the return of their loved ones from deployment in Iraq.  http://rdcrss.org/25gDftg
