Many communities across the south have been inundated with floodwaters in recent days. With so many forced from their homes  hundreds of American Red Cross disaster workers are responding to help. Get the latest updates here: http://rdcrss.org/1R0JuYH

Red Cross volunteers continue to provide emergency assistance across several states where storms and flooding have left many communities damaged or destroyed. Get the latest on what's being done to aid areas impacted and what you can do to help: http://rdcrss.org/1RhHvEx

Cynthia Ann Starr’s home in West Monroe  Louisiana  was flooded earlier this week. She arrived at a shelter with only her medication and a dry set of clothing. “It means so much to know that we have a safe place to stay and won’t have to sleep under the stars ” she said of the Red Cross shelter where she found refuge.

When Terina Smith  Michael Stevenson and their three small children were rescued from floodwaters in Monroe  Louisiana  they found safety at a Red Cross shelter. Volunteer Ethel Payne has helped lift their spirits during their stay. Across several southern states  the Red Cross continues to provide relief to communities like Monroe that have been devastated by flooding.
Don't forget it's Daylight Saving Time this weekend! While you're turning your clocks forward  this is a great time to brush up on these #firesafety tips: http://rdcrss.org/turnandtest #TurnandTest

Red Cross volunteers provided safe shelter Wednesday night for more than 350 people impacted by flooding in Louisiana and Texas. Storms and rising waters have forced the evacuations of several thousand residents in Louisiana and the severe weather is expected to continue for several days. Today we take a look back at Red Cross workers across the waters in New Guinea during World War II. In June 1944  Jo David of Seattle  Washington (left) and Zelma Leggett of Savannah  Georgia set up "Jenny " their makeshift mobile canteen to serve refreshments to men of isolated units in the foothills of the Owen Stanley mountains.  Find out more about our involvement during WWII: http://rdcrss.org/24QQ7Gm

Sarah Springer takes her fight to end Alzheimer's to new heights as she hikes a "14er" on The Longest Day. Read her story: http://bit.ly/28IDqpD

Happy Father's Day to all who have shown strength and love in the face of Alzheimer's. Whether you care for someone with the disease or you are living with it yourself  you are an inspiration.
Even though my dad doesn’t remember that day  I always will. It was a day of light. In honor of Father's Day  Sara Gearheart shares a moment with her dad she will treasure forever.

Alzheimer's takes so much from us  but Mike and Julia's story reminds us that it can't take love.

The Senate Appropriations Committee approved a $400 million increase for Alzheimer's federal research funding and included the Health Outcomes  Planning  and Education (HOPE) for Alzheimer’s Act in its funding bill. We are appalled that anyone would plan to develop a film that satirizes an individual living with Alzheimer's or another dementia. To the 5 million+ Americans living with Alzheimer’s & the 15 million family caregivers providing support  Alzheimer’s is no joke.  We will rally against anyone who marginalizes the devastating and deadly impact of Alzheimer’s. It’s time to stop this forever. #AlzheimersIsNoJoke  #NotFunny #ReaganMovie

UPDATE: The Obama Administration has just made Arctic drilling hard to do—but not impossible.  "Where we drill  we spill. The only safe Arctic drilling is no Arctic drilling...The Arctic is harsh  fragile  remote  and pristine. We can’t contain or clean up the oil from a blowout in these waters. And we can’t protect them from the devastation that would bring. That’s why no regulations will make Arctic drilling safe.”   —Niel Lawrence  Alaska Director at NRDC

This is the first-ever national monument devoted to the LGBTQ community.    Here's a statement from NRDC president Rhea Suh:   “We tell the story of who we are through our national treasures  and the president’s decision represents a new definition of inclusivity for our national parks. Stonewall’s tiny urban park has a powerful cultural history—and using the Antiquities Act to declare it a monument helps us preserve for future generations the lesser-told story of the LGBTQ community's struggle for equality."

We've come a long way! Last fall  we called on world leaders to form an international agreement to fight climate change. And today  175 nations officially signed the Paris Agreement! Plus  more than 13 MILLION people from around the world have added their names to demand climate action!

Happy #EarthDay! Today at the United Nations  171 countries signed the historic Paris Agreement to fight climate change! This sets a new record for the number of countries signing an international agreement!  "Today marks a beginning  a historic start. We’re leaving the age of Jurassic fuels behind - for good - and moving to cleaner  smarter ways to power our future. The world is watching. We’ll hold our leaders to account. We’ll hold each other to account. And we’ll cut the global carbon footprint today so climate chaos doesn’t overwhelm our kids tomorrow.”   —NRDC president Rhea Suh
This historic agreement sets the world on a path of reducing the dangerous carbon pollution driving global climate change. #ParisAgreement

This Earth Day will be historic: World leaders will meet tomorrow at the United Nations in New York to sign the historic Paris climate agreement they struck last December. The signing will officially put the world's blueprint for a clean energy future into motion.   Help us tell "The Big 5" carbon polluting countries to deliver on their Paris climate commitments: http://on.nrdc.org/1NtAoSw

BIG NEWS! Today  South Africa dropped its plan to lift the four decade ban on international trade in rhino horn!   Thank you to everyone that signed our petition and helped call on the South African government to do this!   Legalizing trade in rhino horn would have been a disaster for species that are just barely hanging on now as it is. This decision does not fix the plight of rhinos—but it gives space and time to tackle poaching  close down illegal markets and eliminate the loopholes that already help enable the $20 billion market in illegal international wildlife trade. South Africa bought more time for rhinos today—and should follow up with more key actions to keep these animals on the planet.
It is the actions we take  as nations  that will form the sum of our collective efforts  and bring about the change we need to leave our children a livable world.  —NRDC President Rhea Suh

UPDATE: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency will limit methane emissions from existing oil and gas facilities. This move was announced in conjunction with President Obama's meeting today with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.  “No credible plan to combat climate change can ignore methane emissions  which are the second largest industrial source of climate-changing pollution after power plants ” said NRDC's David Doniger. “The danger is real and urgent and the Environmental Protection Agency must act without delay.” #CutMethane

After the police killings of Alton Sterling and Philando Castile this week  our executive director Michael Brune shared this:   "It is impossible to not be outraged by the devastating images of black people being gunned down by police on a shockingly regular basis and it should be impossible to remain silent in the face of this sustained injustice any longer. Sadly  the tragedies that are unfolding before our eyes are just a fraction of the violence that has been happening off camera in our nation for far too long.    The Sierra Club believes all people deserve a healthy planet with clean air and water  a stable climate and safe communities. That means all people deserve equal protection under the law and the right to a life free of discrimination  hatred and violence. Unfortunately  those aspirations and goals are not a reality in our country  and that is why the Sierra Club stands in solidarity with all of those saying #BlackLivesMatter  demanding justice  accountability  and action to confront the racism and inequality that has allowed these tragedies to persist. We can do better and by standing together to work for the changes that are needed  we will.”  Showing Up for Racial Justice (SURJ) has ways to help.

I  too  believe that 'America the Beautiful' should be our national anthem  a conviction that has only deepened in the years since I returned from Iraq. My fight for free lands for all the people of the United States didn't end when my military career was over. My mission just took on a different shape: I went from defending the nation overseas to defending public lands here at home. Like many other veterans  I found a kind of healing in wild places. I also found something just as important—a renewed sense of purpose and another way to serve my country. - U.S. Army veteran and Rocky Mountain director for the Vet Voice Foundation Garett Reppenhagen

The Yosemite Grant Act was signed by President Abraham Lincoln on June 30  1864. This week's #ThrowbackThursday is a Valley View in Yosemite  with Helen and Anita Gompertz in the foreground. This photograph was taken on June 15  1897  more than 30 years after the Yosemite Grant Act was signed and before the formation of the National Park Service.

“Glamping” is the ugly mash-up of “glamour” and “camping.” For some  glamping is simply camping made more comfortable. Others have a darker view. One critic has called it “nature on a silver platter.”  This might all be true. But  at the same time  it’s crucial to remember that for some people—those with disabilities  the elderly  and some families with small children—glamping might be the only way they can enjoy the outdoors. Glamping can make the outdoors accessible.  Read more from Sierra Magazine --> http://sc.org/28Xo6aU  After reading the piece  what do you think? Has your mind changed from what you thought before reading the article?

The residents of Flint already have some of the highest water bills in the nation. According to the Michigan Department of Treasury  those bills are projected to double by 2021 if the current "system is not upgraded and certain costs remain fixed." So when will Flint's water be potable again without a filter? No city  state or federal officials have promised a date. "For over two years  the people of Flint have been drinking through lead-painted straws " said pediatrician Dr. Mona Hanna-Attisha.   Read more --> http://on.freep.com/1X67LmZ

An astonishing 40 percent of all coal produced in the United States comes from public  taxpayer-owned land. The government recently put a hold on new federal coal leases to study the impact that coal mined on public lands has on our climate. This means we have an unprecedented opportunity to push this country towards a clean energy future and away from dirty fuels. The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is taking public comments on the scope of its study looking at how our public lands are used for coal mining.  Tell them it’s time that we keep the coal in the ground and use our public lands to reflect what’s best for our climate and communities --> http://sc.org/1XVliiq

States can do a great deal  and cities can do a lot  says Mark Jacobson  a Stanford University scientist whose work has helped guide state and local climate plans  and co-founder of the nonprofit the Solutions Project. We couldn't agree more! That's why earlier this year we launched the Ready for 100 campaign  which aims to enlist more cities to make a 100 percent clean energy commitment.   Already  a handful of small cities - Burlington  Vermont; Aspen  Colorado; and Greensburg  Kansas - get all their electricity from renewable energy. Another 12 communities - from Grand Rapids  Michigan  to Georgetown  Texas - have pledged to do so. Are you ready for your city to commit to 100% clean energy too? Ask your mayor if they are #ReadyFor100 now?!  http://sc.org/1si2tYW   #ReadyFor100 #SeizeTheGrid

Did you know Arctic terns have the longest migration of any animal on the planet -- at least 25 000 miles every year?! They fly from their breeding grounds in the Arctic to Antarctica and back.   Each year millions of birds of many species visit breeding grounds in the Arctic Wildlife Refuge before migrating to our parks and backyards.  This Migratory Bird Day  tell Congress to permanently protect the Arctic National Wildlife Refugue as well as the birds that depend on this special place! http://sc.org/1WxUJyp  #wearethearctic

Puerto Rico is in the midst of a debt crisis  with more than $72 billion of debt  and no way to pay it off.  This is where H.R. 4900  or the Puerto Rico Oversight  Management  and Economic Stability Act (PROMESA)  comes in. PROMESA would establish an oversight board to assist the government of Puerto Rico manage its public finances. But the only thing PROMESA (Spanish for "promise") promises to do is threaten the future of our public lands by granting power to an oversight board to sell off federally protected public land in the Vieques National Wildlife Refuge.  The Vieques National Wildlife Refuge is a true safe haven for numerous endangered species. If PROMESA becomes law we will see condominiums and developments for the rich and powerful to play  where the manatees and the sea turtles use to call home before they were forced into extinction.  Tell Congress: Public lands need to stay in public hands --> http://sc.org/1R1yFEm

Meet Art and Helen Tanderup. They're farmers in Nebraska. They  along with Bold Nebraska  the Brave Heart Society  the Ponca and Sioux tribes  and other families from along the proposed KXL route  fought hard to stop TransCanada from destroying their land  air  and water. Now  they're solutions-driven  installing solar panels on their farm  and are ready for 100% clean energy for all!

In a community whose environmental rights had long been sidelined to make room for heavy industry  Destiny Watford inspired residents of a Baltimore neighborhood to defeat plans to build the nation’s largest incinerator less than a mile away from her high school. Happy National Volunteer Week! Today we honor Dan Shoemaker. He has been an outings leader for Sierra Club's Military Outdoors (sc.org/military) for three years. Dan is a retired Captain with almost a decade of service in the US Army  who now lives in Gunnison  CO  and is currently working with local veterans and organizations to establish a regional Military Outdoors program in Colorado and the Rocky Mountain area.  He has deployed twice to the Middle East  as a member of the 4th and 2nd Infantry Divisions  for which he was awarded both the Bronze Star and Purple Heart. Once Dan began to regain his strength he returned to the outdoors wanting to show other military personnel and veterans how much being in nature could help them and using mountaineering to get both mentally and physically wounded soldiers into the wilderness.  Check out the video Dan made at our 2014 Adventure Film School --> https://www.facebook.com/SierraClub/videos/10152538314982572/

The Keep Mongolian Green project by Korean and Mongolian #Rotary members aims to counter the desertification and erosion by overgrazing livestock. It has planted more than 250 000 trees  built infrastructure and provided training to local farmers. #EarthDay

In Ecuador  the powerful 7.8-magnitude quake that struck Saturday night has killed more than 500 people and injured thousands. Rotary founder Paul Harris was born on this day in 1868. Through Rotary  Harris encouraged personal connections as a way to promote peace and understanding. Celebrate his vision by encouraging friendship and goodwill in your community today. https://www.rotary.org

Today marks the 61st anniversary of Jonas Salk's polio vaccine.  We are closer than ever to ending polio but need your help. Get involved  donate or share your voice: http://www.endpolio.org

On this day in 1955  the Salk polio vaccine was declared safe and effective  following a year-long field trial. In the United States  children who participated received a Polio Pioneer card and pin from the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis (March of Dimes) This card and pin were donated to our archives by a Rotary member who was part of the trial. http://www.endpolio.org
Mother’s Day is coming up on 8 May and eBay Live Auctions has unique gifts Rotary members can get for Mom.  See the list of auctions that partially benefit Rotary at http://on.rotary.org/RotaryEbay

Representatives from Rotary clubs worldwide will gather for the Council on Legislation in Chicago 10-15 April to consider changes to the policies that guide Rotary and its clubs. NPR is live and behind the scenes at Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History!
The Smithsonian Folklife Festival is back today! Who's up for tug-of-war?
Tomorrow afternoon: Visit the fossil lab at Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History without leaving your desk  when NPR broadcasts live on Facebook.

You may know Martin Puryear's works from Madison Square Park in New York City or downtown Washington  D.C. A new exhibition at Smithsonian American Art Museum and the Renwick Gallery gives you a look at the artist's creative process through his sketches and models.
Coming back from a holiday weekend is a little easier when there's a new sea lion pup at Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute.
Happy Fourth of July! Our National Museum of American History explains how the Continental Army celebrated the nation's independence. (Hint: It involved rum and cannons.)

Happy birthday  National Air and Space Museum  Smithsonian Institution!   For its 40th year  the museum has unveiled a new look for the central space that includes the Spirit of St. Louis  the Bell X-1 rocket plane and a lunar module. Spiffy  indeed.
Batter up! See “One Life: Babe Ruth” now through next May at the National Portrait Gallery  Smithsonian Institution.

When you can't get to outer space yourself  you can experience it through books  media and television. Fictional depictions of space  like Star Trek  reflect real American attitudes to worlds beyond our own.   The Star Trek starship Enterprise  recently restored  is now back on view at the National Air and Space Museum  Smithsonian Institution.

The Smithsonian Folklife Festival opens today  and one of the cultures featured in this year's festival is the Basque country. Whether you can come in person or not  you can experience a taste of the region with this dessert recipe.  See the full festival schedule for this year at festival.si.edu.
Digitization is changing how engineers can use museum collections for invention.

“When you’re drawn to a sense that you’re not anticipating experiencing  you almost give it more attention " says curator Karen Milbourne at the National Museum of African Art  Smithsonian Institution. "It makes you appreciate the nuances between the visual and the auditory.”
As commencement season winds to a close  Smithsonian Libraries looks at graduation garb from the last century.
In honor of #PollinatorWeek  Smithsonian Gardens announces a change to one of its outdoor spaces.
With 1.5 million mosquitoes specimens in our collection  we're able to help scientists predict where people are at risk for Zika and other diseases.

Big news from Smithsonian Digitization: They've digitized 1 million of our objects!   You can explore the millionth piece  this teapot  online in all its shiny  digital glory. It's from the collection of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture.

We've launched a new tool to put more than 1 million of our digital resources at your fingertips.   Designed for teachers and students  Smithsonian Education's Learning Lab is open to anyone to discover  create and share. Explore at learninglab.si.edu.

In 1913  an Ohio couple mailed their young son to his grandmother. It only cost 15 cents to send him about a mile  but the parents did insure their child for $50.   Read more about the history of these special deliveries from the Smithsonian National Postal Museum.
Stare into Walter Sickert's eyes. What do you see?  Decide what's sinister and what's ordinary with Smithsonian's Freer and Sackler Galleries discussion of the portrait.

This isn't the first Smithsonian balloon  explains a curator from the National Air and Space Museum  Smithsonian Institution.   See it in person Saturday  at the family event at National Air and Space Museum  Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center  Smithsonian: http://bit.ly/1XpvWgs
Ask an astronaut your questions  live with National Air and Space Museum  Smithsonian Institution
Smithsonian Libraries explains the bond between two men: the fictional secret agent and the real author of books about birds.
Our Zoo has a big announcement!
For #FlagDay  our National Museum of American History shares some little-known facts about the national icon in our collection.
Check back tomorrow for an exiciting live announcement from the Zoo
We're excited to announce a new collaboration with the Victoria and Albert Museum for a Smithsonian presence in London  our first long-term gallery space in another country in our 170-year history.

The head of the Smithsonian shares his thoughts on the events in Orlando:  "Our commitment to make the Smithsonian a place where all Americans can come together  see themselves in what we do  and be themselves  is stronger than ever."   Full statement to staff below:
We've changed a lot since the 1800s. For some #FlashbackFriday fun  see these before-and-after shots from Smithsonian Institution Archives.

Going to be in Washington this summer? This year's Smithsonian Folklife Festival schedule is now online. Start planning your festival experience  and be sure to check back as more information gets added. #2016Folklife
On #WorldOceansDay  the case for being optimistic about the future of our oceans  #OceanOptimism

Born into slavery in 1853  artist Bill Traylor lived through Reconstruction  the Jim Crow era  and the Great Migration. He's one of the only known artist with a sizeable body of works that reflect and embody black culture of his time
These beautiful sculptures are meant to bring awareness to the ugly truth of ocean pollution

Remembering the legacy of Muhammad Ali. His gloves and robe are on view at our National Museum of American History. When he donated them to the museum he predicted they'd become "the most famous thing in this building."
The internet tells us today is #NationalDonutDay  so it is our duty to share with you everything you ever wanted to know about the history of the doughnut

Interesting facts about kiwis: 1. Chicks hatch ready to go  no parental care needed 2. An egg is 20 percent of the size of a female kiwi's body 3. The Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute is one of the few places in the world outside New Zealand  that has successfully bred this endangered bird
Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while you could miss some great art.
Mosquitoes cause an estimated 725 000 deaths per year  making them the deadliest animals on the planet
Beauty shots of our moon are featured in a new exhibition at National Air and Space Museum  Smithsonian Institution. See a few at the link below
What can we learn from old cosmetics? A lot  it turns out. A curatorial assistant explains how they can be a lens into advertising history  industry  women's history and cultural studies
The first Memorial Day observances were organized by women and African Americans to commemorate Civil War soldiers
Need something to bring to your pot luck barbecue this weekend? Go retro with a "Crown Roast of Wieners" or "Barbecued Bologna."
Come party like it's 1899  when affiliation with a political party usually included actual parties
Get to know the mysterious life of the early Smithsonian scientist who dug tunnels under DC  from Smithsonian Libraries' #DigIntoDyar project.
The archives aren't just for dusty paper—Smithsonian's Archives of American Art has a rattlesnake head in a jar.
Check out how a high-tech conveyor belt helps us digitize hundreds of thousands of specimens in this video with Smithsonian Digitization.

Boy-Scout-turned-political-leader Norman Mineta is just one of many Japanese Americans whose life was changed by incarcerations camps during World War II.  Japanese American incarceration is the subject of our National Museum of American History's National Youth Summit coming up on May 17. Find out more about the free  online event: http://s.si.edu/janys
In the early 20th century  some city business areas got three to five mail deliveries each day.   What changed? Smithsonian National Postal Museum has the answer  no signature required.
Our National Museum of American History wants your help choosing which snapshots of African American celebrations it will display this fall.
Oh deer.
Filed away for years in a basement  these photos from hip-hop's early days are now in the collection of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture.

Politicians campaigning for the youth vote isn’t anything new.  A curator from our National Museum of American History explains how young people have been involved in elections  and what it meant to cast your 'virgin vote.'
This should be a good year for blue crabs in the Chesapeake Bay  but Smithsonian Environmental Research Center says we shouldn't get too excited yet.

All right  Mr. Entomologist  I'm ready for my close-up.  You might not know it  but mites are everywhere  with an estimated three to five million species across the globe. Now you can have face time with them.
Why Cinco de Mayo isn't a celebration of Mexico's independence  a holiday history lesson from Smithsonian Magazine.

Egyptian pilgrims used to bring a mummified shrew as an offering for worship—the shrew was to serve as a messenger to the gods.   Now  through X-ray technology  they carry a message about Egyptian species and practices of the past.

Powerful costumes  they are.   On May the Fourth (aka #StarWarsDay)  the Force is strong with our Smithsonian Institution Traveling Exhibition Service and their traveling showcase of costumes from the films.
Hear traditional Basque folk songs in this blog post from the Smithsonian Folklife Festival  and hear them live on the National Mall for this summer's festival.
He started on staff as a laborer  but Soloman Brown left a legacy of prolific poetry at the Smithsonian.
A new exhibition at Smithsonian's Archives of American Art peeks into artists’ creative processes.
For Jazz Appreciation Month  our National Museum of American History is highlighting a lesser-known performer  bandleader and composer: Benny Carter.
“She sells sea shells by the sea shore" is about a real woman  and she was one of the best known paleontologists of her time. Learn more from The Ocean Portal.
This ancient beetle find from Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History gives a new meaning to the term "metal mouth."
Want to know more about biodiversity  gardening or pollinators? Ask our scientists live now! #EarthDay
Learn even more about trees and bees when we talk LIVE today at 1 p.m. ET on the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History's Facebook page.

Since this iconic photograph of the planet was captured in 1972  it has become a symbol of Earth Day.   For this year's Earth Day  learn about the history of the shot from the National Air and Space Museum  Smithsonian Institution.

He's part of being an American to many  said Eric Jentsch  curator at our National Museum of American History. "It's not just about Prince as a performer  it's also about how Prince and his work have become part of our American culture."  Smithsonian Magazine asked our curators about the legacy of Prince  who died today.
Oh red-ruffed lemurs  what big eyes you have!   Meet the newest members of this critically endangered species at Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute. #WeSaveSpecies
Learn about an unexpected connection between the Embassy of Switzerland in the United States of America and the National Portrait Gallery  Smithsonian Institution.
Harriet Tubman's hymnal  in the collection of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture  reveals the humanity behind the new face of the $20 bill.
We're buzzing with excitement for this Earth Day chat with Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History. Join us Friday LIVE  right here on Facebook.
By now you've probably heard about Inky  the octopus who escaped from an New Zealand aquarium. But he's not the only cephalopod who has amazed us with his intellect.
A National Museum of American History curator explains Americans' shifting view of vino.
A decade ago  a campaign encouraged fishing for cownose rays because they were accused of eating too many shellfish. New research has scientists thinking they're not to blame.
Tax day got you down? Smithsonian Folkways Recordings has a playlist featuring such songs as "I'm a Beggar " "Magic Penny " and "Ida Mae (The Social Security Song)."
On this day in 1865  President Abraham Lincoln was assassinated. Smithsonian Magazine looks at how America responded to the event that changed the course of the nation.

Kelly Carmody's plan was to paint her subject with a duck  but only a rooster was available.  Learn more about her inspiration for "Woman with Rooster " a portrait competition finalist featured in the National Portrait Gallery  Smithsonian Institution.

Where does a work of art end? Pieces in “Robert Irwin: All the Rules Will Change ” a new exhibition at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden  don't have the boundaries of a traditional painting. #RobertIrwinHH
Baked fish molds  tomato jelly and sponge pudding...sounds delicious.   Nibble on some vintage recipes with the National Museum of American History.

These photos of the collections at Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History have gone viral.  Smithsonian Magazine takes you even further behind the scenes with the story of how these images were taken (over nearly 20 years) and what we do with all those birds.
It's official: "Large Toad" has taken the #MarchSadness tournament from Smithsonian's Freer and Sackler Galleries.   Missed the doleful match-ups? See the full bracket at s.si.edu/marchsadness.
Did you know Ella Fitzgerald was a big baseball fan? Her collection of signed baseballs is now in our National Museum of American History.
The future is at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden  and it's uncomfortable.
It's your last chance to crown the champion of melancholy  with the final round of the #MarchSadness tournament from Smithsonian's Freer and Sackler Galleries
April is National Garden Month  and we hope these blooms from Smithsonian Gardens might brighten up your Monday.

For the 50th anniversary of Star Trek  we've started a tribble breeding program at the National Air and Space Museum  Smithsonian Institution. Because  what could go wrong?  Since we know you love live video of our animals  they've also set up a tribble cam. Watch it at s.si.edu/TribbleCam  Follow along with the pilot project here: http://s.si.edu/25AvcaV #TribbleTrouble
Where did brides find inspiration before Pinterest? Fashion catalogs.   Take a look  and maybe research your vintage theme  with the Smithsonian Libraries collection.
A (failed) search for malaria treatment gave us one of the world's first synthetic dyes.   It's one of the many colorful tales in a Smithsonian Libraries exhibition  "Color in a New Light."
You can get up close with the moon in a recent exhibition  "A New Moon Rises " at the National Air and Space Museum  Smithsonian Institution.

Missed the big announcement? Check out who took home first place in this year's Outwin Boochever Portrait Competition  and see all the winners in the National Portrait Gallery  Smithsonian Institution.

If #MarchMadness isn't your style  the most miserable objects from Smithsonian's Freer and Sackler Galleries are facing off for March Sadness. You can vote for your favorite...er  most upsetting contestant below.
We might not be hitting the court  but we do have your NCAA basketball background covered. Get your March Madness history from our National Museum of American History.
Portraiture doesn't have to be static. Take a behind-the-scenes look at Bo Gehring's video portrait of jazz musician Esperanza Spalding  at the National Portrait Gallery  Smithsonian Institution.

Meet Brownie Wise  the female executive in the 1950s who pioneered selling parties and empowered women through plastic.

Not for the faint of heart: Get up close and personal with our scientists collecting and investigating horse-flies.
For St. Patrick's Day  our National Museum of American History looks at Irish American history through four objects in the collection.

You can help Smithsonian Institution Archives write more women into history  and you can do it from anywhere.   Learn more about this Saturday's Wikipedia edit-a-thon and sign up to join in D.C. (free lunch!) or online.

Congratulations to Amy Sherald  whose piece “Miss Everything (Unsuppressed Deliverance)” won this year's portrait competition at the National Portrait Gallery  Smithsonian Institution. Learn more about the competition and current exhibition: http://portraitcompetition.si.edu

That's no dye job  this duck's color is all natural.   Flamingos are pink because of pigments in the shrimp and algae they eat  but they're not the only birds who've gotten a boost of color from their diet.

They say a zebra can't change its stripes. But then why do they look different based on distance or the angle of the light?  That's one of the questions that drives the Smithsonian Libraries exhibition  "Color in a New Light." Challenge yourself to change your perspective and think beyond the spectrum: http://s.si.edu/1USTWGE

Today  World Health Organization (WHO) announced that the WHO European Region has hit its 2015 target and has become the first malaria-free region in the world. From more than 90 000 cases of malaria in 1995 to zero cases in 2015  this marks a major achievement for the European Region and for the global effort to #endmalaria. But political commitment  financial resources and vigilance will be needed to prevent reintroduction and maintain the Region's malaria-free status. http://bit.ly/1U1WvWU

Many define the poor by their lack of financial resources. While that is true  it is an oversimplification of all the poor lack. When you look at how the Bible defines "poverty " you see that we have much in common with the poor ... and that we are all truly in poverty.

Around the world  the poor carry the burden of poverty on their heads and on their backs. But poverty doesn’t always win. Not even close. These pictures of poverty show that joy  hope and dignity can still bloom in the hearts of the poor.  Poverty cannot snuff out a life — unless we let it.

For families in developing countries  access to clean water means freedom too. The freedom to choose how they spend their time. The freedom to earn income and go to school. The freedom to build better futures. You can help bring clean water and the freedom that comes with it to families just like Tenin’s all year long by giving monthly.  Learn more at https://donate.charitywater.org/donate/home (3/3)

Everything changed the day Tenin’s village got clean water. With no obligation to wait in line for water  Tenin had the freedom to choose how she wanted to spend her time. Selling mangoes to earn money. Sharing meals with her family. Even relaxing in the shade at the end of the day.   “This water has changed our life ” Tenin said. (2/3)

Tenin used to bring a rug with her when she went to collect water from the dirty hand-dug well outside her village in Mali. The rug was to sleep on -- in case the line so long that she’d have to stay the night  waiting with others for the water level to rise back up.  “I used to spend my whole day collecting water ” Tenin said.  But that was then. Today  Tenin’s life looks very different. (1/3)

Now that they have clean water right at home  women in Odisha  India are able to use their extra time (and even their run-off water) to grow all kinds of fresh fruits and vegetables for their families.

The Boy Who Walked for Water: Part 3/3  Devison wasn’t trying to be a hero or take a stand; he just wanted to do the right thing. He wanted his mom to have time to do more important things. He wanted his sister to be able to go to school too.  And not only did he give time back to his family in the same way that clean water would  but he also set an example for the other boys in his community.  Collecting water requires hours of painful work for women around the world every single day. But we can help change that. We can bring clean water into these communities and significantly lighten the load for women (and boys like Devison) so all of them can focus on more important things: like each other.

The Boy Who Walked for Water: Part 2/3  Having learned about equality in school  Devison decided that it wasn’t fair for his mother and sister to be responsible for all of this work.  Despite his small bony frame  Devison started walking for water so the women he cared about most wouldn’t have to.  “I walk for water because I believe in gender equality. There must be no discrimination between boys and girls in relation to chores.”

The Boy Who Walked for Water: Part 1/3  The unfortunate reality in most of Malawi is that water is a woman’s job.  Women walk to locations outside their village— river beds and holes in the ground— and take turns collecting water using pans or ladles. It’s a brutally slow process that can take hours. Especially when they have to wait in line.  Women and girls are making this trip  with forty pounds of water on their head  no less than five times each day.  Devison saw it all around him. And he refused to do nothing while his mother and sister shouldered the burden of this work. So one day  Devison started walking for water too.
Here’s to strong women. May we know them. May we be them. May we raise them. - Unknown

#HR2646 has advanced in the United States Congress⚖This #MentalHealthReform bill will reauthorize the Garrett Lee Smith Memorial Act and can prevent #LGBTQ youth suicide. “The reauthorization of the Garrett Lee Smith Memorial Act is one of Trevor’s key legislative priorities this year.  Every 95 minutes a young person takes their life by suicide.  We now urge the Senate to take this bill up so needed resources can continue to save young lives ” says Abbe Land  CEO and Executive Director of The Trevor Project.  ⚖ http://ow.ly/Hgja301ZO8K

PowerON  our tech initiative to bring refurbished electronics to homeless LGBTQ youth  would not be here today if our Youth Advisory Council Member Thomas Woermer did not have access to technology. As Thomas said: "The Trevor Project connects with more than 140 000 youth every year through phone  chat  text  TrevorSpace.org  (our online social network)  and social media.  Homeless youth need electronics to gain access to Trevor's lifesaving resources. The Trevor Project is dedicated to supporting PowerON and working with safe and supportive locations like Lost-n-Found Youth to provide this technology to homeless youth who often have to overcome the largest digital gap." We thank our supporters  Josh Hutcherson  Straight But Not Narrow  LGBT Technology Partnership & Institute  and human I T for empowering homeless LGBTQ youth to become the future leaders of the LGBTQ community. Learn more about the event from Georgia Voice here: http://bit.ly/29xjgTS. Support our #PowerON initiative here: bit.ly/PowerOnSolar.

At The Trevor Project  we understand that race  disabilities  sexuality  and gender are interrelated and must be talked about in the context of socioeconomic privilege so that we can move towards creating a brighter future for all youth. To raise awareness about intersectionality  we often share on social media about how privilege can both undermine and uplift folks of varying identities  and that it is our responsibility to listen and affirm queer youth of color whose individual lives have been shaped differently by their experiences. We are here for #LGBTQ+ youth-- black  brown  white  trans  non-binary  disabled...all intersectional identities--24/7 at 866-488-7386 and thetrevorproject.org. http://bit.ly/29yAkZh

Meg Zulch discusses how #chronicillness affects #bodyimage  and how #selfies and makeup has allowed them to reclaim their body✨   "Documenting my symptomatic days by taking selfies became an important way for me to reframe these times into something that I have more control over and see enough beauty in to solidify in a photo."   http://ow.ly/vRKY3008E6j

Before we were born  the typical question our mothers got asked was: “Is the baby a boy or a girl?” Immediately  we were expected to fit inside a socially constructed binary box that prescribed physical characteristics  personal mannerisms  bathrooms  and even colors to us. But  the way we identify with our gender is not always congruent with biological sex or gender assigned at birth. Just as sexuality isn’t a choice  gender identity isn’t either. Thank you Center on Rights Development for featuring Trevor! http://bit.ly/1TApthW

✨ #JeffreyMarsh on being #genderqueer and the importance of being open  inclusive  and supportive of all identities✨  “I always emphasize that a label is not the same as self respect. Some people find it empowering to have a label  but you have to learn to love yourself and respect yourself. There are as many ways to talk about gender as there are to talk about people. We are human after all  so we have a lot of ways to define it.”  http://ow.ly/4nnva0

The world pushes boys  men  and folks who identify with masculinity into harmful  oppressive boxes within which they cannot feel  express  love  grow  or care in all the ways that they might want to. We need to send boys  men  and those aforementioned folks that it’s okay. It’s okay to grieve. It’s okay to cry. It’s okay to ask for help. It’s okay to be vulnerable and it’s okay to let other people be your rock. It’s okay to love without reservation and it’s okay to feel whatever it is that you’re feeling. Read more about The Trevor Project's involvement with David Grosso of Washington D.C. in creating a model school suicide prevention policy specifically aimed at protecting the needs of #LGBTQ+ youth. We are here for you 24/7 at 866-488-7386.   "The importance of establishing laws that focus on the #LGBTQ+ population cannot be overstated  as LGB youth are four times more likely to attempt suicide than their heterosexual peers and between 40 percent and 50 percent of #transgender individuals will attempt suicide at some point in their lifetime. With the enactment of #Bill21361  there is now model legislative language that other jurisdictions can use to implement similar policies in their schools. In fact  California has already held a hearing on a similar bill requiring middle and high schools to adopt suicide prevention policies that specifically address the needs of LGBTQ youth  among other high-risk subgroups."  http://ow.ly/4nsgLK

#GraceAnnStevens discusses how creating #healthyboundaries is an act of #selfcare !  "The first word that come to mind for me is #boundaries. There are so many ways to have boundaries. For example  there are physical  emotional  spiritual and for some  even energetic boundaries. Some of us may have totally stable and rigid boundaries across all these dimensions  while others may have weak  unstable and easily crossed boundaries. These boundaries define where we each sense we begin and end. Given that so many of these boundaries are invisible to others  and that most humans are not very good at mind reading  the best way to find someone’s boundary is perhaps to ask."  http://ow.ly/ZNSJD

The homophobia and transphobia infused in Tennessee’s House Bill 1840 is a disgrace to the mental health community. Denying mental health services to any person based on a counselor’s religious beliefs is harmful to every marginalized person in need of help and is a violation of American Counseling Association's code of ethics. Talking about sex openly can be uncomfortable for many  but discomfort doesn’t change our duty to give teens every chance to take control of their bodies and their futures. #LGBTyouth deserve a place in the #sexeducation classroom They are in desperate need of access to information and resources to keep them safe. They need people in power to make a safe place to talk about life outside the antiquated notion of a binary heterosexual climate. And straight kids need that  too. A well-rounded  LGBTQ-inclusive  and comprehensive sexual education program benefits everyone  LGBT and straight teens alike. It’s time to talk about sex in the way that it needs to be talked about.  CDC #STDMontth16  http://ow.ly/Zxr1O

#FarihaRoisin discusses her journey to #selfacceptance as a #queer #Muslim. We want you to know that we are always here to support you at 866-488-73686. You are not alone.   "Being queer  and accepting that label for myself  is about survival. It’s about the power we get when words are ascribed to ourselves out of our own choice. When the correct term finds its way to you  it’s liberating  like a big sigh of relief. If people don’t understand you  it’s probably because they don’t need to. They’ve never had to explore themselves the way you’ve had to (or maybe they have  but they’re in denial) you shiny  beautiful thing."  http://ow.ly/ZcWKw   #FaithfullyLGBT #BHAM2016 #BiHealthAwarenessMonth

Emilia in Tanzania works as a tailor in her clothing store 10 hours per day  6 days per week and volunteers for 2.5 hours per week teaching life skills to local students. She used her Kiva loan to expand her tailoring business so she could continue being an example for her community.

Lelys in Colombia started a dressmaking business with the guidance of a friend. Without that support  she says she wouldn’t have her own shop. She now employs two people as a way to pay the kindness forward. Her Kiva loan helped her buy a sewing machine but more importantly  it will allow her to offer more jobs and continue paying it forward.

Daniel successfully repaid his first Kiva loan and just received his second which he’ll use to further grow his small carpentry shop. This loan of $225 – for wood  nails  glue and other materials – will help him expand his list of products and solidify his business in Madagascar.
“The Kiva loan was a key step to helping me grow my farm”

Entrepreneur  mother  and determined are all words that describe Maritza from rural Nicaragua. To guarantee a better future for her and her son  she used her Kiva loan to buy materials that would help her increase the yield and quality of her coffee crop.

Marie Léonie sells fresh fruits and vegetables in Madagascar. She used her Kiva loan to expand her small business and plans to use the extra revenue to support her dream of seeing her 2 children complete university!

Khady from Senegal is a mother of ten and currently operates a small grocery shop from her home. With help from 91 lenders  she used her Kiva loan to expand her store. The profits went to buy food for her family. She is not only an inspiration to her children  but also to many entrepreneurs like herself.

Kiva partner FMSD is providing more than 50 000 housing units for over 242 000 inhabitants in Barranquilla and Cartagena  Colombia. They've provided over 130 000 micro entrepreneurs with loans  including Justina who used her Kiva loan to increase the goods offered by her grocery store.

One of our fellows had the opportunity to meet with Kiva borrower Aivys in Panama  whose most recent loan is being used to invest in pig farming.  She also used her previous Kiva loan to repair her vehicle  which she uses to promote her jewelry-making business.

According to World Bank  Mozambique is one of the fastest growing non-oil economies in sub-Saharan Africa. Despite the country’s rapid economic growth over the last decade  it is still one of the world’s poorest countries.

Ms. Nancy applied for her first at 62 years old. Regardless of age  she and a group of women in her community are intent on using their new loan to start a business of selling food in their local community in Senegal. They even plan to make and sell ice cream!

ID Ghana is a Kiva partner that provides financial and social services to underserved urban communities in Accra  Ghana. With help from Kiva lenders  Robert has increased his social capital as a trader there. This is his 7th successful loan cycle!

In Colombia  Miriam is a craftswoman – a family tradition she learned from her mother.  Her belief that craftsmanship is a special gift led her to become an independent businesswomen. Her Kiva loan allows her to invest in the raw materials she needs to make and sell a variety of merchandise including backpacks  handbags  blouses  and hammocks.

Spreading the Kiva love!  Fulgence owns a coffee processing station  Mugina Coffee Co  in Rwanda's Eastern Province. He thanks Kiva lenders for helping him build more drying tables -- nearly doubling his production capacity. With this increase  he will also create 30 new jobs for men and women from his community.

By funding partner EDESA  Kiva lenders are allowing the organization to reach extremely marginalized populations in Costa Rica than they would otherwise reach. Marcelina  for example  used her multiple Kiva loans to renovate her home and increase the number of hens she looks after.

Sont oo Tehtwin  a new Kiva partner serving the poor in Myanmar  works with people living just across the river from downtown Yangon. This community still lacks access to basic services despite their proximity to the capital city.

On World Refugee  and every day  Kiva stands with refugees. Kiva lenders have lent more than $2.6M to refugees & internally displaced people including Ki  who spent much of her early life in a refugee camp and now owns a thriving sandwich shop in San Francisco.
“Born in a refugee camp in Sudan  I never thought that one day I would be launching my own fashion line.”

Najah grew her business from inside a refugee camp  where access to capital is hard to come by. In the West Bank  only 1 in 5 women have a bank account – but 69 lenders from around the world helped Najah get the money she needed to start her animal husbandry business.

Kone was separated from his family and lost everything during the First Ivorian Civil War. He became a refugee  fleeing across 8 countries to Kenya  where he's rebuilding his life and tailoring business with the help of a Kiva loan.  Refugees often struggle to find the financial support they need to rebuild stable lives. Kiva is #withrefugees  and in honor of World Refugee Day on June 20 we're sharing some of their incredible journeys from refugees to entrepreneurs.

Yuster from Uganda started out as a tea plucker and then decided to try her hand at tea farming. She used her first Kiva loan to buy green tea for planting. She now grows tea on a larger scale and recently took out a second Kiva loan to rent a tea plantation!

Ten years ago we had a dream to empower people through lending small amounts of money so they could create a better life. Since then  1.5 million of you have joined us to impact 2 million people’s lives.
Let’s illuminate the world with love  this week and always.
Thank you Maroon 5 for supporting Kiva and entrepreneurs around the world!
We don't take a cut of people's dreams: 100% of every dollar you lend on Kiva goes towards funding loans.
Luis's group loan was powered by 174 lenders from around the world. Their support and his hard work has meant better harvests on his family farm.
One of the strongest things that connects us as humans is our ability to imagine a better world.
We support dreamers everywhere.  kiva.org
Our new mobile-friendly website makes creating a positive impact on someone's life easier than ever.
To celebrate a decade of impact and the launch of our new website  we’ve created a video to show what 10 years of people investing in people looks like. Watch as a simple idea changes the world!
Kiva is a true global community: there are Kiva borrowers in 84 countries and Kiva lenders in 192 countries!
Through lending  we can each play a special part in someone else's story – whether it’s a loan to a baker in rural Paraguay or a clothing designer in California (or both)!
We believe all people are connected and one of the strongest things that connects us is our desire to create a better future for our families  our communities and our world.
We envision a world where all people hold the power to create opportunity for themselves and others. Join us at kiva.org

Exciting news! Today  we’re proud to introduce a new look and feel for Kiva  and a new  mobile-responsive website that makes supporting small businesses around the world easier than ever.   Over the past 10 years  Kiva’s grown into a true global community  where people come together to support and believe in each other. Thank you for making Kiva a special  hopeful corner of the internet. We’re so excited to continue this journey with you! Check out the new site at kiva.org

Verena is the group leader of Twigire  meaning “self-dependent”. The Rwandan group sells a variety of products.  Verena  herself  has owned a shop for the past 6 years and used her loan to refill her store with rice  sugar  biscuits and other goods.

Many lower income families cannot afford housing that meets their needs. When you make a housing loan on Kiva  you give people like Alcinda in Mozambique access to the flexible capital they need to obtain or improve their homes.

Kiva partner Fundación Mario Santo Domingo (FMSD) in northern Colombia runs a microfinance program to strengthen micro-businesses in the area. Fortunately  they operate offices near local communities they serve to provide financial and non-financial services (e.g. training  business plan consultation).

Ressig is 88% of the way to completely repaying his loan!  He used those Kiva funds to make improvements to the house he rents out in Panama.  Floor tiles  a water reserve tank  and a new door will help secure his rental income and a safe home for someone his community.

Marlene is a woman to be admired!  Despite now only having one hand  she works fervently as a cheese producer to provide for herself and her student son in Costa Rica. Marlene used her Kiva loan to increase her cheese production and boost her income.

Francis from Uganda requested a Kiva loan to help build his dream home. As part of that construction effort  he has also started a small garden where he grows cocoa  tea and vegetables. He plans to eventually expand his primary business  a retail shop  to include rental properties.

Yaya from Mali has successfully repaid four Kiva loans! After training as a therapist  he became began a business in pharmaceutical sales. He used his most recent loan to obtain medical supplies  including aloe  norfloxicin (for typhoid fever) and Indian inzam (for anemia).

Irma is a hard-working woman with unbeatable strength. This strength helped her to face the death of one of her sons. In the face of tragedy and high medical expenses  she began to sell food just outside of her house. She has taken several Kiva loans since then  which have helped her grow this business into a success.
Antonio lives in San Juan  Puerto Rico  and uses his public community space to bring together his neighborhood and promote art as an instrument of change.
In this remote village in Azerbaijan there aren’t many ways to earn a living. Avaz is a young farmer who Kiva lenders helped develop his agribusiness  so he can sell his products at the local market.
Since 2013  Kiva lenders like you have supported over 2 000 borrowers in Myanmar  and contributed more than $390 000 to support farming businesses across the region.

After retirement  John from Ghana re-invested his pension to grow oranges on a 4-acre citrus farm and subsequently  became chairman of his local farmers' association. With his Kiva loan  he procured a processing plant for the association to increase the value of their crops in the marketplace.

Olive is only 24 years old but is already on her way to becoming a savvy businesswoman. Her first Kiva loan allowed her to set up her own wholesale business selling eggs – a staple food in Rwanda – and business is booming!
Spread the love today: lend to a mom and your loan will be matched! Your $25 will go twice as far for a mother and her family.  kiva.org/match

Kiva partner  NOVICA  allows artisans around the world to sell unique  high-quality goods directly to consumers via their website. Repayments on Novica loans are tied to artisan revenue. This means that if an artisan has a good month  they will pay back more – or less during slower months. Visit novica.com/kiva to see our artisans’ work!
Small business  huge impacts. It's National Small Business Week and we're proud of our role in helping US small business grow.

Fernando  María  Begnino  and Catalino make up the borrower group  Los Pinos Monquecagua  in Honduras. They used their Kiva loan to buy seed and fertilizers for their potato and grain crops; they successfully paid their loan back in one year!

Fundación Paraguaya in Asunción  Paraguay has helped many farmers boost their crop yields and other borrowers start and grow their social businesses – delivering eyeglasses  medicines and other helpful services to their local communities.

When she first got her loan  Talent was in the business of selling clothes. Due to low demand  she decided to sell food and groceries. This business has been more lucrative and with the proceeds  she has been able to buy a commercial stand where she’ll soon build her own shop.

Oaklin is a Flint  Michigan native looking to elevate his lifestyle streetwear clothing brand. He runs Goodboy Clothing based on a “shop to shelf” business model  making and merchandising his clothing through ethical practices.

People’s Forum  one of our field partners based in Odisha  India  provides affordable loan products and support services to particularly marginalized groups including: leprosy-affected families  widows  single mothers  and disabled persons.
Leonard is the leader of his borrowers’ group  called 'Duterimbere ' which means "to be developed". His Kiva loan helped him open his small store in Rwanda.

Kiva’s field partner  Community Economic Ventures  helped Cirila run her sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines. With her loan  she was able to buy additional items to stock to attract more customers.
Marcela from Chile makes clothes  purses  and accessories. Her goal is to create a fashion line of clothing that is available online - she’s already got design ideas too!
José runs a vehicle paint and body shop in El Salvador. José's ambition is to make his children proud by running a successful business that supports them.
Jasmine started her home-based bakery after growing up with a love of baking! She is now opening her first storefront and looking to hire her first employee with her Kiva loan.

Happy Earth Day! We love green loans like this one: a Kiva loan helped the Egyani women’s group in Ghana buy ELSA clean cookstoves that run on palm kernel shells instead of wood. The ELSA stove will drastically improve the indoor air quality for their families and decreases regional demand for wood-fuel.
With the funds from her Kiva loan  Hoa in Vietnam was able to buy wood for her carpentry shop. Her specialty is intricately carving designs into chairs and benches. Beautiful!
Zeppa in Zimbabwe remembers how  as a young girl  she would watch her mother bake delicious tea scones and cake. Now  she’s becoming a baker and her Kiva loan is helping her to pursue that dream.
Maria worried about accumulating debt to grow her sewing business but her neighbors in Mexico encouraged her to take out her first small loan and she has been so pleased with what it’s helped her do.

For over 10 years  coffee production has been the main work for Juan’s family in Nicaragua. Juan has repaid two Kiva loans  which enabled him to cyclically increase coffee production and carry out his work and keep his coffee Fair Trade certified.
Help people keep dreaming: kiva.org/lend
Have you ever dreamt of living on a farm? Kate is a farm educator who hosts farm stays and day camps for her community  helping people connect and learn from their natural environment.

Something we loved this week: Jamila  creator of M-Farm  knows 70% of Kenyans work in agriculture and that most don't have access to important market information. M-Farm closes the information gap and empowers farmers to make better decisions.

Aisulu and her husband support themselves by selling milk and other dairy products in the Terek village in Kyrgyzstan. Their Kiva loan allowed them to successfully expand their livestock supply and increase their cash flow.

Got questions about being a Kiva Fellow? Join our AMA tomorrow and learn about our incredible fellows program.  Thursday 4/14 at 10 am PT: https://www.reddit.com/r/IAmA/comments/4env4g/were_the_kiva_fellows_program_team_sending/
Dadon  member of the Benkan group in Mali  used her loan to buy smoked fish to sell at the local market and recently paid her loan back in full.

Our new Thai partner Hilltribe Organics calls their eggs “Beyond Organic."  They are helping hill tribe farmers like Ayae  build up a new egg farm  which will give him and his family a stable monthly income for the first time in their lives.
Did you know: Kiva works with 300 partners in over 80 countries across the world.
Torie’s catering service provides healthy soul food to her community. Her vision is to expand her business so that she can reach more customers and make people happy through her love of food!

Mile owns and operates a small convenience store for her local community in Samoa. She successfully repaid her Kiva loan  which she used to buy a second-hand pick-up truck to help run her business. She is using her increased profits to pay for her children’s education.

Zimbabwe struggles greatly with food insecurity.  1.5 million people – 16 percent of their population – are estimated to be food insecure during 2016’s lean season.  This is a 164% increase in food insecurity since last season. Kiva loans give farmers the resources to make investments to increase their crop yields.

Since we were founded in 2005  Kiva has facilitated over $833 million in loans through the support of our awesome lending community. Emmanuel  for example  was able to build up his stock and grow his artisan business in Ghana.

We've got some exciting news to kick off this week! Today we’re partnering with shop malena to launch an innovative new platform to support our community of borrowers  helping us to continue to support the voices  futures  and small businesses of people worldwide.   Check out the campaign and join shop malena and Kiva in this incredible new endeavor!

Our partner  Thrive Microfinance in Zimbabwe  provides auxiliary training before and after making loans to women. The training enables borrowers to fully understand the strengths and weaknesses of their businesses.
Kiva U fans!: Our president Premal Shah is speaking LIVE at CGI U  joined by more than 1 200 student innovators.  Don't miss out  watch now and send in your questions: live.cgiu.org. #CGIU

Mr. Erdenebayar has been running a tailoring family business from his ger  a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. He specially tailors Mongolian national dresses  an inherited skill that few tailors still have. Thanks to Kiva’s lenders  he was able to continue practicing his craft and repaid his loan in full.
You'll dig these edible utensils that help you dig in.

Our partner SAWA serves vulnerable populations like Bedouin women in the Negev  and Arab women in northern Israel. Salaam opened a salon providing haircuts and cosmetic treatments to women in her town. Her Kiva loan helped her expand her salon’s services and become financially stronger.

Desak is a Balinese artisan specializing textiles and traditional art of hand-painting batik. She has built her career step by step – from apprenticeship to selling her collection from her home. Now  she needs assistants to help meet demand!

Paul is a seasoned welder living in coastal Ghana. He is using his loan to buy bulk materials for clean cookstoves – his family and 15 local employees will benefit from the sales and his whole community will see health benefits from clean burning stoves.
Why not?
Pamela is a Louisville native looking to expand her neighborhood restaurant. An exhaust hood will let her use more equipment (like a deep fryer!) so she can expand her menu.

Ruiyong (center) has owned and operated a grocery stall in his hometown in Sichuan province since 2010. Though a disability rendered his left leg incapacitated  Ruiyong works everyday and makes enough to support his whole family. He is using his Kiva loan to better match his supply with his customers’ demands.
When we invest in women entrepreneurs  they are empowered to become agents of change for their families  communities and countries.

Kiva works internationally with partners who ensure water is safe to drink. Evidence Action  for example  provides rural communities in Kenya with access to safe drinking water through the installation and maintenance of chlorine dispensers. None of this would be possible without the support of our incredible lenders around the world – thank you and happy World Water Day!

Kiva loans through partner  KOMAZA  have been used to purchase planting inputs for tree farms and provide technical training and support to farmers in Kenya.  This has greatly helped farmers  such as Ishumael (left)  convert drylands into productive tree farms.

Seneca started his pop-up garden kitchen with the goal of optimizing nutrition by harvesting the food right before putting it on the plate. Bottoms Up Cafe has become a staple in the area  bringing affordable  delicious food to the neighborhood.
Twenty-eight lenders supported Fernando in Honduras  who used his Kiva loan to invest in his potato crops.
When our small businesses succeed  our communities thrive. We're proud to share these stories of inspiring small businesses supported by Kiva Oakland lenders:

I come from a family of traditional wood carvers. While at school  funding was becoming a difficulty  so...I would visit my father's workshop and assist him. The realization eventually dawned on me to stay on  work on my own designs  and... preserve the family legacy.   --Francis  Ghana
We love Oakland! Together in partnership with the City of Oakland and Mayor Libby Schaaf  we're supporting small Oakland business owners who are helping their community flourish.
Quiz time! How well do you know the regions Kiva operates in?

While VisionFund Albania is focused on the empowering the poor  they pay special attention to women. About 60% of their loans on Kiva go to women.  A Kiva loan helped Vera build a stable to protect her livestock.

With Kiva’s help  Gladness bought a windmill to secure a water source for her farm. As a result  she has been able to provide for her family. In fact  her oldest daughter earned a degree in agriculture to learn how to improve their farm.

Tamika started Fruiggie Organic Arts & Crafts Studio to provide a safe  worry-free and educational environment where all children  including those with special needs and allergies  can engage in play together.

Asha operates a retail shop  selling wheat flour and maize flour. Her loan was administered through Kiva’s field partner Yehu Microfinance Trust  which began with 300 female members in a rural village in Kenya.

María Isabel is a single mother with 4 children living in Choloma  Cortes. For 15 years she has earned her living making and selling corn tortillas from her home.  She has successfully repaid her 9th loan!
Final tally: we had a HUGE impact this International Women's Day. Huge thank you to our amazing Kiva community!

I met incredible women in the camp  who could be me. The world feels very unstable and I think we have to remind ourselves that we belong to each other as beings and to stop ignoring it and turning away and being fearful. -Lena Headey to People.  After a field visit with the IRC to Greece  Game of Thrones stars reflect on the powerful stories of refugees they met: http://bit.ly/29kyBXf

Until last year  Line had spent almost her entire life in a refugee camp. Originally from the Democratic Republic of Congo  her family fled to Tanzania when she was just one year old. After nearly two decades at Nyarugusu camp  everything changed. Line and her family were resettled in San Diego In November 2015. Today  in less than a year and with help from the IRC in San Diego  Line was able to secure her first job. We're so proud of you  Line!   #RefugeesWelcome
The one and only Sir Patrick Stewart goes country... to benefit the IRC. You can't miss this.  We are honored. Watch in full here  via Rolling Stone: http://bit.ly/29lL3ai
Thank you to Google's #GoogleServe volunteers for volunteering at our New Roots Garden in New York City this week! Learn how you can volunteer with IRC in the United States: http://bit.ly/297NZUb

From Emma Watson to Harry Styles  Sharon Stone and even Elton John  celebrities have been donating their jeans to an artist who is panting them to raise money for the IRC and our work with refugees around the world. So great! We're honored. Jeans for refugees- watch & share.

Happy Fourth of July!   Today  we celebrate all new and naturalized U.S. citizens  like Cho pictured here  who contribute to and help to strengthen American society and culture.   Two years ago  on exactly July 4  2014  Cho  a Burmese refugee  became a naturalized U.S. citizen in a ceremony in Monticello (founding father Thomas Jefferson's home).   Cho was resettled by the IRC in 2006. With the IRC's assistance  she was able to attend English classes  take a locally partnered citizenship class in the community  work to support her children  and apply for citizenship.  Share this post if you  too  stand with refugees & the contributions they make to their new homes.   #RefugeesWelcome #IndependenceDay

“They want their children to continue their education. They want to continue their university and they are stuck. They're stuck. And they're unbelievably sad  understandably. We can do better for them. We must do better for them.” -- Lena Headey   http://bit.ly/29cCcmr
A humanitarian and IRC leader  #ElieWiesel opened our eyes to the horror of human cruelty and the hope and beauty of life beyond crisis. http://bit.ly/29fdDde

Tomorrow  Fourth of July will be celebrated by 19 more new American citizens! On World Refugee Day  we were honored to partner with The Public Theater & U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services to host a naturalization ceremony for 19 people from 12 different countries who were welcomed officially into their new home: the United States of America.  As Department of Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson said  the U.S. is "a nation of immigrants and we remember that refugees have added to the strength & fabric of our country." This Independence Day weekend  we couldn't agree more.  #RefugeesWelcome  Photo: Christian L. Tom

In Greece  Game of Thrones star Maisie Williams spoke with 13-year old Haya  a refugee currently stuck in Greece on the journey to safety. Haya dreams of becoming an actor and has already performed three plays at the IRC's safe space for women and girls. <3 Follow along for more updates from the Game of Thrones cast field trip with IRC: http://bit.ly/295wFBE #RealmToTheRescue #RefugeesWelcome  Photo: Kathleen Prior/IRC

I want to reunite our family  just like in the old times. So our family will be the best family ever. -Zeyneb  13  from Aleppo.  Zeyneb  her father and siblings escaped war in Syria  but are now stranded in Idomeni at Greece's north border  unable to continue through Europe. Zeyneb's mother and youngest brother made it to Holland  but the rest of her family was left behind. Now  Zeyneb is left to care for her family members--a large task for a young girl.  #RefugeesWelcome

What has been done to them is absolutely  unquestionably shameful.   After their trip to Greece with IRC  Game of Thrones stars are speaking out on behalf of refugees and calling on EU leaders to do more. Watch & share.

As summer arrives in Greece and temperatures begin to soar  refugee children cool off at an IRC supported water point.  The IRC is leading the NGO coordination of water and sanitation programs in Northern Greece adding 74 water taps  like these  in Cherso for drinking  washing-- and  yes  playing! Learn more about our #RefugeeCrisis response here: http://bit.ly/29oGWpl  Photo: Kathleen Prior/IRC

Thank you to Boy Scout Troop 411 LDS Camelview Ward for helping to make #RefugeesWelcome in Phoenix!  Watch the uplifiting video of how they're building bycicles for refugees here: http://bit.ly/297GLmR

As their IRC trip to Greece comes to an end  Game of Thrones stars Lena Headey  Maisie Williams & Liam Cunningham call on EU leaders to do much more for refugees currently stranded in Greece.   "These smart  hardworking people want to go home. They want to return to their communities and to their neighborhoods. They want their children to continue their education. They want to continue their university and they are stuck. They’re stuck. And they’re unbelievably sad. Understandably. We can do better for them. We must do better for them " said Lena Headey.   "For me it is about the children…" said Maisie Williams. "Children with so much potential  so many hopes and dreams. Where is the humanity that makes it acceptable for them to languish in refugee camps – in Europe?"   As for Liam Cunningham  his call focused on EU leaders: "This is not an earthquake  this is not a tidal wave. This is a man-made crisis. 57 000 stranded in Greece. Refugee camps in Europe? Is this truly the standard EU leaders want to set as the way to respond to the global refugee crisis?"  We're honored and grateful for their support in making sure this crisis is not forgotten  for making #RefugeesWelcome  for joining us on this journey. And as they said  "this is only the beginning." Learn more about their trip— and stay tuned for more!— at: https://www.rescue.org/press-release/game-thrones-cast-members-visit-irc-programs-greece-call-eu-leaders-do-much-more

While their children are engaged in reading through USAID - US Agency for International Development & IRC's Pakistan Reading Project's Mobile Library  mothers are also learning to read and write for the first time.   “I will now share with my husband  kids  and other family members that I can write my name myself " said one proud mother at a school in Rawalpindi.   How inspiring!

Over the last year  American students have sent over 350 000 pinwheels as part of the Students Rebuild Healing Classrooms Challenge  raising money for Syrian refugee students. Some of these Syrian students—through the IRC in Lebanon—were so inspired by the challenge that they  as a way of saying ‘thank you’  made their own pinwheels in return to send to their new American friends!  Simply amazing.  #SRSyria #RefugeesWelcome

In the future I hope to become a nurse. Nowadays without education  life is not complete. Going to school is always important  wherever you are. When militants showed up at her school carrying guns  Ruth became one of millions uprooted by violence in northeast Nigeria-- an area where an estimated 1 million children  like Ruth  are out of school. No child should miss out on an education. In Nigeria  we're helping children like Ruth get back in the classroom. Watch Ruth's story: http://bit.ly/28SFFGC cc: International Rescue Committee UK & European Commission - Humanitarian Aid & Civil Protection (ECHO)

Women rock the cradle with their right hand and they rock the world with their left. -- a Syrian saying that the IRC's Nazanin Ash quoted at The United State of Women summit. We could not agree more.  Learn how we've committed to empowering women and girls around the world: http://bit.ly/28QPTI9

“We are the generation that will rebuild Syria.”  When she was just 10-years old  Nada was uprooted from her home in Syria-- a place where she watched her grandfather and neighbors lose their lives to the violence. The toll of Syria’s ongoing armed conflict on children is stark. But  with help from the IRC  Nada and other children are given access tools to recover as well as educational opportunities to continue their studies.  Read Nada's story: http://bit.ly/28IUtaM

In the course of the four weeks they spend in Za'atari Camp  you almost see the adventure of a lifetime. We're proud to support the stories that need to be shared. Watch #SalamNeighbor (featuring IRC's work in Jordan!) now streaming globally on Netflix.

There are over 65 million refugees & displaced people around the world. 65 million human beings-- just like you and me.  And yet  what unites us is far greater than what divides us. Now more than ever we must stand together as one.   Today  on #WorldRefugeeDay  we celebrate the incredible resilience  courage  and strength of refugees around the world. Join us. Share this post if you stand #WithRefugees!

Happy #WorldRefugeeDay!  Today  we honor the incredible resilience and strength of each and every single refugee  asylee and displaced person around the world.  Today  we stand with refugees because what unites us is far greater than what divides us. Today  we ask you to join us. Join us in celebrating their immeasurable courage. Join us in making #RefugeesWelcome-- wherever they are. Together  let's welcome them home. http://bit.ly/1Qc9dm0  #RefugeesWelcome

A home free from fear  surrounded by the people we love. That's all that Genesis  and millions of other refugees and displaced people around the world  ever wanted.  When Genesis’ safety was threatened by escalated gang violence in El Salvador—she knew she had to leave. Her mother had come to the US eight years earlier  but was unable to bring her daughter. Through the US government’s Central American Minor refugee program  they were finally reunited in New York this year. “I feel safer here  which is the most important thing in my life  and being with my mom  which is all I wanted." #RefugeesWelcome

Ten years apart from your children-- can you imagine?  Mawa was separated from his family during Sudan's civil war. After almost a decade apart  and with the help of International Rescue Committee Baltimore  Mawa and his children were finally reunited.  This #FathersDay  watch their tearful reunion and help the IRC reunite more families: http://bit.ly/1UdMnqu

Yaba and her family lost everything to conflict in their home country of Ivory Coast. When they family arrived in the United States just last month they were given keys not only to a new house  but to a new place to call home--a place filled with opportunity. 60 million people around the world  including families like Yaba's  have been uprooted by violence unable to return the the places they called home. America has long been a new home for refugees. We must not let this tradition end. This #WorldRefugeeDay  raise your voice and tell your elected officials that you want America to remain a welcoming new home for refugees. Join us.  ACT NOW: http://bit.ly/1XXIqwG
