This inspiring  heartwarming letter from 5-year old 'Aka  which was sent to the International Rescue Committee in Seattle back in December  is an important #WorldRefugeeDay reminder of the outpouring of support from people all over the US and the world (of all ages!) in the last year making #RefugeesWelcome. Share this letter if you  too  stand #WithRefugees!

Salam was resettled in the U.S. from Iraq in 2014  fleeing escalated violence in the country. After living in New York for close to two years  he feels like an American.  “I have been here for a year and a half  and no one ever insulted me or looked down upon me " he said. "This is a great thing in America.” As some political leaders and elected officials attempt to divide us by scapegoating one religion or an entire community  we must stand united.  America has a longstanding history of making #RefugeesWelcome. This #WorldRefugeeDay  raise your voice and tell your elected officials that you want America to remain a welcoming new home for refugees. TAKE ACTION:  http://bit.ly/1XpmlpS

We're so proud to support #LetGirlsLearn at The United State of Women because ALL girls deserve the right to an education.  At IRC  we're committed to providing hardest-to-reach adolescent girls with vital educational opportunities. Learn how  via The White House:  http://bit.ly/1US6p9q #StateOfWomen
Now more than ever we must come together and transcend any political rhetoric that attempts to divide us.

Congratulations to the IRC in Myanmar for celebrating its 8th year of operations this year!  The IRC began working in Myanmar in May 2008 to support emergency response and early recovery interventions for communities affected by Cyclone Nargis.  Since then  we have broadened our work to include health  women’s protection and empowerment  livelihoods  water and sanitation  community development and governance. We are so proud and inspired by our dedicated #IRCAroundTheWorld!
Our thoughts are with those who lost their lives or were hurt during this awful tragedy. Our hearts go out to their loved ones and our FL family.

On World Day Against Child Labor  we join the call for a world without child labor-- where education is a priority. More than 1 million Syrian refugees have fled to neighboring Lebanon to escape their country's violent civil war. Many of the refugees have settled in urban areas rather than traditional refugee camps. Noticeably  there has been an increase in the number of children--mainly Syrian refugee children--working in the streets of Lebanon's major cities. Some are trying to help their families in desperate need; others have been separated from their families and are forced to fend for themselves. Still others must support siblings and even send money back to relatives who remain in Syria. The majority of them have discontinued their education at a critical time in their development  putting an entire generation at risk  with grave consequences for the future. In Lebanon  our Street and Working Children program to provides “street children” with vital child protection services allowing them to play  heal  dream  and--most importantly--just be kids. Learn more: http://bit.ly/1rgwveD  Photo: Andrea Falcon/IRC

If I get to Germany  I will work as a mechanic. A trade is gold  and a job is money.” Mohaned worked as a mechanic in Syria until his garage was destroyed in the country's civil war. Now  Mohaned  like thousands of refugees  is living in Greece seeking safety in Europe and hoping to put his skills as a mechanic to work in a new home. The majority of refugees now stranded in Greece have important skills--from mechanics to lawyers  from nurses to doctors-- and they must be given the chance to pursue their chosen careers and  in so doing  contribute to their new communities in a substantial way. This should apply to refugees who choose to relocate to other countries in Europe and to those who choose to seek asylum in Greece.  In all  the world must do more to make #RefugeesWelcome. Read more of Mohaned's story and other stories of Lost Identities" in our latest Medium piece: http://bit.ly/1XecgvS  Photo: Kathleen Prior/IRC

Though from different countries--Togo and Cuba--these two refugee families have one thing in common: a new home in America.  When this photo was taken  during an IRC-Abilene World Refugee Day event last year  the Attipoe family from Togo had been in the US for several years while the Diaz family had just been resettled in the US that year.   We're so proud of our history making the United States a home to refugees for decades.   This World Refugee Day  we hope you'll join us in celebrating the resilience and strength of refugees around the world at one of our events. Here's a list of all of them: http://bit.ly/1TZxgRv   #RefugeesWelcome   Photo: Keith Perry

Books do bring happiness!  We're so proud to partner with USAID Pakistan on the Pakistan Reading Project to ensure that some of the most vulnerable children have access to education.  Through the Pakistan Reading Project we continue our commitment to helping Pakistan develop one of its greatest resources—its children.  Learn about PRP's latest visit to Karachi with orphan & vulnerable girls at the link below:

We must make sure there isn't a ‘lost generation’ of Syrian children missing on an education.    An estimated 200 000 Syrian children in Lebanon have no access to education. Those lucky enough to find a place at local schools need extra support because of the years of lost schooling. Many children will have experienced trauma due to the country's brutal war and are in need of emotional support to begin to heal.   In Lebanon  we're helping Syrian children in Lebanon continue their education and reclaim their childhoods to play  learn  and dream. Explore our work: http://bit.ly/1VP8TdT   Photo: Sam Tarling/FT

After 19 years living in a refugee camp on the eastern border of Nepal  Neeru  originally from Bhutan  was resettled in Dallas in 2009 with only $6 to her name. She worked three jobs from 5 a.m. to 1 a.m  7 days a week to make ends meet. But  within the large Nepalese community  Neeru saw an opportunity. With help from a grant from the International Rescue Committee Dallas  Neeru turned her smart idea into a fashion business. Today  she owns her own story.  Read Neeru's inspiring story in The Dallas Morning News    http://bit.ly/28irvIl   #RefugeesWelcome

Refugee success stories: our forever #MondayMotivation!  Taghreed  who was resettled in Seattle from Iraq with her family in 2013  dreams of becoming a pastry chef. Each weekday morning  she catches a 4 a.m. bus to take her to her 7 a.m. class at Seattle Community College's Pastry & Baking Arts Program. Taghreed's instructors are so impressed with her work that they believe she is a great candidate for a scholarship for the upcoming school year. Good luck  Taghreed!   #RefugeesWelcome

Before she was a refugee  she was a hairdresser. In Syria  Randa had a salon that she ran with a friend--a profession that she loved. "I love speaking with people  hearing about their lives and their dreams " she said. "But most of all  I like doing the children’s hair. They are always so excited.” Randa  her husband  and their four children escaped Syria's brutal civil war in the hopes of finding safety in Europe. Instead  the family has been stranded in Greece for months  uncertain of what is to come. With their youngest son's first birthday approaching  Randa had started planning how they would celebrate. “My husband hoped we would celebrate it in Germany " she said with a shrug and a meek smile  "but here we are." Read more of Randa's story in our Medium series "Stranded Lives" http://bit.ly/24mvhLZ

Save the Date! World Refugee Day is June 20th. If you're in the US  join us across the country to make #RefugeesWelcome and recognize the strength and resilience of those whose lives have been uprooted by conflict. Find an event near you today to celebrate with us: http://bit.ly/1XjBjOL

The European Union is setting a low bar for the global response to the refugee crisis.  Of the approximately 53 000 refugees still stranded in Greece since the EU-Turkey Deal went into effect two months ago  about 22 000 are children. Many of those children are traveling alone.  It is vital that vulnerable groups  such as unaccompanied children  receive adequate support immediately  yet most remain living in refugee camps where access to specialized services is limited.  We continue to call on EU leaders to do more for refugees including ensuring that those currently stranded in Greece are living in conditions that meet humanitarian standards.

Today  history was made. The first ever Refugee Olympic team was announced  and the 10 members of #TeamRefugees will compete at Rio 2016 this summer. We're so proud that the Olympic Games are making #RefugeesWelcome and wish the team the best of luck on the #RoadToRio! http://bit.ly/1t6rcQP

A teddy bear left behind.   Until last week  Idomeni  a site in northern Greece  was filled with thousands of trapped refugees hoping to cross the border into Europe. There  we ran safe spaces for some of the most vulnerable refugees where women and children could get one-on-one support  among other work.   Idomeni has been completely evacuated and refugees have moved to nearby camps. We're concerned about the humanitarian standards at the new sites and have called on immediate action to ensure refugees--especially vulnerable women and children--are protected. Learn more: http://bit.ly/285Maz8  Photo: Kathleen Prior/IRC

No child should be left behind. At IRC  we're committed to ensuring children  while in our care  are protected from abuse  neglect  exploitation and violence. Our work with our partners ensures that they have access to health  education and play.   As children flee war in Syria to seek safety in neighboring Jordan  some children embark on a journey alone or with their siblings. As these unaccompanied children arrive  they are referred to IRC’s child protection program in Azraq refugee camp. The team of some 64 aid workers—which includes 36 Syrian volunteers who are refugees themselves—is on hand 24 hours a day  seven days a week to welcome and care for them  try to locate their relatives and  if necessary  identify potential foster parents.   More than 3 000 such children have crossed into Jordan since 2012. An estimated 94% have been reunited with their families.  At Azraq  we encourage children to express themselves through art in order to help them cope with the trauma they have experienced.    15-year old Hiba  for instance  lost both parents and her younger sister to bombings in Syria. She and her three younger brothers were able to escape to Azraq where they are waiting to be reunited with their grandmother and uncle. The following pictures are of her drawings. This is Hiba's story.   #InternationalChildrensDay

It may seem simple  but it is crucial.  On Lesbos' Kara Tepe transit center  we've built a well-lit  gender-separated bathroom to ensure refugee women in Greece are safe and  protected. Learn more on Quartz: http://bit.ly/2819kGP

Nahala had been a teacher for 27 years  teaching six-year olds in Dara'a  Syria  before war uprooted her from her home.   “For children that age  education is everything ” she told us. “We must give them a good start  give them every chance to be whoever they want to be  to be what Syria needs.”  Yet  due to violence  about half of school-aged Syrian children have not seen the inside of a classroom for years.   “I thought I could help save Syria " Nahlala said. "I had hope for five years. But now that hope has gone.”  Read more stories of Lost Identities in Part III of our Stranded Lives Medium series: http://bit.ly/20BqtBj

What does home mean to you? That was the question we posed to 21-year old Genesis and her mother at IRC's New York resettlement office. After years of separation   Genesis (left) was finally reunited with her mother and brothers as the first Central American Minor (CAM) to be resettled by the International Rescue Committee in New York. The U.S. government's CAM program provides qualified young people in El Salvador  Guatemala and Honduras a safe and legal alternative to the dangerous journey that many children have undertaken to come to the U.S.  Genesis' mother had left their home in El Salvador in 2008 to pave the way for a brighter future for her children in the U.S. Now  mother and daughter are starting their new life in New York--together.  As the U.S. Department of Homeland Security plans to carry out immigration raids targeting Central American children and families  the IRC is calling on the administration to  halt the planned raids and extend protection to Central American children and families seeking safety in the United States. Our statement: http://www.rescue.org/press-releases/irc-denounces-planned-homeland-security-raids-targeting-central-american-families-see

Thank you to The Spice Girls's Mel C for helping to raise money for International Rescue Committee UK at the Star Boot Sale! There is only one day left to bid on items donated from incredible stars like Coldplay  Blur  and much more. Learn more here: http://bit.ly/20BnBEJ

Every night  I dream of my mother’s spirit coming back to us  says Anita  a 14-year old girl from Democratic Republic of the Congo whose parents were killed by rebels. Children like Anita and her two younger brothers are caught in the crossfire and struggle to cope with loss and trauma  but suffering goes largely undocumented. The local authorities simply don't have the means or training to care for grieving children. At IRC  we're working with our partners on the groung to provide counseling and safe spaces for children like Anita  where they can learn  play  and make new friends.  This is Anita's story: http://bit.ly/1WMPI5k

How long do we expect people – so many of whom have fled war and conflict – to be living in tents in refugee camps in Greece? An important question posed by IRC's Associate Director of Policy and Advocacy Melanie Ward.   This week  the Greek government began the evacuation of the informal refugee site at Idomeni on Greece’s northern border  transporting the approximately 8 500 refugees to multiple formal sites set up by the government in Northern Greece.  As refugees move to the new sites  it is imperative that their needs are prioritized and humanitarian standards are upheld. Learn more: http://bit.ly/20ByAxU   Photo: Jodi Hilton/IRC
We need our presidential candidates to stand up for the world's most vulnerable  not fear monger and discriminate. http://bit.ly/1Xv6iGl

Every child deserves access to a quality education.  In Ethiopia--a country which is experiencing its worst drought in 50 years--13-year old Mohammed used to walk about 2 hours every day to get water  often missing school. Now  thanks to an IRC supported water system close to his home  getting water takes him less than 10 minutes.  “We wouldn’t have attended school if the scheme was not working as we need to support our family in collecting water from distant places " Mohammed said. "But now we have regular attendance in school."  Amazing story!   Learn more about our Ethiopian drought response here: http://bit.ly/1qiJhZE  Photo: Mulugeta Ayene/IRC

“Many communities [in Maryland] and all over the country want to welcome and help the Syrians ” says Executive Director of International Rescue Committee Baltimore Ruben Chandrasekar. "They are people who have fled war and terror  they have been carefully vetted  and all they want is peace and a chance to provide for their families."  We couldn't agree more. It was amazing to hear Maryland legislators in support of making #RefugeesWelcome this week. Learn more in Washington Post:  http://bit.ly/1ZNOsgi

This week  the government of Kenya announced it has plans to close Dadaab  the world's largest refugee camp  and send the thousands of refugees  many of whom are Somalis  back to their war-torn homeland or to other countries.  Our president & CEO David Miliband visited Kenya this week  including to Dabaab camp  and spoke with refugees like Silo  pictured  who are concerned about Kenya's plan to shutdown the camp. "We don't have anywhere to go back to " Silo told him. Learn more about the situation in Kenya on The Guardian: http://bit.ly/27kpdYs

I often find myself having to remind people that no one chooses to be a refugee. A refugee is what you become when you've run out of choices. People need to understand that refugees are not a threat. They want security  safety  and peace. People don't risk their lives  unless they are desperate to live.  Beaautiful words by Her Majesty Queen Rania. Don't miss her interview with Mic following her visit to IRC programs in Greece:  http://bit.ly/27kbSQa

There are 60 million displaced people. They are displaced through no fault of their own and what has happened to them could very easily have happened to you or me.  Game of Thrones's Liam Cunningham on why he's rising up for refugees. Learn more-- and join #RealmToTheRescue here: http://bit.ly/1qitSsa

“Without water  I could do nothing ” said Sheyte  a 25-year-old farmer and mother living in southwest Ethiopia. "We would have been displaced. The availability of water is the one thing that helped us stay here."  Before the IRC rehabilitated her village's water point  Sheyte would start her trek for water at midnight  hoping to find puddles that hadn't dried up--otherwise she would have to take a 12-hour journey  round trip  to the nearest water point.  Learn how access to water helped change Sheyte's life: http://bit.ly/1TaqzPs

In honor of #NursesWeek  we celebrate extraordinary individuals like Amira--a Syrian refugee who works as a health volunteer at an IRC clinic in Jordan. Back home in Syria  Amira worked as a nurse before she was forced to flee her country due to ongoing violence.  As a trained nurse  Amira is a true asset to the clinic   preparing patient files and helping visitors identify the documents they need for treatment. Her fellow refugees always thank Amria and her colleagues for all of their hard work and support. “I find their words very motivating ” Amira said  “and it helps me realize that what the IRC and I are doing is making a difference in people’s lives.” Read more of Amira's story: http://bit.ly/1UTqhOe

Happy #NursesWeek! This week we're proud to honor dedicated  hardworking nurses like Hassan  a junior clinical nurse at an IRC-supported health post in Ethiopia.  Because of the country's unrelenting drought--the worst in 50 years--Hassan's health post has seen a surge in patients. Many internally displaced people from across the region moved to Hassan's village in search of food  water and health care. Today the health post sees about 80 people ever day-- up from about 5-7 people before the drought. Learn more about Ethiopia's drought and our work here: http://bit.ly/1qek3eT

Fantastic news: 76 members of the Maryland General Assembly have signed a letter to Governor Larry Hogan in support of Syrian refugee resettlement. Thank you for making #RefugeesWelcome in Maryland!   http://bit.ly/1ZFsn3A
We urge Kenya to continue to provide protection for refugees that it has welcomed for decades.  http://bit.ly/24LuHNk

An honor: stars like Coldplay  Blur  Kylie Minogue  and Stephen Fry have donated items which will be auctioned off for the IRC. "People have lost sight of what this is all about. Refugees are fleeing because someone bombed their house  but the most powerful thing we have is their individual stories " said Dave Rowntree  Blur drummer  who helped put together this auction  called Star Boot Sale  after visiting IRC programs in Jordan.  Read more in TIME: http://bit.ly/1TAwbhX

This film is about changing the dialogue on how we talk about refugees and seeing them actually as the solution  not a burden.   We're proud to partner with Salam Neighbor  an important documentary film in Zaatari made by the Living on One filmmakers. Watch this film on iTunes today: http://bit.ly/iTunes_Salam

“When we were back in Syria  we had a good life " recalls Amira  a 37-year old Syrian refugee living in Jordan.  “We were living in luxury. I don’t want my children to feel like we’re missing anything in our lives now.” Four years ago  Amira and her family fled to Mafraq in northern Jordan when the Syrian civil war spilled onto the streets of their hometown  Dara’a. Amira  a former nurse  knew she did not want to sit around idly and searched for a way to contribute to her new community. Now  Amira works as a health volunteer with the IRC in Jordan providing critical services to refugees and other vulnerable people--while also working to ensure her children have a bright future  just as any mother would.  This #MothersDay  read Amira's inspiring story: http://bit.ly/26ZTvjf

This #MothersDay we're honoring the amazing mothers around the world--mothers like Wedjan.  Wedjan gave birth to baby Fawaz about a month ago near Greece's northern border  where her family is stranded on their journey to safety from their native Syria. As Syria's brutal war reigned terror on their hometown  Wedjan and her husband made the difficult decision to leave everything they've ever known in the hope of giving their children a better life.  Despite the hardships  Wedjan  like any mother  just wants the best for her children.  On Mother's Day  share this post to shine a light on the many mothers displaced around the world  doing their best to give their children a brighter future. Read more of Wedjan & Fawaz's story: http://bit.ly/26QHQmC

He is part of the family. We could never give him up. Like any pet  for this Syrian family  their cat Tabboush (which means "chubby" in Arabic) is more than a cat--he's a family member. When the family was forced to flee Syria due to the country's civil war  there was no question about whether to bring Tabboush along. In a time of crisis and uncertainty  Tabboush provides the family with love  care  comfort and solace. Feelings we can all relate to.  Learn more about Tabboush and his family's journey here: http://bit.ly/1SKD441  #RefugeesWelcome

There’s only one thing worse than enduring brutal conflict  escaping your homeland  leaving behind everything you know  abandoning your dreams  risking your life  becoming destitute  being abused  fragmenting your family  watching your children suffer and losing loved ones  and it is this: arriving at a place you think is a haven only to be told you will likely be sent back. Queen Rania writes of her visit to IRC's Greece programs where she met with refugees who have risked everything for a chance at a better life. Don't miss her Washington Post Op-Ed: http://bit.ly/1T2q3Sq

A Syrian mother and her two children fall asleep on the ferry from the Greek island of Lesbos to the mainland.   On #MothersDay  and every day  we honor all of the mothers making the difficult  and at times dangerous  journey to safety in order to provide their children with a chance of brighter future.   Share this post if you stand with mothers around the world who have suffered unimaginable tragedy  but all share one common goal: giving their children a better life.  Photo: Jacobia Dahm/IRC

Rebiya  10  waits to fill her family's jerry cans at an IRC rehabilitated water point in the Ethiopia. Rebiya lives in one of the most drought-affected regions of the country which is experiencing its worst drought in 50 years. Not having access to water changes the lives of those affected in so many ways  many of them unexpected to the rest of the world. Don't miss our Medium feature detailing just how important water is to everyday life: http://bit.ly/1NFq1v1

On #TeacherAppreciationWeek  meet Sinan  a chemist turned elementary school teacher to refugee and displaced children in Iraq—and our hero.  Sinan  who is also starting over just like her students after fleeing her home of Mosul in 2014  helps create a safe haven for her students who have experienced war and tragedy but remain eager to learn.  “My students and me  we are all fleeing from somewhere ” said Sinan  who has used her training to supplement her indomitable spirit. “In other circumstances  if a student was doing something wrong  usually I would scold him. Now I give him a break. As for me  I need a break  too. So I give them more chances—and have empathy for them.” We're so grateful for amazing teachers like Sinan who work to ensure children in crisis settings are given the opportunity to learn and continue their education.  Read more Sinan's inspiring story here: http://bit.ly/1TqUT4k

Kefah and her husband fled Iraq after ongoing violence made it too dangerous for them to live there. They relocated to Jordan and  in 2012  were resettled to the United States. To cut costs in her new home of Wichita  Kansas  Kefah decided to plant a garden. Though small  the garden is now filled with bell peppers  tomatoes  mint  cantaloupe and--Kefah's favorite--okra. “We give food from my garden to my neighbors and we give it to other refugees—it’s a great thing " Kefah said. "We put mint in our tea in Iraq  so it makes me happy to hear my neighbors say they think it’s delicious  too." Today  Kefah is referred to as the 'matriarch of her community' because of her willingness to help other newly arrived refugees still adjusting to life in the U.S.  Kefah is truly a refugee success story. As politicians such as Kansas Governor Sam Brownback and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie terminate the refugee resettlement program in their states  it is important to remember the many contributions refugees  like Kefah  make to their new communities. Join us as we continue to make #RefugeesWelcome across the U.S.  including in Kansas and New Jersey  and read more of Kefah's story: http://bit.ly/26Mkw9D

Refugees are just like us because we were once them  said IRC Voice and actress Sarah Wayne Callies (star of Colony  Prison Break and The Walking Dead)  who sat down with Amy Poehler's Smart Girls to discuss the #RefugeeCrisis and her work with us. Don't miss it:  http://bit.ly/1Tq549A

Last week  Kansas Governor Sam Brownback announced that his state will no longer partner with the federal government to resettle refugees. “It’s been definitely very unfortunate to see that kind of transition from somebody who we considered a close ally in this area " said IRC's Senior Vice President of U.S. Programs Jennifer Sime. "And it’s disappointing at that level because we know what his views were before but also because the communities in Kansas have been incredibly supportive of this work." Despite Gov. Brownback's decision  the IRC will continue to make #RefugeesWelcome in Kansas. Read more on The Huffington Post: http://bit.ly/26Lzsop

All I can I think about is being able to hold my son again  said Tha-- our inspiration ahead of Mother's Day and a special #MondayMotivation in honor of moms around the world.   In 2004  Tha fled her home of Myanmar as a political refugee. She and her family were resettled in Baltimore--except for her son. After 10 long years spent apart  Tha was finally reunited with her son: the best Mother's Day gift of all.   Help support moms like Tha and families in need this Mother’s Day. Donate now: http://bit.ly/1SPtGee

The humanitarian sector doesn't just need more aid  it needs #BetterAid. We've started a new Medium publication  Rescue Aid  to delve into the conversation about reforming humanitarian aid delivery.  Don't miss our first post: http://bit.ly/26BPrp9

24-year old Ibrahim was studying civil engineering when Syria's civil war forced him to leave his studies behind. Now in Greece  Ibrahim is one of tens of thousands of refugees whose fates are to be determined by an unexpected application: Skype.  The calling and messaging platform is currently being used to book relocation or asylum appointments  but with small call windows and limited internet access  the process has become a waiting game for refugees. And as waiting times increase  so does desperation. Learn more about this on Medium: http://bit.ly/1UmgXlJ

“As a parent  I cannot imagine the fear and sadness of having to leave your home  everything you worked for  the safety and routine that you had set up for your kids  to be separated from your community and end up in a new country with nothing " said Game of Thrones star Lena Headey.  Before tomorrow's episode 2  join Lena & the cast of Game of Thrones in supporting refugees affected by the Syrian crisis. Rally the realm  host a viewing party and earn exclusive #RealmToTheRescue swag  all the while helping the refugees in need: http://bit.ly/1QFGmzT    Read Lena's full interview here: http://bit.ly/1N7U7gd

I fled for my children. I left so they could forget the bombing  the tanks and the poverty.  Like any mother  this Syrian mom is simply trying to give her children the best future possible. After losing countless family members in Syria's civil war  including her husband  she decided to flee for safety in Europe. And yet  she and thousands of others are left stranded in terrible conditions at Idomeni camp in northern Greece.  With #MothersDay around the corner  watch & share our latest video of one mother's difficult journey-- and her heart-breaking message.

One of 15 children  15-year old Samir was separated from his family after bombs started falling near his home in Aleppo. "Our house was hit  but was not completely destroyed " he recalled. "I stayed there alone for 15 days waiting for my family. No one knew whether they were dead or alive.”   For the past four months  Samir has been at Azraq camp in Jordan where he is hoping to be reunited with his family. Don't miss Samir's heartbreaking story: http://bit.ly/1Tg2bId

Maisa Leyla  from Damascus  is trying to reach her husband in Germany. She has 5 children: Reem  12  Heba  11  Shehed  8  Mohammad  6  and Ahmed  4. They’re sleeping in a tent at the border camp in Idomeni. Maisa tried at least three times to get to Greece from Turkey  crossing mountains  braving rocky terrain and treacherous sea conditions on the boat to Greece. Smugglers charged her almost $4 000 for the family of 6 to escape to Europe. Maisa sold everything to bring her children to safety. "Now I have nothing " she told our regional communications officer Lucy Carrigan.  Every day  Maisa prays for a solution so that her family can be reunited in Germany  so her daughters can fulfill their dreams of being doctors  her son a teacher. This family has been trapped for over a month in Idomeni  a land near the border which is now a sea of tents. Inside each tent is a story of a life put on hold.  These are stories of mothers  fathers  husbands  wives  sisters  brothers  daughters  sons. These are people just like you and me  who are trying to rebuild their lives in the midst of war and tragedy. We must not forget about these stories. Share this post if you stand with refugees and demand action from the EU.  #RefugeesWelcome #RefugeeCrisis   Photo: Jodi Hilton/IRC

Amazing! The author of this letter  Ghadeer  was resettled to the U.S. only one year ago and is already writing in English to her mother  who was giving birth at the time to her little brother Mohammed. What an inspiration! #RefugeesWelcome

This week  Governor Sam Brownback announced that the state of Kansas will no longer partner with the federal government to resettle refugees.   "Governor Brownback’s decision to end Kansas’ involvement in resettling refugees is completely out of touch with local communities’ overwhelming support and embrace of refugees." said Jennifer Sime  Senior Vice President of U.S. Programs for the International Rescue Committee. "The United States has a longstanding history of protecting the world’s most vulnerable. As Governor Brownback turns his back on this American legacy  the IRC will step up and ensure that refugee families continue to receive the protection and services they are entitled to."  Read our full statement and learn more about our commitment to making #RefugeesWelcome in Kansas: http://bit.ly/1T5pZ16

A mother. On the journey to safety.   Meet Makbola and her daughter  Turkiya  currently at the border camp in northern Greece  Idomeni. There are currently over 10 000 refugees stranded in Idomeni  uncertain of their futures. All they want is to feel safe.   Learn about our work: http://www.rescue.org/where/greece  Photo: Jodi Hilton/ IRC

Refugees are not numbers  they are human beings like you and me  Her Majesty Queen Rania said today after visiting IRC's programs at Kara Tepe  a refugee site hosting over 950 people on the Greek island of Lesbos.  "Except they have seen unimaginable horror  experienced unthinkable hardship and risked their lives to get here. This crisis is about people  not borders and barriers. It is about human dignity  not deals."  For refugees  Her Majesty's words reassure them that they are not alone. We are grateful for her visit and for her recognition of the pressing needs as well as the real potential of refugees who have been uprooted from their homes. Read more of Queen Rania's visit here: http://bit.ly/1Qxdj1m

Over 23 million people in more than 40 countries and 26 US cities benefited from the IRC's programs in 2015. That's nearly 5.5 million more people served than in 2014.  Learn how we're helping people survive  recover & reclaim control of their futures in our 2015 annual report: http://bit.ly/1VqcMq7

It's a win-win-win  Eat Offbeat co-founder and CEO Manal Kahi says. "We get excellent chefs  refugees get a job  and the IRC gets help finding them jobs."   We're so proud to partner with Eat Offbeat to make #RefugeesWelcome in New York City as they help refugees succeed in their new home.  http://bit.ly/1SAYWRl via Eater

I never thought I would have to flee Syria. Our life was like a paradise. But when the bombs started falling over us  I said to myself: 'it's better to go to Europe than be killed.'  Syrian refugees didn't want to leave their homes  they were forcibly uprooted. Plagued by violence and destruction  they were forced to leave everything they've ever known in order to find safety. All they want is to live in dignity.  Don't miss our latest video from Idomeni  Greece & learn more about the refugee crisis: http://bit.ly/1Vk2mIu  #RefugeesWelcome

For millions of women around the world  their families have been uprooted--splintered by violence. Mothers and children separated  families broken apart. They need our help. Join the stars of Game of Thrones Lena Headey  Sophie Turner Maisie Williams rise up for the mothers  sisters  wives  daughters and families on the journey to safety.  Learn more in Vanity Fair: http://bit.ly/1WhP1PU  #RealmToTheRescue

Today  Governor Chris Christie has announced that New Jersey state government will no longer partner with the federal government to resettle refugees.  In response to the Governor’s announcement  Jennifer Sime  Senior Vice President of U.S. Programs for the International Rescue Committee  released the following statement:  “Governor Chris Christie’s decision to stop the state’s involvement in resettling refugees is in complete contradiction to New Jersey communities’ overwhelming support and welcoming of refugees. Refugees have been resettled in the state for many years and have been a vital part of its growth and diversity.  “The Governor’s claim that security processes remain inadequate is patently false. Refugees are subject to a range of rigorous and thorough security checks  including the use of Biometrics and name checks against a robust set of databases. The vetting system has been methodically structured to both safeguard the security of the U.S. and provide protection to those who need it most  and to whom we have a moral obligation to protect.   “As Governor Christie turns his back on the world's most vulnerable  the IRC will step up and ensure that refugees receive the services they are entitled to.”    Learn more: http://bit.ly/1WItxfy

Abir and Amani  11-year old Syrian rfeugee students in Lebanon  are thinking of questions they would like to ask American students.  “What do you do at school?” “What games do you like to play?” “Is there war where you live?” “Do you feel safe?”  These young Syrian refugees are in IRC Healing Classrooms in Lebanon  where they’ve fled the war in Syria with their families. Healing Classrooms help Syrian kids find safety and stability  and continue their education so they can be the next generation of Syrian teachers  engineers  doctors and scientists.   Join us tomorrow  4/21  at 9am EST for a live webcast between Syrian and US students in the Students Rebuild Healing Classrooms Challenge. RSVP now and send in your questions on the live chat: http://bit.ly/22NYNJH   #SRSyria

Imagine having to walk for 8 hours  just to get one day's worth of water. And then doing the same thing all over again the next day. And the next.  That is the reality for many people living in Ethiopia-- a country experiencing its worst drought in decades. The lack of water has serious repercussions on everyday life  some of them are even unexpected. Learn how water changes lives on our latest Medium piece: http://bit.ly/1SviYwv

What an amazing way to make #RefugeesWelcome:  A local school in Massachusetts has raised over $30 000 for Syrian refugee children as part of the #SRSyria challenge sponsored by Students Rebuild  Global Nomads Group  and IRC. Thank you  Lenox students for your humanity and compassion for refugees who have suffered unimaginable tragedy. This Thursday  April 21 we hope you will join us at 9am EST for a live webcast between Syrian refugee children and American students. RSVP here: http://bit.ly/22NYNJH

A village coming together to work to end cholera: our #MondayMotivation.  Monleu  in Cote D'Ivoire  is a rural community of about 365 residents that was once ravaged by cholera  a water-borne disease that can cause death within hours. Cholera  however  is easily preventable.   With the help of the IRC  village residents came together to promote proper hygiene and sanitation practices among its residents. As a result  Monleu has not seen a single case of the deadly disease in over a year.  Today  the village hopes to keep it that way. The community has set up a committee to enforce proper hygiene practices and are also encouraging their neighboring villages to adopt similar measures to prevent the spread of disease. As for IRC  we continue to focus on hygiene and sanitation in the village.   Photo: Christian Bastiansen/IRC

This weekend  Pope Francis went to the island of Lesbos in Greece  highlighting the plight of refugees  and chose 12 Syrian refugees to go back with him to be relocated to Italy.  "We hope the Pope’s message of solidarity will have an impact on the hearts and minds of European policy-makers " said our Deputy Director in Greece Jane Waite.  The Pope's gesture sends a strong message of the importance of the relocation program which is far behind expectations. The EU had set an overall target of 160 000 relocations-- about 6 000 a month. Since the EU-Turkey deal was signed on March 26th  only 46 people have been relocated.  Following the strong gesture of humanity towards refugees by the Pope  we urge EU policy makers  and the world  not to forget the 53 000 refugees who remain in Greece. Truth is  long-term solutions need to be sought. We're calling for a resettlement program where 100 000 refugees are resettled every year for the next five years. Learn more  via Channel 4 News: http://bit.ly/1WBh5yb

In the past five years  I have realized how strong I am  said Mahabad  a 25 year old Syrian refugee working with the IRC in Duhok  Iraq.   Before the war  Mahabad worked as a primary school teacher. Today  with the IRC  she continues to support children as a child protection officer.  "I am proud that I can support my family  and consider this a personal success " she says. “Working in the humanitarian field  I also learned that one of the best ways for me to be happy is to help others and bring positive changes to their lives. In August 2014  thousands of Syrian refugees crossed the border into Iraq. At that time  I was working with the IRC to support these new arrivals. As a refugee  I saw myself in them  and I worked day and night to provide them with the support they needed  especially the children. Their smiles were the best reward for me."  Refugees supporting refugees: inspiring. Read more stories like Mahabad's here: http://bit.ly/1V6JEUJ

Muhereb  7  pictured at an IRC rehabilitated water point in Ethiopia.   Approximately 10.2 million people in Ethiopia  including 5.65 million children like Muhereb  will require food relief assistance in 2016-- a number considered to be growing. By the end of the year  that number is expected to rise to 18 million.   We're redoubling our efforts to provide clean water and other emergency resources across the country  especially in drought stricken regions. Learn more about the drought and IRC's response here: http://bit.ly/1V1X6Jm  Photo: Tyler Jump/IRC

Stranded as a refugee-- and now raising a newborn. Can you imagine?   This is the story of Isak  Wedjan and their now three-week old son  Fawaz  born as the family flees Syria. They've escaped war  but due to border closures  they're stranded in Greece. Uncertainty is all around them.  Learn more about their story on our Medium series "Stranded Lives": http://bit.ly/1SGRfCS

The much anticipated visit of Pope Francis to Lesbos has drawn the world’s attention to the plight of the 53 000 refugees stranded in Greece.  Pope Francis has the power to shape both political and public opinion  and has been a constant advocate for refugees at a time when hard-won refugee rights in international law are under threat.  Today  we hope his message of solidarity will have an impact on European citizens & policy-makers.  The Pope has sent a strong message in relocating 12 people  including women and children  from three Syrian families from the camps on Lesbos.  For the 53 000 that remain in Greece  their life in limbo continues.  We hope that today marks a shift and acceleration in ensuring those fleeing war can be given safe and legal means to begin to rebuild their lives.  Learn more: http://bit.ly/1WxzhbZ

Every tent has a story. A human story.  "She used to love flowers " a mother said  clutching flowers preserved in plastic. The flowers are in memory of her daughter  who was killed in the fighting in Syria.  In Idomeni  at Greece's northern border  thousands of refugees remain trapped by border closures. The land near the border is now a sea of tents. Inside each tent is a story of a life put on hold.  These are stories of people  just like you and me  who are trying to rebuild their lives in the midst of war and tragedy. Watch & share their stories.  #RefugeesWelcome

Like any father  Yousef just wants to provide for his family.   The 33-year old was an engineer back home in Syria and very much misses being able to support himself and his family. Currently  he his living in a large communal tent with his two children and his wife  who is pregnant. All he wants is to feel safe.  “We don’t want anything from anyone ” he says. “We are runners from a war. Just understand us. We don’t need anything.”  Read more of Yousef's story: http://bit.ly/1SHmYUr
In Tanzania  75% of girls and boys reported experiencing physical violence before the age of 18. We're working to change that:  http://bit.ly/22sxCEe
Watch our partners Living on One Salam Neighbor LIVE with our president David Miliband and Queen Rania:

“I know what it is like to be away from your home. I chose to work for the IRC as I myself am displaced. Helping those displaced and seeking refuge is the main reason I do this work.”  Muqatil  a senior officer with IRC’s economic empowerment and recovery team in Iraq  was forced to flee his home in Mosul  also in Iraq  due to violence  instability and crisis. Today  he supports people who were displaced by violence-- just like he was.   In Duhok  Muqatil works to provide displaced Iraqis with cash assistance. In this program  families can choose to spend the cash however way they want to: on medical care  rent  food or other vital  everyday necessities. Cash assistance gives people the opportunity to make their own choices and to determine what it is best for their family in that moment.   In short  cash restores a sense of dignity.  Learn more about Muqatil's work and IRC's cash assistance program in Iraq  supported by European Commission - Humanitarian Aid & Civil Protection (ECHO): http://bit.ly/1oXZWkr

A rainy day in Idomeni camp.  The situation in Idomeni  northern Greece  where over 10 000 people are currently stranded due to border closures  has greatly intensified. This week  refugees reported widespread use of tear gas and rubber bullets as some people protested at the border fence.   These are men  women and children that have fled homes destroyed by war and traveled in desperation to seek safety. Yet now they face new dangers.  "Safe routes for refugees must be created and soon " said IRC's Deputy Director of Operations in Greece. "The current EU-Turkey agreement is illogical and the cracks are already beginning to show.”    Read more of the situation and our response here: http://bit.ly/22uy9We   Photo: Jodi Hilton/IRC

On April 21  US students in New Jersey will participate in a unique  life-changing experience: they will join a live conversation with Syrian refugee children in Lebanon. Students across the world talking to each other  getting to know each other. Experiencing lives in each others' shoes.  You can join this special moment. RSVP to watch the live-stream today: https://plus.google.com/events/cv4d0n7slff3nv115c3uhdl80oc
Education saves and protects lives in crisis.  Period.  We're proud to join the global call to action to fund education in emergencies. Learn more: http://bit.ly/1qGFUg2  #ShareHumanity

In Idomeni camp in northern Greece  where thousands of refugees remain trapped by border closings  baby Fawaz was born.  Today  Fawaz is just three weeks old-- and his family still has no idea when they'll be able to continue their journey to safety.  Learn how this family is raising a newborn while stranded as a refugee on our latest Medium post: http://bit.ly/1NmVJx1

When you look at the numbers  the number of people uprooted from their homes around the world extends far beyond the Syria refugee crisis.  Don't miss this important Quartz video that examines the big questions behind the global displacement crisis: who are the displaced and what caused their displacement in the first place? Watch here: http://bit.ly/1N4JZo9

Ruben Chandrasekar  Executive Director for IRC in Baltimore  knows what it's like to start a new life in a new country as he immigrated to the United States from India at the age of 14.  Today  he works with others whose lives have been uprooted  working to make #RefugeesWelcome in Baltimore.  Read Ruben's inspiring story in Repair the World: http://bit.ly/1TGe1Qt

Back home in Dara'a  Syria  25-year old Monir worked as a nurse. Because of the constant bombing  Monir and his family were forced to flee. Some went to Britain  others to Saudi Arabia. Monir is currently trying to make his way to safety through Europe. Monir has been stranded in #Idomeni at Greece's northern border for about a month  uncertain of his fate. “The war ended everything  destroyed everything " he said. "There is nowhere that is safe. We are just waiting for the borders to be open. We don’t know what we will do if they don’t.”  Monir is one of thousands of refugees stranded at Idomeni. Read more stories of the forgotten faces in our latest Medium series  "Stranded Lives." http://bit.ly/1qybDzH

“[Syrian refugees] were living normal lives. And their lives have just been torn apart and totally shaken."   That's what IRC's Needs Assessment Coordinator Colette Le Jeune told the The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. Colette is one of several people from the state of Georgia who are working to make #RefugeesWelcome in the Syria region. Her story: http://bit.ly/1NdyYeR

Ladies and gentlemen  meet Tabboush the cat. Tabboush  which means "chubby" in Arabic  is currently in Greece accompanying his family on the journey to safety from Syria.   “He is a part of the family. We could never give him up.”   Born among the carnage of a bombed home where his mother had died  Tabboush was adopted by his family back in Syria—and has never left their side since. Tabboush provides the family with love  care  comfort  and solace: things we all search for in a home.  Today  Tabboush helps bring his family as close to a home as possible.   Watch and share Tabboush’s story.   #RefugeesWelcome

Rabia'a – also known as Um Mazen - is a nurse at IRC's health clinic in northern Jordan  where the IRC provides primary and reproductive health services to Syrian refugees living in urban areas as well as vulnerable Jordanians. To date  more than 175 000 clinical consultations have been provided at the clinics.   Um Mazen  who examines between 80 to 100 patients daily  is a firm believer in health education that has a sustainable impact on her patients.   “I really believe in health education  especially in individual sessions  where the patient and I discuss his/her condition. I then advice them on how to better take care of their health through nutrition and lifestyle habit changes. That makes the biggest difference for the patients I have found.”  #WorldHealthDay #RefugeesWelcome

Today  on #WorldHealthDay  the World Health Organization (WHO) is calling for action from all of us to halt the rise in diabetes. According to the WHO  about 422 million people worldwide have diabetes-- a number likely to more than double in the next 20 years.  And more: Around the world  children are at an increasing risk of developing the disease.  In Jordan  our staff met a young boy called Hisham  a 7-year old Syrian refugee  who has type 1 diabetes. Today  he is receiving care with the help of IRC.  This is his story: http://bit.ly/1Wd9t4M

Meet Marwan. A 29-year old originally from Damascus  Syria  Marwan had been a university student before the war. Today  he works as a health volunteer with the IRC in Mafraq  Jordan.   "The young generation of Syrians have lost so much — their childhoods  their education  health  safety and care. I want to return to my country and help build it again once the war is over. I want to spread peace  love and justice and unite the people of Syria once more. I want us to take care of this young generation and raise them to make up for everything they lost and everything we lost.”  We're honored that Marwan  one of the over 5 million Syrians who have been forced to flee their homes in search of safety  is now working with us. Learn much more of his story here: http://bit.ly/1PcCCVS  #RefugeesWelcome

In recent months  we've begun to devote more attention to mental-health care of refugees on their journey to safety. “Our role is to hear them so that they can let out their emotions  in the rhythm that they want  not to interrupt them  and to help them with dealing with the reaction rather than the trauma itself ” said IRC's Angeliki Kardi  one of our psychologists on the ground in Lesbos.  We're so proud of this work. Learn how our team is providing vital psychological first aid to refugees on Lesbos: http://bit.ly/1RWNo7z  via The Atlantic

This is it. Your last chance. Join HBO in supporting the IRC for your chance to join the Game of Thrones cast at their season 6 premiere. Enter here: http://bit.ly/1N5lbqS  And don't worry  the cast members are nothing like their characters in real life--we think.  #RealmToTheRescue

“The entire #EUTurkeyDeal is illogical & unethical " said Panos Navrozidi  IRC's Greece country director on The Guardian. "It focuses on borders  not people. By and large the people who have made this journey to Europe are fleeing war. They need to be assured due process. They need to have a rigorous and thorough hearing of their claims."  http://bit.ly/1RIWB0L

“My own family is from Lebanon  and they also ran away from a war  and were lucky enough to be accepted by a European country ” said Amal Clooney to three Syrian refugee families in Berlin. Her family was later able to return to Lebanon  something she says will hopefully be the case for Syrians. “I hope one day you will all get to go back to a free Syria.”   We're honored to have organized this meeting. Learn more: http://bit.ly/1SGBK0H  #RefugeesWelcome

Young boys sit in front of a mural painted by Syrian refugee children at Arbat refugee camp in northern Iraq.  Women and children make up three-quarters of the Syrian refugee population.   IRC coordinates art projects like the one pictured to provide children who have been exposed to violence with vital psycho-social support while allowing them to express themselves creatively and  most importantly  to just be kids.  Learn more about our work: http://bit.ly/1PBvJO2

Asthma  12  and Mohammad  10  are brothers from Damascus  Syria  who are traveling with their mother and older sister.  Their mother decided to flee after a bullet struck her older son. The boys' father has already reached Germany  but the rest of the family remain stranded in #Idomeni at Greece's northern border.  It remains unclear what will happen to the brothers or the thousands of refugees stranded in Greece who are waiting as Europe determines their fate.  Read more stories of the forgotten souls in Idomeni: http://bit.ly/1Vg2eYV  #RefugeesWelcome

There is no better message than to be an open  democratic society which embraces victims of conflict regardless of their religion  said IRC's Director of Policy and Advocacy for US Programs on why the US should make #RefugeesWelcome.  A must read from CNN http://bit.ly/1RR9Nms

Everyone  meet Abir.  "When we came  we thought there was no class in Lebanon but it turns out there is one and it's beautiful and I was so happy."  Abir is a 10-year old Syrian refugee girl who participates in our Healing Classrooms program in Lebanon. This video shows a day in Abir's life.  Heart-warming video from our partnership with Students Rebuild & Global Nomads Group. Don't miss our live webcast between Syrian refugee students and American students on April 21-- RSVP today: https://plus.google.com/events/cv4d0n7slff3nv115c3uhdl80oc

Amal means "hope" in Arabic.  Her six-year-old daughter has autism and doesn’t like to be touched or sit in confined spaces — impossible to avoid in the cramped camp.  Amal and her family lived in Aleppo  where she worked as a school teacher. They fled about two months ago and are now in Idomeni  at Greece's northern border  where thousands are stranded awaiting their fate. Amal is determined to find support for her daughter.   Read more stories of the forgotten souls in Idomeni in our latest Medium series "Stranded Lives": http://bit.ly/1MBEcWI

Spring has arrived at IRC's office in Peshawar  Pakistan!  Abdul  IRC's amazing gardener in Peshawar  joined IRC in 2004. As an illiterate man  Abdul realized the importance of education and worked hard to ensure all of his children received one (his eldest son just completed his Master's degree!).  Abdul says he loves IRC because they implement education projects in Pakistan and around the world for refugees and displaced people. Likewise  the IRC staff couldn't be more appreciative of the energy Abdul brings to the IRC team in Pakistan  especially in reducing work related stress of the teams when they take tea and lunch breaks or play badminton in the lawn.  Thank you  Abdul for your hard work and dedication. We're always proud of our staff around the world! #IRCAroundtheWorld

Must-watch  hilarious video from the Game of Thrones cast in support of IRC!   The cast of GoT is inviting you to enter a chance to meet them at the season 6 premiere in Los Angeles-- and all the while support our life-saving work with the Syria crisis. Don't miss this opportunity!   Enter today: http://bit.ly/GameOfThrones-Premiere #RealmToTheRescue

A hat  a head lamp  a WakaWaka solar-powered light  a pack of playing cards  a coffee maker and an iPhone.   Those are just a few of the items that IRC's Regional Director for Horn & East Africa  Kurt Tjossem  who has been with the IRC for over 19 years  packs ahead of a humanitarian mission.   Learn more about what it's like to be a humanitarian aid worker  on The Wall Street Journal: http://bit.ly/1PDdSGy

I want to reunite our family  just like in the old times. So our family will be the best family ever. -Zeyneb  13  from Aleppo.  Zeyneb  her father and siblings escaped war in Syria  but are now stranded in Idomeni at Greece's north border  unable to continue through Europe. Zeyneb's mother and youngest brother made it to Holland  but the rest of her family was left behind. Now  Zeyneb is left to care for her family members--a large task for a young girl.   Hear Zeyneb's story of strength: http://bit.ly/1UqElPz cc TIME

Back home in Syria  Eyoub was so well known and well-liked after 20 years as a taxi driver  he was dubbed the "Son of Aleppo." Now  he is one of the thousands stranded at Greece's northern border.  Eyoub decided to flee Syria with his family last winter when smugglers transporting refugees dropped their prices. He saved every penny to bring his children to safety  having already lost one son in the war.  "I will stay [in Idomeni] " he said. "I have no money to go back."  Eyoud is one of thousands living in limbo--unable to continue to safety and unable to return to their beloved Syria  consumed by war. Read more stories in our Medium feature  "Stranded Lives." http://bit.ly/1UqAH8o

We cannot be part of an unfair system. We cannot be part of an unrealistic agreement. - IRC's Greece Country Director Panos Navrozidis on why IRC is not transporting refugees to the closed facility at Moria Camp in Lesbos  Greece after the #EUTurkeyDeal. Listen on NPR: http://bit.ly/1PvHXrq

Meet Saleh  35  originally from Hasakah province in Syria  where he worked as a lawyer. Now  Saleh lives in Dohuk  Iraq and works with the IRC as a Child Protection Social Worker. Here is his story:  "I have just won a humanitarian award for my work with IRC. The fact that I was chosen from staff all over the world makes me very happy and proud. It was hard to adapt to my new circumstances  but now I feel I am more understanding with others  better able to deal with the difficulties of life.  "I want to return to my homeland. Family is the most important thing for me and I will do everything I can to make things easier for them. I would like to apply in Syria the things I have learned in Iraq  to build a better future for our children. Once the war ends I would like to visit my parents  who remained behind in our village when we fled. I would not say anything  I would only hug them."  Read more stories like Saleh's: http://bit.ly/1UOTGbk

Moza Yena was resettled from the Democratic Republic of the Congo to the state of Georgia at the age of 13. Now  as a high school senior  Moza is looking forward to her upcoming graduation and one of the quintessential American high school experiences: prom.  With the help of the IRC in Atlanta's prom dress drive  Moza has found the perfect dress. Learn more: http://bit.ly/1Pva2za via WABE   #RefugeesWelcome

22-year old Ammar from Damascus  Syria  has been stuck in Idomeni at Greece's northern border for 20 days. Now  Ammar has been making his trade as a translator even though he only started speaking English about 28 days ago-- learning the basics by listening to songs by Rihanna  Eminem and other pop stars.  Currently  Ammar is sleeping on the floor of "Tent 1"  a large communal shelter that accommodates 100 people  awaiting his fate. When he heard he may be possibly sent back to Turkey  Ammar told our regional communications officer Lucy Carrigan that he "felt like a loser." "He is  of course  the opposite of that " Carrigan said  "[he is] a determined  resourceful young man with his whole life ahead of him  if only he gets the chance to live it."  Read more powerful stories like Ammar's in our new Medium series "Stranded Lives." http://bit.ly/1RryJRp

An amazing story from the IRC in Salt Lake City:  In her home country of Somalia  Kadija was a famous musician and singer. In her new home of Salt Lake City  however  Kadija has not been able to do one of the things she loves most: play the piano.   After hearing Kadija's story  the Mundi Project  decided to help. This week  they surprised Kadija with her new electronic keyboard. Now  Kadija will-- at last-- have the chance to play her music.   Thank you  Mundi Project & IRC-Salt Lake City for making #RefugeesWelcome!

I have found out that I am strong and never give up. - said Nareen  26  an art student and Syrian refugee now working as a Senior Child Protection Officer with the IRC in Dohuk  Iraq.  "I have changed a lot during the past five years " Nareen told us. "I have lost close family members  lived in poverty  not been able to graduate from college. My little sister died in Syria and I have not even had a chance to visit her tomb. I had two choices: either to fall down or stand up. I have found out that I am strong and I never give up.  "There were many moments in the past five years when I was proud of myself. When I started to support many vulnerable children and when I was promoted. I am also proud that I am able to support my family.  “I would like to live in the UK with my family. I hope I can be an active and successful person there. I would like to continue to help children wherever I am. I am also interested in going back to college and studying either fashion design  fine arts or human and child rights.”  We're so inspired by stories like Nareen's. Read more stories like hers: http://bit.ly/1UdNafr

Our friends at Game of Thrones promise that if you join them at the Season 6 premiere  you’ll have an incredible time.  And don't forget: every entry supports the IRC’s work supporting refugees in crisis! Enter here: http://bit.ly/GameOfThrones_Premiere  #RealmToTheRescue

Don't miss this feature from Vanity Fair documenting the incredible work of volunteers and aid workers helping refugees as they arrive on the Greek island of Lesbos--the gateway to Europe.  http://bit.ly/1SNc18I

If you came here a year ago  it used to be green with sorghum. Today there is nothing.  Ethiopia is suffering from its worst drought in 50 years  affecting more than 10 million people. Today  on  #WorldWaterDay  watch this video to learn how IRC is working to provide clean water to some of the most vulnerable communities. http://www.rescue.org/blog/unrelenting-drought-has-gripped-millions-lives-ethiopia?ms=fm_vid_ak_160322&utm_source+facebook&utm_medium=video&utm_content=ethiopiavideo
From Flint to Syria  children need clean water to grow and learn. We’re proud to provide 1.2 million liters of safe water each day to camps and schools across North Syria.  #WorldWaterDay

On #WorldWaterDay  a reminder of just how life-changing having access to water can be:   "Before I didn't come to school regularly  but now I can " said 13-year old Abdi from the Somali region of Ethiopia  standing in front of the region's flag at his school.  Abdi used to spend hours helping his family search for and gather water every day--often walking as far as 6 hours to find it. The time he spent in search of water was time he could have spent in school.   Today  thanks to a new IRC water point near his village  it only takes Abdi's family 5 minutes to gather water everyday. Now  Abdi can finish his chores before and after school  spending the rest of the day learning with his peers. His favorite subject is English  and he hopes to be a teacher when he grows up.   Ethiopia is experiencing their worst drought in 50 years. But there is hope. As a leading provider of clean water and sanitation in Ethiopia  IRC is working to support Ethiopians like Abdi gain access to water. After all  access to safe and clean water is a human right.  Photo: Tyler Jump/IRC
Our staff in Mubi  Nigeria celebrate after completing IRC Way Day. We're so proud and inspired by our dedicated staff around the world!   #IRCAroundTheWorld

Mohammad  along with his wife and children  escaped Damascus  Syria after the home they were staying in was bombed. His wife and children escaped  but two of his wife's relatives died in the bombing."Five floors crashed over their heads " he explained.   The real stories behind the numbers.   The family is currently in Idomeni transit site at Greece's border with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. Despite escaping war  thousands of families like Mohammad's are stuck in Idomeni  unable to continue their journey to safety through Europe.   #RefugeesWelcome  Photo: Jodi Hilton/IRC

Helping refugees thrive and gain control of their futures. That's our goal.   As Lisa Welze  Resettlement Director at IRC in Sacramento  puts it: "It’s more than just being self-sufficient. It’s whether they feel connected to their community.”  Read how Sacramento has been making #RefugeesWelcome in Sacramento Magazine:  http://bit.ly/1XiADVP

The baby was crying so much. She needed her mother. It's been so difficult.  Moayad and his six month old daughter  Zehraa  sit at a transit center in Idomeni  Greece. The father and daughter are trying to reach the rest of the family  who traveled ahead of them and are now in Sweden. The family was divided when they were trying to get into rubber dinghies to travel from Turkey to Greece. The scene was so chaotic  Moayad said  there were people fighting and throwing luggage. So many people were trying to get onto the small boats and Moayad feared for his infant’s safety. In the mayhem  his wife and his four other children were able to make it into the boat that sped towards Turkey. Moyayd and Zehraa were left behind.  For the next month  he tried to get into another boat to Greece  but police raids and other factors delayed them for a month. When Moayad and baby Zehraa arrived in Greece  only a trickle of refugees were being let through the Macedonian border to continue the journey through Europe. Last week  the border was closed completely  leaving the father and daughter stranded in Greece.  Now  Moayad and Zehraa can only wait—hoping for the day they can rejoin their family in Sweden.  We’re calling on the EU to set up safe and legal routes to refuge and to ensure effective relocation for refugees already in Europe so that families like Moayad’s can reunite to rebuild their lives in a new country—together.   Learn more: http://bit.ly/1pM8goq   Photo: Jodi Hilton/IRC

As a parent  I cannot imagine the fear and sadness of having to leave your home  everything you worked for  the safety and routine that you had set up for your kids  to be separated from your community and end up in a new country with nothing  said Game of Thrones star Lena Headey.  "I'm so happy to be able to support the IRC and I hope everyone who can will donate and help us to make life a little brighter for those who need it."   We're so honored to have the cast of Game of Thrones support us in our #RealmToTheRescue campaign. Learn more about it: http://bit.ly/1pziCsb

I think Serbia  and the work that's being done here stands as a testament to what we can achieve when there is safe and legal passage for refugees to move. - IRC Voice and Colony USA star Sarah Wayne Callies  Learn all about our work in Serbia as we support refugees on their journey to safety.    #RefugeesWelcome

“I used to always go to the gym back in Syria; I like sports. But the gyms in Jordan are very expensive. When I found out that the IRC center offers Zumba classes  I was very motivated to join for me  for my health.”   Learn how our women's centers in Jordan provide vital psycho-social support--and Zumba!--to Syrian refugees: http://bit.ly/1RmriI5  #RefugeesWelcome

When I asked this young boy 'Who gave you the cape?'  he told me 'The doctor did-- for being brave.' He has now been wearing it for two days.   An inspiring story from Kara Tepe transit center on Lesbos  Greece  told by the IRC's mental health technical advisor.

First  she is only 12. Second  she has been living in the mud and filth of Idomeni now for one whole week while her family wait to see what happens. Third  her favorite colors are pink and red. She was wearing pink. It was a muddy pink but it was pink. And she has a beautiful smile. Her name is Zeyneb.  Her mother and brother are already in Holland. It’s unclear why they left earlier than the rest of the family but they left  crossed borders  crossed the Aegean sea and made it to Holland about one year ago.  Zeyneb doesn’t like it at Idomeni and who could blame her? The day and night before it rained and rained and in the morning it was still raining. 'It was cold ' she said  'freezing. And the tent filled with water. The blankets were so wet.' She learned to speak English in Aleppo and then  when her family fled that city  in Lebanon. They have been out of Syria for two years. When they get to Holland she would like to go to school and 'study very well.' She wants to be – her words – 'a very important person. She will be very proud of herself.' And then  I asked her how she spent her days in Idomeni. Her father said something to her  joking  and she responded with a small cry I initially took for a laugh  and then she rushed into his arms and started to cry. Sob. And then he started to cry. It was the most heartbreaking thing to see these two people  father and daughter  wrapped in this embrace. They stayed like that for a good few minutes; her crying  him in tears. Then they walked away. We asked a friend why she was crying and he said 'she feels like she is the responsible one  that she has to take care of everyone in the family.' She was the one  the night before  who had tried to keep the clothes dry – an impossible task given the relentlessness of the rain. 'It’s all on her ' the friend said.  We stayed there for a few minutes and watched as she and her father set to work trying to fix a zip on the tent they were living in. This young  gorgeous girl  trying to be brave  trying to distract herself from the misery of the life that surrounds them right now. And then  she walked back up to me. Clear-eyed  sweet smile on her face. 'I’m ready to continue the interview ' she said. 'I promise I won’t cry again. Ask me anything you want.' And that of course about broke my heart.   Heart-breaking story  by the IRC's regional communications officer  Lucy Carrigan.  The IRC is currently in Idomeni addressing immediate needs and treating refugees with the dignity and respect they deserve. Learn more at: http://bit.ly/1Z6ysX1 #RefugeesWelcome Photo: Jodi Hilton/IRC

Thank you  Sesame Street & Sesame Workshop for coming to Za'atari Refugee Camp and bringing joy to Syrian refugee children.  Thank you for making #RefugeesWelcome.  It's an honor for us to have collaborated in this wonderful event!

Over 10 000 refugees are currently stranded in Idomeni-- caught between Greece and Macedonia  in limbo as a result of recent  unilateral border closures along the route in Europe. Conditions in Idomeni  as our Communications Officer Lucy Carrigan explains  are "appalling." Mud  litter  garbage. Needs are immense.   In the short term  the IRC is there. Our emergency response team is on the ground and focused on addressing immediate needs and treating refugees with the dignity and respect they deserve. Learn more: http://bit.ly/1UAdWNC

Vision Not Victim is about creating a movement that works towards building a world where all girls get an education  all girls have equal access to healthcare and good job opportunities-- a world where they're valued and supported to pursue their aspirations.   "I hope I am a model for other girls " said Fatima  a future architect.   Don't miss our Vision not Victim project on Refinery29: http://bit.ly/1PbPqf7  #withSyria #LetGirlsLearn

The crisis in Syria  as told by a five-year old boy from the UK: "I'm five years old and so is the crisis in Syria. But for a five-year old in Syria  life can be so different."  13.5 million people are in desperate need of help. 6 million are children. Help change their lives today and donate: http://bit.ly/1TM8xUT  (Video by IRC-UK)

Ahmed was a car mechanic in his home of Aleppo  Syria. He  his wife and two children left Syria two months ago after their house was destroyed during a bombing.   Since the Syria crisis began 5 years ago today  an average of 50 families--like Ahmed's--have been uprooted every hour of every day.   Join us as we stand #withSyria and with families like Ahmed's in support of all Syrians who have been victims of 5 years of a brutal war.  Our work: http://bit.ly/1prKK08  Photo: Jodi Hilton/IRC

Today  on the 5th anniversary of the Syria conflict  we share a message of hope stemming from a recent meeting with George Clooney and Amal Clooney and three Syrian refugee families now safe in Germany.   The families shared with the Clooney's the terror of fleeing war-ravaged Syria and their hopes for a better future. In turn  George also shared his family’s history of flourishing in America after fleeing Ireland  and Amal her family’s history of leaving war-torn Lebanon for the United Kingdom.    We're honored to have organized this meeting. Share this video if you stand #withSyria  IRC  George  and Amal in making #RefugeesWelcome-- wherever they are.

Only a life lived for others is a life worthwhile. -Albert Einstein    Happy Birthday to our founder  Albert Einstein! In honor of his birthday  learn more about Einstein & the IRC's beginnings: http://bit.ly/1P8T8pZ

What would you do to protect your life  your family  your future? Today  you can help make a real difference in the lives of refugees. Join IRC as we partner with HBO & the cast of Game of Thrones at this critical time. Learn about our #RealmToTheRescue campaign: http://bit.ly/1YRKmnB And enter a chance to go to the GoT Season 6 premiere with the cast in Los Angeles (and still support IRC!) here: http://bit.ly/1P8n2uo

Tomorrow marks 5 years since the Syria crisis began. And for the last 5 years  roughly 50 families have been displaced every hour of every day from Syria-- including this father & son from Damascus  photographed in Idomeni  Greece  on the Macedonian border.   Over 13 000 refugees are currently in Idomeni  caught in limbo. Sanitation and protection are two key needs. In the short term  the IRC’s emergency response team is on the ground and focused on addressing immediate needs – water  sanitation and protection. The team is also procuring dignity kits to meet the hygiene needs of women and girls. Learn more about the situation in #Idomeni  as well as our work  here: http://bit.ly/1UruNlG   #RefugeesWelcome

We're so proud to announce our partnership with HBO and Game of Thrones to support Syrian refugees at this critical time as the crisis enters its 6th year.  Learn all about it-- and stay tuned for much more:  http://bit.ly/1QPrmmF   #RealmToTheRescue

The Syria crisis is approaching its 5th anniversary.  250 000 Syrians have lost their lives and almost 5 million have fled in the search of safety and security.  As we reach a devastating anniversary  we must remember: refugees aren't a danger  they're fleeing from danger. http://bit.ly/1Um5dP7   #withSyria

Imagine growing up surrounded by war  violence  and bloodshed. That's the reality for 7.5 million Syrian children who have grown up knowing nothing but conflict.  Forced to flee for their lives  Syrian children are  understandably  scared of what lies ahead. We spoke with Syrian families in Greece about the difficult questions children ask on the journey to safety. Don't miss it: http://bit.ly/1RcSh8Q  #withSyria
With the 5th anniversary of the Syria crisis approaching  an important reminder of the human stories behind the numbers.   #withSyria #RefugeesWelcome

So far in 2016  an estimated 5.8 million people have been affected by water shortages across Ethiopia. Approximately 10.2 million people  including 5.65 million children  will require food relief assistance this year-- a number that continues to grow.   The IRC is in Ethiopia providing vital assistance such as clean water and other emergency resources in communities across the country stricken by drought. Shita  for instance  pictured here  fills jerry cans with fresh drinking water from an IRC rehabilitated water point in Ethiopia.   Learn more about our work: http://bit.ly/1YyhPmW

At the young age of 7  Hisham has already seen his life altered dramatically--twice.   The first was when he and his family had to flee their home of Syria  settling in Jordan. The second  when he was diagnosed with Type 1 Diabetes.   And yet  thanks to an IRC clinic beautifully named "Hope"  Hisham is able to receive the care he needs. This is his story: http://bit.ly/1THsz37
URGENT: Help Syrians fleeing 5 years of war. You can save lives. http://bit.ly/1QLYlpB
So inspiring! Syrian mothers joined forces and were able to get a high school opened in an Iraqi refugee camp. Fearless  indeed: http://bit.ly/1nw8sXd #WomensDay #RefugeesWelcome

It is with heavy and grieving hearts that we share the tragic news of the passing of one of our own  Kisha Hudson. Kisha began working on our alumni team 8 years ago  went on to lead our diversity work  helping Teach For America travel many miles to building a more inclusive community  and eventually became our Chief People Officer. She had consistent values of diversity and people. Her grace  boldness  and steadiness are unmatched. Kisha had a gift for helping people see their own truth and other people’s truth to be the best version of themselves. She always modeled the importance of balancing head and heart in our leadership. Kisha helped shape our culture and strengthened all of our efforts at Teach For America. She has left a lasting legacy within our community.   We share our profound sadness with Kisha’s family. To honor Kisha  let’s commit to living and loving fully today and every day  and let’s never back down in fighting for justice  access  and opportunity for all.  Let’s make her proud.

It is with heavy hearts that we share the tragic news of the passing of one of our own  George Paitich  a 2015 Greater New Orleans corps member and second grade teacher at Arthur Ashe Charter School. George was well known for his passion for education and his commitment to the New Orleans community. “#forthekids” was the hashtag George used every single day.  We share our profound sadness with George’s family  students  and everyone at Arthur Ashe Charter School and FirstLine Schools communities. As we all continue to mourn his loss and celebrate George’s life and impact  we’re staying focused on what we can all do as educators and citizens to honor George as we work toward the day when all students get the opportunity to reach their full and incredible potential. #forthekids
