Congratulations to Hamilton: An American Musical for their epic Tony Awards win!   This image is from Wikimedia Commons and is in the public domain: Illustrator not identified. From a painting by J. Mund. - Lord  John  LL.D. (1902). Beacon Lights of History. Vol. XI  "American Founders." (London: James Clarke and Co Ltd. Republished as a Project Gutenberg eBook  2004-01-08. eBbook no. 10644.  Illustration  "Duel between Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr. After the painting by J. Mund." The duel took place in Weehawken  New Jersey on July 11  1804. Note: possibly due to artistic license and the problems of perspective and canvas size etc  the duellists are standing at an unusually short distance from each other. However  it is known that some duels did indeed take place at very short distances such as this  though most were fought where the opponents were standing approximately 50 feet apart. The protagonists are dressed in anachronistic 18th century dress  not the common fashion of the early 19th century.  https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Hamilton-burr-duel.jpg      Public Domain     File:Hamilton-burr-duel.jpg     Created: 11 July 1804

Uruguay is in the process of updating its copyright law  and in April a bill was preliminarily approved in the Senate. The law introduces changes that would benefit students  librarians  researchers  and the general public. These organizations have made suggestions that would remove or modify many of the positive portions of the bill.

David Wiley responds to the editorial on #OER that Pearson paid to have published. Wiley says  "while commercial publishers do have a market incentive to invest in the creation and update of educational materials  those incentives are aligned primarily with selling the materials and only secondarily with supporting learning."
Free knowledge projects like Wikipedia couldn’t exist if their users could not easily share information and legally re-use content that is in the the public domain.

Nice post by John Wonderlich at Sunlight Foundation:   "The fundamental questions of public life are all increasingly mediated through questions of access to data. All this collaboration  outrage  experimentation and litigation are laying the groundwork for our new definition of publicness. Who and what gets counted  and who gets to know about it  may look incremental  but that’s because these questions have crept into every aspect of our politics (in addition to many other aspects of our lives). Radical questions about the commons  speech and representation are being decided on listserv fights about database licenses  in litigation  and  yes  in photo ops with heads of state."

Garcia v. Google was an object lesson in the power of copyright claims to undermine political debate and expression. We should learn from it. This proposed legislation is a mess that could wreak havoc on our already skewed copyright regime. It needs to be challenged  now  before it goes any further.

This is why freedom of panorama is so important  and should be supported in the update to the EU's copyright rules.

Unlike the informal system that scientists use for sharing intellectual credit  the patent system is winner take all. Whoever gets his or her application approved first gets all the money. That creates an incentive for secrecy -- if scientists' ideas leak out  someone else could file the patent more quickly.
The European Science Photo Competition is a wrap. 10 000 more amazing CC BY-SA images for the commons!

Europe continues to consider options for reforming their copyright rules. Now the European Commission wants to hear your thoughts on 2 topics: freedom of panorama and new copyright-like rights for publishers. The deadline for providing feedback is June 11. Make sure your voice is heard!

The facts: Poor nutrition causes 45 percent of deaths in children under 5. But we're working to turn that around. Across the globe we provide parents with nutrition education  teach them how to grow healthy food and help them earn steady incomes so they can provide for their kids. Change is possible!

Despite a peace agreement signed in August 2015  violence is still rampant in South Sudan. Millions are displaced and facing hunger. Here's what else you need to know about this crisis: http://ow.ly/JiVa301xBAG

In 2002  a volcanic eruption on the outskirts of Goma  DRC covered the city in lava  destroying much of its water system in the process. Since then  the city's residents have had to walk hours every day to collect water from nearby Lake Kivu. We're working to change that. We're building taps and repairing pipelines to bring clean water close to home for family's like 1-year-old Michael's. When we're finished  1.55 million of the city's residents will have access to the water they need for cleaning  cooking  drinking and — you guessed it — bathing.

Did you know? Women and girls disproportionately bear the burden of collecting water  spending up to six hours every day gathering it in many places around the world. In Baura  Niger  we're working to build gender equality so girls have opportunities  not just responsibilities  within their communities. #dyk
We are stronger when we work together! Thank you John Deere for partnering with us to transform lives in Indonesia.

“I just want to help others ” Zahra says. “I want to spread love and peace everywhere I go. Because we're really tired of hate  really tired of war. And anger. All that.” How Zahra is bringing young women in Baghdad together through movement and mentorship: http://ow.ly/SQjY301A8hB

Across the globe  over 65 million have been forced from their homes by conflict and disaster. What can get lost in the magnitude of this crisis are the real  human stories of loss  hope and survival that each of these people carries with them  wherever they're from  and wherever they go. In support of World Refugee Day today  we sought out people who have made that difficult journey and can recall the experience of having to leave home  possibly forever. These are their stories: http://ow.ly/r93v301n6Ro #WorldRefugeeDay

Imagine yourself on the same harrowing journey many refugees fleeing conflict undertake every day: You must travel by rubber dinghy  foot  bus  rail and smuggler over uncharted waters and through foreign territories. You are forced to spend days or weeks in makeshift camps and reception centers. And you must do it all against a backdrop of ever-changing government laws and policies. In these conditions  having a smartphone is not just reassuring; it's practical: http://ow.ly/NFXf3016IkK

In times of war  children are often forced far from their homes  schools and communities  which can put them at risk of missing out on their education  and their future. But it doesn't have to be that way. In South Sudan  where at least 870 000 children have been displaced from their homes by conflict  here's how we get kids to class: http://ow.ly/qhVB3016JeO

“We had to leave everything behind and say goodbye to the city we love ” said Sami. He was nervous at first  but his voice grew steady as he described how he fled his home in Aleppo  Syria to start a new life in Gaziantep  Turkey. "At first  I wasn’t sad because I did not realize that we would not be returning  and I didn’t know how hard it would be. It was difficult for me to start a new life in this city – I missed my home  I often felt alone  and it was difficult to make new friends."  At 15  Sami was the youngest of five youth panelists who spoke to leaders at the World Humanitarian Summit in May. Here's what they had to say: http://ow.ly/nIHh3013nbG

The global refugee crisis is 60 million and growing. Every day families all around the world — in Syria  South Sudan  DR Congo  Ukraine  Yemen and more — are forced from their homes by conflict and disaster. It's one of the largest and most complex challenges of our time. We're on the ground in these tough places providing food  water  money and vital supplies  and helping people find the resources they need to rebuild their lives. So  in advance of World Refugee Day June 20  #tellus: What more do you want to know about this crisis?

More than 4 million Syrians have fled to neighboring countries to escape the raging conflict in their homeland — and more are leaving every day. Yet even as the number of refugees continues to grow  one number remains the same: Half of them are children. Read their stories on mercycorps.org: http://ow.ly/Chov300MjE8

FIELD DISPATCH | Ethiopia: In the remote Ethiopian village of Kantras  young mothers like Arafo are proving that when it comes to nutrition  you can never start too early.  Women in this village used to wean their babies on a mixture of sugar water and butter but  with support from Mercy Corps  now they have a healthier plan. We took part in a village cooking demonstration today  watching as 19-year-old Halima sliced carrots  diced onions  and chopped an egg to teach young mothers how to make a vegetable porridge for their babies.   Arafo (center) watched intently  but not because she needed to know how to cook: She was witnessing the power of inspiration. Arafo inspired Halima to teach this class after leading a similar session earlier. Now Halima passes it to her community as Arafo passed it on to her.

#POTD: Women in a rural village in Niger gather to discuss their food supply  which is solely dependent on what they can grow and raise within their community. Ninety percent of the country's population relies on agriculture to support their families — but the region’s unpredictable rains and vulnerability to drought  which can wreak havoc on harvests and livestock  mean hunger is a constant threat. It doesn't have to be  though. We're teaching people in villages like this one how to grow more resilient crops and keep their livestock strong  so that heartbreaking question — whether or not they'll be able to feed their families — will no longer be a worry.

Right now  800 million people around the world don’t have enough to eat. In places like Syria  Ethiopia  and South Sudan  children and families are hungry and suffering because of drought  conflict and food shortages. They need our help — and together  we can make a difference. Give today and your gift will be matched dollar-for-dollar to make 2x the impact for people in need. http://ow.ly/viGD300fsxx
Did you know? When a girl remains in secondary school  she is six times less likely to marry young. Education is powerful.

WATCH: 5 million girls in Nigeria are out of school  putting them at risk of social isolation and persistent poverty. But in these girls  Mercy Corps sees a world of possibility. Through life skills training  financial education  apprenticeships and small business start-up support  we are empowering thousands of Nigerian girls to see themselves differently and to create a brighter future for themselves  their families and their communities.

“My own 5-year-old  he ran. My youngest  even 2 years old  he ran. They had to ” says Hadiza  a mother of five recalling her family's harrowing escape after Boko Haram killed her husband and raided her village. She and other widows tell their stories of loss and survival:  http://ow.ly/mXlT3005A7p

In mountainous Tajikistan  more than 70 percent of families live in rural areas where access to medical care  especially during pregnancy  is extremely limited. We're helping mothers there get the support they need for themselves and their families: http://ow.ly/4nnTtz

Today we're celebrating mothers everywhere who are giving their all to keep kids safe and clean  provide them with nutritious meals  get them to school and  above all  give them promising futures. This Mother's Day  tell us: What has your mom done for you?

Mentor. Teacher. Provider. Mothers around the world wear so many different hats! Meet six inspiring moms we know from across the globe and learn about the different roles they play to ensure the children in their lives have bright  healthy futures.

More than half of school-aged children in South Sudan are out of school due to widespread conflict and displacement. But a bright future is still possible! We build temporary learning spaces  train teachers and distribute UNICEF School-in-a-Box kits  which contain blackboards  books  pencils  erasers and other supplies  so impacted children can continue learning  growing and dreaming despite the uncertainty around them.

In Yabello  Ethiopia  Dima Halke's livelihood is cattle — milk  specifically — and like the rest of her agricultural community  her ability to feed her family depends on the health of her animals. In Ethiopia and across Africa  it isn't always a lack of food that drives hunger. What is it  then? http://ow.ly/4mPGZr

“When I learned about the computer classes I got very excited from the bottom of my heart ” says Shamsiya. She  lives in Afghanistan’s southern Helmand province  where traditional values rule and women are rarely seen in public. It’s difficult for young people to build careers  and almost impossible for young women. Making the choice to get any kind of education is a brave one  but when Mercy Corps opened a vocational training center near Shamsiya’s home  she was quick to sign up anyway. Shamsiya knows that  despite the risks  education can improve her life. Meet more of the world's most courageous women: http://ow.ly/4mPBE3

The global humanitarian organization Mercy Corps is mobilizing a team of emergency responders to Ecuador to conduct a rapid needs assessment in the areas affected by the earthquake.  Currently  Mercy Corps is responding to humanitarian crises around the globe  including crises in Greece  Yemen  Turkey  Jordan  Iraq  Syria and Nepal.   Donations to support Mercy Corps’ humanitarian responses are urgently needed at www.mercycorps.org.

The global humanitarian organization Mercy Corps is closely monitoring the impact of the earthquake in the areas expected to be hardest hit in Ecuador. The organization already has dedicated team members working in the region  as well as emergency responders around the globe who are prepared to redeploy as the situation evolves.  “Based on initial reports  we anticipate the most pressing needs to be temporary shelter  clean water and food  says Javier Alvarez  Director of Strategic Response and Global Emergencies. "While the tsunami warning has been cancelled  we can expect significant aftershocks that will continue to cause damage and impede relief  efforts."  According to recent reports  the earthquake has already impacted tens of thousands of people  and at least 233 people have died.  Recognized as a leader in delivering rapid  lifesaving aid to hard­-hit communities  Mercy Corps has responded to almost every global emergency in the past 20 years  including the Nepal earthquakes (2015)  Philippines typhoon (2013)  the Japan earthquake and tsunami (2011)  Horn of Africa drought and hunger crisis (2010) and Kashmir earthquake (2005). Mercy Corps was also one of the first responders to the Indian Ocean tsunami (2004) and Haiti earthquake (2010).

“I want to see them grow  study  progress  and to leave them with something they can live with and defend themselves in their lives ” says Maria Flor  as her grandson plays soccer outside their home in the coffee-growing community of Tolima  Colombia.   Small farmers like Maria Flor are paid only after the coffee harvest  making it difficult to purchase the nutritious — and energizing — food their families need year-round. But  we helped Maria Flor start a home garden. Now the family has a bounty of fresh produce growing right outside their front door  and Maria can provide the food her grandchildren need to be strong  healthy and happy.

It's springtime! That means it's almost harvest season in many places around the world. In Uganda  where food supply is low and malnutrition is common  this little guy is playing in the sesame fields during a break from school. We're helping farmers there boost their incomes by learning how to farm the high-quality crop. What are you growing this spring?

Why do you think families go hungry in Africa? The reason might not be as simple as you think. Many different factors  including conflict  cultural norms and climate change  keep people from getting the food they need. In South Sudan  civil war has displaced millions of people  disrupted planting and shut down markets  making it difficult for mothers like this one to feed their families. Learn what we're doing there and across Africa to help people overcome the obstacles that are keeping food off their plates: http://ow.ly/10y67D

Boko Haram  the world's deadliest insurgent group  has displaced more than 2 million people in Nigeria  incuding these two little girls. The sisters fled with their family when the group attacked their village — now they live in a displacement community where they sleep with nearly 40 other people in two rooms of a small house. How can we facilitate long-term peace in the face of this crisis? Our new research investigates how we can weaken Boko Haram by preventing young people  who make up the majority of its fighters  from joining. Get the facts: http://ow.ly/10y5OP

What advice would you give to new mothers? In the rural Alta Verapaz region of northern Guatemala  which has the highest rate of chronic malnutrition in the western hemisphere  we lead health trainings to teach pregnant women and new mothers how to keep their families healthy. Through the sessions they learn about prenatal care  breastfeeding  nutrition  handwashing and other ways to give their young ones a healthy  vibrant future. Tell us your parenting tips in the comments below!

It's 4:15 p.m. in rural Timor-Leste. Lourdes  15  only has a few hours to complete her schoolwork before the sun goes down — like more than half the population  her family doesn't have access to electricity. But  as the oldest child living at home  Lourdes has many responsibilities in addition to her studies. Most days  she goes to school  then collects water for the family  completes her chores and helps her mother cook. This afternoon she's collecting cassava and sweet potato leaves near her house for dinner. Follow Lourdes through the rest of her day and find out how solar power is helping her find more time to focus on her future: http://ow.ly/10nUMn

Whether or not there’s food on the tables of millions of families in Ethiopia is dependent primarily on one thing: the weather. This landlocked country in the Horn of Africa is home to more than 96 million people  almost all of whom rely on rain-fed agriculture  including crops and livestock  for the food and income they need to survive.  We’ve been on the ground in Ethiopia since 2004 helping families access more food  earn steady incomes  build resilience against unpredictable weather patterns and survive emergencies like the 2011 hunger crisis  when drought put 12 million people in the region at risk of starvation. Today  we're helping them cope with yet another dry spell. Read about the current drought and how we're getting families through it: http://ow.ly/10hjIx

Young Syrian refugees and kids from the host community paint a wall mural together at our community center in Turkey. For refugees who have left everything behind and now face isolation as they try to make due in foreign territory  the center offers a safe  secure place to learn  make friends and feel a sense of community. Refugees and community members of all ages visit the center to participate in activities like language lessons  art and music  and form social networks that can help them feel supported and at home.

The Maradi region in Niger is one of the most populous areas of the country outside of the capital city  Niamey. While it’s slightly more fertile and less drought-prone than areas closer to the Sahel  Maradi still has one of the nation’s highest rates of child malnutrition: 60 percent. That’s why Mercy Corps is working to help families in this area overcome the obstacles that keep them from getting the nutrients they need.  We’re teaching them how to take better care of the livestock they depend on for food and income  and how to grow nutritious vegetables in home gardens. We also facilitate mother care groups  like this one  so mothers can learn how to prepare healthy meals with the crops they grow  and about other things that will keep their families strong.

Members of Mercy Corps Europe met with musician  global activist and co-founder of ONE  #Bono  in Turkey to talk about our work  helping millions of Syrian refugees who are now living in Turkey  Iraq  Lebanon and Jordan.   Thank you  Bono  for your generous passion and concern for #refugees!

All winter long  refugees from places like Syria  Iraq and Afghanistan made the dangerous journey across the Mediterranean — hoping to eventually reach a safer future in northern Europe. Thousands came through Greece  Macedonia and Serbia every day  and our team was there to help them make the trip as safely as possible.   Though this route north is now closed  refugees are still arriving in droves  however they can make it  waiting for safe passage and hoping for a better future. See what the journey was like  and learn how our team helped: http://ow.ly/1014ig

In Tolima  Colombia  Maria Flor Morales’ home garden is thriving — and she beams with pride that she can provide fresh  nutritious food for her children and grandchildren.  As a coffee farmer  Maria Flor is paid only after the coffee harvest  which in the past has made it difficult for her to purchase healthy food for her family year-round. “Truthfully  we ate very few vegetables because of the cost and having to go get them. I don’t have a refrigerator and they would go bad very quickly ” she says.   But Mercy Corps provided Maria Flor with seeds and training to start her own organic garden  and now her family has an abundance of fresh  organic produce at their fingertips. The garden has helped them supplement starchy primary food sources like rice  yucca and potatoes. And Maria Flor has noticed a big change in her family. “A big difference. Because now they are more nutritious  they eat better ” she says. “He's [the youngest grandchild] a lot better. He’s gained weight  he’s more active.”

Nice to meet you  says 14-year-old Hanan  a Syrian refugee living in Tyre  Lebanon. Hanan started taking English lessons at a Mercy Corps youth center in her community just a few short months ago  and speaking this greeting is a meaningful achievement for her — her new language skills will help her participate and succeed in a Lebanese school  where the ability to speak English is critical. Read more about how our youth centers are changing the lives of refugee girls via Mashable: http://ow.ly/100chk

A little girl smiles for the camera in Uganda  where Mercy Corps facilitates mother care groups in which local leader mothers promote maternal health and family nutrition for other women in their community.  Uganda is among the top 10 countries in the world for maternal  newborn and child mortality. The mother care groups work to educate women about things like nutritious eating  breastfeeding  maintaining good hygiene and other lessons they can use to give their families healthy  vibrant futures.

After a months-long blockade on fuel and other imports in Nepal  small amounts of petrol were made available to the public in February 2016  creating long lines of people hoping to gas up their cars and motorbikes.   The crisis blocked shipments of essential supplies  including gas and cooking fuel  stymied people’s movements  and slowed our earthquake recovery efforts. Now that fuel is available we have hit the ground running helping families rebuild their homes  access financial services and prepare for future disasters.

Five years of civil war have had a devastating impact on Syrian families. Over 4 million people have fled the conflict with what little they can carry  leaving them few options to survive the elements or meet their basic needs.  Those who've run must make due in frigid temperatures  going long periods of time without food  water or adequate shelter  all in search of safe haven. To help ease their burden  we’re providing them with warm food and clothing  and we rehabilitate homes in the places they've sought refuge.

Lucy's busy day starts in the morning with her poultry business: feeding  watering and tending to her 100 chickens  which she'll eventually sell for meat or eggs. The chickens provide her with income  and also with food to feed her family.   Lucy  now an entrepreneur and single mom  was born with drive and ambition  but she faced many obstacles on her path to success in her community in Kenya. When she joined a Mercy Corps youth group in her area  that all changed. The group provided her with skills  leadership opportunities and business knowledge — so much so that she didn't just start this one business  she started three. Read her full story: http://ow.ly/Zvx6p

15-year-old Kalpana Sarki (front) was married two years ago — she was in seventh grade. Despite her in-laws objections she went on to finish eighth grade but  after Kalpana passed her final exam  her in-laws pulled her out of school permanently.   Kalpana is Dalit  Nepal’s lowest caste  which is traditionally allowed few educational and work opportunities. That's why we're focused on helping girls like Kalpana overcome the cultural and financial barriers that hold them back.   Kalpana participates in our after-school program  which teaches business and life skills to vulnerable girls who are in school and those who have dropped out. With this type of support  they can form healthy relationships and gain the confidence they need to build stronger  more equitable lives.

Nidal  4  and his family fled the violence in their hometown of Aleppo  Syria a few months ago hoping to find a safe  promising future away from the conflict. The journey has been expensive and arduous but  they say  it’s better than the uncertain fate they faced in Aleppo.   “I want my kids to be educated  to have a better life  not to be afraid of tanks  not have fear in their hearts ” says Nidal’s mother  Siham. “Just like any other kid. Not to have fear.”

After five years of war in Syria  4.6 million people have fled to foreign countries for safety  over half of them children like 5-year-old Mustafa (center).   We work in host communities and refugee settlements to make sure refugee kids have the emotional support they need to cope with the trauma they’ve experienced  and we help families like Mustafa’s make ends meet by providing food  water  warm clothing and basic supplies. You can help  too. Sign our petition to tell Congress to provide humanitarian funding for the millions of Syrians who need our support: http://ow.ly/ZCDwG

People wander the main vegetable market in Kathmandu  Nepal. Food prices skyrocketed after political turmoil erupted along the Nepal-India border in September 2015  blocking essential imports of food  medicine and fuel for more than four months.  The shortage of supplies wreaked havoc on families and forced humanitarian operations into a standstill. We used the time to coordinate logistics and build our relationships with communities  partners and the local government so  when trade routes were reopened in February 2016  we were able to quickly resume our projects. THANK YOU to everyone who has supported our earthquake recovery efforts — this work is possible because of you!

This week  Syrian refugee children at Jordan’s Zaatari camp welcomed a special group of visitors — characters from Hikayat Simsim  the locally-produced Jordanian version of Sesame Street.    About 500 refugee children gathered at Mercy Corps’ Dream Land  a child-friendly space in the camp  where they meet Elmo and other Sesame friends.   “They are unable to go to school and participate in normal childhood activities. We see these kids so excited to learn  and are glad this day with Sesame has brought them some fun ” said Dominic Graham  Mercy Corps’ Country Director for Jordan.

Thumbs up from 4-year-old Muhamed  who is on the road with 14-year-old Alaa (left)  5-year-old Omer (right) and their families. The boys are from Deir A Zur  in northeastern Syria  but today  they're refugees in search of a warm  safe home.  Five years of violence in Syria means Muhamed and Omer have never known a life without war. Millions of Syrian kids like them have been ripped from their homes and schools and now face an uncertain future. That’s why we’re focused on helping the youngest Syrian refugees cope with trauma  access education and participate in healthy  healing activities that support their continued development in the places their families have sought refuge.

Today marks five years of war in Syria. For Syria’s youth  it marks five years out of school  away from home  far from family and without a future. But though they may have come of age in conflict  these youth want to leave a legacy of peace. Hear them put it in their own words and read about the work we’re doing to unlock their potential: http://ow.ly/Zjp42

Five years into the war in Syria  the violence shows no sign of stopping. Millions of children and adolescents have suffered tragic loss and trauma. Together  they are a generation at risk of becoming the forgotten collateral of war.  Many Syrian youth have been out of school for years  and they are becoming restless and frustrated as they try to find their way in the most difficult of circumstances. If we don’t help them  their future will remain trapped by the consequences of ongoing conflict.  We need your help — tell your Representatives and Senators to support funding for programs that empower Syrian youth and young people throughout the Middle East to work towards a stronger tomorrow. http://ow.ly/ZgpKZ

Around the world  Mercy Corps’ work helps people meet the urgent needs of today—and nowhere are those needs more pressing than Syria. Mercy Corps works with Syria's youth because we see them as changemakers  with the passion to dream of a better world and the drive to build it.   At Mercy Corps’ youth centers in Lebanon  Iraq  Jordan and Turkey  we are working to bridge critical gaps in learning and connect Syrian youth to peers in their communities. In a world that offers few connections  these youth have a place where they feel valued. http://ow.ly/ZgoyF

Mercy Corps focuses on Syrian youth because their critical stage of development has placed them at a crossroads. Before the war  more than 70 percent of Syrian adolescents were enrolled in secondary school  and 95 percent of the country could read. But a life of learning has become a fight to stay alive. http://ow.ly/ZmWEh

Amina couldn’t keep quiet.   She had seen conditions deteriorate near her home in Damascus. But when life became too dangerous to even walk to school  19-year-old Amina spoke out by joining local protests. Soon  however  her family had to flee  and though life as a refugee in Jordan has put her future on hold  it hasn’t changed her biggest dream: to return to Syria and be a voice its future.   “I believe I will return one day because I really want to help Syria rebuild ” she says. “But if I return now and I haven’t finished my studies  I can do nothing.”   Syria’s youth can be a voice for their country’s future. Unlock their future today: http://ow.ly/ZjoZp

What’s the cost of five years of war?  More than 11 million Syrians have been displaced by violence that has plagued the country since March 15  2011. More than 6 million people are trapped inside the warring nation  and another 4.6 million have fled to neighboring countries for refuge. The country’s development has regressed almost four decades  school attendance has declined over 50 percent and most Syrians have lost their livelihoods. More than 13 million people are need of urgent support like food  water and shelter.  It's time to end this crisis. Learn more and find out how you can help: http://ow.ly/ZgmII

Sami doesn’t want to be forgotten.   As a teenager growing up in Syria  his biggest dream was to be a doctor. But war ended his education and sent his family on the run. Now he’s 15 and living in limbo  no longer planning for a future  but worried about losing the chance.   “I try to imagine that if I grew older and passed away  what impressions would I leave?” he says. “How would people remember me? If they didn’t remember anything about me except being a person who spent his life having fun … that’s not good enough.”   #SyriaYouth can leave a legacy of peace. Unlock their future today: http://ow.ly/ZjoX3

From refugee camps in Turkey and Jordan to basement apartments in Lebanon and Iraq  time for these youth is dissolving. Three months away from home becomes nine; a semester out of school becomes four years. Relatives are scattered and friends unreachable.  Yet despite the circumstances  we have an incredible opportunity to unlock their potential. Mercy Corps is connecting youth with education  job training and community. Helping them heal and prepare to rebuild.   This generation may have come of age in conflict  but they can leave a legacy of peace. We refuse to leave their futures up to fate. #SyriaYouth http://ow.ly/ZeADP

Syria’s youth are a generation trapped  losing critical years of their lives to unending war. But they are also a passionate generation filled with possibility. When they talk about home  they don’t just tell of what they left behind—they dream about how they can rebuild it. Hear that dream in their own words and learn more about the work we’re doing to unlock their potential: http://ow.ly/ZgtxB

At 18  Dalia was just a year away from her dream of becoming a flight engineer. But war ended her education and sent her family on the run. She thought she would only be gone a month  but three years later she is stuck in limbo in Lebanon—one of an entire generation of young Syrians in danger of growing restless and frustrated by unending conflict.   “I’m not a quitter ” Dalia says. “I want to be a flight engineer and I’m going to be a flight engineer. The only thing that I’m sad about is I wasted three years.”   #SyriaYouth are filled with possibility. Join us to help unlock their potential today: http://ow.ly/Zexny

the assumption is that people are trying to get to Europe  but in reality the majority of people just want to go home.”

“Room to Read opened up the world of children to me ” said writer Abul Kalam Azad after attending our Writers' Workshop in Bangladesh. Read how we develop local writers in Africa and Asia in Part I of our four-part series on our book publishing process: http://ow.ly/Q5K4301OLlb #RtRBookLifecycle

Nothing is more empowering than the ability to read and write  to navigate one’s own future  & discover within oneself the right to choose. Education is the ultimate weapon of empowerment.   This powerful quote by our CEO  Erin Ganju  expresses the need for change in our priorities worldwide. Check out her piece on the Fourth Industrial Revolution written for the World Economic Forum's #AMNC16!

A snapshot of Gloria Steinem at a Life Skills Workshop at Kacheta Basic School in Zambia. She worked with some of our 38 000 girls supported by the program  ensuring that they have access to the resources & mentors that they need to be successful. Thank you for being one of them  Gloria!

It was an honor to have you visit our work  Gloria Steinem and see firsthand the impact we are having on young women in Zambia through our Girls' Education Program. You were an inspiration to our staff and the girls we support. Thank you!

Want an inspiring story? This little girl opened her own library in India and we were thrilled to donate 50 books to help it grow. Thanks to BuzzFeed and BuzzFeed India her story is spreading fast. Only 9 years old and Muskan is already making a big impact. Just wow. http://ow.ly/8vV7300Phfg

Amazing! We just received the results of the Bangladesh Secondary School Certificate exam--the big gateway exam to university. In Bangladesh 74% of girls are married before they turn 18 and finishing school is a major struggle. We're so proud to share that all but two of the 238 girls from our Girls’ Education Program in Bangladesh who took it passed!! That means our students achieved a 99% pass rate  soaring above the national pass rate of 88.7%. Huge congratulations to ALL 238 Bangladesh Girls' Ed students for all your hard work and for helping overcome gender barriers to education!!  #girlpower #educationforall

There are many little ways to enlarge your child's world. Love of books is the best of all.          - Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis  Happy World Book and Copyright Day to all the authors who continue inspire the imaginations of children around the world!  #BookDay

Today is World Book and Copyright Day!  With UNESCO  we pay tribute to literary giants like Cervantes and Shakespeare  while celebrating all the amazing books and authors that encourage young people to pick up a book and read.   Take a look at some of the incredible children's books Room to Read local authors and illustrators have produced for 2016 in the 10 countries where we operate. Thanks to them  so many more kids have learned to love reading!  Learn more about the authors and illustrators behind these books here: http://ow.ly/4mUqGZ  #BookDay

Globally  more than one-third of children lack basic reading and math skills.   How can we get #MillionsLearning by 2030?   Check out the Millions Learning project  working to identify where and how education interventions are scaling quality learning for children and youth in low- and middle-income countries around the world.   The new report features Room to Read's Literacy Program as a model for how we provide quality reading instruction for all: http://brook.gs/23C1vnS

When called on to read  Reaksa from Cambodia can't wait to share her favorite book  "Chek Chek Wants to Get Married " with her class.   Although the school's library has only been open now for three months  Reaksa can't wait to go check out new books - thanks to her teachers who know the best way to reinforce the habit of reading in their students.   Learn what Reaksa's teachers and librarians do to encourage their students to read for fun: http://ow.ly/4mHB0s

Did you know it's #VolunteerWeek?   From New York to Tokyo  we're grateful to our Room to Read chapter volunteers who give their time to support our literacy and girls' education programs!  10 million children would not have received the benefit of education without their amazing contributions.   Learn how you can volunteer:  www.roomtoread.org/GetInvolved

There's always a reason to celebrate great children's books that encourage kids to keep reading into adulthood.   See what books Room to Read students in Sri Lanka love to check out from their local libraries: http://ow.ly/1064mI

Education is a lamp that can brighten a child's life Their education can  in turn  brighten the society and bring progress and prosperity.   Read how this father learned that even an illiterate farm laborer can harness the power of education and stop two girls from dropping out of school: http://ow.ly/ZMlnC

Please help us in welcoming Heather Simpson to Room to Read's Management Team as our new Chief Program Officer!   Heather Simpson joins Room to Read with 20 years of international development experience  most recently at Save the Children  where she has worked since 2009. She has worked as a project manager and technical adviser for organizations such as the American Institutes for Research  Juarez and Associates  and Save the Children for education projects funded by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation  USAID and other public and private donors  beginning her career as a Peace Corps volunteer based in Honduras.  “Heather’s expertise in tackling large and medium scale education projects for major nonprofit organizations will be enormously valuable to the future of Room to Read’s Literacy and Girls’ Education programs " says Erin Ganju  Room to Read's CEO and co-founder.
For me 62 million girls not getting an education: That’s personal. - First Lady Michelle Obama inspires at South-by-Southwest (SXSW) Take the PLEDGE: http://ow.ly/ZylII #62MillionGirls #LetGirlsLearn

When Suma was just six years old her parents sold her as an indentured servant. Inspired by First Lady Michelle Obama and musical talents Missy Elliott and Queen Latifah sharing their passions at South-by-Southwest (SXSW) we wanted to share this video of Room to Read alumna Suma who was featured in the film Girl Rising https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tyjADRIuDwk  She sang this song about her time as an indentured servant when she was unable to go to school and her lament for being born a girl. This is for the #62MillionGirls who deserve to be in the classroom today. #LetGirlsLearn

Where are they today? When this photo was taken almost one year ago  First Lady Michelle Obama had just met three bright students in our Girls' Education Program in Cambodia  which she visited last March during her launch of the #LetGirlsLearn initiative.   We're thrilled to share that all three girls--Phounam  Sohang and Savean--received college scholarships! Today Phounam is studying English communications in Siem Reap and her friend Sohang  who loves math  is getting a degree in finance and banking. Savean decided to forego college for now to remain closer to home with her family and marry. We're so proud of Phounam  Sohang and Savean and we celebrate what they've accomplished in honor of the #62MillionGirls who are missing from our classrooms. http://ow.ly/Zw3Yx

Look at all these new titles Scholastic just donated to Room to Read Cambodia! Our team there is packing them up to deliver to our partner libraries across the country. Over the last 15 years Scholastic offices around the world have donated over 1.5 million books to our Literacy Program  helping us stock our libraries. Thanks Scholastic!

Arien is homeless on the streets of Hollywood. She says homelessness is rough. That a lot of people look down on her. That guys proposition her with money to go home with them. She's had soda thrown on her while sleeping.   Although graphic  Arien shares the realities of what women have to endure while living on the streets. People yell at her to "sell her pussy" until she can get a job because to them that's better than sleeping on the ground.   Arien says she's lucky to wake up without being robbed overnight. Her phone gets getting stolen. Along with not being able to shower  Arien says not having a regular phone makes it hard to find a job. To make matters worse  she says the shelters are even worse than the streets.   It's amazing that this young woman can still smile!  ________________________________________________  This important journey cannot continue without YOUR help. Telling each story — reaching out in each city– helping each person we can  takes donations from people who will give what they can to make a difference — will you please help us continue this essential work. When I asked Shannon about homelessness in San Jose  she responded it is cold and very rough. "People steal from you when you're sleeping" Shannon continued.  Bob  her father  goes on to say there is not enough housing. Bob say the only place available to them it the local shelter and it's too crowded.    Shannon and her father have been homeless since 1994!  I can't even imagine what they must have gone through. I also can't imagine why as a society we have not provided them with the help they need to get out of homelessness.

The night I met Joseph it was 21 (°F) outside.  He has lived outside in Toronto for over ten years now.  Joseph said last year he spent the whole winter outside with temperatures as low as -40.  He went on to say "it's not like I am doing it on purpose. I have been waiting for a decent place to stay".   At one time Joseph was in housing  but the housing was so bad he didn't feel safe and he walked away from it.  When I asked Joseph how services can help someone like himself he simply responded by getting him a place to live where he feels safe and doesn't have to fear others.   I know some people think that any housing is better than the streets. I also know that most every community has challenges in finding affordable housing and good landlords that will accept housing vouchers.  But putting people into situations that are dangerous to a person's health or safety has to stop! WE can do better. We must do better!   Special thanks to Ve’ahavta’s Mobile Jewish Response to the Homeless. http://www.veahavta.org/programs/mjrh/

WARNING: This post contains adult language and disturbing content! It's disturbing that anyone has to live on the streets. It's heartbreaking the amount of childhood trauma and abuse that people go through. The lack of mental health support is this country offensive!   Bam Bam is a transgender woman homeless on the streets of Sacramento. She is sleeping in the doorway of a church. My heart breaks for her. The years of abuse show in her eyes. Bam Bam was molested by several members of her family. She shares about her mom separating from her father and throwing a mattress in the back of a station wagon for seven people to live.    The pain and suffering Bam Bam experienced in life no one should have to go through. Sadly  the suffering continues on the streets of Sacramento.

Walt is a displaced tech worker living on the streets of San Jose.  He worked in the electronic industry for thirty years. Then around ten years ago  his job "went away"  and soon after he ended up homeless.   Walt claims to be "comfortably homeless." He manages to stay warm. He manages to stay clean.  Get gets off the streets into a hotel a few times a month. Although some might think this is OK  homelessness is never a way for people to live. Add to that Walt is a homeless veteran and a senior  he should not be on the streets of Silicon Valley.  Walt refuses to accept any kind of public assistance. He believes that type of support should go to women and families who need it. Instead  Walt plays his flute to raise the money he needs.

Terry is a 65 year-old veteran homeless in Austin  Texas.  He says Social Security made a mistake and for the last few months his payments stopped.  That "blooper" as Terry calls it  caused him to lose his housing and end up on the streets.   When I asked Terry how he survives  he responded that if a person goes hungry in Austin there is something wrong.  He added that there are plenty of places to eat.   Please watch this short video to the end. Terry's three wishes are important and people need to hear them.
Another video featuring Alan Graham of Mobile Loaves & Fishes sharing their model of engagement with Bombas and KIND Snacks. This is a must-watch video for anyone working in homeless services.
Friend and hero Alan Graham from Mobile Loaves & Fishes  briefing  Bombas and KIND Snacks  before we go out on the streets to help people experiencing homelessness in Austin.
68 amazing people donated $5 366 to my birthday wish to support @InvisiblePeople. THANK YOU!

I had just connected with a large group of "travelers" handing out Hanes socks before meeting John and Brenda. Travelers are a subculture of the homeless population often known for hopping trains. You’ve seen them hanging out in your city. They almost have a uniform wearing brown clothes and often have dogs and musical instruments.  Many are kids that have been "thrown away" by their families and find community traveling with others.   I used to think no one wants to be homeless  and that is the truth for the vast majority of people sleeping outside. Even the ones who tell you that want to be homeless  at one time tried to get out of homelessness  but after hitting so many barriers  they just give up. It's called "learned helplessness."   But now  after meeting a few people like John and Brenda  I have changed. There are a few people that want to live a nomadic lifestyle.   John and Brenda are a married couple that travels by choice. They normally go up and down California  but this time  they decided to head east a little and visit Austin during SXSW.   They start by telling a story of joining up with a group of hippies. A fun moment is when we chat a little about what's the difference between a hippie and a traveler. You'll have to watch for the answer.   While passing through San Antonio  police picked them up and placed them in detox for smoking marijuana. That's insane!  I love that their three wishes were so simple  but that's the traveling lifestyle. John and Brenda are great kids. I wish them safe travels on all of their journeys.

Patrick has been homeless in Austin for seven years. He likes to stand out on 6th street and make people smile.   Patrick says it's cold and it's wet  but he calls himself an old country boy and he makes the best of it.  While I was recording this  a waitress from one of the clubs came outside to see what I was up to. She told me Patrick is a good person. She sees him helping people every day. She said he's helped her a few times.   Patrick was panhandling. Once he got a few dollars  he went to a store and bought himself a sandwich.

David has been on the streets of New York City for about a year.  After his girlfriend had died in his arms   David ended up in a psychiatric hospital  and his landlord evicted him because of it.   This is not David's first time homeless.  He says the reason is he is in and out of prison. Having a criminal record makes it extremely hard to find employment  and there is little support anymore for people reentering society.   David is working with the city hoping to get his housing back.
